protein with the MalE domain N-terminal and the MalF domain C-terminal. <span style="font-size: 12px; font-style: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; -moz-text-size-adjust: auto; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; display: inline !important; float: none; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000;">The protein, of 733 aas, has 8 TMSs, one N-terminal to MalE (a signal sequence for export of the MalE domain to the periplasm), an extra TMS at the N-terminus to bring the N-terminus to the periplasmic side of the inner membrane, and then the usual 6 TMSs observed for many ABC membrane proteins.&nbsp; MalG (M, 272 aas, 6 TMSs) and MalK (C, 374 aas) are of normal size and composition. </span>While MalE of E. coli was able to additionally increase ATPase activity of MalFGK<sub>2</sub> in vitro, the isolated MalE domain of B. bacteriovorus failed to stimulate the E. coli system (<span id="ref34548717.30193862" class="cite">Licht et al. 2018</span>). The adjacent genes are an &alpha;-amylase (Q6MNM3) and a glucokinase (Q6MNM4).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MalEF/MalG/MalK of <em>Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus<br />MalEF, R-M, 733 aas, 8 TMSs (Q6MNM0)<br />MalG, M, 272 aas, 6 TMSs (Q6MNM1)<br />MalK, C, 374 aas, (Q6MNM2)<br /><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.1.52"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.1.52&tcname=">3.A.1.1.52</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sugar (sucrose, maltose, glucose, fructose, esculin (coumarin&nbsp;&beta;-glucoside)) uptake system possibly consisting of 5 or 6 proteins (see below) (<span id="ref34547686.29159995" class="cite">Nieves-Mori&oacute;n and Flores 2017</span>). These proteins are all implicated in sugar uptake, but they may include components of multiple transporters. The system may also regulate formation of septal nanopores (<span id="ref34549842.30577420" class="cite">Flores <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sugar uptake porter of <em>Nostoc</em> (<em>Anabaena</em>) strain PCC7120<br />GlsR, MalE-like, All1916, 418 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS (R) (Q8YVQ8)<br />GlsQ, MalF-like, Alr2532, 301 aas and 6 TMSs (M) (Q8YU29)<br />GlsP, MalG-like, All0261, 276 aas and 6 TMSs (M) (Q8Z042)<br />GlsC, MalK-like, Alr4781, 432 aas and 0 TMSs (C) (Q8YMZ3)<br />GlsD, MalK-like, All1823, 366 aas and 0 TMSs (C) (Q8YVZ3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.1.53"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.1.53&tcname=">3.A.1.1.53</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oligosaccharide transporter RafEFGK. RafE, the binding protein, has be extensively characterized.&nbsp; It binds &alpha;-(1,6)-linked glucosides and galactosides of varying size, 
linkage, and monosaccharide composition with preference for the 
trisaccharides raffinose and panose. This preference is reflected in the &alpha;-(1,6)-galactoside uptake 
profile of the bacterium. Structures of RafE (BlG16BP) in complex with 
raffinose and panose revealed the basis for the ligand 
binding plasticity, which recognizes the non-reducing 
&alpha;-(1,6)-diglycosidic linkages in its ligands (<span>Ejby <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). RafK has not be identified experimentally, but it may be NCIB protein acc# <a class=""dflSeq"" title=""Show report for WP_022543180.1"" href=""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/protein/WP_022543180.1?report=genbank&amp;log$=prottop&amp;blast_rank=8674&amp;RID=HKEFRS0S01R"" target=""lnkHKEFRS0S01R"">WP_022543180.1</a>, ATP binding protein, annotated as UgpC, and this protein has been enterred into TCDB as RafK. Sugar binding substrates of RafE include: raffinose (highest affinity), panose, melibiose, <span>stachyose, verbascose, isomaltose, isomaltotriose, isomaltotetraose, </span>isomaltopentaose, isomaltohexaose, and isomaltoheptaose (<span>Ejby <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RafEFGK of <em><span>Bifidobacterium</span> animalis</em><br />RafE, (R) D3R799; 439 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS<br />RafF, (M) D3R798;&nbsp; 330 aas and 6 TMSs<br />RafG, (M) D3R797; 301 aas and 6 TM<br />RafK (C) <a class=""dflSeq"" title=""Show report for WP_022543180.1"" href=""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/protein/WP_022543180.1?report=genbank&amp;log$=prottop&amp;blast_rank=8674&amp;RID=HKEFRS0S01R"" target=""lnkHKEFRS0S01R"">WP_022543180.1</a>, 377 aas and 0 TMSs.</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.1.54"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.1.54&tcname=">3.A.1.1.54</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC sugar uptake porter with 4 constituents which unlike other members of this subfamily, has two large membrane proteins of 16 - 18 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC porter of Candidatus Heimdallarchaeota archaeon LC_3 (marine sediment metagenome)<br />OLS24721 R, 427 aas<br />OLS20027, M, 641 aas and 16 putative TMSs<br />OLS20028, M, 779 aas and 18 putative TMSs<br />OLS20029, C, 379 aa</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.1.55"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.1.55&tcname=">3.A.1.1.55</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Four comoponent ABC uptake porter, possibly transporting mannosyl glycerate.&nbsp; The four components of this system and a potential mannosyl glycerate hydrolase are encoded within a single operon.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative mannosy glycerate transporter<br />R, 428 aas and 1 N-terminla TMS, D7BAR7<br />M, 281 aas and 6 TMSs, D7BAR6<br />M, 266 aas and 6 TMSs, D7BAR5<br />C, ATPase, cytoplasmic, D7BAR4</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.1.56"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.1.56&tcname=">3.A.1.1.56</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uptake transport system for L-arabinose and D-xylose, XacGHIJK (<span id="ref34549802.31089701" class="cite">Johnsen <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The system has a receptor, two 6 TMS membrane proteins and two ATPases.&nbsp; <em>xacGHIJK</em> is upregulated by growth in the presence of either D-xylose or L-arabinose, mediated by the transcriptional regulator, XacR, the general regulator of <em>xac</em> catabolic genes (<span id="ref34549802.31089701" class="cite">Johnsen <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>XacGHIJK of<em> Halofax volcanii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.1.57"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.1.57&tcname=">3.A.1.1.57</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC uptake porter consisting of AbnE (R), AbnF (M) and AbnJ (M).&nbsp; The ATPase (C) has not been identified and does not appear to be encoded within the same gene cluster. This gene cluster also encodes an extracellular arabinanase, an intracellular arabinofuranosidase, and many other enzymes of arabinose/pentose metabolism as well as a sensor kinase/response regulator and another ABC transporter, probably specific for arabinose (TC# 3.A.1.2.32).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbnEF(G?)J of <em>Geobacillus stearothermophilus (Bacillus stearothermophilus)<br />AbnE, R, B3EYM9<br />AbnF, M, B3EYN0<br />AbnG, C, ?<br />AbnJ, M, B3EYN1<br /></em></p>

NodI (C)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.102.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.102.2&tcname=">3.A.1.102.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NodIJ nodulation factor transporter.&nbsp; Involved in lipo-chitooligosaccharide secretion (<span id="ref34550795.8809752" class="cite">Fern&aacute;ndez-L&oacute;pez <em>et al.</em> 1996</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NodIJ of <em>Azorhizobium caulinodans<br /></em>NodI, C, Q07756<br />NodJ, M, Q07757</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.103">3.A.1.103 The Lipopolysaccharide Exporter (LPSE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.103.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.103.1&tcname=">3.A.1.103.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Lipopolysaccharide exporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-negative bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>RfbAB of <I>Klebsiella pneumoniae</I> <br>
RfbA (M)<br>
RfbB (C)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.103.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.103.10&tcname=">3.A.1.103.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Wzm (M; 280 aas; 6 or 7 TMSs in a 2 + 3 + 1 or 2 TMS arrangement)-Wzt (C) ABC lipid-linked galactan precursor exporter. Deletion of the encoding genes results in severe morphological changes and the accumulation of an aberrantly long galactan precursor. A model for coupled synthesis and export of the galactanpolymer precursor in mycobacteria has been proposed (<span id="ref34552966.33879617" class="cite">Savkov&aacute; <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The two encoding genes are separated by a gene that encodes a galactofuranosyltransferase, GlfT1.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Wzm-Wzt of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis <br /></em>Wzm, M, P72049 (Rv3783)<br />Wzt, C, P72047 (Rv3781)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.103.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.103.2&tcname=">3.A.1.103.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Heteropolysaccharide O-antigen exporter, Wzm/Wzt (<span id="ref5802.15231783" class="cite">Feng <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>). The C-terminal cytoplasmic domain of Wzt (an IgG-like &beta;-sandwich) determines the specificity of the transporter for either O8 or O9a O-PS  (<span id="ref6568.18032609" class="cite">Cuthbertson <em>et al.,</em> 2007</span>). The transporter structure reveals a continuous transmembrane channel in a nucleotide-free state (<span id="ref34549616.30778065" class="cite">Caffalette <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Upon ATP binding, large structural changes within the nucleotide-binding and transmembrane regions push conserved hydrophobic residues at the substrate entry site towards the periplasm and provide a model for polysaccharide translocation. With ATP bound, the transporter forms a large transmembrane channel with openings toward the membrane and periplasm. The channel's periplasmic exit is sealed by detergent molecules that block solvent permeation. Molecular dynamics simulation data suggest that, in a biological membrane, lipid molecules occupy this periplasmic exit and prevent water flux in the transporter's resting state (<span id="ref34549616.30778065" class="cite">Caffalette <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Wzm/Wzt of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> Wzm (M)  (AAS99164)  <br /> Wzt (C)  (AAS99165)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.103.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.103.3&tcname=">3.A.1.103.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter required for O-antigen biosynthesis and multicellular development, RfbAB (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10323">Guo <em>et al.</em> 1996</a>). Functions with the RfbC glycosyl transferase (TC#4.D.1.3.4).¬†</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RfbAB of <em>Myxococcus xanthus</em>&nbsp;<br />RfbA (M) 260aas (Q50862)<br />RfbB (C) 437aas (Q50863)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.103.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.103.4&tcname=">3.A.1.103.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RfbAB lipopolysaccharide exporter (<span id="ref10323.8626291" class="cite">Guo <em>et al.</em> 1996</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RfbAB of&nbsp;<em>Myxococcus xanthus</em>.<br />RfbA (MXAN_4623) (M)<br />RfbB (MXAN_4622) (C)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.103.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.103.5&tcname=">3.A.1.103.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter mediating ethanol tolerance, Slr0977 (M)/Slr0982 (C) (<span id="ref34544292.26052317" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; Present in a gene cluster with (lipo)polysaccharide biosynthetic enzymes, so could be a cell surface carbohydrate export system.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cyanobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Ethanol tolerance transporter of <em>Synechocystis sp.</em> (strain PCC 6803 / Kazusa)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.103.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.103.6&tcname=">3.A.1.103.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Two component lipopolysaccharide exporter, Wzm/Wzt.&nbsp; Wzm is the membrane component (265 aas with 6 TMSs) which forms a ring-like large ion conductance channel. The ATPase, Wzt, functions both as the energizer and regulator (<span id="ref34545546.27379442" class="cite">Mohammad <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Wzm/Wzt of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa<br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.103.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.103.7&tcname=">3.A.1.103.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC-type polysaccharide/polyol phosphate export systems, permease componentof 262 aas and 6 or 7 TM</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Transporter of <em>Acidovorax</em> sp. MR-S7</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.103.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.103.8&tcname=">3.A.1.103.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of 258 aas and 6 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of <em>Moranbacteria bacterium</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.103.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.103.9&tcname=">3.A.1.103.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC O-antigen lipopolysaccharide/polysaccharide export transporter, Wzm/Wzt of 253
 aas and 6 TMSs (Wzm; also called AbcT3) and 396 aas and 0 TMSs (Wzt). The crystal 
structure is available (PDB 6AN7) (<span>Bi <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>) for the Wzm-Wzt homologue from <em>Aquifex aeolicus </em>in an open conformation. The transporter forms a transmembrane channel that is sufficiently wide to accommodate a linear polysaccharide. Its nucleotide-binding domain and a periplasmic extension form 'gate helices' at the cytosolic and periplasmic membrane interfaces that probably serve as substrate entry and exit points (<span>Bi <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). O antigen structures are serotype specific and form extended cell surface barriers endowing many pathogens with survival benefits. In the ABC transporter-dependent biosynthesis pathway, O antigens are assembled on the cytosolic side of the inner membrane on a lipid anchor and reoriented to the periplasmic leaflet by WzmWzt for ligation to the core lipopolysaccharides. This process depends on the chemical modification of the O antigen's nonreducing terminus, sensed by WzmWzt via a carbohydrate-binding domain (CBD) that extends its nucleotide-binding domain (NBD). <span id="ref34552599.33443152" class="cite">Caffalette and Zimmer 2021</span> provided the cryoEM structure of this full-length WzmWzt transporter bound to ATP in a lipid environment, revealing a highly asymmetric transporter organization. The CBDs dimerize and associate with only one NBD. Conserved loops at the CBD dimer interface straddle a conserved peripheral NBD helix. The CBD dimer is oriented perpendicularly to the NBDs and its putative ligand-binding sites face the transporter to likely modulate ATPase activity upon O antigen binding. A closed WzmWzt conformation in which an aromatic belt near the periplasmic channel exit seals the transporter in a resting, ATP-bound state. The sealed transmembrane channel is asymmetric, with one open and one closed cytosolic and periplasmic portal (<span id="ref34552599.33443152" class="cite">Caffalette and Zimmer 2021</span>).&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Wzm/Wzt of<em> Aquifex aeolicus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.104">3.A.1.104 The Teichoic Acid Exporter (TAE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.104.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.104.1&tcname=">3.A.1.104.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Teichoic acid exporter, TagGH.&nbsp; It is present in a large complex with the teichoic acid precursor synthetic enzymes (<span>Formstone <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).&nbsp; The substrate may be the diphospholipid-linked disaccharide portion of the teichoic acid precursor (<span>Schirner <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).&nbsp; 3-d structural studies have been reported (<span>Ko <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>) showing that TagG and TagH are localized on the cytoplasmic membrane in a patch, and the TMS of TagH is important for normal transport activity (<span>Yamada <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). The crystal structure of the N-terminal domain of TagH reveals a potential drug targeting site (<span id="ref34552375.33360015" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The ATPase activity of TagH-N was inhibited by clodronate, a bisphosphonate, in a non-competitive manner, consistent with the proposed wall teichoic acid-binding site for drug targeting (<span id="ref34552375.33360015" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TagGH of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em> <br /> TagG (M)<br /> TagH (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.104.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.104.2&tcname=">3.A.1.104.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.104.2"></a></p>
<p>The teichoic acid precursor exporter, TarGH. May be specific for the diphospholipid linked disaccharide portion of the teichoic acid precursor (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9599">Schirner <em>et al.</em> 2011</a>). TarG is the target of a small antimicrobial inhibitor of <em>S. aureus</em>&nbsp;growth (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9600">Swoboda <em>et al.</em> 2009</a>). TarGH is a WTA transporter and has been purified and reconstituted in proteoliposomes (<span id="ref34547129.28727445" class="cite">Matano <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). They showed that a new compound series inhibits TarH-catalyzed ATP hydrolysis even though the binding site maps to TarG, near the opposite side of the membrane. These are the first ABC transporter inhibitors to block ATPase activity by binding to the transmembrane domain.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TarGH of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em>&nbsp;<br />TarG (M) (D1GQ18)<br />TarH (C) (D1GQ17)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.105">3.A.1.105 The Drug Exporter-1 (DrugE1) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.1&tcname=">3.A.1.105.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Daunorubicin, doxorubicin etc. (multidrug resistance) exporter, DrrAB.&nbsp;  DrrB binds drugs with variable affinities and contains multiple drug binding sites. The two asymmetric nucleotide binding sites in DrrA have strikingly different binding affinities. Long-range conformational changes occur between DrrA and DrrB. The transduction pathway from the nucleotide-binding DrrA subunit to the substrate binding DrrB subunit includes the Q-loop and CREEM motifs in DrrA and the EAA-like motif in DrrB (<span id="ref34548793.30243711" class="cite">Rahman and Kaur 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>DrrAB of <em>Streptomyces peucetius</em> <br /> DrrA (C), 330 aas<br /> DrrB (M), 283 aas and 6 TM</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.10&tcname=">3.A.1.105.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcG homologue, ABCH1 of 705 aas and 6 TMSs in a C-M arrangement.&nbsp; May be involved in steroid or drug efflux (<span id="ref10735.19926124" class="cite">Popovic <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).&nbsp; Of the vertbrates, it may be restricted to fish.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcH1 (C-M) of <em>Danio rerio</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.11&tcname=">3.A.1.105.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.105.11"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>ABC-2 transporter probably specific for a lantibiotic.¬† The genes for this system are adjacent to an S2P-M50 peptidase (G0Q3D2), probably involved in pro-lantibiotic processing, as well as a lantibiotic biosynthetic enzyme (G0Q3D1) and a lantibiotic dehydratase (G0Q3D0).¬†</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC-2/ATPase of <em>Streptomyces griseus</em><br />ABC-2 (M) (G0Q3D4)<br />ATPase (C) (G0Q3D3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.12&tcname=">3.A.1.105.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Three component ABC-2 transporter: (1) the membrane (M) subunit with a C-terminal CBS domain, (2) an ABC ATPase subunit and (3) an M50 peptidase (Zn<sup>2+</sup>-metalopeptidase) of 392 aas and 6TMSs. they may export a bacteriocin, and the protease cleaves off the signal peptide during export. The three encoding genes are in
 a single gene cluster.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter<br />ABC2 (M) (F8D412)<br />ABC ATPase (C) (F8D413)<br />M50 peptidese,&nbsp; (F8D414)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.13&tcname=">3.A.1.105.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SclAB (Sco4359-60) (<span id="ref10340.21636652" class="cite">Gominet <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SclAB of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em>.<br />SclA (C)<br />SclB (M)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.14&tcname=">3.A.1.105.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RagAB, involved in both aerial hyphae formation and sporulation (<span id="ref10344.16925552" class="cite">San Paolo <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RagAB&nbsp;of&nbsp;<em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em>.<br />RagA: Sco4075 (C)<br />RagB: Sco4074 (M)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.15&tcname=">3.A.1.105.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative drug exporter, YbhFGRS (<span id="ref34543636.18634750" class="cite">Moussatova <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YbhFGRS of <em>E. coli <br /></em>YbhF<em>, </em>(C) (578 aas)<br />YbhG, (MFP) (332 aas)<br />YbhR, (M) (368 aas)<br />YbhS, (M) ((377 aas)<em><br /></em></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.16&tcname=">3.A.1.105.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC export system (MDR?), RbbA/YhhJ/YhiI (All three genes are in a single operon; this system may comprise a single ABC exporter with MFP; substrate unknown (<span id="ref34543636.18634750" class="cite">Moussatova <em>et al.</em> 2008</span> and unpublished observations).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><br />RbbA/YhhJ/YhiI of <em>E. coli</em><br />RbbA (C-M; 911 aas; C8TJS4)<br />YhhJ (M; 374 aas; P0AGH1)<br />YhiI (MFP; 355 aas; P37626)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.17&tcname=">3.A.1.105.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative polyketide drug exporter, YadGH.&nbsp; May also transport phospholipids, participating in phospholipid trafficking together with the Mla complex. It interacts with MlaABCDEF (TC# 3.A.1.27.3) to preserve outer membrane asymmetry (<span id="ref7039.19383799" class="cite">Malinverni and Silhavy 2009</span>; <span id="ref34548359.29176613" class="cite">Babu <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YadGH of <em>E. coli</em><br />YadG (C; 308 aas)<br />YadH (M, 256 aas)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.19&tcname=">3.A.1.105.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Poorly characterized ABC exporter involved in bacterial competitiveness and bioflim morphology, YfiLMN (<span id="ref34546714.28461449" class="cite">Stubbendieck and Straight 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YfiLMN of <em>Bacillus subtilis <br /></em>YfiL (C) 311 aas, 0 TMSs<br />YfiM (M) 296 aas, 6 TMSs<br />YfiN (N) 385 aas, 6 TMSs<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.2&tcname=">3.A.1.105.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Oleandomycin (drug resistance) exporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>OleC4-OleC5 of <I>Streptomyces antibioticus</I> <br>
OleC4 (C)<br>
OleC5 (M)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.20&tcname=">3.A.1.105.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative 5 component ABC exporter with two membrane constituents, two cytoplasmic ATPases, and one membrane fusion protein (truncated at the N-terminus, probably because of an incorrect initiation codon assignment).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>5-component ABC exporter of <em>Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus<br /></em>Q6MLX4 (M)<br />Q6MLX5 (M)<br />Q6MLX6 (C)<br />Q6MLX7 (C)<br />Q6MLX8 (MFP)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.21&tcname=">3.A.1.105.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized ABC transporter with two components, a transmembrane protein with 6 TMSs and an ATPase. The substrate in unknown.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC system of Candidatus <em>Saccharibacteria bacterium</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.22&tcname=">3.A.1.105.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein pair of a presumed ABC transporter. C is of 317 aas.&nbsp; The genes encoding these two proteins are adjacent to each other.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of  Armatimonadetes bacterium (groundwater metagenome)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.24&tcname=">3.A.1.105.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC exporter with two membrane constituents encoded by adjacent genes.&nbsp; The ATPase does not map adjacent to these genes and has not been identified.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC exporter of <em>Methanomassiliicoccus</em> sp.</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.25&tcname=">3.A.1.105.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-binding cassette transporter subfamily Gof 687 aas and 7 TMSs in a 1 + 6 TMS arrangement. 13 ABCG genes were identified in N. lugens, and expression levels of these ABCG transporter genes after treatment with thiamethoxam, abamectin, and cyantraniliprole has been examined.&nbsp; Some increase in amounts while others do not (<span id="ref34550380.31597380" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG of <em>Nilaparvata lugens</em> (Brown plant leafhopper)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.26&tcname=">3.A.1.105.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC transporter with two membrane proteins, both with 6 TMSs, one with them in a 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement, the other in a 2 + 3 + 1 TMS arrangement. The two genes encoding these proteins are next to each other on the chromosome.&nbsp; The ATPase is fused to the first of these two membrane protein domains (acc # C7QI22). These two genes, presumable encoding an ABC exporter, are adjacent to lantibiotic biosynthesis genes. Therefore their function may be to export a lantibiotic. The N-terminal hydrophilic domain of C7QI22 is an S2P-M50-like peptidase (TC# 9.B.149) that may process the pro-lantibiotic during export.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC membrane transport proteins of <em>Catenulispora acidiphila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.27"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.27&tcname=">3.A.1.105.27</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC exporter with two protein components, the first, a large protein with an N-terminal membrane domain with 6 TMSs in a 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement, and a C-terminal ABC-type ATPase domain. The second protein is a smaller protein with only a membrane domain with 6 TMSs in a 2 + 3 + 1 TMS arrangement.&nbsp; The two genes encoding these proteins are adjacent to each other, and are adjacent to a lantibiotic dehydrophenase gene. They may therefore export the newly synthesized lantibiotic.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Catenulispora acidiphila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.28"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.28&tcname=">3.A.1.105.28</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC-like transporter with 4 components, two integrals membrane ABC proteins (O26020 and O26021, 376 and 365 aas, respectively) , an MFP protein (OP94851; 329 aas) and a TolC-like protein (O026022; 510 aas). This system appears to play a role in flagellar stability and bacterial motility (<span id="ref34555449.36232924" class="cite">Gibson <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>4 component ABC-like transporter</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.3&tcname=">3.A.1.105.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The 4A-4E-O-dideacetyl-chromomycin A<sub>3</sub> (biosynthetic precursor of chromomycin) exporter (may also export chromomycin and mithramycin (<span id="ref6021.17768249" class="cite">Menendez <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CmrAB of <em>Streptomyces greseus</em><br /> CmrA(C) (Q70J75) <br /> CmrB(M) (Q70J76)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.4&tcname=">3.A.1.105.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>The pyoluteorin (a chlorinated polyketide) efflux pump, PltHIJKN (<span id="ref34543634.16269724" class="cite">Brodhagen <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>; <span id="ref34543635.16581203" class="cite">Huang <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&gamma;-Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PltHIJKN of <em>Pseudomonas sp. M18</em>: <br /> PltH (336aas; MFP) - (Q4VWD0) <br /> PltI (589aas; C-C) - (Q4VWC9) <br /> PltJ (377aas; M; COG0842; similar to 9.B.74.2 (ABC-2)) - (Q4VWC8) <br /> PltK (372aas; M; The C-terminal hydrophobic half has 5TMSs and is most similar to PltJ, and then to  9.B.74.2, but it is also homologous to 3.A.1.105.2 and 3.A.1.102.1) - (Q4VWC7) <br /> PltN (480aas; OMF) - (Q4VWC6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.5&tcname=">3.A.1.105.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.105.5"></a></p>
<p>AbcG homologue, Snustorr, sioform A, Snu, of 808 aas and 6 TMSs in a 1 + 5 TMS arrangement at the C-terminal part of the protein.&nbsp; The N-terminal domain is the ATPase domain.&nbsp; The protein therefore has a C-M domain arrangement.&nbsp; Lipids in extracellular matrices (ECM) contribute to barrier function 
and stability of epithelial tissues such as the pulmonary alveoli and 
the skin. In insects, skin waterproofness depends on the outermost layer
 of the extracellular cuticle envelope that contains cuticulin, 
an unidentified water-repellent complex molecule composed of proteins, 
lipids and catecholamines. Based on live-imaging analyses of fruit fly 
larvae,&nbsp;<span id="ref34553146.29306642" class="cite">Zuber <em>et al.</em> 2018</span> found that initially, envelope units are assembled within 
putative vesicles harbouring the ABC transporter Snu and the 
extracellular protein Snsl. In a second step, the content of these 
vesicles is distributed to cuticular lipid-transporting nanotubes named 
pore canals and to the cuticle surface, dependent on Snu function. The surface of <em>snu</em> and <em>snsl</em> mutant larvae is depleted of
 lipids and cuticulin. Consequently, these animals suffer uncontrolled
 water loss and penetration of xenobiotics. The data allude to a 
two-step model of envelope (i.e. barrier) formation. The proposed 
mechanism in principle parallels the events occurring during 
differentiation of the lipid-based ECM by keratinocytes in the 
vertebrate skin, suggesting establishment of analogous mechanisms of skin
 barrier formation in vertebrates and invertebrates (<span id="ref34553146.29306642" class="cite">Zuber <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>AbcG homologue, Snu, of <em>Drosophila melanogaster</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.6&tcname=">3.A.1.105.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.105.6"></a> The ABC-2-like transporter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC-2-like transporter of <em>Dehalococcoides ethenogenes</em> <br />ABC2 protein (M) (Q3Z8A7)<br />ATPase (C) (Q3Z8A8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.7&tcname=">3.A.1.105.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.105.7"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>Putative ABC2 tranport system, SagGHI; may export streptolysin S.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.105.7"></a>
																																																																	                                     Putative Streptolysin ABC2 tranport system, SagGHI.<br />SagG (C) (Q9A0K0)<br />SagH (M) (Q9A0J9)<br />SagI (M) (Q9A0J8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.8&tcname=">3.A.1.105.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC-2 transporter.&nbsp; The two genes encoding this system are adjacent to one encoding an squalene-hopene cyclase that coverts squalene to hopene.&nbsp; The substrate could therefore be hopene or a hydrocarbon triterpene derivative of it (<span id="ref9718.22488823" class="cite">Racolta <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Planctomycetes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC2 membrane protein (Q7UE57) and ATPase (Q7UE58) of <em>Rhodopirellula baltica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.105.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.105.9&tcname=">3.A.1.105.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC2 membrane proteins (J7ZHK9 and J8A8S6) with ATPase (J8ABC0) transporter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC2 transporter of <em>Bacillus cereus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.106">3.A.1.106 The Lipid Exporter (LipidE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.1&tcname=">3.A.1.106.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Phospholipid, LPS, lipid A and drug exporter, MsbA, which flips the substrate from the inner leaflet of the cytoplasmic membrane to the outer leaflet (<span>Eckford and Sharom, 2010</span>). MsbA also confers drug resistance to azidopine, daunomycin, vinblastine, Hoechst 33342 and ethidium (<span>Reuter <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>). Four x-ray structures, trapped in different conformations, two with and two without nucleotide, have been solved (<span>Ward <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). They suggest an alternating accessibility mode of transport with major conformational changes.&nbsp; The mechanism and conformational transitions have been discussed (<span>Moradi and Tajkhorshid 2013</span>).&nbsp; MsbA is energized both by ATP hydrolysis and the H<sup>+</sup> electrochemical gradient (<span>Singh <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). <span>Mi <em>et al.</em> 2017</span> used single-particle cryo-electron microscopy to elucidate the structures of lipid-nanodisc-embedded MsbA in three functional states. The 4.2 &Aring;-resolution structure of the transmembrane domains of nucleotide-free MsbA revealed that LPS binds deeply inside MsbA at the height of the periplasmic leaflet. Two sub-nanometre-resolution structures of MsbA with ADP-vanadate and ADP revealed a closed and an inward-facing conformation, respectively. A&nbsp; 2.9 A resolution structure of MsbA in complex with G907, a selective small-molecule antagonist with bactericidal activity, revealed an unanticipated mechanism of ABC transporter inhibition. G907 traps MsbA in an inward-facing, lipopolysaccharide-bound conformation by wedging into an architecturally conserved transmembrane pocket. A second allosteric mechanism of antagonism occurs through structural and functional uncoupling of the nucleotide-binding domains (<span>Ho <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Coupled ATPase-adenylate kinase activity in ABC transporters including MsbA has been demonstrated (<span id="ref34549525.28004795" class="cite">Kaur <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Close-proximity effects and structural coupling of the transmembrane domains with the NBDs has been suggested (<span id="ref34550849.31899087" class="cite">Josts <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Two first-generation inhibitors of MsbA, TBT1 and G247, induce opposite effects on ATP hydrolysis. Using single-particle cryo-electron microscopy and functional assays, TBT1 and G247 were found to bind adjacent yet separate pockets in the MsbA transmembrane domains (<span id="ref34553934.34554829" class="cite">Th&eacute;lot <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). MsbA adopts the wide inward-open conformation in <em>E. coli</em> cells (<span id="ref34555457.36223470" class="cite">Galazzo <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp; Solid-state NMR spectroscopy rvealed that substantial chemical shift changes within both CH1 and CH2 occur upon substrate binding, in the ATP hydrolysis transition state, and upon inhibitor binding. CH2 is domain-swapped within the MsbA structure, and substrate binding induces a larger response in CH2 compared to CH1. These data show that CH1 and CH2 undergo structural changes as part of the TMD-NBD cross-talk (<span id="ref34557790.38182790" class="cite">Novischi <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MsbA (M-C) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.10&tcname=">3.A.1.106.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Involved in the export of a molecule required for the autochemotactic process. AbcA integrated permease/ATPase (M-C) protein, MXAN_1286 (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10348">Ward <em>et al.</em> 1998</a>).¬† </p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MXAN_1286 (M-C) of <em>Myxococcus xanthus</em>.</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.11&tcname=">3.A.1.106.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HlyA/MsbA family transporter of 595 aas.¬† The gene for this protein is adjacent to and probably in the same operon as that encoding 3.A.1.106.12.¬† They both have 6 TMSs, so they may together comprise a single heterodimeric system.¬† </p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cyanobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Gloeobacter violaceus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.12&tcname=">3.A.1.106.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HlyA/MsbA family transporter of 577 aas.¬† The gene encoding this protein is adjacent to and in the same operon with that encoding 3.A.1.106.11.¬† They both have 6 TMSs, so they may together comprise a single heterodimeric system.¬† </p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cyanobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of<em> Gloeobacter violaceus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.13&tcname=">3.A.1.106.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance-like ABC exporter, MdlAB; exports peptides of 6 - 21 aas (<span id="ref34543636.18634750" class="cite">Moussatova <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MdlAB of <em>E. coli</em><br />MdlA (M-C; 590 aas)<br />MdlB (M-C; 593 aas)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.14&tcname=">3.A.1.106.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Lipid A exporter homologue of 593 aas and 6 TMSs (N-terminal with a C-terminal ATPase domain.&nbsp; Essential for acid, salt and thermal tolerance (<span id="ref34544662.25822232" class="cite">Matsuhashi <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Exporter of  <em>Synechocystis</em> sp. PCC6803</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.15&tcname=">3.A.1.106.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Lipid flippase, PglK or WlaB, of 564 aas and 6 N-terminal TMSs with a C-terminal ATPase domain.&nbsp; <span>Mediates the ATP-dependent translocation of an undecaprenylpyrophosphate-linked heptasaccharide intermediate (LLO) 
across the cell membrane, an essential step during the N-linked 
protein glycosylation pathway. Transport across the membrane is effected
 via ATP-driven conformation changes. Most likely, only the polar and 
charged part of the glycolipid enter the substrate-binding cavity, and 
the lipid tail remains exposed to the membrane lipids during the 
transmembrane flipping process (<span id="ref34545203.16498400" class="cite">Alaimo <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>; <span id="ref34545204.16547029" class="cite">Kelly <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>; <span id="ref34545205.26266984" class="cite">Perez <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). </span><span>PglK may employ a "substrate-hunting" mechanism to locally increase the 
LLO concentration and facilitate its jump into the translocation 
pathway, for which sugars from the LLO head group are essential; the release of LLO to the outside occurs before 
ATP hydrolysis and is followed by the closing of the periplasmic cavity 
of PglK (<span id="ref34551372.30799077" class="cite">Perez <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). </span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PglK (M-C) of <em>Campylobacter jejuni</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.16&tcname=">3.A.1.106.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span class="recommended-name">Probable integral membrane protein NMA1777 with </span>6 TMSs in a 2 + 2 + 2 arrangement, ; function and ATPase unknow<em>n.</em><span id="ref34545295.25092708" class="cite"> </span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Klebsiella pneumoniae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.17&tcname=">3.A.1.106.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC1 transporter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>transporter of <em>Acidobacterium capsulatum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.18&tcname=">3.A.1.106.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peptide and multidrug resistance porter of the ABC superfamily, TmrAB. TmrA (Q72J05; 600 aas with 6 N-terminal TMSs) and TmrB (Q72J04; 578 aas with 6 N-terminal TMSs) comprise this heterodimeric transporter, both proteins of the M-C structure.&nbsp; The system has been found to export the dye, hoechst 33342, and to be inhibited by verapamil (<span id="ref34549522.21190941" class="cite">Zutz <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>). The subnanometre-resolution structure of detergent-solubilized <span class="highlight">TmrAB</span> in a nucleotide-free, inward-facing conformation by single-particle 
electron cryomicroscopy has been solved (<span id="ref34549523.25363761" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). A cavity in the 
transmembrane domain is accessible laterally from the cytoplasmic side 
of the membrane as well as from the cytoplasm, indicating that the 
transporter lies in an inward-facing open conformation. The two 
nucleotide-binding domains remain in contact via their carboxy-terminal 
helices. Comparison between this structure and those of other ABC transporters suggests a possible trajectory of 
conformational changes that involves a sliding and rotating motion 
between the two nucleotide-binding domains during the transition from 
the inward-facing to outward-facing conformations (<span id="ref34549523.25363761" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). A subset of annular lipids is normally invariant in composition, with negatively charged lipids binding tightly to <span class="highlight">TmrAB, suggesting that</span> this exporter may be involved in glycolipid translocation (<span id="ref34549524.25698336" class="cite">Bechara <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Coupled ATPase-adenylate kinase activity in ABC transporters including TmrAB has been demonstrated (<span id="ref34549525.28004795" class="cite">Kaur <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). A 2.7-&Aring; X-ray structure of <span class="highlight">TmrAB</span> has been determined. It not only shares structural homology with the antigen 
translocation complex TAP, but is also able to restore antigen 
processing in human TAP-deficient cells. <span class="highlight">TmrAB</span> exhibits a broad peptide specificity and can concentrate substrates 
several thousandfold, using only one single active ATP-binding site. It
 adopts an asymmetric inward-facing state, and the 
C-terminal helices, arranged in a zipper-like fashion, play a 
role in guiding the conformational changes associated with substrate 
transport (<span id="ref34549526.28069938" class="cite">N&ouml;ll <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Conformational coupling and trans-inhibition have been characterized (<span id="ref34549527.29308886" class="cite">Barth <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>), and a&nbsp; conserved motif in intracellular loop 1 stabilizes the outward-facing conformation of TmrAB (<span id="ref34552606.33524413" class="cite">Millan <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). A strong entropy-enthalpy compensation mechanism enables the closure of the nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs) over a wide temperature range. This is mechanically coupled with an outward opening of the transmembrane domains (TMDs) accompanied by an entropy gain (<span id="ref34553127.32818376" class="cite">Barth <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).&nbsp; TmrAB undergoes a reversible transition in the presence of ATP with a significantly faster forward transition. The impaired degenerate NBS stably binds Mn<sup>2+</sup>-ATP, and Mn<sup>2+</sup> is preferentially released at the active consensus NBS (<span id="ref34556884.37459565" class="cite">Rudolf <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). ATP hydrolysis at the consensus NBS considerably accelerates the reverse transition. Both NBSs fully open during each conformational cycle, and the degenerate NBS may regulate the kinetics of this process (<span id="ref34556884.37459565" class="cite">Rudolf <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TmrAB of <em>Thermus thermophilus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.19&tcname=">3.A.1.106.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter.&nbsp; It has been suggested that it might be a glycolate exporter (<span id="ref34549528.28348231" class="cite">Braakman <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). However it's closest hit in TCDB (31% identity in the transmembrane domain) has TC# 3.A.1.106.18, which is probably a peptide/multidrug (and possibly glycolipid) exporter with broad substrate specificity.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Prochlorococcus marinus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.2&tcname=">3.A.1.106.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The homodimeric Sav1866 multidrug exporter (transports doxorubicin, verapamil, ethidium, tetraphenylphosphonium, vinblastine and the fluorescent dye, Hoechst 33342; 3-D structure known at 3 &Aring; resolution; <span id="ref5857.16943773" class="cite">Dawson and Locher, 2006</span>; <span id="ref6429.18690712" class="cite">Velamakanni <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>) The empty site opens by rotation of the nucleotide-binding domain whereas the ATP-bound site remains occluded (<span id="ref8519.21689537" class="cite">Jones and George, 2011</span>). Conformational changes induced by ATP-binding and hydrolysis have been proposed (<span id="ref8631.21488101" class="cite"><span id="ref8976.21069970" class="cite">Becker <em>et al.</em> 2010; </span>Oliveira <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). The alternating access mechanism and the flippase activity of this ABC exporter has been shown to be lipid-dependent (<span id="ref34549389.30693324" class="cite">Immadisetty <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sav1866 of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em> (M-C) 2HYDA/2HYDB (578 aas)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.20&tcname=">3.A.1.106.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MsbA of 582 aas and 6 TMSs in an M-C arrangement.&nbsp; The X-ray structure at 2.8&nbsp;&Aring; resolution in an inward-facing conformation after cocrystallization with lipid A and using a stabilizing facial amphiphile has been reported (<span id="ref34549803.31130486" class="cite">Padayatti <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The structure displays a large amplitude opening in the transmembrane portal, which is likely to be required for lipid A to pass from its site of synthesis into the protein-enclosed transport pathway. Putative lipid A density is observed further inside the transmembrane cavity, consistent with a trap and flip model. Additional electron density attributed to lipid A is observed near an outer surface cleft at the periplasmic ends of the transmembrane helices (<span id="ref34549803.31130486" class="cite">Padayatti <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). This protein is 96% identical to the E. coli ortholog, TC# 3.A.1.106.1.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MsbA of <em>Salmonella enterica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.3&tcname=">3.A.1.106.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The dimeric multidrug resistance exporter, ABC1/2 (exports the peptide antimicrobials, nisin and polymyxin; (<span id="ref5872.17159201" class="cite">Margolles <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>) (both ABC1 and ABC2 also show striking similarity to family 3.A.1.117).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC1/2 of <em> Brevibacterium longum</em>: <br /> ABC-1 (M-C) (ZP_00121338)<br /> ABC-2 (M-C) (ZP_00121339)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.4&tcname=">3.A.1.106.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The duplicated ABC transporter, CgR_1214 (1247 aas; MC(poorly conserved) MC(well conserved))</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>CgR_1214 of <i>Corynebacterium glutamicum</i> (MCMC)
(A4QD95)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.5&tcname=">3.A.1.106.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The heterodimeric multidrug efflux pump, SmdAB (exports norfloxacin, tetracycline, 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI), and Hoechst 33342) (<span id="ref5925.18024518" class="cite">Matsuo <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SmdAB of <i>Serratia marcescens</i>: <br>
SmdA (M-C) (A7VN01) <br>
SmdB (M-C) (A7VN02)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.6&tcname=">3.A.1.106.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Multidrug efflux pump, Rv0194 (exports & causes resistance to ampicillin, streptomycin and chloramphenicol by 32- to 64-fold and to vancomycin and tetracycline by 4- to 8-fold (<span id="ref5951.18458127" class="cite">Danilchanka <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>)).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Rv0194 of <i>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</i> (MCMC) (O53645)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.7&tcname=">3.A.1.106.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Salmochelin/Enterobactin secretory exporter, IroC (<span id="ref6040.18194158" class="cite">Crouch <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>; <span id="ref10783.19214756" class="cite">M&uuml;ller <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>IroC of <em>Salmonella enterica</em> (MCMC) (Q8RMB7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.8&tcname=">3.A.1.106.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.106.8"></a></p>
<p>The heterodimeric BmrC/BmrD (YheHI) MDR transporter.&nbsp; Transports a wide range of structurally unrelated drugs including doxorubicin, mitoxantrone, ethidium, and hoechst 33342 (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref6426">Torres <em>et al.</em>, 2009</a>). It activates the sensor kinase, KinA, during sporulation initiation (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9765">Fukushima <em>et al.</em> 2006</a>). Large scale purification has been achieved (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9766">Gali&aacute;n <em>et al.</em> 2011</a>).&nbsp; It has been reconstituted in giant unilamellar vesicles (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9767">Dezi <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).&nbsp; It exhibits an asymmetric
configuration of catalytically inequivalent nucleotide binding sites. The two-state transition of
the TMS domains, from an inward- to an outward-facing conformation, may be driven exclusively by ATP hydrolysis (<span id="ref11141.24837547" class="cite">Mishra <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). A novel intermediate of BmrCD, a heterodimeric multidrug ABC exporter from <em>Bacillus subtilis</em>. has been identified (<span id="ref34554180.34931066" class="cite">Thaker <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). In the cryo-EM structure, ATP-bound BmrCD adopts an inward-facing architecture featuring two molecules of the substrate Hoechst-33342 in an asymmetric head-to-tail arrangement. Deletion of the extracellular domain capping the substrate-binding chamber or mutation of Hoechst-coordinating residues abrogates cooperative stimulation of ATP hydrolysis. These findings support a mechanistic role for symmetry mismatch between the nucleotide binding and the transmembrane domains in the conformational cycle of ABC transporters (<span id="ref34554180.34931066" class="cite">Thaker <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Lipid interactions with BmrCD modulate the energy landscape, suggesting a distinct transport model that highlights the role of asymmetric conformations in the ATP-coupled cycle with implications to the mechanism of ABC transporters in general (<span id="ref34556817.37398337" class="cite">Tang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BmrC/BmrD (YheHI) of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em> <br />YheH (M-C) (O07549)
<br />YheI (M-C) (O07550)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.106.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.106.9&tcname=">3.A.1.106.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SoxR regulon single protein ABC exporter, Sco7008, containing an N-terminal membrane domain and a C-terminal ATPase domain (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10342">Shin <em>et al.</em> 2011</a>). SoxR responds to extracellular redox-active compounds.&nbsp; Thus, it is induced in stationary phase during the production 
of the benzochromanequinone blue-pigmented antibiotic, actinorhodin (<span id="ref34544864.25162599" class="cite">Naseer <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). Possibly an actinorhodin exporter.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sco7008 (M-C) of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em>.</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.107">3.A.1.107 The Putative Heme Exporter (HemeE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.107.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.107.1&tcname=">3.A.1.107.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative heme exporter, CcmABC=CycVWZ (Note: CcmC may function independently of CcmAB) (<span id="ref5846.16824107" class="cite">Feissner <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>; <span id="ref5884.17419738" class="cite">Christensen <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-negative bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>CycVWZ of <I>Bradyrhizobium japonicum</i> <br>
CycV (C)<br>
CycW (M)<br>
CycZ (M)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.107.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.107.2&tcname=">3.A.1.107.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The mitochondrial ABC transporter involved in cytochrome c maturation, CcmA/CcmB. (Note: CcmA is nuclearly encoded while CcmB is mitochondrially encoded) (<span id="ref5892.17550895" class="cite">Rayapuram <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>) </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Plant Mitochondria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CcmA/CcmB of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em><br />
CcmA (C)  (Q9C8T1)<br />
CcmB (M) (P93280)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.107.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.107.3&tcname=">3.A.1.107.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CcmABCD exporter; CcmD (69aas, 1TMS) is required for the release of CcmE (which binds heme in the periplasm) from CcmABC.  CcmC (9.B.14.2.3) is required for the transfer of heme to CcmE in the periplasm (<span id="ref5948.18326572" class="cite">Richard-Fogal <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>) In the presence of heme, CcmC and CcmE form a stable complex (<span id="ref7659.20599545" class="cite">Richard-Fogal &amp; Kranz, 2010</span>) as do CcmE and CcmF (<span id="ref10877.24513106" class="cite">San Francisco and Kranz 2014</span>). The cytochrome c maturation system I, consisting of eight membrane/periplasmic
proteins (CcmABCDEFGH), results in the attachment of heme to cysteine 
residues of cytochrome c proteins. Since all c-type cytochromes are 
periplasmic, heme is first transported to a periplasmic heme chaperone, 
CcmE. A large membrane complex, CcmABCD has been proposed to carry out 
this transport and linkage to CcmE.&nbsp;<span id="ref34555528.36307425" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2022</span> described high 
resolution cryo-EM structures of CcmABCD in an unbound form, in complex 
with inhibitor AMP-PNP, and in complex with ATP and heme. The 
ATP-binding site in CcmA and the heme-binding site in CcmC were identified. They proposed a
model of heme trafficking, heme transfer to CcmE, and ATP-dependent 
release of holoCcmE from CcmABCD. CcmABCD represents an ABC transporter 
complex using the energy of ATP hydrolysis for the transfer of heme from
 one binding partner (CcmC, see TC# 9.B.14.2.3) to another (CcmE) (<span id="ref34555528.36307425" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). It appers that CcmC is in a complex with CcmABD but is not part of the ABC transporter. The same may be true of CcmD (see description above).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CcmABCD of <em>E. coli</em><br /> CcmA (C) (Q8XE58)<br /> CcmB (M; 7 TMSs) (P0ABM0)<br /> CcmC (M; 6 TMSs) (P0ABM1 = P0ABM3)  (listed under TC# 9.B.14.2.3 not here)<br /> CcmD (M; 1 TMS) (P0ABM7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.107.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.107.4&tcname=">3.A.1.107.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cytochrome c maturation system (heme exporter?), CcmA/B</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&gamma;-Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CcmAB of<em> Pseudomonas virdiflava</em><br />CcmA (C) (K6BJ24)<br />CcmB (M) (K6BIH6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.108">3.A.1.108 The &#946;-Glucan Exporter (GlucanE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD
