bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>NdvA (M-C) of <I>Rhizobium meliloti</i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.109">3.A.1.109 The Protein-1 Exporter (Prot1E) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.109.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.109.1&tcname=">3.A.1.109.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&alpha;-Hemolysin exporter. HlyB has an (inactive?) N-terminal C39 peptidase-like domain (<span id="ref8867.21347827" class="cite">Lecher <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).&nbsp; It is essential for secretion and interacts with the unfolded HlyA, thereby protecting it from cytoplasmic degradation (<span id="ref8973.22959622" class="cite">Lecher <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). Type 1 secretion systems (T1SSs)&nbsp; extruding protein substrates following synthesis
 of the entire polypeptide. The <em>E. coli</em> hemolysin A secretion 
system has three membrane proteins - an inner membrane 
ABC transporter HlyB, an adaptor protein HlyD TC# 8.A.1.3.1), and an outer membrane 
porin TolC (TC# 1.B.17.1.1). All are required for secretion. Cryo-EM structures determined in two conformations revealed that the 
inner membrane complex is a hetero-dodecameric assembly comprising three
 HlyB homodimers and six HlyD subunits. Oligomerization of HlyB and HlyD is essential for protein secretion, and polypeptides translocate through a canonical ABC transporter 
pathway in HlyB (<span id="ref34555200.36055198" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HlyB (M-C) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.109.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.109.2&tcname=">3.A.1.109.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cyclolysin exporter, CyaB (<span id="ref5954.2905265" class="cite">Glaser <em>et al</em>., 1988</span>) (Possesses an N-terminal lysosomal sorting signal within the amino-terminal transmembrane domain; <span id="ref6538.18952056" class="cite">Kamakura <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CyaB (M-C) of <em>Bordetella pertussis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.109.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.109.3&tcname=">3.A.1.109.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>LapA adhesin protein exporter, LapB (<span id="ref6268.12890017" class="cite">Hinsa <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>LapB of <i>Pseudomonas putida</i>  <br>
LapB (MC)  (AAN65800)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.109.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.109.4&tcname=">3.A.1.109.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The biofilm inducible ABC drug (tobramycin, gentamycin, and ciprofloxacin) resistance pump, PA1875-PA1877 (<span id="ref5952.18469108" class="cite">Zhang and Mah, 2008</span>).&nbsp; It is specifically induced and is most active when&nbsp; growing in a biofilm.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PA1875-PA1877 of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em><br /> PA1875 (OMF; 425 aas) (Q9I2M2)<br /> PA1876 (ABC; M-C; 723 aas) (Q9I2M1)<br /> PA1877 (MFP; 395 aas) (Q9I2M0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.109.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.109.5&tcname=">3.A.1.109.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable giant non-fimbrial adhesin, SiiE, exporter, SiiFDC.&nbsp; SiiF interacts with SiiAB (TC# 1.A.30.4.1) which probably forms a proton channel homologous to that of MotAB (TC# 1.A.30.1.1) and facilitates energization of SiiE export using the pmf (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10377">Wille <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SiiFDC of <em>Salmonella enterica<br /></em>SiiF (M-C; 688 aas; E1WEV2)<br />SiiD (MFP; 425 aas; E1WEV0)<br />SiiC (OMF; 439 aas; E1WEU9)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.109.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.109.6&tcname=">3.A.1.109.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable 2646 aa extracellular adhesin (acc# C6BWI7) ABC exporter of 715 aas.&nbsp; Functions as a type I protein secretion system together with an MFP and an OMF which all are encoded within a single operon together with the adhesin and SiiAB homologues as for TC# 3.A.1.109.5.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC/MFP/OMF type I protein secretion system of <em>Desulfovibrio salexigens</em><br />ABC protein (M-C; 715 aas; C6BWI0)<br />MFP protein (430 aas; C6BWj0)<br />OMF protein (513 aas; C6BWI6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.109.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.109.8&tcname=">3.A.1.109.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Leukotoxin export protein of 707 aas, LtxB (has a fused M-C structure with 6 TMSs) (<span id="ref34545926.7476096" class="cite">Guthmiller <em>et al.</em> 1995</span>). Functions with the MFP, LtxD (TC# 8.A.1.3.4) and the TolC-like protein, TdeA (TC# 1.B.17.3.11).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Leukotoxin exporter of <em>Aggregatibacter (Actinobacillus; Haemophilus) actinomycetemcomitans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.11">3.A.1.11 The Polyamine/Opine/Phosphonate Uptake Transporter (POPT) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.11.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.11.1&tcname=">3.A.1.11.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Polyamine (putrescine/spermidine) uptake porter.&nbsp; Plays a role in biofilm formation (<span id="ref10202.23539287" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; Spermidine-preferring (<span id="ref10419.24178434" class="cite">Igarashi and Kashiwagi 1996</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PotABCD of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> PotA (C)<br /> PotB (M)<br /> PotC (M)<br /> PotD (R)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.11.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.11.10&tcname=">3.A.1.11.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The 3-component polyamine uptake transporter, PotABD. Transports homospermidine and possibly other polyamines. Inactivation of the <em>potADB</em> gene cluster (potADB) disrupted diazotrophic growth, clearly suggesting the importance 
of polyamine homeostasis in Anabaena. (<span id="ref34549844.29923645" class="cite">Burnat <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PotABD of <em>Anabaena variabilis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.11.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.11.2&tcname=">3.A.1.11.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putrescine porter (<span id="ref10419.24178434" class="cite">Igarashi and Kashiwagi 1996</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PotGHIF of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> PotG (C)<br /> PotH (M)<br /> PotI (M)<br /> PotF (R)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.11.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.11.3&tcname=">3.A.1.11.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Mannopine porter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Proteobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MotABCD of <I>Agrobacterium tumefaciens</i> plasmid pTi15955  </br>

(PrtF=1.B.17.1.2)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PrtDEF of <em>Erwinia chysanthemi</em>&nbsp;<br />PrtD (M-C) (P23596)<br />PrtE (MFP) (P23597)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.110.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.110.12&tcname=">3.A.1.110.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Thermostable lipase, TliA (Q9ZG91; 476 aas with a C-terminal region that shows similarity to members of the RTX toxin family (1.C.11)) exporter, TliDEF.&nbsp; The wild type transporter has a temperature sensitive defect which can be corrected by a single mutation in TliD (<span id="ref34545309.27033673" class="cite">Eom <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TliDEF of <em>Pseudomonas fluorescens<br /></em>TliD, 578 aas (M-C) and 6 N-terminal TMSs<br />TliE, 433 aas (MFP) <br />TliF, 481 aas (OMF)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.110.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.110.13&tcname=">3.A.1.110.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Protein export system, PrtD of 564 aas and 6 TMSs. The 3.15 &Aring; structure has been solved (<span id="ref34546566.28216041" class="cite">Morgan <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp; The structure suggests a substrate entry window just above the transporter's nucleotide binding domains. Highly kinked transmembrane helices, which frame a narrow channel, not observed in canonical peptide transporters, are likely involved in substrate translocation. The PrtD structure supports a polypeptide transport mechanism distinct from alternating access (<span id="ref34546566.28216041" class="cite">Morgan <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PrtD of <em>Aquifex aeolicus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.110.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.110.3&tcname=">3.A.1.110.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The multiple protein exporter, PrsD/PrsE (exports EPS glycanases, PlyA and PlyB, as well as <i>Rhizobium</i> adhering proteins) (<span id="ref5842.16740954" class="cite">Russo <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>). 12 substrates have been identified; PrsDE provide the major route of protein export in <i>R. leguminosarum</i> (<span id="ref5940.18230162" class="cite">Krehenbrink and Downie, 2008</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-negative bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>PrsD/PrsE of <I>Rhizobium leguminosarum</i> <br>
PrsD(M-C) (O05693) <br>

<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.110.7"></a></p>
<p>Exporter for heme-binding protein, HasA and metaloprotease, PrtA.&nbsp; Functions as a complex spanning the two membranes of the cell envelope: HasDEF (HasD = ABC protein; HasE = the MFP; HasF = the OMF (see 2.A.6.2.31 for HasF) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9538">Akatsuka <em>et al.</em> 1997</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HasDEF of <em>Serratia marcescens</em><br />HasD (M-C) (Q53368)<br />HasE (MFP) (Q57387)<br />HasF (OMF) (Q54452)<span style="font-size: 10px;"><em>&nbsp;</em></span></p>

NukT and its peptidase-inactive mutant have been expressed, purified, and reconstituted into liposomes for analysis of their peptidase and ATPase activities. The ATPase activity of the NBD (C) region is required for the cysteine-type peptidase activity, and leader peptide cleavage enhances the ATPase activity (<span id="ref34547703.29167920" class="cite">Zheng <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NukT of <em>Staphylococcus warneri </em>(P-M-C)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.111.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.111.8&tcname=">3.A.1.111.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized ABC export system of 608 aas and 6 N-terminal TMSs in a 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement followed by the ATPase domain (M-C).&nbsp; It is adjacent to a 10&nbsp; protein where the TMSs are in a 5 + 5 TMS arrangement.&nbsp; Possibly this latter protein is a chaparone protein for proper insertion and folding of the transporter (see TC# 9.B.29.2.17 whick seems to be a chaparone protein for insertion and folding of ABC transporter with TC# 3.A.1.122.2.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Lachnospiraceae bacterium</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.112">3.A.1.112 The Peptide-2 Exporter (Pep2E) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.1&tcname=">3.A.1.112.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Competence factor (CSF; a heptadecapeptide) exporter of 717 aas.&nbsp; The transporter is fused to an N-terminal peptidase&nbsp; domain and functions with an MFP&nbsp; accessory protein, ComB (TC# 8.A.1.4.2) (<span id="ref10847.16377622" class="cite">Ishii <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ComA (peptidase-M-C) of <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em> (functions with MFP accessory protein, ComB)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.10&tcname=">3.A.1.112.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteriocin exporter of 721 aas and 7 TMSs. Residues 10 - 134: peptidase with N-terminal TMS; residues 167 - 446: TM domain; residues 480 - 715: ATPase.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peptide exporter of <em>Bacteroides salanitronis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.11&tcname=">3.A.1.112.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Enterocin CRL35 exporter, MunB, of 674 aas and 6 TMSs in an M-C domain arrangement.&nbsp; The specific receptor for Enterocin CRL35 (MunA; TC# 1.C.24.1.15) acts as a docking molecule, not a structural part of the pore, but the bacteriocin must be anchored to the membrane (<span id="ref34550053.31381962" class="cite">R&iacute;os Colombo <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Enterocin CRL35 exporter of <em>Enterococcus mundtii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.12&tcname=">3.A.1.112.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Colicin V exporter. The ATPase is a GTPase (<span id="ref34544963.9515899" class="cite">Zhong and Tai 1998</span>; ).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Enteric bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CvaB (M-C) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.13&tcname=">3.A.1.112.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Microcin E492 exporter, MceFGH (MceF has 5 - 7 TMSs and is most likely a CAAX amino terminal protease that might function in the processing of microcin E492; MceG has a short hydrophilic N-terminus, a centra 6 TMS ABC domain, and a C-terminal ABC ATPase domain; MceH has 1 N-terminal TMS) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref5864">Bieler <em>et al</em>., 2006</a>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref6006">Lagos <em>et al</em>., 1999</a>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MceGH of <em>Klebsiella pneumoniae</em><br /> MceG (C-M-C) (Q93GK5)<br /> MceH (MFP) (Q93GK4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.2&tcname=">3.A.1.112.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Pediocin PA-1 exporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>PedD (M-C) of <I>Pediococcus acidilactici</i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.3&tcname=">3.A.1.112.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteriocin (lactococcin) exporter.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LcnC (M-C) of <em>Lactococcus lactis</em> (functions with putative MFP accessory protein LcnD)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.4&tcname=">3.A.1.112.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Sublancin exporter, SunT</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SunT (M-C) of <I>Bacillus subtilis</i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.5&tcname=">3.A.1.112.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.112.5"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>Exporter of the BlpC peptide pheromone (B5E242) and several bacteriocins, BlpAB (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9721">Kochan and Dawid 2013</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicute</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BlpAB of <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em><br />BlpA (M-C) (B3E244)<br />BlpB (MFP) (B3E242)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.6&tcname=">3.A.1.112.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC transporter (6 TMSs)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC Transporter of <em>Ureaplasma parvum</em> (Q9PPY0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.8&tcname=">3.A.1.112.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mesenterici Y105 (bacteriocin) ABC exporter and porcessing protease, MesD(E) of 722 aas and 6 TMSs (MesD) (<span id="ref34544021.7551032" class="cite">Fremaux <em>et al.</em> 1995</span>). MesDE can transport and catalyze maturation of the two pre-bacteriocins, mesentericin Y105 and B105 (<span id="ref34544022.15019729" class="cite">Aucher <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).&nbsp; Hydrophobic conserved amino acyl residues and the C-terminal GG doublet of the 
leader peptide of pre-mesentericin Y105 are critical
 for optimal secretion (<span id="ref34544023.15743973" class="cite">Aucher <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>).&nbsp; MesE has TC# 8.A.1.4.1.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MesDE of <em>Leuconostoc mesenteroides</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.112.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.112.9&tcname=">3.A.1.112.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC bacteriocin exporter with two peptidase domains, Pcat1. 3-D structures are known (4S0F, 6V9Z, 4RY2). The pathway for peptide export consists of an large &alpha;-helical barrel for small folded peptides.&nbsp; ATP binding alternates access to the transmembrane pathway and reglates protease activity (<span id="ref34544323.26201595" class="cite">Lin <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Subunit asymmetry of the M3-M4 loops contribute to optimizing AChR activation through allosteric links to the channel and the agonist binding site (<span id="ref34550752.15615813" class="cite">Shen <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>). Structures were more recently determined in the absence and presence of ATP, revealing how ATP binding regulates the protease activity and access to the translocation pathway. Two substrate CtAs, 90-residue polypeptides, are bound via their N-terminal leader peptides, but only one is positioned for cleavage and translocation. The structures were determined in the absence and presence of ATP, revealing how ATP binding regulates the protease activity and access to the translocation pathway. It seems that substrate cleavage, ATP hydrolysis, and substrate translocation are coordinated in a transport cycle (<span id="ref34550753.31934861" class="cite">Kieuvongngam <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The N-terminal C39 peptidase (PEP) domain of PCAT1 processes its natural substrate, CtA, by cleaving a conserved -GG- motif to separate the cargo from the leader peptide prior to secretion. The ATP-mediated association between PEP and the transmembrane domains of PCAT1 offers a putative mechanism to optimize peptide cleavage by regulating the width and flexibility of the enzyme active site (<span id="ref34554160.34865273" class="cite">Bhattacharya and Palillo 2021</span>). Structures of the peptidase-containing ABC transporter PCAT1 under equilibrium and nonequilibrium conditions have been solved (<span id="ref34554335.35074919" class="cite">Kieuvongngam and Chen 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pcat1 of <em>Ruminiclostridium thermocellus (Clostridium thermocellum; Hungateiclostridium thermocellum</em>)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.113">3.A.1.113 The Peptide-3 Exporter (Pep3E) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.113.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.113.1&tcname=">3.A.1.113.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Modified cyclic peptide (syringomycin) exporter, SyrD </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-negative bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SyrD (M-C) of <I>Pseudomonas syringae</i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.113.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.113.2&tcname=">3.A.1.113.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Pyoverdin (siderophore) exporter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-negative bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>PvdE (M-C) of <I>Pseudomonas aeruginosa </i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.113.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.113.3&tcname=">3.A.1.113.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The multidrug/microcin J25 (MccJ25; 21 aa cyclic peptide antibiotic; the precursor peptide is McjA) exporter, YojI (<span id="ref5816.15866933" class="cite">Delgado <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>). TolC is also required for export; <span id="ref6432.19199920" class="cite">Vincent and Morero, 2009</span>). This system exports many phytol derivatives (<span id="ref34543658.24891085" class="cite">Upadhyay <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Also exports L-cysteine (<span id="ref7183.16820466" class="cite">Yamada <em>et al.</em>, 2006</span>).&nbsp; This is one of two microcin J25 exporters, the other being McjD (TC# 3.A.1.118.1).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YojI of <em>E. coli</em> (P33941)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.114">3.A.1.114 The Probable Glycolipid Exporter (DevE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.114.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.114.1&tcname=">3.A.1.114.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glycolipid exporter (under nitrogen control in heterocysts), DevABC-HgdD (<span id="ref5899.17720784" class="cite">Moslavac <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). Heterocyst envelope glycolipids (HGLs) function as an O<span><sub>2</sub></span>&nbsp;diffusion barrier, being deposited over the heterocyst outer membrane, surrounded by an outermost heterocyst polysaccharide envelope. DevBCA and TolC form an ATP-driven efflux pump required for the export of HGLs across the Gram-negative cell wall (<span id="ref8044.21917923" class="cite">Staron <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). DevB, the MFP, must be hexameric to create a functional export complex.&nbsp; This system is under NtcA and nitrogen control and is required for heterocyst development (<span id="ref34543681.11371545" class="cite">Fiedler <em>et al.</em> 2001</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cyanobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>DevABC-HgdD of <em>Anabaena variabilis</em> (sp. strain PCC7120) <br /> DevA (C) <br /> DevB (MFP) <br /> DevC (M) <br /> HgdD (TolC like)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.115">3.A.1.115 The Na<sup>+</sup> Exporter (NatE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.115.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.115.1&tcname=">3.A.1.115.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Na<sup>+ </sup> efflux pump NatAB. It <span style="font-weight: normal;">is induced by ethanol andby protonophores (<span id="ref5979.9106203" class="cite">Cheng <em>et al.</em> 1997</span>). A similar system was found in the </span><span style="font-weight: normal;">alkaliphilic <em>Bacillus firmus</em> OF4 species (<span id="ref34554808.10356997" class="cite">Wei <em>et al.</em> 1999</span>).</span><span class="docsum-title"> The <em>Bacillus subtilis</em> NatK-NatR two-component system regulates expression of the <em>natAB</em></span> operon (<span id="ref34554809.17322186" class="cite">Ogura <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NatAB of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em> <br /> NatA (M) <br /> NatB (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.115.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.115.2&tcname=">3.A.1.115.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>

650).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Planctomycetes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NatAB of <em>Rhodopirellula baltica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 McbF (C)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.117">3.A.1.117 The Drug Exporter-2 (DrugE2) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.117.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.117.1&tcname=">3.A.1.117.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The multidrug exporter, LmrA (can also substitute for MsbA [TC #3.A.1.106.1] to export lipid A; <span>Reuter <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>).&nbsp; Structural models have been presented (<span><span id="ref34551240.15304548" class="cite">Ecker <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>; Federici <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). Hoechst 33342 is a substrate (<span>van den Berg and van Saparoea <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>). Coupled ATPase-adenylate kinase activity in ABC transporters including LmrA has been demonstrated (<span id="ref34549525.28004795" class="cite">Kaur <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). This efflux porter mediates efflux of hydrophobic cationic substrates including antibiotics. TMS 3 of one monomer probably contacts TMS 5 or TMS 6 of the opposite monomer where substrate-binding occurs at the monomer/monomer interface (<span id="ref34551240.15304548" class="cite">Ecker <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LmrA (M-C) of <em>Lactococcus lactis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.117.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.117.2&tcname=">3.A.1.117.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.117.2"></a></p>
<p>Hop resistance protein, HorA. Reconstitution in phosphatidyl ethanolamine bilayers resulted in normal activity, but reconstitution in phosphatidyl choline resulted in uncoupling of ATP hydrolysis from transport and a change in the orientations of the TMSs (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10066">Gustot <em>et al.</em> 2010</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HorA (M-C) of <em>Lactobacillus brevis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.117.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.117.3&tcname=">3.A.1.117.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance homodimeric efflux pump, BmrA (YvcC) of 589 aas (<span id="ref34550294.15766260" class="cite">Dalmas <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>).&nbsp; The low resolution cryo-electron microscopy reconstitution suggests large conformational changes occur during it's catalytic cycle (<span id="ref10971.24630999" class="cite">Fribourg <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). Backbone NMR assignments of the nucleotide binding domain of BmrA in the post-hydrolysis state have been determined (<span id="ref34554371.34988902" class="cite">P&eacute;rez Carrillo <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). The protein is homodimeric, and it's unfolding and themodynamic stability have been studied (<span id="ref34556316.36982314" class="cite">Oepen <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmictues</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BmrA of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.118">3.A.1.118 The Microcin J25 Exporter (McjD) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.118.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.118.1&tcname=">3.A.1.118.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The cyclic peptide antibiotic, microcin J25 (MccJ25; the precursor peptide is JcjA) exporter, the self immunity protein, McjD. TolC is also required for export; <span id="ref6432.19199920" class="cite">Vincent and Morero, 2009</span>.&nbsp; The 3-d structure has been determined to 2.7&Aring; resolution in an outward occluded state (<span id="ref11209.24920594" class="cite">Choudhury <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Binding and efflux as well as stimulation of the ATPase activity upon binding of MccJ25 have been demonstrated (<span id="ref11209.24920594" class="cite">Choudhury <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; This is one of two MCCJ25 exporters, the other being YojI (TC# 3.A.1.113.3).&nbsp; The
large conformational changes in some crystal structures may not be necessary even for a large
substrate like MccJ25 (<span id="ref34544485.26334959" class="cite">Gu <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>McjD (M-C) of <em>E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.119">3.A.1.119 The Drug/Siderophore Exporter-3 (DrugE3) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.119.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.119.1&tcname=">3.A.1.119.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>5-Hydroxystreptomycin and other streptomycin-like aminoglycoside exporter, StrVW</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>StrVW of <I>Streptomyces glaucescens</I> <br>

gene is in a gene cluster encoding the recognized coelichelin uptake 
system (TC# 3.A.1.14.12) as well as coelichelin biosynthetic enzymes (<span id="ref6045.17074905" class="cite">Barona-G&oacute;mez <em>et al.</em> 2006).</span>&nbsp;
 Sco0493&nbsp; (see TC# 3.A.1.119.4) may function together with Sco0540, both of which are putative 
ABC exporters of similar sequence. Alternatively, these two genes may encode two distinct transport

(ChoX binds acetyl choline and betaine with low affinity (80&mu;M and 470&mu;M, respectively) (<span id="ref7960.21803998" class="cite">Aktas <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>) (most similar to 3.A.1.12.7)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ChoVWX of <em>Agrobacterium tumefaciens&nbsp;</em><br />ChoX (R) (Q7CXG0)<br />ChoW (M) (Q7CXG1)<br />ChoV<em>&nbsp;</em>(C) (A9CI32)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.12.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.12.14&tcname=">3.A.1.12.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>OsmU (OsmVWXY) transporter for glycine betaine and choline-O-sulfate uptake. The sequence of OpuB, the membrane component of the system, is not included here. The 3-d structure of OpuC (or a part of it) has been solved (5IIP_A-D).</p>

BusAA, the ATPase subunit, has a C-terminal tandem cystathionine &beta;-synthase (CBS) domain which is the cytoplasmic K<sup>+</sup> sensor for osmotic stress (osmotic strength)while the BusABC subunit has the membrane and receptor domains fused to each other (<span id="ref5844.16815971" class="cite">Biemans-Oldehinkel <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>; <span id="ref5847.16844687" class="cite">Mahmood <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>; <span id="ref8774.22656643" class="cite">Gul <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). An N-terminal amphipathic &alpha;-helix of OpuA is necessary for high activity but is not critical for biogenesis or the ionic regulation of transport (<span id="ref8774.22656643" class="cite">Gul <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). NAME="3.A.1.120.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.120.7&tcname=">3.A.1.120.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter, SgvT2 (ATP-hydrolyzing subunit of 551 aas. Functions to export griseoviridin and viridogrisein (etamycin) (<span id="ref34547494.29065880" class="cite">Xie <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). However, it may also function as an <span id="feature_AGN74890.1_Region_2" class="feature">ATP-binding cassette domain of elongation factor 3, interacting with the ribosome which stimulates its ATPase activity (<span id="ref34547496.24379402" class="cite">Sasikumar and Kinzy 2014</span>).<br /></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SgvT2 of <em>Streptomyces griseoviridis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.120.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.120.8&tcname=">3.A.1.120.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&nbsp;ABC protein of 558 aas and 0 TMSs, Rv2477c.&nbsp; It is a<span> translation factor that gates the 
progression of the 70S ribosomal initiation complex (IC, containing 
tRNA (fMet) in the P site) into the translation elongation cycle by using
 a mechanism sensitive to the ATP/ADP ratio. Binds to the 70S ribosome E
 site where it modulates the state of the translating ribosome during 
subunit translocation. It is </span>an ABC-F subfamily protein, members of which are implicated in diverse cellular processes such as translation, antibiotic resistance, cell growth and nutrient sensing. <span>Daniel <em>et al.</em> 2018 </span>showed that Rv2477c displays strong ATPase activity (Vmax = 45 nmol/mg/min; Km = 90 muM) that is sensitive to orthovanadate. The ATPase activity was maximal in the presence of Mn<sup>2+</sup> at pH 5.2. The protein hydrolyzed GTP, TTP and CTPas well as ATP but at lower rates. Glutamate to glutamine substitutions of amino acid residues 185 and 468 in the two Walker B motifs severely inhibited its ATPase activity. The antibiotics, tetracycline and erythromycin, which target protein translation, were able to inhibit the ATPase activity. <span>Daniel <em>et al.</em> 2018 </span> postulated that Rv2477c is involved in mycobacterial protein translation and in resistance to tetracyclines and macrolides.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>v2477c of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.121">3.A.1.121 The (Putative) Drug Resistance ATPase-2 (Drug RA2) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.121.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.121.1&tcname=">3.A.1.121.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Erythromycin ATPase (membrane constituent unknown) </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MsrA (C-C) of <I>Staphylococcus epidermidis </i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.121.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.121.10&tcname=">3.A.1.121.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCF1 (out of 5 isoforms) of 595 aas and 0 TMSs. Functions as a ribosome regulator.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCF1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.121.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.121.11&tcname=">3.A.1.121.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-binding cassette sub-family F member 2, ABCF2 of 623 aas and 0 TMSs.&nbsp; Its function is unknown, but it is probably not a transporter (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCF2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.121.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.121.2&tcname=">3.A.1.121.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Pristinamycin resistance protein, VgaG</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>VgaB (C-C) of <I>Staphylococcus aureus</i></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.121.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.121.3&tcname=">3.A.1.121.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Antibiotic (virginiamycin and lincomycin) resistance protein, VmlR</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>VmlR (C-C) of <i>Bacillus subtilis</i> (P39115)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.121.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.121.5&tcname=">3.A.1.121.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC-type streptogammin A resistance exporter, VgaA of 522 aas and 0 TMSs (C-C arrangement).&nbsp; Inhibited by pristinamycin IIA (<span id="ref34544778.18562322" class="cite">Jacquet <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>). A transport function is not known.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>VgaA of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.121.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.121.6&tcname=">3.A.1.121.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MsrD of 487 aas and 0 TMSs. Involved in macrolide resistance (<span id="ref34547417.26531240" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Two ATPase domains are present in tandem. A membrane constituent is not known. <span id="ref34548737.30108557" class="cite">Iannelli <em>et al.</em> 2018</span> suggested that MefA (TC# 2.a.1.21.1) can function with MsrD, and therefore that this MFS exporter can function as an ABC drug exporter.&nbsp; However, 
the data presented seem inconsistent with this suggestion. Nevertheless, the two genes
 encoding these two proteins are adjacent to each other, suggesting that
 they may somehow function together (<span id="ref34548737.30108557" class="cite">Iannelli <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MsrD of <em>Streptococcus pyogenes </em>(C-C)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.121.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.121.7&tcname=">3.A.1.121.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC protein of 684 aas and 0 TMSs, ATCF1.&nbsp; F<span><span>ound</span><span> </span><span>to</span><span> </span><span>be</span></span><span> essential</span><span> </span><span>for</span><span> </span><span>bloodstream-form</span><span> </span><span><em><span>Trypanosoma</span><span> </span><span>brucei</span></em><span> </span></span><span>through</span><span> </span><span>a</span><span> genome-wide</span><span> </span><span>RNAi</span><span> </span><span>screen (<span id=""ref34548493.29063677"" class=""cite"">Schmidt <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCF1 of <em>Trypanosoma brucei</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.121.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.121.8&tcname=">3.A.1.121.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-binding cassette subfamily F member 1, ABCF1 or ABC50, of 845 aas and 0 TMSs. There is no transmembrane protein associated with ABCF1, and this protein does not function in transport.&nbsp; It <span>is required for efficient Cap- and 
IRES-mediated mRNA translational initiation, </span><span><span>not in ribosome biogenesis </span>(<span id="ref34548649.19570978" class="cite">Paytubi <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</span> ABCF1 regulates dsDNA-induced immune responses in human airway epithelial cells (<span id="ref34553442.33042865" class="cite">Cao <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCF1 of<em> Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.121.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.121.9&tcname=">3.A.1.121.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCF3 of 709 aas and 0 TMSs. It is not a transporter, but is a translational regulator that also promotes apoptosis (<span id="ref34548650.25101958" class="cite">Hirose and Horvitz 2014</span>). It has an antiviral effect against flaviviruses (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCF3 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.122">3.A.1.122 The Macrolide Exporter (MacB) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.1&tcname=">3.A.1.122.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Macrolide (14- and 15- but not 16-membered lactone macrolides including erythromycin) exporter, MacAB (formerly YbjYZ). Both MacA and MacB are required for activity (<span id=""ref5877.17214741"" class=""cite"">Tikhonova <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). MacAB functions with TolC to export multiple drugs and heat-stable enterotoxin II (enterotoxin STII) (<span id=""ref6332.18805970"" class=""cite"">Yamanaka <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>).  The crystal structure of MacA is available (<span id=""ref6389.19254725"" class=""cite"">Yum <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>). MacB is a dimer whose ATPase activity and macrolide-binding capacity are regulated by the membrane fusion protein MacA (<span id=""ref6533.18955484"" class=""cite"">Lin <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>). <span id=""ref6612.19432486"" class=""cite"">Xu <em>et al.</em> (2009)</span> have reported the crystal structure of the periplasmic region of MacB which they claim resembles the periplasmic domain of RND-type transporters such as AcrB (TC# 2.A.6.2.2). Also exports L-cysteine (<span id=""ref7183.16820466"" class=""cite"">Yamada <em>et al.</em>, 2006</span>). The periplasmic membrane proximal domain of MacA acts as a switch in stimulation of ATP hydrolysis by the MacB transporter (<span id=""ref7944.21696464"" class=""cite"">Modali and Zgurskaya, 2011</span>).&nbsp;<span id=""ref34546728.28504659"" class=""cite"">Fitzpatrick <em>et al.</em> 2017</span> presented an electron cryo-microscopy structure of the tripartite assembly (MacAB-TolC) at near-atomic resolution. A hexamer of the periplasmic protein MacA bridges a TolC trimer in the outer membrane to a MacB dimer in the inner membrane, generating a quaternary structure with a central channel for substrate translocation. A gating ring found in MacA may act as a one-way valve in substrate transport. The MacB structure features an atypical transmembrane domain with a closely packed dimer interface and a periplasmic opening that is the likely portal for substrate entry from the periplasm, with subsequent displacement through an allosteric transport mechanism (<span id=""ref34546728.28504659"" class=""cite"">Fitzpatrick <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). The structure of ATP-bound MacB has been solved, revealing precise molecular details of its mechanism (<span id=""ref34547566.29109272"" class=""cite"">Crow <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). MacB has a fold that is different from other structurally characterized ABC transporters and uses a unique molecular mechanism termed mechanotransmission. Unlike other bacterial ABC transporters, MacB does not transport substrates across the inner membrane in which it is based, but instead couples cytoplasmic ATP hydrolysis with transmembrane conformational changes that are used to perform work in the extra-cytoplasmic space. In the MacAB-TolC tripartite pump, mechanotransmission drives efflux of antibiotics and export of a protein toxin from the periplasmic space via the TolC exit duct. Homologous tripartite systems from pathogenic bacteria similarly export protein-like signaling molecules, virulence factors and siderophores (<span id=""ref34548412.29892271"" class=""cite"">Greene <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MacAB of <em>E. coli</em>: <br /> MacA(MFP) (P75830) <br /> MacB(C-M) (P75831)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.10&tcname=">3.A.1.122.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Duf214 (423aas) ABC3 membrane protein with ABC-type ATPase (232 aas).&nbsp; Sandwiched inbetween the genes encoding these two proteins is a large protein of 869 aas with 2 TMSs, N- and C-terminal. Some homologues are annotated as "S-layer domain protein".&nbsp; It may be an ABC auxiliary protein.&nbsp; Most members occur in archaea, but distant homologues are also found in bacteria.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Duf214/ABC system of <em>Sulfurisphaera tokodaii (Sulfolobus tokodaii)</em>: <br /> Duf214 protein (M) (Q973J4)<br />ATPase (C) (Q973J6)<br />Putative auxiliary protein (Q973J5)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.11&tcname=">3.A.1.122.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The hemin resistance transporter, HrtAB. Expression is activated by hemin or hemoglobin via the ChrAS transmembrane sensor kinase/response regulator system (<span id="ref9529.20639324" class="cite">Bibb and Schmitt 2010</span>). HrtBA extracts heme from the membrane and expells it.&nbsp; HrtBA consists of two cytoplasmic HrtA ATPase subunits and two transmembrane HrtB permease subunits. A heme-binding site is formed in the HrtB dimer and is laterally accessible to heme in the outer leaflet of the membrane. The heme-binding site captures heme from the membrane using a glutamate residue of either subunit as an axial ligand and sequesters the heme within the rearranged transmembrane helix bundle. By ATP-driven HrtA dimerization, the heme-binding site is squeezed to extrude the bound heme (<span id="ref34554952.35767641" class="cite">Nakamura <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HrtAB of <em>Corynebacterium diphtheriae<br /></em>HrtA (C) (H2GZC3)<br />HrtB (M) (H2GZC4)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.12&tcname=">3.A.1.122.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Arthrofactin efflux pump, ArfDE (<span id="ref10018.16298298" class="cite">Balibar <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&gamma;-Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ArfDE of <em>Pseudomonas</em> sp. MIS38<br />ArfD (MFP) (Q84BQ3)<br />ArfE (ABC) (A0ZUB1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.13&tcname=">3.A.1.122.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative ABC3-type antimicrobial peptide transporter, fused ATPase-porter protein, U-ABC3-1b (667aas; 4TMSs:1+3)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>U-ABC3-1b of <i>Lactobacillus brevis</i> (CM) (Q03RZ6)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.14&tcname=">3.A.1.122.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of unknown function, but aspects of its structure and mechanism of action are known (<span id="ref34546711.11402022" class="cite">Yuan <em>et al.</em> 2001</span>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10444">Zoghbi and Altenberg 2013</a>).<strong>&nbsp; </strong>Nucleotide-binding domain dimerization occurs as a result of binding to the natural nucleotide triphosphates, ATP, GTP, CTP and UTP, as well as the analog ATP-gamma-S. All the natural nucleotide triphosphates are hydrolyzed at similar rates, whereas ATP-gamma-S is not hydrolyzed. The non-hydrolyzable ATP analog AMP-PNP, frequently assumed to produce the nucleotide-bound conformation, failed to elicit nucleotide-binding domain dimerization (<span id="ref34546936.27765627" class="cite">Fendley <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of <em>Methanocaldococcus jannaschii (Methanococcus jannaschii)<br /></em>Membrane protein, MJ0797 (M) (Q58207)<br />ATPase, MJ0796 (C) (Q58206)<em></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.15&tcname=">3.A.1.122.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative heavy metal ion exporter, YbbAB (<span id="ref34543636.18634750" class="cite">Moussatova <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YbbAB of <em>E. coli</em><br />YbbA (C; 228 aas)<br />YbbB (M; 804 aas)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.16&tcname=">3.A.1.122.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative macrolide-specific efflux system, MacAB</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MacAB of <em>Bifidobacterium longum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.17&tcname=">3.A.1.122.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LolC/E family lipoprotein releasing system, transmembrane protein of 639 aas and 4 TMSs</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LolC/E family lipoprotein releasing system, transmembrane protein of Candidatus<em> Saccharibacteria</em><em> bacterium</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.18&tcname=">3.A.1.122.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MacAB-TolC MDR effllux porter. Exports macrolide antibiotics, virulence factors, peptides and cell envelope precursors. The 3-d crystal structure of MacB has been solved at 3.4&nbsp;&Aring; resolution (<span id="ref34547704.29109439" class="cite">Okada <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). MacB forms a dimer in which each protomer contains a nucleotide-binding domain and four TMSs that protrude in the periplasm into a binding domain for interaction with the membrane fusion protein MacA. It has unique structural features (<span id="ref34547704.29109439" class="cite">Okada <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MacAB of <em>Acinetobacter baumannii <br /></em>MacA, Q2FD52, 445 aas and 1 TMS<br />MacB, N9J6M5, 664 aas and 4 TMSs<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.19&tcname=">3.A.1.122.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC3-type efflux porter, YtrEF, encoded within an operon, <em>ytrABCDEF</em>, apparently encoding two ABC exporters, one, YtrBCD, with TC# 3.A.1.153.1, and the other, this one. The operon is induced in early stationary phase under the control of YtrA, a GntR-type HTH transcriptional regulator, probably a repressor (<span id="ref34547762.10986249" class="cite">Yoshida <em>et al.</em> 2000</span>). These authors suggest this operon may be involve in acetoin secretion and/or reutilization.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YtrEF of <em>Bacillus subtilis<br /></em>YtrE, C, 231 aas; O34392<br />YtrF, M, 436 aas; O35005<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.2&tcname=">3.A.1.122.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The SpdC antimicrobial peptide resistance efflux pump, YknXYZ (<span id="ref5838.16629676" class="cite">Butcher and Helmann, 2006</span>).&nbsp; YknW (TC# 9.B.29.2.17), a 5 TMS protein, interacts directly with YknXYZ and is essential for facilitation of its assembly, thus serving as an integral membrane chaparone&nbsp; (<span id="ref8837.22707703" class="cite">Yamada <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). The MFP YknX requires the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter YknYZ 
and the Yip1 family protein YknW to form a functional complex. YknX (MFP) is hexameric (<span id="ref34550457.28917834" class="cite">Xu <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YknXYZ of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em><br /> YknX (MFP) (O31710) <br /> YknY (C) (O31711) <br /> YknZ (M) (O31712)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.20&tcname=">3.A.1.122.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MacAB-MFP complex of 3 subunits involved in the resistance of antibiotics and antimicrobial peptides.&nbsp;<span>Yang <em>et al.</em> 2018</span> reported the crystal structures of Spr0694-0695 (MacAB) at 3.3&nbsp;&Aring; and Spr0693 (MFP; TC# 8.A.1) at 3.0 &Aring; resolution, revealing a MacAB-like efflux pump. The dimeric MacAB adopts a non-canonical fold, the transmembrane domain of which consists of a dimer with eight tightly packed TMSs (4 per subunit) with an extracellular domain between the first and second helices, whereas Spr0693 (the MFP) forms a nanotube channel docked onto the ABC transporter. Structural analyses, combined with ATPase activity and antimicrobial susceptibility assays, enabled the proposal of a putative substrate-entrance tunnel with lateral access controlled by a guard helix (<span>Yang <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MacAB-MFP of <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae<br /></em>MacA, Spr0694, 233 aas (C)<br />MacB, Spr0695, 419 aas (M)<br />MFP, Spr0693, 399 aas, (MFP)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.21&tcname=">3.A.1.122.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transport system with a type 3 ABC membrane protein (386 aas and 4 TMSs; B8GHI1) and an ABC ATPase (234 aas; B8GHI2).&nbsp; The encoding genes are adjacent to those encoding a putative transport system with TC# 9.B.29.2.7.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of <em>Methanocorpusculum labreanum </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.22&tcname=">3.A.1.122.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized ABC exporter of two subunits, a 4 TMS membrane subunit of 177 aas, and an ATPase of 229 aas</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP ABC exporter <br />(M) 177 aas and 4 TMSs, KKK40843<br />(C)&nbsp; 229 aas and ) TMSs, KKK48044</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.23&tcname=">3.A.1.122.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized ABC exporter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized ABC exporter of Candidatus Thorarchaeota<br />(M) 173 aas and 4 TMSs, RDE13437<br />(C) 225 aas, RDE13438</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.24&tcname=">3.A.1.122.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized ABC exporter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of Candidatus Odinarchaeota<br />(M) 166 aas and 4 TMSs, OLS17116<br />(C)&nbsp; Both membrane proteins have 10 TMSs in a 1 + (3 + 2 + 1) + 3 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.34"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.34&tcname=">3.A.1.122.34</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized putative ABC exporter of 4 components, all encoded by adjacent genes: one membrane protein, two ATPases and one membrane fusion protein (MFP).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Paenibacillus mucilaginosus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.35"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.35&tcname=">3.A.1.122.35</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The MacAB drug exporter.&nbsp; MacB is an ABC transporter that collaborates with the MacA adaptor 
protein (a membrane fusion protein, MFP) and the TolC exit duct to drive efflux of antibiotics and 
enterotoxin STII out of the bacterial cell.&nbsp;<span id="ref34547566.29109272" class="cite">Crow <em>et al.</em> 2017</span> presented the 
structure of ATP-bound MacB and reveal precise molecular details of its 
mechanism. The MacB transmembrane domain lacks a central cavity through 
which substrates could be passed, but instead conveys conformational 
changes from one side of the <span class="highlight">membrane</span> to the other, a process termed mechanotransmission. Comparison of 
ATP-bound and nucleotide-free states revealed how reversible dimerization
 of the nucleotide binding domains drives opening and closing of the 
MacB periplasmic domains via concerted movements of the second 
transmembrane segment and the major coupling helix. They proposed that the 
assembled tripartite pump acts as a molecular bellows to propel 
substrates through the TolC exit duct, driven by MacB 
mechanotransmission. Homologs of MacB that do not form tripartite pumps,
 but share structural features underpinning mechanotransmission, include
 the LolCDE lipoprotein trafficking complex and FtsEX cell division 
signaling protein. The MacB architecture serves as a blueprint for 
understanding the structure and mechanism of an entire ABC transporter 
superfamily and the many diverse functions it supports (<span id="ref34547566.29109272" class="cite">Crow <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). The crystal structure of MacA has been solved (<span id="ref6389.19254725" class="cite">Yum <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MacAB of <em>Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans (Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans) </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.36"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.36&tcname=">3.A.1.122.36</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC-type antimicrobial peptide transport system with two components, one having a domain structure of C-M and 653 aas with 4 TMSs, and the other being a membrane fusion protein (see TC# 8.A.1) (<span id="ref34554098.22367941" class="cite">Cho and Kang 2012</span>). A mutant showed significant reduction in secretion of syringomycin (74%) and syringopeptin (71%), as compared to the parental strain (<span id="ref34554098.22367941" class="cite">Cho and Kang 2012</span>). The PseEF efflux system has a role in secretion of syringomycin and syringopeptin, and is 
required for full virulence in <em>P. syringae</em> pv. syringae.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PseEF of <em>Pseudomonas syringae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.37"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.37&tcname=">3.A.1.122.37</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter permease of 831 aas and 8 TMSs in a 1 + 3 + 1 + 3 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC permease of Gemmatimonadota bacterium (marine sediment metagenome)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.122.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.122.4&tcname=">3.A.1.122.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Probable Heme exporter, HrtAB (<span id="ref6271.18326576" class="cite">Stauff <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>HrtAB of <i>Staphylococcus aureus</i>: <br>

(Pep5E) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.124.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.124.1&tcname=">3.A.1.124.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.124.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.124.4&tcname=">3.A.1.124.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The macedocin exporter, McdEFG (<span id="ref5893.17581139" class="cite">Papadelli <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>) </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>McdEFG of <i>Streptococcus macedonicus</i><br>
McdE (M; 254 aas) (A6MER6)<br>
McdG (M; 245 aas) (A6MER7)<br>
