</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.124.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.124.5&tcname=">3.A.1.124.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The salivaricin exporter, SboEFG (<span id="ref5876.17194838" class="cite">Hyink <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>SboEFG of <i>Streptococcus salivarius</i><br>
SboE (M; 249 aas) (Q09IH9)<br>
SboF (C; 303 aas) (Q09II0)<br>
SboG (M; 242 aas) (Q09IH8)<br></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.124.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.124.6&tcname=">3.A.1.124.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CprABC antimicrobial peptide resistance ABC exporter.&nbsp; Exports both mammalian and bacterial toxic peptides (<span id="ref34544197.20974818" class="cite">McBride and Sonenshein 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CprABC of <em>Clostridium difficile</em><br />CprA (C, 235 aas)<br />CprB (M, 238 aas, 6 TMSs)<br />CprC (M, 252 aas, 6 TMSs)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.125">3.A.1.125 The Lipoprotein Translocase (LPT) Family (This TC subfamily overlaps with TC# 3.A.1.122)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.125.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.125.1&tcname=">3.A.1.125.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Lipoprotein translocation system (translocates lipoproteins from the inner membrane to periplasmic chaperone, LolA, which transfers the lipoproteins to an outer membrane receptor, LolB, which anchors the lipoprotein to the outer membrane of the Gram-negative bacterial cell envelope) (see 1.B.46; <span id="ref5782.12823819" class="cite">Narita <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>; <span id="ref5866.17038124" class="cite">Ito <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>; <span id="ref5562.18029423" class="cite">Watanabe <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). The structure of ligand-bound LolCDE has been solved (<span id="ref5866.17038124" class="cite">Ito <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>). LolC and LolE each have 4 TMSs (1+3). Unlike most ATP binding cassette transporters mediating the transmembrane flux of substrates, the LolCDE complex catalyzes the extrusion of lipoproteins anchored to the outer leaflet of the inner membrane. The LolCDE complex is unusual in that it can be purified as a liganded form, which is an intermediate of the lipoprotein release reaction (<span id="ref5939.18218629" class="cite">Taniguchi and Tokuda, 2008</span>). LolCDE has been reconstituted from separated subunits (<span id="ref5886.17509078" class="cite">Kanamaru <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).&nbsp; LolE binds the outer membrane lipoprotein, PAL (<span id="ref34543640.23187171" class="cite">Mizutani <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). The mechanism of LolCDE as a molecular extruder of bacterial triacylated lipoproteins has been reported (<span id="ref34553586.34344901" class="cite">Sharma <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>) who determined the cryo-EM structures of nanodisc-embedded LolCDE in the nucleotide-free and nucleotide-bound states at 3.8-&Aring; and 3.5-&Aring; resolution, respectively. The structural analyses, together with biochemical and mutagenesis studies, uncovered how LolCDE recognizes its substrate by interacting with the lipid and N-terminal peptide moieties of the lipoprotein, and identify the amide-linked acyl chain as the key element for LolCDE interaction. Upon nucleotide binding, the transmembrane helices and the periplasmic domains of LolCDE undergo large-scale, asymmetric movements, resulting in extrusion of the captured lipoprotein. Comparison of LolCDE and MacB revealed the conserved mechanism of type VII ABC transporters and emphasized the unique properties of LolCDE as a molecule extruder of triacylated lipoproteins (<span id="ref34553586.34344901" class="cite">Sharma <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p>
<p></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-negative bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LolCDE of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> LolC (M) <br /> LolD (C) <br /> LolE (M)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.125.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.125.2&tcname=">3.A.1.125.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative lipoprotein LolCDE homologue LolCE (10TMSs:1+6+3)/LolD</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>LolCE/LolD of <i>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</i><br>
LolCE (M) (Q7D911)<br>
LolD (C) (O53899)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.125.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.125.3&tcname=">3.A.1.125.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Duf214 protein (843aas; 10TMSs:1+6+3)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Duf214 protein/ ABC protein of <i>Frankia</i> sp. CcI3: <br>
Duf214 protein (M) - Q2J9P4 <br>
[LolD/FtsE/SalX]-type ABC protein (C) - Q2J9P5</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.125.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.125.5&tcname=">3.A.1.125.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized ABC transporter with two consituents, a 4 TMS (in a 1 + 3 TMS arrangement) membrane (M) protein and an ATPase (C).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized ABC transporter of <em>Opitutus terrae<br /></em>M: B1ZMT9<br />C: B1ZMU0<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.125.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.125.6&tcname=">3.A.1.125.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC transporter, LolCDE, with three components, similar to (but substantially different from) LolC, LolD and LolE of <em>E. coli</em>. The three genes encoding these proteins are adjectent to each other on the bacteria chromosome, but there is no direct experimental evidence that they function together as lipoprotein exporters.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LolCDE of Candidatus Heimdallarchaeota archaeon LC_3<br />LolC, 690 aas and 4 TMSs in a 1 + 3 TMS arrangement (MC)<br />LolD, 236 aas with 2 or 3 TMSs followed by a hydrophilic C-terminal domain (MC)<br />LolE, 1106 aas and 12 TMSs in a 1 + 3 + 4 +1 + 3 TMS arrangement (MM)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.125.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.125.7&tcname=">3.A.1.125.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC-type transport system, possibly involved in lipoprotein release. There are two and possibly three protein constituents. First, there is a permease component of 1004 aas with 13 TMSs in a 2 (N-terminal) + 3 +4 + 1 + 3 TMS arrangement (I2F7A7)).&nbsp; This protein is unusual because it has 2 N-terminal TMSs rather than the usual 1, and between the two 1 + 3 TMS repeat units, there are 4 TMSs rather than the more usual 0 or 2 TMSs. Second, there is an ABC-type ATPase (I2F7A6) and third, there is a possible auxiliary subunit of 183 aas and 4 TMSs in a 2 + 2 TMS arrangement that appears to be two repeated 2 TMS sequences, one near the N-terminus and one near the C-terminus; I2F7A5).&nbsp; Adjacent to these genes is one annotated as a "PRC barrel protein" (with a single N-terminal TMS and is a conserved, ubiquitous, chromo domain, shared by photosynthetic reaction center subunits and proteins of RNA metabolism (<span id="ref34556677.12429060" class="cite">Anantharaman and Aravind 2002</span>); I2F7A4) of unknown function, and adjacent to that gene are two genes encoding putative chromate resistance efflux (transport) protein, ChrA (I2F7A3 and I2F7A1; see TC family 2.A.51).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC type 3 transporter of <em>Mesotoga prima</em> MesG1 Ag.4.2</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.125.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.125.8&tcname=">3.A.1.125.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FtsX-type ABC transporter of 902 aas and 10 TMSs in a 1 + 3 + 2 + 1 + 3 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of <em>Vescimonas coprocola</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.125.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.125.9&tcname=">3.A.1.125.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of 1253 aas and 9 TMSs in a 1 + 3 +2 + 2 + 1 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of <em>Exiguobacterium undae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.126">3.A.1.126 The <size=3>&beta;-Exotoxin I</font> Exporter (<size=3>&beta;ETE</font>) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.126.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.126.1&tcname=">3.A.1.126.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Exporter of &#946;-exotoxin I, BerAB</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>&#946;-exotoxin exporter, BerAB, of <I>Bacillus thuringiensis</i> <br>

NarA, ATPase (C) of 293 aas and NarB, membrane protein (M) of 537 aas and 12 TMSs. The polyether ionophores, narasin, salinomycin, and maduramicin, but not monensin, are actively exported (A-O Naemi et al., NarAB Is an ABC-type Transporter That Confers Resistance to the 
Polyether Ionophores Narasin, Salinomycin, and Maduramicin, but Not 
Monensin, 2020 Front Microbiol.).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NarAB of <em>Enterococcus faecium</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.126.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.126.6&tcname=">3.A.1.126.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cereulide (cyclic depsipeptide) K<sup>+</sup> ionophore exporter, CerCD. CerC is 291 aas without TMSs, while CerD is 268 aas with 5 or 6 TMSs (<span id="ref34557850.38111319" class="cite">Yuan <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CerCD of the <em>Bacillus cereus</em> group</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.127">3.A.1.127 The AmfS Peptide Exporter (AmfS-E) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.127.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.127.1&tcname=">3.A.1.127.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Exporter of AmfS extracellular peptidic morphogen (<span id="ref5773.12657041" class="cite">Chater and Horinouchi, 2003</span>; <span id="ref5749.11844785" class="cite">Ueda <em>et al</em>., 2002</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>AmfS exporter, AmfAB of <i>Streptomyces griseus</i> <br>
AmfA (MC) (BAA33537) <br>
AmfB (MC) (BBA33538)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.128">3.A.1.128 The SkfA Peptide Exporter (SkfA-E) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.128.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.128.1&tcname=">3.A.1.128.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Exporter of SkfA processed peptide (spO31422), SkfEF (<span id="ref5780.12817086" class="cite">Gonz&aacute;lez-Pastor <em>et al.</em>, 2003</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SkfEF (YbdAB) of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em> <br /> SkfE (C)  O31427  <br /> SkfF (M-M)  O31438</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.128.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.128.10&tcname=">3.A.1.128.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Apparent two component ABC transporter, probably an exporter of the sporulation killing factor, SkfB. The membrane component has 12 TMSs, and therefore is probably either due to an intragenic duplication of the usual 6 TMS domain protein or a fusion of two such proteins that are more usual for this subfamily of ABC exporters.&nbsp; This system acts in conjunction with a CAAX protease (EMI14127; TC# 9.B.2.13.1) that presumably processes SkfB to the mature form. The two genes of this ABC system are preceded by a gene coding for a 174 aa proteins possibly involved in SkfB synthesis and/or export.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC SkfB exporter of <em>Bacillus stratosphericus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.128.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.128.11&tcname=">3.A.1.128.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter, possibly for the sporulation killer factor SkfB.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Parageobacillus thermoglucosidasius</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.128.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.128.2&tcname=">3.A.1.128.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative ABC exporter, Teth 514-0346 &amp; 0347<br /</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Teth 514-0346 &amp; 0347 of <em>Thermoanaerobacter sp.</em> x514: <br /> Teth514-0346 (C) (B0K2P2)<br /> Teth514-0347 (M-M) (B0K2P3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.128.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.128.3&tcname=">3.A.1.128.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative ABC exporter, CLK2533/CLK2534<br /</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CLK2533/CLK2534 of <em>Clostridium botulinum</em><br /> CLK2533 (M-M) (B1L0U0)<br /> CLK2534 (C) (B1L0U1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.128.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.128.4&tcname=">3.A.1.128.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative ABC exporter Tiet1371/1372<br /</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Tiet1371/72 of <em>Thermotoga lettingae</em><br /> Tiet1371 (M-M) (A8F6Z4)<br /> Tiet1372 (C) (A8F6Z5)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.128.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.128.5&tcname=">3.A.1.128.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC transporter.&nbsp; permease; 515 aas, 12 TMSs)<br />TA0066 (C; ATPase)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.128.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.128.8&tcname=">3.A.1.128.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter encoded by two adjacent genes, a membrane protein and an ABC ATPase.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter<br />(M) KXH73395<br />(C)&nbsp; KXH73394</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.128.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.128.9&tcname=">3.A.1.128.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Three component ABC transport system of unknown function.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC porter of <em>Paenibacillus larvae</em> subsp. pulvifaciens</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.129">3.A.1.129 The CydDC Cysteine Exporter (CydDC-E) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.129.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.129.1&tcname=">3.A.1.129.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Heme transporter (previously proposed to be a thiol (cysteine/glutathione) exporter, CydDC; CydC is also called MdrH (periplasmic cysteine is required for cytochrome <em>bd</em> assembly) (<span id="ref6020.15470119" class="cite">Cruz-Ramos <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>).&nbsp; The purified asymmetric heterodimer exhibits low ATPase activity which is activated by both thiols and heme (e.g., heme b) (<span id="ref11356.24958725" class="cite">Yamashita <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Bacterial redox homoeostasis during nitrosative stress is influenced by CydDC.&nbsp; Periplasmic low molecular weight thiols restore haem incorporation into a cytochrome complex (<span id="ref34547623.26699904" class="cite">Holyoake <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Iron-bound cyclic tetrapyrroles (hemes) are redox-active cofactors in 
bioenergetic enzymes.&nbsp;<span id="ref34556338.37095238" class="cite">Wu <em>et al.</em> 2023</span> used
 cellular, biochemical, structural and computational methods to 
characterize CydDC which is a 
heme transporter required for functional maturation of cytochrome bd. The conformational 
landscape of CydDC during substrate binding and occlusion was revealed. Heme binds laterally from the membrane space to 
the transmembrane region of CydDC, enabled by a highly asymmetrical 
inward-facing CydDC conformation. During the binding process, heme 
propionates interact with positively charged residues on the surface and
 later in the substrate-binding pocket of the transporter, causing the 
heme orientation to rotate 180&deg; (<span id="ref34556338.37095238" class="cite">Wu <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CydDC of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> CydD (M-C)  (P29018) <br /> CydC (M-C)  (P23886)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.13">3.A.1.13 The Vitamin B<sub>12</sub> Uptake Transporter (B<sub>12</sub>T) Family (Similar to 3.A.1.14)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.13.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.13.1&tcname=">3.A.1.13.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Vitamin B<sub>12</sub> porter. The 3-D structure of BtuCDF has been solved to 2.6 &Aring; (<span id="ref5896.17673622" class="cite">Hvorup <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).&nbsp;The conformational transition pathways of BtuCD has been revealed by targeted molecular dynamics simulations (<span id="ref8470.22272354" class="cite">Weng <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).&nbsp;Asymmetric states of BtuCD are not discriminated by its cognate substrate binding protein BtuF (<span id="ref8709.22569249" class="cite">Korkhov <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).&nbsp; ATP hydrolysis occurs at the nucleotide-binding domain
(NBD) dimer interface, whereas substrate translocation takes place at the
translocation pathway between the TM subunits, which is more than 30 angstroms away
from the NBD dimer interface.&nbsp; Hydrolysis of ATP appears to facilitate substrate translocation by opening the
cytoplasmic end of translocation pathway (<span id="ref34546096.27870912" class="cite">Pan <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). The molecular mechanism of ATP hydrolysis by BtuCD-F may proceeds in a stepwise manner (<span id="ref34549123.30410971" class="cite">Prie&szlig; <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). First, nucleophilic attack of an activated lytic water molecule at the ATP gamma-phosphate yields ADP + HPO<sub>4</sub><sup>2-</sup>. A conserved glutamate located close to the gamma-phosphate transiently accepts a proton acting as a catalytic base. In the second step, the proton transfers back from the catalytic base to the gamma-phosphate, yielding ADP + H<sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub><sup>-</sup>. These two reaction steps are followed by rearrangements of the hydrogen bond network and the coordination of the Mg<sup>2+</sup> ion. The overall free energy change of the reaction is close to zero, suggesting that ATP binding is essential for tight dimerization of the nucleotide-binding domains and the transition of the transmembrane domains from inward- to outward-facing. ATP hydrolysis resets the conformational cycle (<span id="ref34549123.30410971" class="cite">Prie&szlig; <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BtuCDF of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> BtuC (M)<br /> BtuD (C)<br /> BtuF (R)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.13.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.13.2&tcname=">3.A.1.13.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative cobalamin (vitamin B<sub>12</sub>) uptake porter, BtuFCD (<span id="ref34545288.25345570" class="cite">Rodionova <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BtuFCD of <em>Chloroflexus aurantiacus <br />BtuF (R; 1 TMS)<br />BtuC (M; 9 TMSs)<br />BtuD (C; 0 TMSs)<br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.130">3.A.1.130 The Multidrug/Hemolysin Exporter (MHE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.130.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.130.1&tcname=">3.A.1.130.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The multidrug/hemolysin exporter, CylA/B (note: CylK (AAF01071) may influence its activity)(<span id="ref5851.16885467" class="cite">Gottschalk <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>CylA/B of <i>Streptococcus agalactiae</i> <br>
CylA (C) (Q9X432) <br>
CylB (M) (Q9X433) </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.130.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.130.2&tcname=">3.A.1.130.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC export system, possibly an MDR pump, consisting of two proteins, and membrane protein of 293 aas and 6 TMSs, and an ATPase of 301 aas.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Acidipropionibacterium virtanenii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.130.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.130.3&tcname=">3.A.1.130.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter with two constituents, a membrane protein of 263 aas and 6 TMSs, and an ATPase of 310 aas.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of<em> Lactobacillus hokkaidonensis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.131">3.A.1.131 The Bacitracin Resistance (Bcr) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.131.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.131.1&tcname=">3.A.1.131.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The 2 or 3 component bacitracin-resistance efflex pump, BcrAB or BcrABC (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref5955">Podlesek <em>et al</em>., 1995</a>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref5906"><span id="ref7188.14612242" class="cite">Bernard <em>et al.</em>, 2003</span></a>) (BcrA is most similar to SpaF (3.A.1.124.2), but BcrB (5-6 TMSs) is only distantly related to other ABC2-type membrane proteins (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref7189">Wang <em>et al.</em>, 2009</a>). BcrC is not sufficiently similar to detect similarity in BLAST searches. BcrC (5TMSs) belongs to the PAP2 phosphatase superfamily and may not be a contituent of the BcrAB transporter. Transcription is regulated by BcrR, a one-component transmembrane signal transduction system (<span id="ref34549518.30777814" class="cite">Darnell <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BcrABC of <em>Bacillus licheniformis</em> <br /> BcrA (C) - (P42332) <br /> BcrB (M) - (P42333)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.131.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.131.2&tcname=">3.A.1.131.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Lantibiotic immunity system, LanEF. NosD (R; periplasmic copper binding receptor)(Q52899)<br>
NosF (C; like GldA) (Q52900)<br>

Expression of vraH in the absence of vraDE is sufficient to mediate 
low-level resistance, but VraDEH is required to&nbsp; confer high-level 
resistance against daptomycin and gallidermin. (<span id="ref34545307.26856834" class="cite">Popella <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>VraDE of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></p>

<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.134.3"></a></p>
<p>The putative bacitracin exporter, BceAB (BarAB; YtsCD) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref7188">Bernard <em>et al.</em>, 2003</a>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref5787">Ohki <em>et al</em>., 2003</a>).&nbsp; Functions in both signaling to the two component system, BceRS, and in export of the antimicrobial peptide (<span id="ref34543622.25118291" class="cite">Dintner <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; BceB interacts directly with BceS, and BceB binds bacitracin (<span id="ref34543622.25118291" class="cite">Dintner <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Specific regions and residues are involved in signalling or transport (<span id="ref9989.23687272" class="cite">Kallenberg <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; More recent studies suggest that BceAB may cause bacitracin resistance by transferring undecaprenyl pyrophosphate from the exteral to the internal leaflet of the inner membrane where it can't bind bacitracin and other lantibiotics that use Lipid II as a receptor (<span id="ref34544194.25787977" class="cite">Draper <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). It may cause drug detoxification by targeet protection (<span id="ref34554307.33450852" class="cite">Rismondo and Schulz 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BceAB (YtsCD) of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em> <br />BceA (C) CAB15016<br /> BceB (M) CAB15015</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.134.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.134.4&tcname=">3.A.1.134.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The bacitracin/vancoresmycin (a tetramic acid antibiotic) resistance exporter (<span id="ref6494.19273682" class="cite">Becker <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>) (most like 3.A.1.134.2)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SPR0812/SPR0813 of <em>Streptococcus pnenmoiae</em><br /> SPR0812 (C) (Q8DQ77)<br /> SPR0813 (M) (Q8DQ76)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.134.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.134.5&tcname=">3.A.1.134.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The MDR exporter, YvcRS. Possibly linked to regulation by a sensor kinase/response regulator system (YvcQP) (<span id="ref7165.12432961" class="cite">Joseph <em>et al.</em>, 2002</span>; <span id="ref5906.17905982" class="cite">Bernard <em>et al.</em>, 2007</span>).<span id="ref.17905982" class="cite"><br /></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YvcRS of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em><br />YvcR (C) (O06980)<br />YvcR (M) (O06981)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.134.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.134.6&tcname=">3.A.1.134.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The cationic peptide/MDR exporter, YxdLM. Possibly linked to a sensor kinase/reponse regulator system (YxdJK) (<span id="ref7165.12432961" class="cite">Joseph <em>et al.</em>, 2002</span>; <span id="ref5906.17905982" class="cite">Bernard <em>et al.</em>, 2007</span>).<span id="ref.17905982" class="cite"><br /></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YxdLM of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em><br />YxdL (C) (P42423)<br />YxdM (M) (P42424)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.134.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.134.7&tcname=">3.A.1.134.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.134.7"></a></p>
<p>The VraFG ABC transporter interacts with GraXSR [GraX, Q7A2W7; GraS, A6QEW9; GraR, A6QEW8] to form a five- or six-component system required for cationic antimicrobial peptide sensing and resistance (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref8314">Falord <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>).&nbsp; VraX has been termed a two component system connector and may not be a component of the transporter. VraFG may be a sensor rather than the transporter for the substrate peptide. The actual transporter regulated by VraFGX may have TC# 4.H.1.1.1 (MprF) (<span id="ref8314.22123691" class="cite">Falord <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). The extracellular loop of the membrane permease VraG interacts with GraS to sense cationic antimicrobial peptides in <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em> (<span id="ref34553686.33647048" class="cite">Cho <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>VraFG/GraXSR of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em>&nbsp;<br />VraF (A6QEX0)<br />VraG (A6QEX1)<br />VraX (Q7A2W7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.134.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.134.8&tcname=">3.A.1.134.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Antimicrobial peptide exporter, ABC12 or YvoST (<span id="ref34544025.23455349" class="cite">Revilla-Guarinos <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YvoST of <em>Lactobacillus casei </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.134.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.134.9&tcname=">3.A.1.134.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Two component toxic peptide exporter with a membrane subunit of 663 aas and 10 TMSs and an ATPase of 256 aas, ABC09 (<span id="ref34544025.23455349" class="cite">Revilla-Guarinos <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font YdbA (M-C) (AAK04409)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.135.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.135.10&tcname=">3.A.1.135.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized two component ABC transporter, both of M-C domain order with 6 N-terminal TMSs. probably orthologous to YdaG/YbdA (TC #3.A.1.117.4) [Transcription is activated by stress conditions (heat, acid) and repressed by a 2-component system, CovRS (<span id="ref5828.16352823" class="cite">Dalton <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>)]</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Gram-positive bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>RscAB of <i>Streptococcus pyogenes</i>
RscA (M-C) (568 aas) (Q9A1K5) <br />
RscB (M-C) (594 aas) (Q9A1K4)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.135.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.135.3&tcname=">3.A.1.135.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Narrow spectrum fluoroquinolone (ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin) efflux pump, SatAB (<span id="ref10279.21930876" class="cite">Escudero <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SatAB of <em>Streptococcus suis<br /></em>SatA, 568 aas (M-C) (G9CHY8)<br />SatB, 594 aas, (M-C) (G9CHY9)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.135.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.135.4&tcname=">3.A.1.135.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance ABC exporter, PatAB (PatA, 564 aas; PatB, 588 aas) (<span id="ref10781.22428019" class="cite">Bidossi <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). Drug-dependent inhibition of nucleotide hydrolysis by PatAB has been demonstrated (<span id="ref34554362.35066976" class="cite">Guffick <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Ethidium-like inhibition was observed with propidium, novobiocin and coumermycin A1, which all inhibit nucleotide hydrolysis by a non-competitive mechanism. This fact casts light on potential mechanisms by which drugs can regulate nucleotide hydrolysis by PatAB, which might involve a novel drug binding site near the nucleotide-binding domains (<span id="ref34554362.35066976" class="cite">Guffick <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PatAB of <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae<br /></em>PatA (M-C)<br />PatB (M-C)<em></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.135.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.135.5&tcname=">3.A.1.135.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The hetrodimeric ABC transporter, TM287/TM288.&nbsp; The 2.9-&Aring; crystal structure has been solved in the inward-facing 
state. The two nucleotide binding domains (NBDs) remain in contact through an interface involving 
conserved motifs that connect the two ATP hydrolysis sites.&nbsp; 
AMP-PNP binds to a degenerate catalytic site which deviates from 
the consensus sequence in the same positions as the eukaryotic homologs, 
CFTR (TC# 3.A.1.202.1) and TAP1-TAP2 (TC# 3.A.1.209.1) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10822">Hohl <em>et al.</em> 2012</a>).&nbsp; The structural basis for allosteric crosstalk (positive cooperativity) between the two ATP binding sites has been studied (<span id="ref34543911.25030449" class="cite">Hohl <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; The two NBDs exhibit unexpected differences and flexibility (<span id="ref34544037.25947941" class="cite">Bukowska <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). It exports daunomycin and the nonfluorescent 2,7-bis(carboxyethyl)-5(6)-carboxyfluorescein-acetoxymethylester (BCECF-AM) (<span id="ref10822.22447242" class="cite">Hohl <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). <span id="ref34546389.28051765" class="cite">Timachi <em>et al.</em> 2017</span> observed
hydrolysis-independent closure of the NBD dimer, further stabilized as the consensus site
nucleotide is committed to hydrolysis.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Thermatogae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TM287/TM288 of <em>Thermatoga maritima</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.135.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.135.6&tcname=">3.A.1.135.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Two component multidrug efflux pump with the 6 TMS membrane domain preceding the ATPase domain in both proteins.&nbsp; Confers resistance to erythromycin and tetracycline and catalyzes export of Hoechst 33342 (<span id="ref34543836.25529295" class="cite">Moodley <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Expression is induced by the presence of erythromycin.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR pump of<em> Bifidobacterium longum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.135.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.135.7&tcname=">3.A.1.135.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug exporter, EfrAB.&nbsp; Confers resistance to many structurally unrelated antimicrobial agents, such as 
norfloxacin, ciprofloxacin, doxycycline, acriflavine, 
4,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole, tetraphenylphosphonium chloride, 
daunorubicin, and doxorubicin (<span id="ref34545554.14638474" class="cite">Lee <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>).&nbsp; Induced by half minimal inhibitory concentrations (MIC) of gentamicin, streptomycin and chloramphenicol which are also exporter (<span id="ref34545555.25084670" class="cite">Lavilla Lerma <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; In some strains, this system may not be the primary drug exporter (<span id="ref34545556.27381387" class="cite">H&uuml;rlimann <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EfrAB of <em>Enterococcus faecalis</em><br />EfrA (MC), 567 aas and 6 TMSs<br />EfrB (MC), 589 aas and 6 TMSs</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.135.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.135.8&tcname=">3.A.1.135.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug efflux pump, EfrCD.&nbsp; Mediates efflux of fluorescent substrates and confers resistance towards multiple dyes and drugs including fluoroquinolones (<span id="ref34545556.27381387" class="cite">H&uuml;rlimann <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EfrEF of <em>Enterococcus faecalis</em><br />EfrE, MC, 575 aas and 6 TMSs<br />EfrF, MC, 592 aas and 6 TMSs</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.136">3.A.1.136 The Uncharacterized ABC-3-type (U-ABC3-1) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.136.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.136.1&tcname=">3.A.1.136.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC3 permease complex U-ABC3-1a (403 aas; 6 or 7 putative TMSs).&nbsp; Expression enhances resistance to oxidative stress (<span id="ref11261.24038693" class="cite">Nicolaou <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FetA/B of <em>E. coli</em><br />FetA (C) (P77279)<br />FetB (M) (P77307)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.139.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.139.3&tcname=">3.A.1.139.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The uncharacterized ABC exporter, U-ABC-M/C</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>U-ABCC/U-ABC-M of <em>Spirochaeta africana</em><br />U-ABC-C (C) (H9UM45)<br />U-ABC-M (M)<em>&nbsp;</em>(H9UM46)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.139.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.139.4&tcname=">3.A.1.139.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plasma membrane ABC exporter, sensitive to aluminum rhizotoxicity 1/2, STAR1/STAR2 (<span id="ref9010.15659095" class="cite">Larsen <em>et al.</em>, 2005</span>). Induced in response to aluminum exposure.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>STAR1/2 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em>&nbsp;<br />STAR1 (C) (Q9C9W0)<br />STAR2 (M) (Q9ZUT3)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.139.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.139.5&tcname=">3.A.1.139.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 318 aas and 7 TMSs in a 5 + 2 TMS arrangement.&nbsp; An ATPase for this putative porter has not been identified.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Tetrapyrgos nigripes</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.14">3.A.1.14 The Iron Chelate Uptake Transporter (FeCT) Family (Similar to 3.A.1.13 and 3.A.1.15)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.14.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.14.1&tcname=">3.A.1.14.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Iron (Fe<sup>3+</sup>) or ferric-dicitrate porter, FecBCDE (<span id="ref5895.17660286" class="cite">Braun and Herrmann, 2007</span>). The Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) ortholog has two substrate binding proteins, FecB and FecB2 (<span id="ref34557293.37747938" class="cite">de Miranda <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; The crystallographic structures of Mtb FecB and FecB2 were determined to
 2.0 &Aring; and 2.2 &Aring; resolution, respectively, and they show distinct ligand 
binding pockets. In vitro ligand binding experiments for FecB and FecB2 
were performed with heme and bacterial siderophores from Mtb and other 
species, revealing that both FecB and FecB2 bind heme, while only FecB 
binds the Mtb sideophore ferric-carboxymycobactin (Fe-cMB). Subsequent 
structure-guided mutagenesis of FecB identified a single glutamate 
residue-Glu339-that significantly contributes to Fe-cMB binding (<span id="ref34557293.37747938" class="cite">de Miranda <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FecBCDE of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> FecB (R) <br /> FecC (M) <br /> FecD (M) <br /> FecE (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.14.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.14.10&tcname=">3.A.1.14.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The heme porter, Shp/SiaABC (HtsABC). Shp is a cell surface heme binding protein that transfers the heme directly to HstA (<span id="ref5840.16717094" class="cite">Nygaard <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>). The crystal structure of the heme binding domain of Shp has been solved (<span id="ref5909.17920629" class="cite">Aranda <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). HtsABC is required for the uptake of staphyloferrin A (<span id="ref6586.19400778" class="cite">Beasley <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>). The Shp cell surface heme receptor feeds iron-heme to the transporter in preparation for uptake (<span id="ref10836.20607329" class="cite">Sun <em>et al.</em> 2010; </span><span id="ref8334.20807204" class="cite">Ouattara <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Shp/HtsABC of <em>Streptococcus pyogenes</em> <br /> Shp (R<sub>1</sub>) (291 aas; Q1J548) <br /> HtsA (R<sub>2</sub>) (294 aas; Q99YA2) <br /> HtsB (M) (340 aas; Q99YA3) <br /> HtsC (C) (278 aas; Q99YA4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.14.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.14.11&tcname=">3.A.1.14.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.14.11"></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.14.11"></a></p>
<p>The molybdate/tungstate ABC transporter, MolABC.&nbsp; For MolC; HI1470(C)/MolB; HI1471(M), the 3D structure is known at 2.4 &Aring; resolution; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref5871">Pinkett <em>et al</em>., 2007</a>).&nbsp; MolA binds to MolBC with low affinity (50 - 100&mu;M), forming a transient complex that is stabilitzed by ligand binding (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9792">Vigonsky <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MolABC of <em>Haemophilus influenzae</em> <br /> MolC; HI1470 (C) (Q57399) <br /> MolB; HI1471 (M; 10 TMSs; type II fold) (Q57130)<br />MolA; HI1472 (R) (E3GUW2)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.14.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.14.12&tcname=">3.A.1.14.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Desferrioxamine B uptake porter, DesABC (<span id="ref6045.17074905" class="cite">Barona-Gomez <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>DesABC of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em> <br /> DesA (R) (1 TMS) (Sco7499; Q9L178)  <br /> DesB (M-M) (18 TMSs; 9 9 TMSs) (Sco7498; Q9L179)  <br /> DesC (C) (0 TMSs) (Sco7400; Q9L177)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.14.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.14.13&tcname=">3.A.1.14.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Ferric iron-coelichelin uptake porter, CchCDEF (<span id="ref6045.17074905" class="cite">Barona-Gomez <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CchCDEF of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em> <br /> CchC (M) (Sco0497) (Q9RK09)<br /> CchD (M) (Sco0496) (Q9RK10)  <br /> CchE (C) (Sco0495) (Q9RK11)  <br /> CchF (R) (Sco0494) (Q9RK12)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.14.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.14.14&tcname=">3.A.1.14.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Fe<sup>3+</sup> /Fe3<sup>+</sup>ferrichrome/Fe<sup>3+</sup>heme uptake porter; haem-binding protein BhuT have been solved (<span id="ref34546055.27830695" class="cite">Naoe <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). The TMSs
show an inward-facing conformation, in which the cytoplasmic gate of the haem translocation pathway
is completely open. Since this conformation is found in both the haem- and nucleotide-free form, the
structure of BhuUV-T provides the post-translocation state and the missing piece in the transport

BtuC (M) (AAG19698)  <br>
BtuD (C) (NP_444218) <br>
BtuE (R) (AAG19697)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.140">3.A.1.140 The FtsX/FtsE Septation (FtsX/FtsE) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.140.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.140.1&tcname=">3.A.1.140.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The FtsX/FtsE ABC transporter (<span id="ref6652.19376877" class="cite">Arends <em>et al.,</em> 2009</span>) (FtsX is of the type III topology).&nbsp;FtsEX directly recruits EnvC to the septum via an interaction between EnvC and a periplasmic loop of FtsX. FtsEX variants predicted to be ATPase defective still recruit EnvC to the septum but fail to promote cell separation. Amidase activation via EnvC in the periplasm is regulated by conformational changes in the FtsEX complex mediated by ATP hydrolysis in the cytoplasm. Since FtsE has been reported to interact with FtsZ, amidase activity may be coupled with the contraction of the FtsZ cytoskeletal ring (<span id="ref8306.22006326" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FtsX/FtsE of <em>E. coli</em><br /> FtsX (M) (P0AC31)<br /> FtsE (C) (P0A9R7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.140.2"></A><A The third gene in the <em>ytg</em>&nbsp;operon is fused, the N-terminal membrane domain being fused to the C-terminal transcriptional regulator homologous to the diphtheria toxin repressor, DtxR. These two domains may be proteolitically processed yielding the two active proteins (<span id="ref10320.22689982" class="cite">Thompson <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Chlamydiae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YtgABC-RD of <em>Chlamydia trachomatis</em>&nbsp;<br />YtgA (R) (O9S529)<br />YtgB (C) (084071)<br />YtgC-R (M-R) (084072)<br />YtgD (M) (084073)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.13&tcname=">3.A.1.15.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The ZnuA18/ZnuA08/ZnuB/ZnuC zinc (Zn<sup>2+</sup>) uptake system (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10514">Hudek <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).&nbsp; ZnuB (M) and ZnuC (C) can function with either of two zinc ion receptors, ZnuA18 (R) which is encoded in the <em>znuACB</em> operon, and ZnuA08 (R) which is encoded elsewhere on the chromosome.&nbsp; ZnuA18 is more efficient that ZnuA08 in promoting uptake (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10514">Hudek <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cyanobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Zn<sup>2+</sup> uptake system of <em>Nostoc punctiforme</em><br />ZnuA18 (R) (B2IWS9)<br />ZnuA08 (R) (B2J0B7)<br />ZnuB (M) B2IWT1)<br />ZnuC (C) (B2IWT0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.14&tcname=">3.A.1.15.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High affinity Mn<sup>2+</sup> uptake complex, PsaABC (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10837">Lisher <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>). The crystal structure of the manganese transporter PsaBC from<em> Streptococcus pneumoniae</em> has been solved in an open-inward conformation (<span id="ref34553617.34362732" class="cite">Neville <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The type II transporter has a tightly closed transmembrane channel due to "extracellular gating" residues that prevent water permeation and ion reflux. Below these residues, the channel contains a metal coordination site, which is essential for manganese translocation. Mutagenesis of the extracellular gate perturbs manganese uptake, while coordination site mutagenesis abolishes import. These structural features are well conserved in metal-specific ABC transporters and are represented throughout the kingdoms of life. Collectively, these results define the structure of PsaBC and reveal the features required for divalent cation transport (<span id="ref34553617.34362732" class="cite">Neville <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PsaABC of <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em><br />PsaA (R; 309 aas)<br />PsaB (C; 240 aas)<br />PsaC (M; 282 aas)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.15&tcname=">3.A.1.15.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High affinity Mn<sup>2+</sup> uptake complex, MntABC.&nbsp; The 3-d structure of MntC has been&nbsp; solved to 2.2&Aring; resolution (<span id="ref11132.23827136" class="cite">Gribenko <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmictues</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MntABC of <em>Staphylococcus aureus&nbsp; <br /></em>MntA of 247 aas (C)<br />MntB of 278 aas (M)<br />MntC of 309 aas (R)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.16&tcname=">3.A.1.15.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ZnuABC Zinc/Manganese/iron uptake porter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ZnuABC of Leptospira sp.<br />ZnuA (R) 345 aas<br />ZnuB (M) 275 aas<br />ZnuC C) 210 aas</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.17&tcname=">3.A.1.15.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ZnuABC Zinc/Manganese/Iron uptake porter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>ZnuABC of <em>Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus<br /></em>ZnuA (R)<br />ZnuB (M)<br />ZnuC (C)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.18&tcname=">3.A.1.15.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC high affinity Zinc (Zn<sup>2+</sup>) uptake porter, ZnuABC.&nbsp; The similar system from <em>Y. pestis</em> has been characterized (<span id="ref34549037.24979062" class="cite">Bobrov <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>; <span id="ref34549036.30353723" class="cite">Neupane <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). ZnuA (R) of that systems can bind up to 5 zinc ions with high affinity.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ZnuABC of <em>Yersinia pseudotuberculosis<br />ZnuA, 318 aas, Q66AT6<br />ZnuB, 261 aas, Q66AT8<br />ZnuC, 253 aas, Q66AT7<br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.19&tcname=">3.A.1.15.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Zinc ion ABC uptake system, AztABCD, where AztD is a periplasmic chaparone protein that feeds Zn<sup>2+</sup> into AztC, the periplasmic receptor/binding protein for the transporter (<span id="ref34549036.30353723" class="cite">Neupane <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AztABCD of <em>Paracoccus denitrificans </em><em><br /></em>AztA, 309 aas, R, (A1B2F3)<br />AztB, 288 aas, 9 TMSs, M, (A1B2F2)<br />AztC. 263 aas, C, (A1B2F1)<br />AztD, 408 aas, Periplasmic chaparone (A1B2F4)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.2&tcname=">3.A.1.15.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Manganese (Mn<sup>2+</sup>) and zinc (Zn<sup>2+</sup>) porter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Firmicutes</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>ScaABC of <I>Streptococcus gordonii</i> <br>
ScaA (R)<br>
ScaB (M)<br>
ScaC (C)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.20&tcname=">3.A.1.15.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC uptake transporter specific for Mn<sup>2+</sup> and Fe<sup>2+</sup>, SloABC (<span id="ref34550524.14526007" class="cite">Paik <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>). The system is repressed by Mn<sup>2+</sup> together with the SloR repressor, encoded by a gene downstream of <em>sloABC</em>.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SloABC of <em>Streptococcus mutans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.21&tcname=">3.A.1.15.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mn<sup>2+</sup> ABC uptake system, MntABC. Titratable transmembrane residues and a hydrophobic plug are essential for manganese import via the <em>Bacillus anthracis</em> ABC transporter MntBC-A (<span id="ref34553546.34416234" class="cite">Kuznetsova <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Zinc is a high-affinity inhibitor. The transmembrane metal permeation pathway is lined with six titratable residues that can coordinate the positively charged metal, and mutagenesis studies showed that they are essential for manganese transport. Modelling suggested that access to these titratable residues is blocked by a ladder of hydrophobic residues, and ATP-driven conformational changes open and close this hydrophobic seal to permit metal binding and release. The conservation of this arrangement of titratable and hydrophobic residues among ABC transporters of transition metals suggests a common mechanism (<span id="ref34553546.34416234" class="cite">Kuznetsova <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MntABC of <em>Bacillus cereus<br /></em>MntA, R, 311 aas, 1 N-terminal TMSs, Q4V0W6<br />MntB, C, 249 aas, 0 TMSs, Q4V0W4<br />MntC, M, 288 aas, 7 TMSs, Q4V0W5</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.3&tcname=">3.A.1.15.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Zinc (Zn<sup>2+</sup>) porter, AdcABC/AII</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Firmicutes</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AdcABC of <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em> <br />
AdcA (R)<br />
AdcB (M)<br />
AdcC (C)<br />AdcAII (Lmb) (R)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.4&tcname=">3.A.1.15.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Iron and manganese porter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Proteobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>YfeABCD of <I>Yersinia pestis</I> <br>

YfeC (M)<br>
YfeD (M)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.5&tcname=">3.A.1.15.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Zinc (Zn<sup>2+</sup>) porter of <em>E. coli</em>, ZnuABC.&nbsp; Required for Zn<sup>2+</sup> homeostasis and virulence in the close <em>E. coli</em> relative, <em>Salmonella enterica</em> <span id="ref5912.17923515" class="cite">(Ammendola <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ZnuABC (YebLMI) of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> ZnuA (R)<br /> ZnuC (C)<br /> ZnuB (M)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.6&tcname=">3.A.1.15.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Iron (Fe<sup>2+</sup>)/Zinc (Zn<sup>2+</sup>)/Copper (Cu<sup>2+</sup>) porter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Firmicutes</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MtsABC of <I>Streptococcus pyogenes</i> <br>
MtsA (R)<br>
MtsB (C)<br>
MtsC (M)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.7&tcname=">3.A.1.15.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Manganese (Mn<sup>2+</sup>) (Km=0.1 &mu;M) and iron (Fe<sup>2+</sup>) (5 &mu;M) porter (inhibited by Cd<sup>2+</sup> &gt; Co<sup>2+</sup> &gt; Ni<sup>2+</sup>, Cu<sup>2+</sup>) (most similar to YfeABCD of <em>Yersinia pestis</em> (TC #3.A.1.15.4)). Important for virulence in <em>Salmonella </em>(<span id="ref7498.20807201" class="cite">Karlinsey <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SitABCD of <em>Salmonella typhimurium</em> <br /> SitA (R) <br /> SitB (C) <br /> SitC (M) <br /> SitD (M)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.8&tcname=">3.A.1.15.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Manganese (Mn<sup>2+</sup>), zinc (Zn<sup>2+</sup>) and possibly iron (Fe<sup>2+</sup>) uptake porter, TroABCD (<span id="ref5775.12668673" class="cite">Hazlett <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>).&nbsp; Transcription of the operon is controlled by the Mn<sup>2+</sup>-activated (not Zn<sup>2+</sup>- or Fe<sup>2+</sup>-activated) repressor, TroR (153 aas, acc# F7IW50;) TroR contains a metal-binding domain homologous to the YtgC-R protein (3.A.1.15.12) which has the membrane domain of this ABC transporter (N-terminus) fused to the repressor domain (C-terminus) (<span id="ref34543686.23945957" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; TroA (Tromp1), the periplasmic metal binding protein, was originally reported to be an outer membrane porin (<span id="ref1346.10572117" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 1999</span>), but this proved to be incorrect.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Spirochaetes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TroABCD of <em>Treponema pallidum</em> <br /> TroA (R)  P96116  <br /> TroB (C)  P96117  <br /> TroC (M)  P96118  <br /> TroD (M)  P96119</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.15.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.15.9&tcname=">3.A.1.15.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Manganese (Mn<sup>2+</sup>) and Iron (Fe<sup>2+</sup>) porter, SitABCD (<span id="ref5874.17172335" class="cite">Davies and Walker, 2007</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Sit ABCD of <i>Sinorhizobium meliloti</i> 
<br>SitA (R) - (Q92LL5)
<br>SitB (M) - (Q92LL4)
<br>SitC (C) - (Q92LL3)
<br>SitD (M) - (Q92LL2)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.150">3.A.1.150 Functionally Uncharacterized ABC2-6 (ABC2-6) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.150.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.150.1&tcname=">3.A.1.150.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC transporter consisting of an ATPase and three membrane proteins having 4, 10 and 2 TMSs, respectively.&nbsp; The structure of the ATPase is similar to those of ABC transorteers, and expression is down regulated in response to cold shock (<span id="ref34544871.17932790" class="cite">Gerwe <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC transporter of <em>Pyrococcus furiosus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.150.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.150.2&tcname=">3.A.1.150.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC transporter consisting of an ATPase and 3 membrane proteins having 4, 10 and 2 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC transporter of <em>Pyrococcus furiosus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.151">3.A.1.151 Functionally Uncharacterized ABC2-7 (ABC2-7) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.151.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.151.1&tcname=">3.A.1.151.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>3-component putative ABC transporter with two membrane proteins and an ATPase. These three genes are adjacent to a gene encoding a DegV domain-containing protein, a fatty acid binding domain, also found in PTS mannose EIIA proteins (TC# 4.A.6) and dihydrolyacetone kinases (<span id="ref34546834.12577257" class="cite">Schulze-Gahmen <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>; <span id="ref34546835.15632288" class="cite">Kinch <em>et al.</em> 2005;</span> <span id="ref34546836.19390149" class="cite">Nan <em>et al.</em> 2009).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC transporter of <em>Halothermothrix orenii </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.151.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.151.2&tcname=">3.A.1.151.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative 3-compenent ABC transporter consisting of two membrane proteins and a cytoplasmic ATPase.&nbsp; Adjacent to genes coding for a MoaJ/NirJ iron-sulfur nitrite-like oxidoreductase and an antilisterial bacteriocin biosynthetic enzyme, AlbA (B5YBB2 and 3, respectively).&nbsp; The system could be a bacteriocin exporter.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of <em>Dictyoglomus thermophilum<br /></em>B5YBA9, M, 186 aas and 6 TMSs (may be N-terminally truncated)<br />B5YBB0, M, 223 aas and 6 TMSs (both in a 2 + 4 arrangement)<br />BSYBB1, C, 239 aas, ATPase<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.152">3.A.1.152 The lipopolysaccharide export (LptBFG) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.152.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.152.1&tcname=">3.A.1.152.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LPS export system, LptF (M), LptG (M) and LptB (C).&nbsp; This system is also listed in TCDB under TC#1.B.42.1.2 as part of a multicomponent system.&nbsp; The entire system is described in detail there. LptB<sub>2</sub>FG extracts LPSs from the IM and transports them to the outer membrane.&nbsp;<span id="ref34546832.28394325" class="cite"><span id="ref34546832.28394325" class="cite">Luo <em>et al.</em> 2017</span></span> reported the crystal structure of nucleotide-free LptB2FG from <em>P. aeruginosa</em>.
 It shows that LPS transport proteins LptF and LptG each contain a TM 
domain (TMD), a periplasmic beta-jellyroll-like domain and a coupling 
helix that interacts with LptB on the cytoplasmic side. The LptF and 
LptG TMDs form a large outward-facing V-shaped cavity in the IM. 
Mutational analyses suggested that LPS may enter the central cavity 
laterally, via the interface of the TMD domains of LptF and LptG, and is
 expelled into the beta-jellyroll-like domains upon ATP binding and 
hydrolysis by LptB. These studies suggest a mechanism for LPS extraction
 by LptB<sub>2</sub>FG that is distinct from those of classical ABC transporters that transport substrates across the IM (<span id="ref34546832.28394325" class="cite"><span id="ref34546837.28394325" class="cite">Luo <em>et al.</em> 2017</span></span>). LptB2FG extracts LPS from the periplasmic face of the IM through a pair of lateral gates and then powers transperiplasmic transport to the OM through a slide formed by either of the periplasmic domains of LptF or LptG, LptC, LptA and the N-terminal domain of LptD. The structural and functional studies of the seven lipopolysaccharide transport proteins provide a platform to explore the unusual mechanisms of LPS extraction, transport and insertion from the inner membrane to the outer membrane (<span id="ref34547248.28821406" class="cite">Dong <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). LptB2 binds novobiocin which stimulates its export activity and renders the membrane more impermeable to novobiocin (<span id="ref34547710.29135241" class="cite">May <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LptFGB<sub>2</sub> of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa<br />LptF, M, Q9HXH4, 375 aas, 6 TMSs<br />LptG, M, Q9HXH5, 354 aas, 6 TMSs<br />LptB, C, Q9HVV6, 241 aas, ATPase<br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.152.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.152.10&tcname=">3.A.1.152.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable LptF/G or YjgP/Q membrane proteins of an ABC exporter, possibly specific for a lipopolysaccharide.&nbsp; Adjacent genes code for proteases/peptidases.&nbsp; An ATPase that energizes this system has not been identified. The two membrane proteins are of 360 and 380 aas with 6 TMSs in a 3 + 3 TMS arrangement, separated by a large hydrophilic loop. Members of this family often work together with outer membrane proteins of TC family 1.B.42, and some of these outer membrane proteins are fused to one of the subunites of these systems.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LptF/G of Candidatus <em>Pelagibacter</em> sp. (marine metagenome)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.152.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.152.2&tcname=">3.A.1.152.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC exporter of the YjgP/Q (LptFG) family.&nbsp; The membrane protein has 772 aas and 12 TMSs in a (3 + 3)<sub>2</sub> duplicated topology.&nbsp; The gene adjacent to this membrane protein gene encodes an ABC1 ATPase of 583 aas and 6 N-terminal TMSs with a C-terminal ATPase domain. Most ATPases of family 3.A.1.152 are of the ABC2-type. Thus, it is unlikely that this protein serves to energized the YjgP/Q-dependent transport process. This protein is in TCDB with TC# 3.A.1.106.17.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC transporter of<em> Acidobacterium ailaaui</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.152.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.152.3&tcname=">3.A.1.152.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized ABC system of the YjgP/Q family; the two membrane proteins are encoded by adjacent genes, but the gene for the ATPase was not found.&nbsp; However, a soluble OstA homologue (Q5SL97) of 824 aas is encoded adjacent to the two membrane protein-encoding genes.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Thermus thermophilus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.152.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.152.4&tcname=">3.A.1.152.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized YjgP/YjgQ family homologue of 441 aas and 6 TMSs. No other YjgP homologue and no ATPase is encoded adjacent to the gene encoding this protein.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Chlorobium phaeovibrioides (Prosthecochloris vibrioformis)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.152.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.152.5&tcname=">3.A.1.152.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized YjgP/Q homologue of 266 aas and 6 TMSs.
