The 134-kDa protein complex is unique among ABC transporters because it extracts lipopolysaccharide from the external leaflet of the inner membrane and propels it along a filament that extends across the periplasm to directly deliver lipopolysaccharide into the external leaflet of the outer membrane.&nbsp;<span id="ref34547272.28790314" class="cite">Dong <em>et al.</em> 2017</span> reported the crystal structure of this transporter in which both LptF and LptG are composed of a beta-jellyroll-like periplasmic domain and six TMSs. LptF and LptG together form a central cavity containing highly conserved hydrophobic residues. Structural and functional studies suggest that LptB<sub>2</sub>FG uses an alternating lateral access mechanism to extract lipopolysaccharide and traffic it along the hydrophobic cavity toward the transporter's periplasmic domains. The structure has been presented by <span id="ref34547272.28790314" class="cite">Dong <em>et al.</em> 2017.</span> LPS transport involves long-ranging bi- directional coupling across cellular compartments between cytoplasmic LptB and periplasmic regions of the Lpt transporter (<span id="ref34552370.33361195" class="cite">Lundstedt <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). LPS transport from the inner membrane (IM) to the OM is achieved by seven lipopolysaccharide transport proteins (LptA-G). LptB<sub>2</sub>FG, a type VI ABC transporter, forms a stable complex with LptC, extracts LPS from the IM and powers LPS transport to the OM.&nbsp;<span id="ref34553616.34303191" class="cite">Luo <em>et al.</em> 2021</span> reported the cryo-EM structures of LptB<sub>2</sub>FG and LptB<sub>2</sub>FGC from <em>Klebsiella pneumoniae</em> in complex with LPS. The LptB<sub>2</sub>FG-LPS structure provides detailed interactions between LPS and the transporter, while the LptB<sub>2</sub>FGC-LPS structure may represent an intermediate state in which the transmembrane helix of LptC has not been fully inserted into the transmembrane domains of LptB<sub>2</sub>FG (<span id="ref34553616.34303191" class="cite">Luo <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LptB<sub>2</sub>FG of <em>Klebsiella pneumoniae <br /></em>LptB, 241 aas; 0 TMSs, A6TEM0<br />LptF, 365 aas, 6 TMSs, A6THI3<br />LptG, 360 aas, 6 TMSs, A6THI4<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.153">3.A.1.153 The Functionally Uncharacterized ABC-X (ABC-X) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.153.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.153.1&tcname=">3.A.1.153.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span>ABC transporter complex YtrBCD that may play a role in acetoin utilization during stationary phase and sporulation (<span id="ref34547762.10986249" class="cite">Yoshida <em>et al.</em> 2000</span>). </span><span>Expression is induced early in the stationary phase. The six<em> ytr </em> genes form a single operon, transcribed from a promoter present upstream of <em>ytrA. </em>YtrA, which 
possesses a helix-turn-helix motif of the GntR family, may be a
 repressor that regulates its own transcription as well as the whole operon. Inactivation of the 
operon led to a decrease in the maximal cell yield and less-efficient 
sporulation. <em>B. subtilis</em> produces acetoin as 
an external carbon storage compound and then reuses it later during 
stationary phase and sporulation. Possibly the Ytr porter plays a role (<span id="ref34547762.10986249" class="cite">Yoshida <em>et al.</em> 2000</span>). The YtrEF system, believed to be a distinct ABC efflux system (M. Saier, unpublished results), can be found under TC# 3.A.1.122.19.<br /></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YtrBCD of <em>Bacillus subtilis<br /></em>YtrB, 292 aas (C)<br />YtrC, 328 aas (M)<br />YtrD, 325 aas (M)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.155.1&tcname=">3.A.1.155.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The phage infection protein of 901 aas, PIP (<span id=""ref3506.8366036"" class=""cite"">Geller <em>et al.</em> 1993</span>). The PIP family (3.A.1.155) includes large proteins with 1 N-terminal hydrophobic 
TMS, a hydrophilic domain of variable length, and 5 C-terminal putative 
TMSs.  The functionally characterized protein from <em>Lactococcus lactis</em> is of 901 aas (<a class=""reflink"" href=""../../search/result.php?tc=9.B.74#ref3506"">Geller <em>et al</em>., 1993</a>).  Homologues obtained with one PSI-BLAST iteration include members of the MmpL family of the RND superfamily (e.g., a <em>Bacillus</em> protein, gi#89208076; 1038 aas).  With poorer scores, a protein 
annotated as an ABC-2-like sequence (gi#89200681; 392 aas with 1 TMS 
followed by a 150 residue hydrophilic domain followed by a C-terminal 5 
putative TMSs) was retrieved.  Another protein annotated as ABC-2 was 
smaller with 6 putative TMSs in a 2 + 3 + 1 arrangement (gi#57234453; 
241 aas). The hydrophilic domain in these proteins may show sequence similarity with the large periplasmic hydrophilic domains of RND porters (2.A.6.1 - 9).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PIP of <em>Lactococcus lactis</em> (P49022)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.155.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.155.2&tcname=">3.A.1.155.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The putative ABC-2-like protein of 678 aas (topology-like PIP) </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>ABC-2-like protein of <i>Arthrobacter</i> sp. Two ABC-type ATPases are encoded by genes adjacent to the membrane protein, and on the other side is encoded a membrane protein of 509 aas with two TMSs, one N-termnal, and one C-terminal. This last protein is included here because if could be an auxilliary protein of the ABC exporter.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC3-type exporter of Candidatus Heimdallarchaeota archaeon LC_3 (marine sediment metagenome)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.157.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.157.3&tcname=">3.A.1.157.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC3 transporter of two constituents</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC3 porter of Candidatus Heimdallarchaeota archaeon</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.158.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.158.1&tcname=">3.A.1.158.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized ABC-type exporter possibly with 4 protein components, all of which are encoded by genes that map adjacent to each other, YybMLKJ.&nbsp; The proteins of this system are distantly related to members of ABC families 3.A.1.124, 132, 146 and 157.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YybJKLM of <em>Bacillus subtilis<br /></em>YybJ, C, 218 and 0 TMSs<br />YybK, M, 251 aas and 6 TMSs<br />YybL, M, 236 aas and 6 TMSs<br />YybM, M, 251 aas and 6 TMSs</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.158.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.158.2&tcname=">3.A.1.158.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC-type multidrug transport system with 3 protein components.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BAC porter with three components<br />ABC-A, M, 264 aas and 6 TMSs<br />ABC-B, M, 287 aas and 6 TMSs<br />ABC-C, C, 220 aas and 0 TMSs</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.158.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.158.3&tcname=">3.A.1.158.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of three protein components</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Clostridium beijerinckii (Clostridium acetobutylicum)<br />ABC-A, M, 6 TMSs, A6LQ39<br />ABC-B, M, 6 TMSs, A6LQ40<br />ABC-C, C, 0 TMSs, A6LQ41<br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.158.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.158.4&tcname=">3.A.1.158.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative 4 component ABC system with 3 membrane proteins, all with 6 TMSs, and one ATPase, all encoded by genes that are adjacent to each other.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative 4 component ABC exporter of Lachnospiraceae bacterium (gut metagenome)</p>

These proteins are encoded in operons that are subject to regulation by vitamin B<sub>12</sub> (<span id='ref10812.12869542' class='cite'>Rodionov <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>). These and other ECF ABC families (3.A.1.18, 23, 25, 26, 28, 31 and 32) have been reviewed (<span id='ref34549157.30485755' class='cite'>Rempel <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.18.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.18.1&tcname=">3.A.1.18.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ECF transporter, EcfSTA; regulated by a cobalamin riboswitch.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EcfSTA of <em>Roseifluxes</em> sp. RS-1<br />EcfS (S) (A5UXW2)<br />EcfT (T) (A5UXW1)<br />EcfA (A) (A5UXW0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.18.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.18.2&tcname=">3.A.1.18.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative Co<sup>2+</sup> ECF transporter, EcfSTA</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EcfSTA of <em>Gloeobacter violaceus</em> <br />EcfS (S) (Q7NIY0)<br />EcfT (T) (Q7NIX9)<br />EcfA (A) (Q7NIX8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.18.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.18.3&tcname=">3.A.1.18.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative Co<sup>2+</sup> ECF transporter, EcfSTA</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EcfSTA of <em>Syntrophobotulus glycolicus</em><br />EcfS (S) (F0SWZ4)<br />EcfT (T) (F0SWZ5)<br />EcfA (A) (F0SWZ6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.19">3.A.1.19 The Thiamin Uptake Transporter (ThiT) Family (Most similar to 3.A.1.10, 3.A.1.6 and 3.A.1.8 in that order)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.19.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.19.1&tcname=">3.A.1.19.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Thiamin, thiamin monophosphate and thiamin pyrophosphate porter. The 2.25 √Ö structure of ThiB (TbpA) has been solved (<span id="ref5933.18177053" class="cite">Soriano <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>). </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Proteobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>ThiBPQ of <I>Salmonella typhimurium</I> (functionally characterized and partially sequenced) and <I>E. coli</I> (fully sequenced but not functionally characterized) <br>
ThiB; TbpA (R)<br>
ThiP; YabK (M)<br>
ThiQ; YabJ (C)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.19.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.19.2&tcname=">3.A.1.19.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span>The thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) uptake porter (</span><span id="ref7884.21622748" class="cite">Bian&nbsp;<em>et al.</em>, 2011</span><span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TPP transporter of<em> Treponena denticola</em> TDE0143/TDE0144/TDE0145<br />TDE0143 (R) (Q73RE6)<br />TDE0144 (M) (Q73RE5)<br />TDE0145 (C) (Q73RE4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.19.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.19.3&tcname=">3.A.1.19.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of unknown function. <p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.19.4"></a></p>
<p>The putative sulfate/thiosulfate transporter, YnjBCD. YnjB has 12 TMSs. The three genes encoding this system are adjacent to one encoding a thiosulfate:sulfur transferase or a rhodanese (B7L6N1).&nbsp; Also considered to be a thiamine transporter (<span id="ref34543636.18634750" class="cite">Moussatova <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&gamma;-Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YnjBCD of <em>E. coli</em> <br />YnjB (possible receptor, R) (B7L6M8)<br />YnjC (M) (B7L6M9)<br />YnjD (C) (B7L6N0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.19.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.19.5&tcname=">3.A.1.19.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p style="margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px;">Putative ABC transporter,<span style="font-style: normal; font-variant: common-ligatures; font-weight: normal; font-stretch: normal; font-size: x-small; line-height: normal; font-family: Helvetica Neue; font-size-adjust: none; font-optical-sizing: auto; font-language-override: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-variation-settings: normal; font-kerning: none; color: #000000;"> WtpB1/C1: molybdate/tungstate transport system.</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><em>Deinococcus-Thermus</em></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of <em>Deinococcus deserti</em> <br />Permesae (M) (C1CWI2)<br />ATPase (C) (C1CWI3)<br />Possible periplasmic receptor (R) (C1CWI4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.19.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.19.6&tcname=">3.A.1.19.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable 4 component ABC transporter with two ATPase of 387 and 368 aas, respectively, both annotated as MalK, one membrane protein that maps together with the two ATPases and is annotated CysW, and one receptor that maps separately for the other three and is designated MalE. It is not established that this repector maps with the other three constituents, but this has been inferred by the similarities of the two ATPases to MalK.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative 4 component ABC uptake porter of unknown specificity, CysW/MalK/MalK/MalE of Candidatus Heimdallarchaeota archaeon LC_3 (marine sediment metagenome)</p>
<p></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.2">3.A.1.2 The Carbohydrate Uptake Transporter-2 (CUT2) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.2.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.2.1&tcname=">3.A.1.2.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Ribose porter.&nbsp; RbsA has two ATPase domains fused together; RbsB is the substrate receptor; RbsC has 10 TMSs with N- and C-termini in the cytoplasm and forms a dimer (<span id="ref5788.12923096" class="cite">Stewart and Hermodson, 2003</span>).&nbsp; ABC importers can be divided into two classes. Type I importers follow an alternating access mechanism driven by the presence of the substrate. Type II importers accept substrates in a
nucleotide-free state, with hydrolysis driving an inward-facing conformation.&nbsp; RbsABC<sub>2</sub> seems to share functional traits with both type I and type II importers, as
well as possessing unique features, and employs a distinct mechanism relative to other ABC
transporters (<span id="ref34543711.25533465" class="cite">Clifton <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RbsABC of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> RbsA (C)<br /> RbsB (R)<br /> RbsC (M)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.2.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.2.10&tcname=">3.A.1.2.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The purine nucleoside permease (probably transports guanosine, adenosine, 2'-deoxyguanosine, inosine and xanthosine with decreasing affinity in this order) (<span id="ref5834.16418175" class="cite">Deka <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Spirochaetes</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>PnrA-E of <i>Treponema pallidum</i> <br>

PnrD (M) (400 aas; 10 TMSs; Tp0322) (NP_218762) <br>
PnrE (M) (316 aas; 10 TMSs; Tp0323) (NP_218763)
</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.2.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.2.11&tcname=">3.A.1.2.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The erythritol permease, EryEFG (<span id="ref7168.20671019" class="cite">Geddes <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>) (probably orthologous to 3.A.1.2.16)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EryEFG of <em>Sinorhizobium meliloti</em> <br /> EryE (C) (CAC48737) <br /> EryF (M) (CAC48738) <br /> EryG (R) (CAC48735)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.2.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.2.12&tcname=">3.A.1.2.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The (deoxy)ribonucleoside permease; probably takes up all deoxy- and ribonucleosides (cytidine, uridine, adenosine and toxic analogues, fluorocytidine and fluorouridine tested), but not ribose or nucleobases (<span id="ref5862.16997965" class="cite">Webb and Hosie, 2006</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>RnsABCD of <i>Streptococcus mutans</i> <br>

																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.2.21"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>The myoinositol (high affinity)/ D-ribose (low affinity) transporter IatP/IatA/IbpA. The structure of IbpA with myoinositol bound has been solved (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9814">Herrou and Crosson 2013</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&alpha;-Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>IatP/IatA/IbpA of <em>Caulobacter crescentus</em> <br />IatP (M) (B8H230)<br />IatA (C) (B8H229)<br />IbpA (R) (B8H228)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.2.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.2.22&tcname=">3.A.1.2.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC sugar transporter that plays a role in the probiotic benefits through acetate production (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10291">Fukuda <em>et al.</em> 2012</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sugar transporter of <em>Bifidobacterium longum</em><br />BL1694, 385 aas (R) (Q8G3R1)<br />BL1695, 517 aas (C) (Q8G3R0)<br />BL1696, 405 aas (M) (Q8G3Q9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.2.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.2.23&tcname=">3.A.1.2.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC sugar transporter, FruEFGK, important for the probiotic effect of <em>Bifidobacterium longum and </em>involved in producing acetate (<a class=""reflink"" href=""result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10291"">Fukuda <em>et al.</em> 2012</a>).&nbsp; The system is specific for fructose (highest affinity) ribose and xylose.&nbsp; All three sugars induce the system (<span id=""ref34548148.22102285"" class=""cite"">Wei <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sugar transporter of <em>Bifidobacterium longum<br /></em>BL0033 of 327 aas (R) (Q8G848)<br />BL0034 of 513 aas (C) (Q8G847)<br />BL0035 of 356 aas (M) (Q8G846)<br />BL0036 of 340 aas (M) (Q8G845)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.2.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.2.24&tcname=">3.A.1.2.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>XylFGH downstream of characterized transcriptional regulator, ROK7B7 (Sco6008); Similar systems are found in other spirochetes such as <span><em>Treponema denticola</em>, and <em>Borrelia burgdorferi </em></span>(<span id="ref34546846.23404400" class="cite">Deka <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RfuABCD of <em>Treponema pallidum<br /></em>RfuA, R, 343 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS<br />RfuB, C, 586 aas and 0 TMSs<br />RfuC, M, 377 aas and 9 or 10 TMSs<br />RfuD, M, 313 aas and 9 TMSs (may be N-terminally truncated)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.2.29"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.2.29&tcname=">3.A.1.2.29</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High affinity fructose uptake porter, FrtABC, Km (fructose) = ~100&mu;M; expression of the<em> frtABC </em>operon is regulated by the product of the upstream gene, <em>frtR</em>, FrtR, a LacI/GalR-type repressor that allows activation in the presence of fructose (<span id="ref34547690.18931119" class="cite">Ungerer <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>). When FruR is eliminated, the cells become hypersensitive to fructose, and the level of fruABC expression is much higher than in the presence of wild type cells grown on fructose (<span id="ref34547690.18931119" class="cite">Ungerer <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FrtABC of <em><span class="highlight">Anabaena</span> (Nostoc) variabilis<br /></em>FrtA, Ava2171, Q3MB45, 341 aas with 1 N-terminal TMS (R)<br />FrtB, Ava2172, Q3MB44, 517 aas and 0 TMSs (C)<br />FrtC, Ava2173, Q3MB43, 332 aas and 8 TMSs (M)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.2.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.2.3&tcname=">3.A.1.2.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Galactose/glucose (methyl galactoside) porter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Proteobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MglABC of <I>E. coli</I> </br>

evidence that this transporter might function to take up such substrates.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative glycerol phosphodiester uptake porter of <em>Bdellovibrio exovorus </em></p>
<p>A11Q_2445 (R), 344 aas and 1 TMS<br />A11Q_2446 (M), 541 aas and 12 TMSs<br />A11Q_2447 (C), 245 aas and 0 TM</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.20.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.20.5&tcname=">3.A.1.20.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Possibly a Mg<sup>2+</sup>-citrate uptake porter with three components, R, M and C, as suggested by <span id="ref34549445.30672551" class="cite">Mandal <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>.&nbsp; However, this system appears more likely to be a ferric iron uptake system, based on sequence similarity studies (see other members of TC sub-family 3.A.1.20).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fe<sup>3+</sup> or Mg<sup>2+</sup>-citrate porter of <em>Thermus thermophilus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.201">3.A.1.201 The Multidrug Resistance Exporter (MDR) Family (ABCB)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.1&tcname=">3.A.1.201.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Broad specificity multidrug resistance (MDR1; MDR-1; Pgp; P-gp; ABCB1; P-glycoprotein) efflux pump. It exports organic cations and amphiphilic compounds of unrelated chemical structure.&nbsp; These include: antibiotics, anti-viral agents, cancer chemotheraputic agents, hypertensives, depressants, histamines, emetics, and the protease inhibitor, lopinavir. Pgp also exports immunosuppressants, detergents, long-chain fatty acids, HIV protease inhibitors, synthetic tetramethylrosamine analogues, calcein M, etc.); it is also a peptide efflux pump, and peptide inhibitors have been designed (<span id="ref34550098.15916428" class="cite">Tarasova <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>). It is also a phospholipid (e.g., phosphatidyl serine), cholesterol and sterol flippase. It binds and probably transports inhibitors and agonists of SUR (3.A.1.208.4) (<a>Bessadok <em>et al.</em>, 2011</a>). Modulatory effects of inhibitory amlodipine and tamoxifen on P-glycoprotein efflux activities have been studied (<span id="ref34551374.15285842" class="cite">Darvari and Boroujerdi 2004</span>). The 3-d structure has been determined (<a>Aller <em>et al.</em>, 2009</a>). It can pump from the cytoplasmic leaflet to either the outer leaflet or the outer medium (<a>Katzir <em>et al.</em>, 2010</a>). The inhibitor,&nbsp;5''-fluorosulfonylbenzoyl 5''-adenosine, an ATP analogue, interacts with both drug-substrate- and nucleotide-binding sites (<a>Ohnuma <em>et al.</em>, 2011</a>). Inhibited by sildenafil (<a>Shi <em>et al.</em>, 2011</a>), verapamil, indomethacin, probenecid, cetirizine (<span>He <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>), and lapatinib derivatives (<a>Sodani <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>), several of which are also substrates.&nbsp;HG-829 is a potent non-competitive inhibitor (<a>Caceres <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>).&nbsp; Berberine, palmatine, jateorhizine, cetirizine and coptisine are all P-gp substrates, and cyclosporin A and verapamil are potent inhibitors (<span><span>He <em>et al.</em> 2010; </span>Zhang <em>et al.,</em> 2011</span>).&nbsp; Transports clarithromycin (CAM), a macrolide antibiotic used to treat lung infections, more effectively than azithromycin (AZM) or telithromycin (TEL) (<span>Togami <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).&nbsp; Nucleotides, lipids and drugs bind synergistically to the pump (<span>Marcoux <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; Fluorescent substrates have been identified (<span>Strouse <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; The central cavity undergoes alternating access during ATP hydrolysis (<span>van Wonderen <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Structural data suggest that signals are transduced through
intracellular loops of the TMSs that slot into grooves on the NBDs. The Q loops at the base of these grooves are required to couple drug binding to the ATP catalytic cycle of drug export (<span>Zolnerciks <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). Ocotillol analogues are strong competitive inhibitors (<span>Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; <span>Durmus <em>et al.</em> 2015</span> have reviewed PGP transport of cancer chemotheraputic agents.&nbsp; ABCB1 variants modulate therapeutic responses to modafinil
and may partly explain pharmacoresistance in Narcolepse type 1 (NT1) patients (<span>Moresco <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).&nbsp; Many inhibitors have been identified (<span>Hemmer <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; The open-and-close
motion of the protein alters the surface topology of P-gp within the drug-binding pocket,
explaining its polyspecificity (<span>Esser <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). The ATP- and substrate-coupled conformational cycle of the mouse Pgp transporter have been defined, showing that the energy released by ATP hydrolysis is harnessed in the NBDs in a two-stroke cycle (<span>Verhalen <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp; Rilpivirine inhibits MDR1- and BCRP-mediated efflux of abacavir and increases its transmembrane transport (<span>Reznicek <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp; It transports Huerzine A in the brain, a drug that is used for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease (<span>Li <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). AbcB1 acts in concert with ABCA1, ABCG2 and ABCG4 to efflux amyloid-&beta; 
peptide (A&beta;) from the brain across the blood-brain barrier (BBB) (<span>Kuai <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).The structure has been determined with&nbsp;the ABCB1 inhibitor, zosuquidar, bound.&nbsp; This structure reveals the transporter in an occluded conformation with a central, enclosed, inhibitor-binding pocket lined by residues from all TMSs. The pocket spans almost the entire width of the lipid membrane and is occupied exclusively by two closely interacting zosuquidar molecules (<span>Alam <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).&nbsp; Iit is also inhibited by dacomitinib (<span>Fan <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Moreover, <span>Kim and Chen 2018 </span>presented the structure of human P-glycoprotein in the outward-facing 
conformation, determined by cryo-electron microscopy at 3.4-&Aring; 
resolution. The two nucleotide-binding domains form a closed dimer 
occluding two ATP molecules. The drug-binding cavity observed in the 
inward-facing structures is reorientated toward the extracellular space 
and is compressed to preclude substrate binding. This observation indicates
 that ATP binding, not hydrolysis, promotes substrate release (<span>Kim and Chen 2018</span>). P-gp also transports opioid peptides (<span>Ganapathy and Miyauchi 2005</span>). MDR1 has been quantified in primary human renal cell carcinoma cells and corresponding normal tissue, and down-regulation or expression loss was documented in tumor tissues, corroborating its importance in drug resistance and efficacy (<span>Poetz <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Regarding the conformational transitions, first the transition is driven by the NBDs, then transmitted to the cytoplasmic parts of TMSs, and finally to the periplasmic parts. The trajectories show that besides the translational motions, the NBDs undergo a rotation movement (<span>Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Isoxanthohumol is a substrate and competitive inhibitor which reverses ABCB1-mediated doxorubicin resistance (<span>Liu <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Tariquidar is a potent inhibitor, even when taken orally (<span>Matzneller <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Combined oral administration of the ovarian hormones, ethinyl estradiol and progesterone, significantly lowered both MDR-1 mRNA and MDR-1 protein in the ovary (<span id="ref34549136.30460040" class="cite">Brayboy <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Its expression in immune cells plays a protective role from xenobiotics and toxins (<span id="ref34549269.30524890" class="cite">Bossennec <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Oxypeucedanin reverses P-gp-mediated drug transport by inhibition of P-gp activity and P-gp protein expression as well as downregulation of P-gp mRNA levels (<span id="ref34549292.30042338" class="cite">Dong <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).<span id="ref34549467.30765569" class="cite"> Alam <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>&nbsp;determined the 3.5-&Aring; cryo-EM
structure of substrate-bound human ABCB1 reconstituted in lipidic 
nanodiscs, revealing a single molecule of the chemotherapeutic compound 
paclitaxel (Taxol) bound in a central, occluded pocket. A second 
structure of inhibited, human-mouse chimeric ABCB1 revealed two 
molecules of zosuquidar occupying the same drug-binding pocket. Minor 
structural differences between substrate- and inhibitor-bound ABCB1 
sites are amplified toward the nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs), 
revealing how the plasticity of the drug-binding site controls the 
dynamics of the ATP-hydrolyzing NBDs. Ordered 
cholesterol and phospholipid molecules suggest how the membrane 
modulates the conformational changes associated with drug binding and 
transport (<span id="ref34549467.30765569" class="cite">Alam <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The TMS4/6 cleft may be an energetically favorable entrance gate for ligand entry into the binding pocket of P-gp (<span id="ref34549656.30899446" class="cite">Xing <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The epigallocatechin gallate derivative Y6 reverses drug resistance mediated by ABCB1 (<span id="ref34549771.30972279" class="cite">Wen <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Substrate-induced acceleration of ATP hydrolysis correlates with 
stabilization of a high-energy, post-ATP hydrolysis state characterized 
by structurally asymmetric nucleotide-binding sites, but this 
state is destabilized in the substrate-free cycle and by high-affinity 
inhibitors in favor of structurally symmetric nucleotide binding sites (<span id="ref34549942.31097669" class="cite">Dastvan <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). It transports temozolomide (TMZ) which is used as a treatment of glioblasomas (<span id="ref34550415.31624332" class="cite">Malmstr&ouml;m <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Unconventional cholesterol translocation on the surface of Pgp provides a secondary transport model for the known flippase activity of ABC exporters of cholesterol (<span id="ref34550618.31676371" class="cite">Thangapandian <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). An in silico multiclass classification model capable of predicting the probability of a compound to interact with P-gp has been developed using a counter-propagation artificial neural network (CP ANN) based on a set of 2D molecular descriptors, as well as an extensive dataset of 2512 compounds (1178 P-gp inhibitors, 477 P-gp substrates and 857 P-gp non-active compounds) (<span id="ref34550673.31130601" class="cite">Mora Lagares <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).&nbsp; Jervine is a natural teratogenic compound isolated from <em>Veratrum californicum</em>.&nbsp;<span id="ref34550873.31207578" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2019</span> showed that jervine sensitizes the anti-proliferation effect of doxorubicin (DOX) and that the synergistic mechanism was related to the intracellular accumulation of DOX via modulating ABCB1 transport. Jervine did not affect the expression of ABCB1 in mRNA or protein levels. However, jervine increased the ATPase activity of ABCB1 and probably served as a substrate of ABCB1. Jervine binds to a closed ABCB1 conformation and blocks drug entrance to the central binding site at the transmembrane domain (<span id="ref34550873.31207578" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). 6-Triazolyl-substituted sulfocoumarins inhibit P-gp (<span id="ref34550963.31330259" class="cite">Podolski-Reniƒá <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). ATP binding causes the conformational change to the outward-facing state, and ATP hydrolysis and subsequent release of &gamma;-phosphate from both NBDs allow the outward-facing state to return to the original inward-facing state (<span id="ref34551027.32111736" class="cite">Futamata <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Replacing the eleven native tryptophans by directed evolution produces an active P-glycoprotein with site-specific, non-conservative substitutions (<span id="ref34551038.32081894" class="cite">Swartz <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). ABCB1 polymorphisms alter P-gp-mediated drug (sunitinib) sensitivities. Homology modeling provided insight into ligand binding through molecular docking studies (<span id="ref34551767.32517082" class="cite">Mora Lagares <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Sitravatinib&nbsp; reverses MDR mediated by ABCB1 and partially antagonized ABCC10-mediated MDR (<span id="ref34551789.32525624" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Apiole from parsley blocks the active P-gp site, with strong binding energy, which, in turn, inhibits doxorubicin and vincristine efflux, increasing the antiproliferative response of these chemotherapeutic agents (<span id="ref34552170.33096917" class="cite">Afonso de Lima <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The mechanisms of action of synthetic, potent, small molecule P-gp inhibitors have been reviewed (<span id="ref34552236.33047304" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). ATP binding to the open NBDs and ATP hydrolysis in the closed NBD dimer represent two steps of energy input, each leading to the formation of a high energy state. Relaxation from these high energy states occurs through conformational changes that push ABCB1 through the transport cycle (<span id="ref34552311.32054924" class="cite">Sz&ouml;ll≈ësi <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). 14 conserved residues (seven in both TMsSs 6 and 12) were substituted with alanine and generated a mutant termed 14A (<span id="ref34552316.33168729" class="cite">Sajid <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Although the 14A mutant lost the ability to pump most of the substrates tested out of cancer cells, it was able to import four substrates, including rhodamine 123 (Rh123) and the taxol derivative flutax-1. Similar to the efflux function of wild-type P-gp, uptake was ATP hydrolysis-, substrate concentration-, and time-dependent. Further mutagenesis identified residues in both TMSs 6 and 12 that synergistically form a switch in the central region of the two helices that governs whether a given substrate is pumped out of or into the cell (<span id="ref34552316.33168729" class="cite">Sajid <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Helix repacking may be the basis for P-glycoprotein promiscuity (<span id="ref34552422.32555203" class="cite">Bonito <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The use of carbon nano-onion-mediated dual targeting of P-selectin and P-glycoprotein has been shown to overcome cancer drug resistance (<span id="ref34552693.33436622" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). A sequentially responsive Nnanosystem breaches cascaded bio-barriers and suppresses P-Glycoprotein function for reversing cancer drug resistance (<span id="ref34552760.32959645" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Lys-268 and the cytoplasmic end of TMS5 may comprise a drug binding site (<span id="ref34552818.33565718" class="cite">Demmer <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). MDR1 protein (ABC-C1) is overexpressed in <em>Giardia intestinalis</em> following incubation with the drugs, albendazole and nitazoxanide (<span id="ref34553062.33840056" class="cite">&Aacute;ngeles-Arvizu <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The human P-gp is inhibited by benzophenone sulfonamide derivatives (<span id="ref34553419.32416700" class="cite">Farman <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>) and androstano-arylpyrimidines (<span id="ref34553505.33039566" class="cite">Gopisetty <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>), and possibly by tepoxalin (<span id="ref34553524.34298440" class="cite">McQuerry <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The inward facing state of P-glycoprotein in a lipid membrane has been confirmed (<span id="ref34553910.32339763" class="cite">Carey Hulyer <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). For transmembrane pharmaceutical drug transport, non-specific trans-phospholipid bilayer transport may be negligible (<span id="ref34553935.34577099" class="cite">Kell 2021</span>). Glabratephrin reverses doxorubicin resistance in triple negative breast cancer by inhibiting P-glycoprotein (<span id="ref34554133.34785319" class="cite">Abd-Ellatef <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). In silico screening of c-Met tyrosine kinase inhibitors targeting nucleotide and drug-substrate binding sites of ABCB1 are potential MDR reversal agents (<span id="ref34554945.35704515" class="cite">Moosavi <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Quercetin acts as a P-gp modulator via impeding signal transduction from the nucleotide-binding domain to the transmembrane domain (<span id="ref34554955.33306006" class="cite">Singh <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). MDR1 promotes intrinsic and acquired resistance to PROTACs in cancer cells and exports the antiseizure drug, levetiracetam (<span id="ref34555215.35953704" class="cite">Behmard <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Air pollution exposure increases ABCB1 and ASCT1 transporter levels in mouse cortex (<span id="ref34555495.36283621" class="cite">Puris <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). MDR-1 dysfunction perturbs meiosis and Ca<sup>2+</sup> homeostasis in oocytes (<span id="ref34555552.36215093" class="cite">Nabi <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). The P-glycoprotein (ABCB1) transporter has been modelled with in silico methods (<span id="ref34555656.36499131" class="cite">Mora Lagares and Noviƒç 2022</span>). <span style="font-weight: normal;">A new ABCB1 inhibitor enhances the anticancer effect of doxorubicin in models of </span> <span style="font-weight: normal;">non-small cell lung cancer</span> (<span style="font-weight: normal;">NSCLC) (<span id="ref34555804.36674503" class="cite">Adorni <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). </span>A homologous series of amphiphiles interact with P-glycoprotein in a membrane environment, and the contributions of polar and non-polar interactions has been estimated (<span id="ref34555808.36678803" class="cite">Moreno <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). <em>TRIP6</em> transcription is regulated primarily by the cyclic AMP 
response element (CRE) in hypomethylated proximal promoters in both 
taxane-sensitive and taxane-resistant MCF-7 cells. In 
taxane-resistant MCF-7 sublines, <em>TRIP6</em> co-amplifies with the neighboring <em>ABCB1</em> gene (<span id="ref34556013.36833223" class="cite">Daniel <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Inhibition of <em>Cryptosporidium parvum</em> by nitazoxanide (NTZ) and paclitaxel (PTX) has been validated (<span id="ref34556166.36972284" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). New inhibitors of ABCB1 have been identified (<span id="ref34556185.36982374" class="cite">Cheema <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Inhibitors of MDR pumps (MDR1, MRP1/2 and BCRP) have been described (<span id="ref34556190.36982886" class="cite">Kapro≈Ñ <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). A hyaluronic acid modified cuprous metal-organic complex reverses multidrug resistance via redox dyshomeostasis (<span id="ref34556206.37028879" class="cite">Wan <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>; <span id="ref34556207.37031496" class="cite">Duan <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The high sensitivity of the steady-state ATP hydrolysis rate to the 
nature and number of dipolar interactions, as well as to the dielectric 
constant of the membrane, points to a flopping process, which occurs to a
 large extent at the membrane-transporter interface (<span id="ref34556302.37070101" class="cite">Seelig and Li-Blatter 2023</span>). ABCB1, NCF4, and GSTP1 polymorphisms predicted lower hematological toxicity during induction, while ABCB1 and CRBN polymorphisms predicted lower risk of grade &gt;/=3 infections (<span id="ref34556379.37058477" class="cite">Ferrero <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Wine-processed Chuanxiong Rhizoma enhances the efficacy of aumolertinib 
against EGFR mutant non-small cell lung cancer xenografts in nude mouse 
brain (<span id="ref34556387.37087581" class="cite">Niu <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The efflux of anti-psychotics through the blood-brain barrier (BBB) via this system has been demonstrated (<span id="ref34556525.37239445" class="cite">Nasyrova <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Residues from homologous TMSs 4 and 10 are critical for P-glycoprotein (ABCB1)-mediated drug transport (<span id="ref34556895.37444569" class="cite">Rahman <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Emamectin B1a, Emamectin B1b, Vincristine, Vinblastine, and Vindesine are promising ABCB1 inhibitors that can reverse MDR (<span id="ref34556945.37513931" class="cite">Ibrahim <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Other substrates and inhibitors from <em>Anemarrhenae rhizoma</em> have been identified (<span id="ref34556995.36500651" class="cite">Dai <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp; Peptides and their analogs can cross the BBB by transmembrane diffusion, saturable transport, and adsorptive transcytosis (<span id="ref34557180.37598757" class="cite">Banks 2023</span>). Saturable transport systems are adaptable to physiologic changes and can be altered by disease states. In particular, transport across the BBB of insulin and of pituitary adenylate cyclase activating polypeptide (PACAP) illustrate many of the concepts regarding peptide transport across the BBB (<span id="ref34557180.37598757" class="cite">Banks 2023</span>).&nbsp; Second-site suppressor mutations reveal connections between the drug-binding pocket and the nucleotide-binding domain 1 of human P-glycoprotein (ABCB1) (<span id="ref34557471.37797431" class="cite">Murakami <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; Betulin derivatives are multidrug reversal agents targeting P-glycoprotein (<span id="ref34557710.38167542" class="cite">Laiolo <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>). Deaggregation of mutant <em>Plasmodium yoelii</em> de-ubiquitinase UBP1 alters MDR1 localization to confer multidrug resistance (<span id="ref34557836.38413566" class="cite">Xu <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p>
<pre><em>	</em></pre></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals, fungi, bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.10&tcname=">3.A.1.201.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mdr1; resistance to Cilofungin and other drugs (<span id="ref7363.19857594" class="cite">Lamping <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mdr1 (MCMC) of <em>Aspergillus fumigatus </em>(B0Y3B6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.11&tcname=">3.A.1.201.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mdr1 azole resistance efflux pump (<span id="ref7363.19857594" class="cite">Lamping <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).&nbsp; Antifungal activity of the repurposed drug disulfiram against <em>Cryptococcus neoformans has been studied (<span id="ref34557762.38273827" class="cite">Peng <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).<br /></em></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mdr1 (MCMC) of <em>Cryptococcus </em>(<em>Filobasidiella</em>)<em> neoformans</em> (O43140)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.12&tcname=">3.A.1.201.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>California mussel ABCB/MDR multixenobiotic resistance efflux pump (<span id="ref5949.18401003" class="cite">Luckenbach and Epel, 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB/MDR transporter of <em>Mytilus californianus</em> (MCMC) (B2WTH9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.13&tcname=">3.A.1.201.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plasma membrane AbcB5, of 812 aas and 6 TMSs, mediates resistance of tumor cells to doxorubicin and other drugs including taxanes and anthracyclines (<span id="ref8365.22306008" class="cite">Kawanobe <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>) by catalyzing efflux of these drugs (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).&nbsp; Expression in metastatic melanoma cells is affected by nano-TiO2 exposure, which as a sunscreen ingredient, may play a role in metastatic melanoma progression (<span id="ref34550178.30941990" class="cite">Zdravkovic <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB5 of <em>Homo sapiens</em>&nbsp;(Q2M3G0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.14&tcname=">3.A.1.201.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>P-glycoprotein-1 MDR exporter.&nbsp; Transports multiple drugs, cancer chemotherapy agents, cancer unrelated compounds and many xenobiotics including ivermectin (<span id="ref10613.23474412" class="cite">Ardelli 2013</span>).&nbsp; The crystal structure at 3.4 A resolution is available (<span id="ref9046.23000902" class="cite">Jin <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).&nbsp; It has 4,000x higher affinity for actinomycin D in the membrane bilayers than in detergent.&nbsp; A "ball and socket joint" and salt bridges similar to ABC importers suggested that both types of systems, importers and exporters, use the same mechanism to interconnect ATP hydrolysis with transport and achieve alternating access of the substrate binding site to the two sides of the membrane.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>P-glycoprotein-1 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.15&tcname=">3.A.1.201.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR efflux pump, ABCB1a.&nbsp; Exports canonical MDR susbtrates such as calcein-AM, bodipy-verapamil, bodipy-vinblastine and mitoxantrone (<span id="ref9272.23124201" class="cite">Gokirmak <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB1a of <em>Stronglycentrotus purpuratus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.16&tcname=">3.A.1.201.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR efflux pump, ABCB4a.&nbsp; Exports canonical MDR susbtrates such as 
calcein-AM, bodipy-verapamil, bodipy-vinblastine and mitoxantrone (<span id="ref9272.23124201" class="cite">Gokirmak <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB4a of <em>Stronglycentrotus purpuratus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.17&tcname=">3.A.1.201.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mitochondrial ABCB10 or ABC-me transporter. It is a mitochondrial inner membrane erythroid transporter involved in heme biosynthesis. ABCB10 possesses an unusually long 105-amino acid mitochondrial 
targeting presequence, the central subdomain of which (aas 36-70) is
sufficient for mitochondrial import (<span id="ref34551589.15215243" class="cite">Graf <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>) and is essential for erythropoiesis and protection of mitochondria
against oxidative stress.&nbsp; The 3-d structures of several conformations are available (3ZDQ; <span id="ref10039.23716676" class="cite">Shintre <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>; <span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Sitravatinib&nbsp; reverses MDR mediated by ABCB1 and partially antagonized ABCC10-mediated MDR (<span id="ref34551789.32525624" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB10 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.18&tcname=">3.A.1.201.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Leptomycin B resistance protein 1, Pmd1, of 1362 aas and 13 predicted TMSs (<span id="ref10272.1349418" class="cite">Nishi <em>et al.</em> 1992</span>). This protein is similar in sequence to Ste6-2b&nbsp; of Pichia pastoralis the structure of which has been solved by cryoEM. It transports rodamines 6G and 123, Dvarapamil, flconazole, and itraconazole, and it's ATPase activity is inhibited by terbinafine, niftifine, ketoconazole and asmorilfine, It also appears to interact with sterols (<span id="ref34555569.36256814" class="cite">Schleker <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pmd1 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.19&tcname=">3.A.1.201.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mitochondrial iron/sulfur complex transporter, AbcB13 of 663 aas (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10774">Xiong <em>et al.</em> 2010</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Alveolata (Ciliates)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcB13 (M-C) of<em> Tetrahymena thermophila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.2&tcname=">3.A.1.201.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bile salt export pump, BSEP, ABCB11 or SPGP in the canalicular membrane of liver cells, is associated with progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis-2 and benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis (<span id="ref5915.17947449" class="cite">Kagawa <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>; <span id="ref10568.23758865" class="cite">Stindt <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>;<span id="ref34546610.27239116" class="cite"> Park <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). It exports unconjugaged bile salts and glycine conjugates &gt; taurine conjugates as well as the statin, pravastatin (<span id="ref34550101.25475361" class="cite">Nigam 2015</span>). BSEP mediates biliary excretion of bile acids from hepatocytes. Compounds based on GW4064 (Q96RI1), a representative farnesoid X receptor (RXR) agonist, enhance E297G BSEP transport activity (<span id="ref8708.22583617" class="cite">Misawa <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). <span style="font-weight: normal;">Rescue of bile acid transport by ABCB11 variants by CFTR potentiators has been extensively documented as a possible treatment for </span>progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis-2 (<span id="ref34555322.36142670" class="cite">Mareux <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp; BSEP is expressed in hepatocytes and extrudes bile salts into the canaliculi of the liver. BSEP dysfunction, caused by mutations or induced by drugs is frequently associated with severe cholestatic liver disease. <span id="ref34557557.37949847" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2023 </span>reported the cryo-EM structure of glibenclamide-bound human BSEP in nanodiscs, revealing the basis of small-molecule inhibition. Glibenclamide binds the apex of a central binding pocket between the transmembrane domains, preventing BSEP from undergoing conformational changes, and thus rationalizing the reduced uptake of bile salts. Two high-resolution structures of BSEP trapped in distinct nucleotide-bound states by using a catalytically inactivated BSEP variant (BSEP(E1244Q)) to visualize a pre-hydrolysis state, and wild-type BSEP trapped by vanadate to visualize a post-hydrolysis state. These studies provide structural and functional insight into the mechanism of bile salt extrusion and into small-molecule inhibition of BSEP, which may rationalize drug-induced liver toxicity (<span id="ref34557557.37949847" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BSEP of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.20&tcname=">3.A.1.201.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>12 TMS multidrug resistance transprter of 1318 aas, AbcB15 (<span id="ref10774.20977778" class="cite">Xiong <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>) is the probable exporter of dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT).  Expression is induced by treatment with DDT, and this transporter appears to be responsible for DDT tolerance by pumping it out of the cell (<span id="ref11344.25260902" class="cite">Ning <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Alveolata (Ciliates)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcB15 (M-C-M-C) of <em>Tetrahymena thermophila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.21&tcname=">3.A.1.201.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Half sized ABCB1 drug (verapamil; rhodamine 6G) exporter of specificity similar to that of P-glycoprotein (3.A.1.201.1).&nbsp; The 3-d structures of the unbound (2.6 &Aring;) and the allosteric inhibitor-bound (2.4 &Aring;) forms have been determined (<span id="ref10956.24591620" class="cite">Kodan <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; The outward opening motion is required for ATP hydrolysis. <span id="ref34549295.30622258" class="cite">Kodan <em>et al.</em> 2019</span> have reported a pair of structures of this homodimeric P-glycoprotein: an outward-facing conformational state with bound nucleotide, and an inward-facing apo state, at resolutions of 1.9&nbsp;&Aring; and 3.0 &Aring;, respectively. Features that can be clearly visualized include ATP binding with octahedral coordination of Mg<sup>2+</sup>; an inner chamber that significantly changes in volume with the aid of tight connections among TMSs 1, 3, and 6; a glutamate-arginine interaction that stabilizes the outward-facing conformation; and extensive interactions between TMS1 and TMS3, a property that distinguishes multidrug transporters from floppases (<span id="ref34549295.30622258" class="cite">Kodan <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The crystal structure of the CmABCB1 G132V mutant, which favors the outward-facing state, reveals the mechanism of the pivotal joint between TMS1 and TMS3 (<span id="ref34552872.33683740" class="cite">Matsuoka <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The crystal structure of this CmABCB1 multi-drug exporter in lipidic mesophase has been revealed by LCP-SFX, suggesting flexibility of the substrate exit region of the protein (<span id="ref34554403.35059217" class="cite">Pan <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp; Structure-based alteration of tryptophan residues of CmABCB1 allows assessment of substrate binding using fluorescence spectroscopy (<span id="ref34554814.35634783" class="cite">Inoue <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Rhodophyta (Algae)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB1 of <em>Cyanidioschyzon merolae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.22&tcname=">3.A.1.201.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span class="FULL_NAME">Mitochondrial ATP-binding cassette 1, ABCB8.&nbsp; Mediates doxorubicin resistance in melanoma cells (<span id="ref11345.19147539" class="cite">Elliott and Al-Hajj 2009)</span></span>. It is regulated by the Sp1 transcription factor and down regulated by mthramycin A which blocks Sp1 binding to the DNA (<span id="ref11346.21046154" class="cite">Sachrajda and Ratajewski 2011</span>). It is also regulated by neuropilin-1, NRP1 (TC# 8.A.47.1.5) (<span id="ref34549284.30623799" class="cite">Issitt <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). The cryo-EM structure of ABCB8 bound to AMPPNP in the inward-facing conformation was solved with a resolution of 4.1 &Aring;. hABCB8 shows an open-inward conformation when ATP is bound, and cholesterol molecules were identified in the transmembrane domain of hABCB8 (<span id="ref34553040.33872987" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB8 of<em> Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.23&tcname=">3.A.1.201.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The cyclic AMP efflux pump of 1432 aas, ABCB3 (<span id="ref34546165.25448698" class="cite">Miranda <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Slime molds</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB3 of<em> Dictyostelium discoideum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.24&tcname=">3.A.1.201.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug exporter, MDR49 or Pgp of 1302 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Exports many drugs as well as pollutants such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) which are major sources of air, water and soil pollution.&nbsp; MDR49 is expressed at all developmental stages of the life cycle and in many tissues (<span id="ref34546164.17665681" class="cite">Vache <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). It is essential for early development, probably because <em>Drosophila </em>germ cell migration depends on lipid-modified peptides that are secreted by MDR49  (<span id="ref34550105.19213920" class="cite">Ricardo and Lehmann 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR49 of <em>Drosophila melanogaster </em>(Fruit fly)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.25&tcname=">3.A.1.201.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR transporter, Crmdr1 of 1266 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Crmdr1 is constitutively expressed in the root, stem and leaf with lower expression in leaf. It has two transmembrane domains (TMDs) and two
nucleotide binding domains (NBDs) arranging in "TMD1-NBD1-TMD2-NBD2" direction (<span id="ref34546209.17541839" class="cite">Jin <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>&nbsp; </strong></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Crmdr1 of <em>Catharanthus roseus (Madagascar periwinkle) (Vinca rosea)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.26&tcname=">3.A.1.201.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC multidrug exporter, MDR1 of 1341 aas, 12 TMSs and two ATPase domains in an MCMC arrangement.&nbsp; Miltefosine (hexadecylphosphocholine), the first orally available drug available to treat leishmaniasis, is pumped out of the parasite by MDR1, a P-glycoprotein-like transporter. Overexpression of LtrMDR1 increases miltefosine efflux, leading to a decrease in drug accumulation in the parasites and resistance (<span id="ref34546912.16940108" class="cite">P&eacute;rez-Victoria <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR1 of <em>Leishmania major</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.27"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.27&tcname=">3.A.1.201.27</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance exporter of 1331 aas and 12 TMSs, TratrD or MDR2. Almost identical throughout must of its length to F2PRR1 from <em>T equinum</em> of 1235 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34547250.27121717" class="cite">Martins <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Displays increased levels of transcription of the TruMDR2 gene when mycelia were exposed to acriflavine, benomyl, ethidium bromide, ketoconazole, chloramphenicol, griseofulvin, fluconazole, imazalil, itraconazole, methotrexate, 4-nitroquinoline N-oxide (4NQO) or tioconazole. Disruption of the TruMDR2 gene rendered the mutant more sensitive to terbinafine, 4NQO and ethidium bromide than the control strain, suggesting that this transporter plays a role in modulating drug susceptibility in <em>T. rubrum</em> (<span id="ref34547251.16849730" class="cite">Fachin <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TratrD or MDR2 of <em>Trichophyton rubrum </em>(Athlete's foot fungus)<em> (Epidermophyton rubrum)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.28"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.28&tcname=">3.A.1.201.28</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR1 alkaloid/multiple drug efflux transporter of 1292 aas and 12 TMSs (<span id="ref34547562.12524452" class="cite">Shitan <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CjMDR1 of <em>Coptis japonica</em> (Japanese goldthread)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.29"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.29&tcname=">3.A.1.201.29</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter B family member 11 isoform X1 or ABCB11 of 1303 aas and 12 TMSs. Functions to export shikonin (<span id="ref34547565.29132307" class="cite">Zhu <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Shikonin is a naphthoquinone secondary metabolite with&nbsp; medicinal value, found in<em> Lithospermum erythrorhizon. </em></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB11 of <em>Jatropha curcas</em> (Barbados nut) (closely related to <em>Lithospermum erythrorhizon</em>)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.3&tcname=">3.A.1.201.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Short chain fatty acid phosphatidylcholine translocase (phospholipid flippase), MDR3; AbcB4; Pgy3.&nbsp; ABCB4 regulates the secretion into bile of phosphatidylcholine (PC), while ABCG5/G8 is active in the excretion of cholesterol and sterols into bile. It is associated with progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis type 3 (PFIC3) (<span id="ref34546133.17726488" class="cite">Degiorgio <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>) and progressive intrafamilial hepatic disease (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref8684">Quazi and Molday, 2011</a>)). ABCB4 exhibits narrow drug specificity relative to MDR1 but exports digoxin, paclitaxel, vinblastin and bile acids. It regulates phosphatidylcholine secretion into bile and its translocation across the plasma membrane in hepatocytes (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref8848">Voloshyna and Reiss, 2011; <span id="ref34543712.25533467" class="cite">Kluth <em>et al.</em> 2014</span></a>) and functions as a floppase (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The cryo-EM structure trapped in an ATP-bound state at a resolution of 3.2 &Aring; has been described (<span id="ref34550661.31873305" class="cite">Olsen <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The nucleotide binding domains form a closed conformation containing two bound ATP molecules, but only one of the ATPase sites contains bound Mg<sup>2+</sup>. The transmembrane domains adopt a collapsed conformation at the level of the lipid bilayer, but a large, hydrophilic and fully occluded cavity at the level of the cytoplasmic membrane boundary, with no ligand bound, is present. This indicates a state following substrate release but prior to ATP hydrolysis. These results rationalize disease-causing mutations in human ABCB4 and suggest an 'alternating access' mechanism of lipid extrusion, distinct from the 'credit card swipe' model of other lipid transporters (<span id="ref34550661.31873305" class="cite">Olsen <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). An in vitro assay to investigate ABCB4 transport function has been developed (<span id="ref34556063.36901890" class="cite">Temesszentandr&aacute;si-Ambrus <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR3 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.30"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.30&tcname=">3.A.1.201.30</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB10 transporter of 655 aas and 6 TMSs.&nbsp; Functions in resistance to acaricides (<span id=""ref34547921.27484910"" class=""cite"">Koh-Tan <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB10 of <em>Rhipicephalus microplus</em> (Cattle tick) <em>(Boophilus microplus)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.31"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.31&tcname=">3.A.1.201.31</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Permeability glycoprotein, P-Glycoprotein 65, P-GP65, MDR65 of 1302 aas and 12 TMSs. a detoxification efflux pump transporting various lipophilic xenobiotics out of the cells. Exports Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), ubiquitous environmental contaminants (<span id=""ref34548022.16519321"" class=""cite"">Vach&eacute; <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). When flies are exposed to benzo[a]pyrene or to ambient air polluted by higher or lower PAH concentrations, P-gp expression was induced (<span id=""ref34548022.16519321"" class=""cite"">Vach&eacute; <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PGP65 of <em>Drosophila melanogaster </em>(Fruit fly)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.33"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.33&tcname=">3.A.1.201.33</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB14 of 1247 aas and an MCMC domain arrangement. Transports malate and auxins (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB14 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.34"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.34&tcname=">3.A.1.201.34</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB15 of 1240 aas with a domain order of MCMC.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB15 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.35"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.35&tcname=">3.A.1.201.35</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>P-glycoprotein, Pgp, ABCB1, of 1241 aas and 12 TMSs with a domain order MCMC.&nbsp; Exports geraniol and other monoterpenes. <span id="ref34549297.30535718" class="cite">Demissie <em>et al.</em> 2018</span> reported two structures of this homodimeric P-glycoprotein: an 
outward-facing conformational state with bound nucleotide and an 
inward-facing apo state, at resolutions of 1.9&thinsp;&Aring; and 3.0&thinsp;&Aring;, 
respectively. Features that could be clearly visualized include ATP binding with octahedral coordination of Mg<sup>2+</sup>;
 an inner chamber that significantly changes in volume with the aid of 
tight connections among transmembrane helices (TMSs) 1, 3, and 6; a 
glutamate-arginine interaction that stabilizes the outward-facing 
conformation; and extensive interactions between TMS1 and TMS3, a property
 that distinguishes multidrug transporters from floppases. These 
structural elements were proposed to participate in the mechanism of the 
transporter (<span id="ref34549297.30535718" class="cite">Demissie <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB1 of <em>Lavandula angustifolia</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.36"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.36&tcname=">3.A.1.201.36</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB21 of 1296 aas and a domain order of MCMC. Transports auxins (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB21 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.37"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.37&tcname=">3.A.1.201.37</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC protei, MDR1 of 1288 aas with 12 TMSs and a domain order of MCMC. Transports alkaloids (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR1 of <em>Coptis japonica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.38"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.38&tcname=">3.A.1.201.38</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fusion protein with a complete ABC transporter (domain order MCMC) followed by a complete probable phosphate uptake transpoter, a member of the DASS family (TC# 2.A.47).&nbsp; Many fusion proteins of this type are present in the NCBI protein database.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fusion protein of <em>Pochonia chlamydosporia</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.39"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.39&tcname=">3.A.1.201.39</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance-1, Mdr1, of 1464 aas and 12 TMSs in a 6 +6 TMS arrangement (domain order: M-C-M-C).&nbsp; Confers resistance to chloroquine (CQ) and primaquine (PQ), but mutations decrease resistance (<span id="ref34550031.29936038" class="cite">Kittichai <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mdr-1 of <em>Plasmodium vivax</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.4&tcname=">3.A.1.201.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The multidrug resistance/chloroquine resistance protein, PfMdr1 (ABCB1, Pgh1).&nbsp; PfMdr1 is the central system in <em>P. falciparum</em> artemisinin therapy regimen resistance (<span>Gil and Krishna 2017</span>).&nbsp; PfMDR1 is inhibited by 4 nM actelion (ACT)-213615 and actelion (ACT)-451840 (<span>Brunner <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>, <span>Brunner <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>, <span>Krause <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>),</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Protozoa</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pfmdr1 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em> (P13568)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.40"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.40&tcname=">3.A.1.201.40</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Serine protease/ABC transporter B family protein TagA of 1752 aas and 9 putative TMSs with one N-terminal TMS followed by a large hydrophilic region that may correspond to the protease domain, followed by 8 putative TMSs in a 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement and the ATPase domain. It is <span>required for general cell fate determination at 
the onset of development andis required for the specification of an initial 
population of prespore cells in which<em> tagA</em> is expressed. It is also required for 
normal SDF-2 signaling during spore encapsulation (<span id="ref34550106.12756178" class="cite">Good <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>;</span> <span id="ref34550107.17056744" class="cite">Cabral <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TagA of <em>Dictyostelium discoideum</em> (Slime mold)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.41"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.41&tcname=">3.A.1.201.41</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC type B transporter of 1207 aas and 12 TMSs.
