ATP-dependent transporter genes are associated with cystic development (<span id="ref34551439.32373094" class="cite">Bai <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of<em> Echinococcus granulosus</em> (tape worm)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.42"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.42&tcname=">3.A.1.201.42</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance protein 1, MDR1, of 1475 aas and 12 TMSs in an M-C-M-C arrangement (<span id="ref34552093.32867773" class="cite">Pimpat <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR1 of <em>Plasmodium malariae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.43"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.43&tcname=">3.A.1.201.43</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable MDR efflux pump of 1451 aas and 12 TMSs in a MCMC domain arrangement where each M domain has 6 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR exporter of<em> Marchantia polymorpha</em> (liverwort)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.44"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.44&tcname=">3.A.1.201.44</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-binding cassette transporter ABCB1, P-glycoprotein, MDR1, of 1339 aas and 12 TMSs. P-glycoprotein inhibitors differently affect <em>Toxoplasma gondii</em>, <em>Neospora caninum</em> and <em>Besnoitia</em><em> besnoiti </em>proliferation (<span id="ref34552973.33806177" class="cite">Larrazabal <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). These organisms are all obligatory intracellular protozoan parasites, and of them, tariquidar treatment affected proliferation only of <em>B. besnoiti</em> (<span id="ref34552973.33806177" class="cite">Larrazabal <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR1 of <em>Besnoitia besnoiti</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.45"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.45&tcname=">3.A.1.201.45</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB28 homolog of 732 aas and 6 N-terminal TMSs plus a C-terminal ATPase. It may play a role in the Cd<sup>2+</sup> stress response, possibly by pumping Cd<sup>2+</sup> out of the cell (<span id="ref34553900.34563781" class="cite">Zhu <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC homolog (M-C) of <em>Digitaria exilis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.46"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.46&tcname=">3.A.1.201.46</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance protein homolog 49 of 542 aas and 6 or 7 N-terminal&nbsp; TMSs (M-C). The sequence may be incomplete. Over-expression of the  Mdr49-like transporter in the brown planthopper, <em>Nilaparvata lugens</em>, confers resistance to imidacloprid (<span id="ref34553920.34596946" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mdr49-like of <em>Eumeta japonica</em>, the brown planthopper</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.47"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.47&tcname=">3.A.1.201.47</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Active peptide/heavy metal cation exporter, MDR4 or ABCB4, of 1365 aas and 7 TMSs in a 1 + 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement, followed by a large hydrophilic ATPase domain; it probably has an M-C domain order (<span id="ref34555310.35811673" class="cite">Wunderlich 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR4 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.48"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.48&tcname=">3.A.1.201.48</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative solute exporter of 925 aas and 7 TMSs in a 1 + 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Solute exporter of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.49"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.49&tcname=">3.A.1.201.49</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR7, ABCB7 active peptide exporter of 1049 aas and 6 TMSs (<span id="ref34555310.35811673" class="cite">Wunderlich 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR7 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.5&tcname=">3.A.1.201.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p>Auxin efflux pump Pgp1 (MDR1; ABCB1) (<a>Carraro <em>et al.</em> 2012</a>). Regulated by Twd1, an FK506-binding protein immunophilin prolyl/peptidyl isomerase; 8.A.11.1.1 (<a>Bouchard <em>et al</em>., 2006</a>).&nbsp; Involved in light-dependent hypocotyl elongation (<span>Sidler <em>et al.</em> 1998</span>). The combination of ibrutinib and paclitaxel can effectively antagonize ABCB1- or ABCC10-mediated paclitaxel resistance (<span>Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Pgp1 also confers herbicide tolerance to cycloheximide, toxic leves of the plant hormone N6-[2-isopentyl]adenine (2iP) and multiple herbicides (<span id="ref34548646.12640467" class="cite">Windsor <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>). It is up-regulated under salt stress conditions (<span id="ref34548798.30261913" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2018)</span>.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pgp1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Q9ZR72)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.50"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.50&tcname=">3.A.1.201.50</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The human ABCB5 exists in two forms (812 aas and 
1257 aas). The latter full length protein confers resistance to taxanes 
and anthracyclines (<span id="ref8365.22306008" class="cite">Kawanobe <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). Resistance and transport were demonstrated for paclitaxel and docetaxel as well. It is <span>present in a number of stem cells that acts as a 
regulator of cellular differentiation. It is able to mediate efflux from cells
 of the rhodamine dye and of the therapeutic drug doxorubicin (<span id="ref34552195.15899824" class="cite">Frank <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>; <span id="ref34552194.15205344" class="cite">Huang <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). It is specifically present in limbal stem cells, where it plays a key role in 
corneal development and repair (<span id="ref34552196.12960149" class="cite">Frank <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB5 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.51"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.51&tcname=">3.A.1.201.51</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance protein 1, ABCB1, of 495 aas and 6 TMSs in a 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement. This system confers triclabendazole resistance in <em>Fasciola hepatica</em> and shows dominant inheritance (<span id="ref34555868.36701396" class="cite">Beesley <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB1 of <em>Fasciola hepatica</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.6&tcname=">3.A.1.201.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Auxin efflux pump Pgp19 (MDR11; ABCB19; ABCB21) (regulated by Twd1, an FK506-binding protein immunophilin prolyl/peptidyl isomerase (TC# 8.A.11.1.1) (<span id="ref5852.16887800" class="cite">Bouchard <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pgp19 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Q9LJX2)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.7&tcname=">3.A.1.201.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Auxin efflux pump Pgp4; AbcB4; MDR4; PGP4 (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>) of 1286 aas and 12 TMSs in a MCMC domain arrangement.&nbsp; Functions in the basipetal redirection of auxin from the root tip. Strongly expressed in root cap and epidermal cells (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref5824">Terasaka <em>et al</em>., 2005</a>).&nbsp; Contributes to the basipetal transport in hypocotyls and root tips by 
establishing an auxin uptake sink in the root cap. Confers sensitivity 
to 1-N-naphthylphthalamic acid (NPA). Regulates root elongation, the
 initiation of lateral roots and the development of root hairs. Can 
transport IAA, indole-3-propionic acid, NPA syringic acid, vanillic acid
 and some auxin metabolites, but not 2,4-D and 1-naphthaleneacetic acid (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref5824">Terasaka <em>et al</em>., 2005</a>). Pgps and PINs (TC# 2.A.69) function in coordinated but independent auxin transport 
but also function interactively in a tissue-specific manner (<span id="ref34547442.17237354" class="cite">Blakeslee <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). Found in the plasma membranes of root hair cells (<span id="ref34547443.22492845" class="cite">Cho <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pgp4 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (MCMC) O80725</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.8&tcname=">3.A.1.201.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The aluminum chelate (aluminum sensitivity (ALS1)) protein; expressed in root vacuoles half-type ABC transporter (not induced by aluminum; <span id="ref5873.17171374" class="cite">Larsen <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Plants</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>ALS1 (M-C) of <i>Arabidopsis thaliana</i> (Q0WML0)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.201.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.201.9&tcname=">3.A.1.201.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Marine skate liver bile salt exporter, BSEP (1348 aas) (transports taurocholine in an ATP-dependent fashion (<span id="ref5738.11447010" class="cite">Cai <em>et al</em>., 2001</span>)) (Most similar to 3.A.1.201.2)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>BSEP of <i>Raja erinacea</i> (MC MC) (Q90Z35)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.202">3.A.1.202 The Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Exporter (CFTR) Family (ABCC)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.202.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.202.1&tcname=">3.A.1.202.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) (also called ABCC7); cyclic AMP-dependent chloride channel; also catalyzes nucleotide (ATP-ADP)-dependent glutathione and glutathione-conjugate flux (<span id="ref5777.12727866" class="cite">Kogan <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>) (may also activate inward rectifying K<sup>+</sup> channels). The underlying mechanism by which ATP hydrolysis controls channel  opening is described by <span id="ref5837.16554808" class="cite">Gadsby <em>et al.</em>, 2006</span>. The most common cause of cystic fibrosis (CF) is defective folding of a cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) mutant lacking Phe508 (DeltaF508) (<span id="ref5944.18304008" class="cite">Riordan, 2008</span>). The DeltaF508 protein appears to be trapped in a prefolded state with incomplete packing of the transmembrane segments, a defect that can be repaired by direct interaction with correctors such as corr-4a, VRT-325, and VRT-532 (<span id="ref5907.17911111" class="cite">Wang <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). CFTR interacts directly with MRP4 (3.A.1.208.7) to control Cl<sup>-</sup> secretion (<span id="ref5929.18045536" class="cite">Li <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). It has intrinsic adenylate kinase activity that may be of functional importance (<span id="ref6272.17965924" class="cite">Randak and Welsh, 2007</span>). The intact CFTR protein mediates ATPase rather than adenylate kinase activity (<span id="ref6028.18241200" class="cite">Ramjeesingh <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>). Regulated by Na<sup>+</sup>/H<sup>+</sup> exchange regulatory cofactors (NHERF; O14745; TC #8.A.24.1.1) (<span id="ref6616.19538313" class="cite">Seidler <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>). Regulated by protein kinase A and C phosphorylation (<span id="ref7028.19966305" class="cite">Csan&aacute;dy <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). It is also activated by membrane stretch induced by negative pressures (<span id="ref7087.20400957" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). TMS6 plays roles in gating and permeation (<span id="ref7248.20805575" class="cite">Bai <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>; <span id="ref8143.22042986" class="cite">2011</span>). The 3-D structure revealed the probable location of the channel gate (<span id="ref8114.21931164" class="cite">Rosenberg <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). Conformational changes opening the CFTR chloride channel pore, coupled to ATP-dependent gating, have been studied (<span id="ref8237.22234285" class="cite">Wang and Linsdell, 2012</span>). Alternating access to the transmembrane domain of CFTR has been demonstrated (<span id="ref8345.22303012" class="cite">Wang and Linsdell, 2012</span>).&nbsp;MRP4 and CFTR function in the regulation of cAMP and beta-adrenergic contraction in cardiac myocytes (<span id="ref8352.22381067" class="cite">Sellers <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). An asymmetric hourglass, comprising a shallow outward-facing vestibule that tapers toward a narrow "bottleneck" linking the outer vestibule to a large inner cavity extending toward the cytoplasmic extent of the lipid bilayer has been proposed (<span id="ref8520.22352759" class="cite">Norimatsu <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). Small molecule CFTR potentiators and correctors that overcome the efects of deleterious mutations have been identified (<span id="ref34548887.29680149" class="cite">Kym <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).&nbsp; The intracellular processing, trafficking, apical membrane localization,
 and channel function of CFTR are regulated by dynamic protein-protein 
interactions in a complex network.&nbsp;<span id="ref34548890.28869532" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2017</span> reviewed the macromolecular complex of CFTR, Na‚Å∫/H‚Å∫ exchanger 
regulatory factor 2 (NHERF2; TC# 8.A.24.1.2), and lysophosphatidic acids (LPA) receptor 2
 (LPA2; see TC# 9.A.14.2.5) at the apical plasma membrane of airway and gut epithelial cells.&nbsp; The structure, gating and regulation of the CFTR anion channel has been reviewed (<span id="ref34549152.30516439" class="cite">Csan&aacute;dy <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Mutants impairing ion conductance giving rise to CF, are partially corrected using the drug ivacaftor, and the structure of CFTR bound to this drug, which keeps the channel open has been solved by cryoEM (<span id="ref34549929.31221859" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The drug binds to a site with a hinge involved in channel gating. CFTR modulators
 reduce agonist-induced platelet activation and function; modulators, such as ivacaftor, present a promising therapeutic strategy for thrombocytopathies, including severe COVID-19 (<span id="ref34556164.36958745" class="cite">Asmus <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Chronic hypoxia reduces the activities of epithelial sodium and CFTR ion channels (<span id="ref34556296.37047450" class="cite">Wong <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).  CFTR function on ex vivo nasal epithelial cell models has been evaluated (<span id="ref34556297.37047546" class="cite">Terlizzi <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). <span style="font-weight: normal;">The therapeutic potential of phytochemicals for cystic fibrosis has been considered, and </span>curcumin, genistein, and resveratrol have been shown to be effective.&nbsp; These compounds&nbsp; have beneficial effects on transporter 
function, transmembrane conductivity, and overall channel activity (<span id="ref34556448.37191383" class="cite">Baharara <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). VX-661 and VX-445 exert effects on the plasma membrane expression of clinical CFTR variants (<span id="ref34556539.37253358" class="cite">McKee <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The Cl<sup>-</sup>-transporting proteins CFTR, SLC26A9 (TC# 2.A.53.2.15), and anoctamins
(ANO1; ANO6) (TC#s 1.A.17.1.1 and 1.4) appear to have more in common than initially suspected, as 
they all participate in the pathogenic process and clinical outcomes of 
airway and renal diseases in humans.&nbsp;<span id="ref34557187.37686084" class="cite">Kunzelmann <em>et al.</em> 2023</span> reviewed electrolyte transport in the 
airways and kidneys, and the role of CFTR, SLC26A9, and the anoctamins 
ANO1 and ANO6. Emphasis was placed on cystic fibrosis and 
asthma, as well as renal alkalosis and polycystic kidney disease. They summarize evidence indicating that CFTR is the 
only relevant secretory Cl<sup>-</sup> channel in airways under basal 
(nonstimulated) conditions and after stimulation by secretagogues. The expressions of ANO1 and ANO6 are 
important for the correct expression and function of CFTR. The Cl<sup>-</sup> transporter, SLC26A9, expressed in the airways, may have a reabsorptive rather than a Cl<sup>-</sup>-secretory function. In the renal collecting ducts, bicarbonate secretion occurs through the synergistic action of CFTR and the Cl<sup>-</sup>/HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> transporter SLC26A4 (pendrin; TC# 2.A.53.2.17), which is probably supported by ANO1. In autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), the 
secretory function of CFTR in renal cyst formation may have been 
overestimated, whereas ANO1 and ANO6 have been shown to be crucial 
in ADPKD and therefore represent new pharmacological targets for the 
treatment of polycystic kidney disease (<span id="ref34557187.37686084" class="cite">Kunzelmann <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; AlphaMissense pathogenicity predictions have been made against cystic fibrosis variants (<span id="ref34557761.38271453" class="cite">McDonald <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>). The selectivity filter is accessible from the cytosol through a large inner 
vestibule and opens to the extracellular solvent through a narrow 
portal. The identification of a chloride-binding site at the intra- and 
extracellular bridging point leads to a complete conductance 
path that permits dehydrated chloride ions to traverse the lipid 
bilayer (<span id="ref34557826.38381791" class="cite">Levring and Chen 2024</span>). The structural basis for CFTR inhibition by CFTR<sub>inh</sub>-172 has been presented (<span id="ref34557839.38422021" class="cite">Young <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>). Fat malabsorption in cystic fibrosis pathophysiology of cystic fibrosis in the gastrointestinal tract may play a role in disease symptoms (<span id="ref34557844.38429959" class="cite">McDonald <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CFTR of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.202.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.202.2&tcname=">3.A.1.202.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CFTR, an e<span>pithelial ion channel, plays a role in the regulation of epithelial ion and water transport 
and fluid homeostasis (<span id="ref34547434.20933420" class="cite">Bagnat <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>; <a href="http://www.uniprot.org/citations/23487313"><span id="ref34547435.23487313" class="cite">Navis <em>et al.</em> 2013</span></a>; <a href="http://www.uniprot.org/citations/25592226"><span id="ref34547436.25592226" class="cite">Navis and Bagnat 2015</span></a>). It mediates the transport of chloride ions across the cell membrane. Channel activity is coupled to ATP hydrolysis. The ion 
channel is also permeable to HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>; selectivity depends on 
the extracellular chloride concentration. CFTR exerts its function in part by 
modulating the activity of other ion channels and transporters, and it contributes to the regulation of the pH and the ion content of the 
epithelial fluid layer. It is required for normal fluid 
homeostasis in the gut (<a href="http://www.uniprot.org/citations/20933420"><span id="ref34547434.20933420" class="cite">Bagnat <em>et al.</em> 2010</span></a>) and for normal volume expansion of Kupffer's vesicle during 
embryonic development as well as for normal establishment of left-right body 
patterning (<a href="http://www.uniprot.org/citations/23487313"><span id="ref34547435.23487313" class="cite">Navis <em>et al.</em> 2013</span></a>; <a href="http://www.uniprot.org/citations/26432887"><span id="ref34547437.26432887" class="cite">Roxo-Rosa <em>et al.</em> 2015</span></a>). It is also required for normal resistance to infection by <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em> (<span id="ref34547438.20732993" class="cite">Phennicie <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CFTR of <em>Danio rerio </em>(Zebrafish)<em> (Brachydanio rerio)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.203">3.A.1.203 The Peroxysomal Fatty Acyl CoA Transporter (P-FAT) Family (ABCD)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.1&tcname=">3.A.1.203.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peroxisomal long chain fatty acyl (LCFA; especially branched chain fatty acids) transporter of 659 aas; associated with Zellweger Syndrome, ABCD3, PMP70, PXMP1.&nbsp; Can form heterodimers with ABCD1/ALD and ABCD2/ALDR, but the transporter is perdominantly a homodimer (<span id="ref34546057.17609205" class="cite">Hillebrand <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). Dimerization is 
necessary to form an active transporter. It interacts with PEX19.&nbsp; <em>abcd3</em>-knockout mice accumulate bile acid precursors suggesting that Abcd3 imports these compounds as CoA derivatives into peroxisomes (<span id="ref10244.17173541" class="cite">Visser <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).&nbsp; These mutants also accumulate pristanic acid suggesting that Abcd3 also imports branched chain substrates into peroxisomes (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The unfolded protein response (UPR) detects and restores deficits in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) protein folding capacity (<span id="ref34549812.31149896" class="cite">Torres <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Ceapins are aromatic compounds that specifically inhibit the UPR sensor ATF6alpha, an ER-tethered transcription factor, by retaining it at the ER. Ceapin's function is dependent on ABCD3. ABCD3 physically associates with ER-resident ATF6alpha in cells and in vitro in a Ceapin-dependent manner. Ceapins induce the neomorphic association of ER and peroxisomes by directly tethering the cytosolic domain of ATF6alpha to ABCD3's transmembrane regions without inhibiting or depending on ABCD3 transport activity (<span id="ref34549812.31149896" class="cite">Torres <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).&nbsp; Ceapins act through ABCD3 which binds to ATF6&alpha;. causing the ER to be tethered to the peroxysome, preventing ATF6&alpha; from carrying out its function as the unfolded protein response sensor (<span id="ref34549812.31149896" class="cite">Torres <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PMP70 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.10&tcname=">3.A.1.203.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Long chain fatty acid transporter consisting of a heterodimer of AbcD1 (719 aas) and AbcD2 (694 aas) (<span id="ref10774.20977778" class="cite">Xiong <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Alveolata (ciliates)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcD1/AbcD2 of <em>Tetrahymena thermophila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.11&tcname=">3.A.1.203.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative fatty acid exporter; homodimer (<span id="ref34543636.18634750" class="cite">Moussatova <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YddA (M-C) of <em>E. coli</em>; 561 aas</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.12&tcname=">3.A.1.203.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter, BclA, of 586 aas and 6 TMSs in a 2 + 2 + 2 arrangement in the N-terminus and the ABC domain in the C-terminus.&nbsp; It is a peptide transprter required for bacteroid differentiation.&nbsp; It catalyzes import of peptides called nodule-specific cysteine-rich (NCR) peptides in the 
symbiotic nodule cells which house the bacteroids. NCR peptides are 
related to antimicrobial peptides of innate immunity, but they induce the 
endosymbionts into a differentiated, enlarged, and polyploid state (<span id="ref34547241.26106901" class="cite">Guefrachi <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). BclA is required for the formation of differentiated and functional 
bacteroids in the nodules of the NCR peptide-producing <em>Aeschynomene</em> legumes. BclA catalyzes import of NCR peptides 
and provides protection against the antimicrobial activity of these 
peptides. Moreover, BclA can complement the role of the related <span class="highlight">BacA</span> transporter of Sinorhizobium meliloti, which has a similar symbiotic function in the interaction with Medicago legumes (<span id="ref34547241.26106901" class="cite">Guefrachi <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BclA of <em>Bradyrhizobium</em> sp. ORS 285</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.13&tcname=">3.A.1.203.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glycosomal ABC transporter of 683 aas and 6 N-terminal TMSs followed by the ATPase domain. Insertion into the glycosomal membrane is facilitated by the chaparone/receptor, Pex19 (<span id="ref34547559.16754359" class="cite">Yernaux <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glycosomal ABC half transporter of <em>Trypanosoma brucei</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.14&tcname=">3.A.1.203.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glycosomal ABC transporter of 641 aas and 6 N-terminal TMSs followed by 
the ATPase domain. Insertion into the glycosomal membrane is facilitated
 by the chaparone/receptor, Pex19 (<span id="ref34547559.16754359" class="cite">Yernaux <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC half transporter of <em>Trypanosoma brucei </em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.15&tcname=">3.A.1.203.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCD1 transporter of 766 aas and 6 TMSs. Similar to human patients with X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD), zebrafish <em>abcd1 </em>mutants have elevated very long chain fatty acid levels, and CNS development was disrupted, with hypomyelination in the spinal cord, abnormal patterning, decreased numbers of oligodendrocytes, and impaired motor function followed by increased cell death (<span>Strachan <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Expression of human ABCD1 in zebrafish oligodendrocytes rescued apoptosis in the <em>abcd1</em> mutant (<span>Strachan <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCD1 of <em>Danio rerio </em>(Zebrafish) <em>(Brachydanio rerio)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.3&tcname=">3.A.1.203.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p>The peroxysomal long chain fatty acid (LCFA) half transporter, ABCD1 (ALD, ALDP, the X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD or ALDP) protein) (functions as a homodimer and accepts acyl-CoA esters (<a>van Roermund <em>et al.</em> 2008</a>)). It transports C24:0 and C26:0 fatty acids and their CoA-derivatives as substrates (<a>van Roermund <em>et al.</em>, 2011</a>; <span id="ref34555681.36374178" class="cite">Jia <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp; ABCD1 deficiency or mutation is associated with plasma and tissue elevation of C24:0 and C26:0 accompanied by demyelination and inflamation (<a>Baarine <em>et al.</em> 2012).</a>&nbsp; X-ALD is a recessive neurodegenerative disorder that
affects the brain's white matter and is associated with adrenal insufficiency. It is characterized
by abnormal function of peroxisomes, which leads to an accumulation of very long-chain fatty
acids (VLCFA) in plasma and tissues, especially in the cortex of the adrenal glands and the white
matter of the central nervous system, causing demyelinating disease and adrenocortical insufficiency
(Addison's disease or X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD) (<span>Kallabi <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>; <span>Andreoletti <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>) The system forms heterodimers with PMP70 (ABCD3; TC#3.A.1.203.1) (<span>Hillebrand <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). X-ALD, the most common peroxisomal disorder, results from mutations in ABCD1 (ALDP) (<span>Margoni <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp;The structure and function of the ABCD1 variant database have been described (<span id="ref34554360.35053399" class="cite">Mallack <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). This peroxisomal very long chain fatty acid (VLCFA) transporter is central to fatty acid catabolism and lipid biosynthesis. Its dysfunction underlies toxic cytosolic accumulation of VLCFAs, progressive demyelination, and neurological impairment including X-ALD.&nbsp;<span id="ref34554387.35013584" class="cite">Le <em>et al.</em> 2022</span> presented cryo-EM structures of ABCD1 in phospholipid nanodiscs in a nucleotide bound conformation open to the peroxisomal lumen and an inward facing conformation open to the cytosol at up to 3.5 &Aring; resolution, revealing details of its transmembrane cavity and ATP- dependent conformational spectrum. They identified features distinguishing ABCD1 from its closest homologs and showed that coenzyme A (CoA) esters of VLCFAs modulate ABCD1 activity in a species dependent manner. A transport mechanism was suggested in which the CoA moieties of VLCFA-CoAs enter the hydrophilic transmembrane domain while the acyl chains extend out into the surrounding membrane bilayer. The structures help rationalize disease causing mutations (<span id="ref34554387.35013584" class="cite">Le <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp;Three cryogenic EM structures of ABCD1: the apo-form, substrate- and ATP-bound forms have been solved (<span id="ref34554939.35676282" class="cite">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Distinct from what was seen in the previously reported ABC transporters, the two symmetric molecules of behenoyl coenzyme A (C22:0-CoA) cooperatively bind to the transmembrane domains (TMDs). For each C22:0-CoA, the hydrophilic 3'-phospho-ADP moiety of the CoA portion inserts into one TMD, with the succeeding pantothenate and cysteamine moiety crossing the inter-domain cavity, whereas the hydrophobic fatty acyl chain extends to the opposite TMD. Structural analysis combined with biochemical assays illustrated snapshots of the ABCD1-mediated substrate transport cycle (<span id="ref34554939.35676282" class="cite">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp;<span id="ref34555681.36374178" class="cite">Jia <em>et al.</em> 2022</span> reported the cryo-EM structure of human ALDP at 3.4 &Aring; resolution. ALDP exhibits a cytosolic-facing conformation. Compared to other lipid ATP-binding cassette transporters, ALDP has two substrate binding cavities formed within the transmembrane domains. Such structural organization may be suitable for the coordination of VLCFAs. X-ALD is caused by a mutation in the ABCD1 gene, encoding a peroxisomal protein, which has various clinical manifestations and a rapid progression from initial symptoms to fatal inflammatory demyelination (<span id="ref34555728.36384734" class="cite">Yu <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Structural insights into substrate recognition and translocation of human peroxisomal ABC transporter, ALDP, have appeared (<span id="ref34556102.36810450" class="cite">Xiong <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LCFA transporter ABCD1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.4&tcname=">3.A.1.203.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The BacA (Rv1819c) porter (selective for the uptake of bleomycin and antimicrobial peptides) (essential for maintenance of extended chronic infection) (<span id="ref6478.18996991" class="cite">Domenech <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BacA of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis </em>(M-C)&nbsp;(Q50614)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.5&tcname=">3.A.1.203.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peroxisomal importer, Comatose, of substrates for &beta;-oxidation (transports fatty acids and precursors 2,4-dichlorophenoxybutyric acid (2,4-DB) and indole butyric acid (IBA) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref6559">Dietrich <em>et al.</em>, 2009; </a><span id="ref10244.17173541" class="cite">Visser <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). The peroxisomal fatty acyl-CoA transporter, Comatose (CTS, ABCD1, ABCD1, ABCC1, PED3, Pxa1; 1337aas) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref7365">Nyathi <em>et al.</em>, 2010</a>) determines germination potential and fertility and is essential for acetate metabolism (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9200">Linka and Esser 2012</a>).&nbsp; It associates with long chain fatty acyl-CoA synthetases (LACS6 (Q8LPS1) and LACS7 (Q8LKS5) and has intrinsic acyl CoA thiesterase activity (<span id="ref10140.23288899" class="cite">De Marcos Lousa <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). It has been proposed that it transports and hydrolyzes acyl-CoA esters, releasing a non-esterified fatty acid into the peroxisomal matrix which then needs to be re-activated by peroxisomal LACS6 or LACS7 (<span id="ref10244.17173541" class="cite">Visser <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). Mutagenesis of three residues in TMS 9 differentially affected the ATPase and thioesterase activities (<span id="ref34549990.31324846" class="cite">Carrier <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Comatose of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Q94FB9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.6&tcname=">3.A.1.203.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span class="RECOMMENDED"><span class="FULL">Peroxisomal long-chain fatty acid/oleic acid importer, PXA1 (Pat2)/PXA2 (Pat1) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref7363">Lamping <em>et al.</em>, 2010</a>; <a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref7416">van Roermund <em>et al.</em>, 2011</a>).&nbsp; PXA1 and PXA2 are two half-ABC transport subunits that can form a heterodimer. They are of 870 and 853 aas, respectively, both probably with 6 TMSs in a 1 + 2 + 2 + 1 TMS arrangement. Oxidation of its substrates requires the peroxysomal fatty acyl CoA ligase, suggesting that the free acids are the transported substrates. &nbsp;&nbsp; <br /></span></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PXA1/PXA2 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </em><br />PXA1 (MC) (P41909)<br />PXA2 (MC) (P34230)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.7&tcname=">3.A.1.203.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peroxisomal fatty acid transporter, ABCD2, ALD1, ALDL1, ALDR, or ALDRP. Transports C22:0 and different unsaturated very long-chain fatty acyl-CoA derivatives including C24:6 and especially C22:6 (<span id="ref7416.21145416" class="cite">van Roermund <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). The loss of AbcD2 results in greater oxidative stress in murine adrenal cells than the loss of abcd1 (<span id="ref34546549.17260006" class="cite">Lu <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). Based on the 2.85 &Aring; resolution crystal structure of the mitochondrial ABC transporter, ABCB10,&nbsp;<span id="ref34547171.28737695" class="cite">Andreoletti <em>et al.</em> 2017</span> proposed structural models for all three peroxisomal ABCD proteins. The model specifies the positions of the transmembrane and coupling helices and highlights functional motifs and putatively important amino acyl residues.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCD2 (M-C) of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (Q9UBJ2)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.8&tcname=">3.A.1.203.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peroxisomal/chloroplast fatty acyl CoA transporter, ABCD2 (<span id="ref9200.22645564" class="cite">Linka and Esser 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCD2 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.203.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.203.9&tcname=">3.A.1.203.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCD4, PMP70-related, P70R, PMP69 or PXMP1L of 606 aas.&nbsp; Forms homo- and heterodimers.&nbsp; May be involved in intracellular processing of vitamin B<sub>12</sub> (cobalamin), possibly by playing a role in the lysosomal release of vitamin B<sub>12</sub> into the 
cytoplasm.&nbsp; Defects cause <a href="http://www.uniprot.org/diseases/DI-03558">Methylmalonic aciduria and homocystinuria type cblJ</a> (MAHCJ), a disorder of cobalamin metabolism characterized by decreased levels of
 the coenzymes adenosylcobalamin (AdoCbl) and methylcobalamin (MeCbl) (<span id="ref34544335.22922874" class="cite">Coelho <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).&nbsp; The amino treminal region determines the subcellular localization of this and other ABC
subfamily D proteins (<span id="ref34544336.19010322" class="cite">Kashiwayama <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>). Maybe involved in intracelluar processing of Vitamin D (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCD4 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.204">3.A.1.204 The Eye Pigment Precursor Transporter (EPP) Family (ABCG)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.1&tcname=">3.A.1.204.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Eye pigment precursor transporter, White.&nbsp; Part of a membrane-spanning permease system 
necessary for the transport of pigment precursors into pigment cells 
responsible for eye color. White dimerize with Brown for the transport 
of guanine. The Scarlet (TC# 3.A.1.204.17) and White complex transports a metabolic 
intermediate (such as 3-hydroxy kynurenine) from the cytoplasm into the 
pigment granules (<span id="ref10173.11294610" class="cite">Mackenzie <em>et al.</em> 2000</span>).&nbsp; The White and Scarlet proteins are located in the
 membranes of pigment granules within pigment cells and retinula cells 
of the compound eye.&nbsp; Somatic knockouts of white in the noctuid moth, <em>Helicoverpa armigera</em> block pigmentation of the
egg, first instar larva and adult eye, but germ-line knockouts of white are recessive lethal in the
embryo (<span id="ref34546356.28053351" class="cite">Khan <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals, yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>White of <em>Drosophila melanogaster</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.10&tcname=">3.A.1.204.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcH homologue</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcH homologue of <em>Caernorhabditis elegans</em>&nbsp;(Q18900)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.11&tcname=">3.A.1.204.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcG Homologue</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcG of <em>Physcomitrella patens </em>(A9SCA8)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.12&tcname=">3.A.1.204.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.204.12"></a></p>
<p>The intracellular sterol transporter, ABCG1 (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref8312">Tarling and Edwards, 2011</a>).&nbsp;Involved in cell signalling, creation of membrane asymmetry and apoptosis (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref8684">Quazi and Molday, 2011</a>). Promotes cholesterol efflux from macrophages and other cells to the mature forms of HDL (HDL2 and HDL3) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref8848">Voloshyna and Reiss, 2011</a>).&nbsp; Plays a role in arteriosclerosis (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9566">M&uuml;nch <em>et al.</em> 2012</a>).&nbsp; The diverse functions in various cell types have been reviewed by Tarling (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9611">2013</a>).&nbsp; Many mammals have two isoforms, long and short, but mice have only the short isoform (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9615">Burns <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).&nbsp; Residues have been identified that play roles in stability, oligomerization and trafficking (<span id="ref10484.24320932" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; Both the full-length and the short isoforms of ABCG1
can dimerize with ABCG4 (3.A.1.204.20) (<a class="reflink" href="../../search/result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref34545410">Hegyi and Homolya 2016</a>). Cholesterol-binding motifs in the membrane may allow transport of different cholesterol pools (<span id="ref34549214.30519876" class="cite">Dergunov <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). It is required for maintenance of cellular cholesterol levels (<span id="ref34553579.34404721" class="cite">Sun <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). It plays a role in the occurrance of some lipids and protein in HDL such as 7-ketocholesterol and some essential proteins such as alpha-1-antitrypsin, apoA-4, apoB-100, and serum amyloid A (SAA) (<span id="ref34554584.35234362" class="cite">Wu <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). ABCG1-mediated cholesterol efflux influences coronary 
atherosclerosis and cardiovascular risk in Rheumatoid Arthritis (<span id="ref34556199.36996698" class="cite">Karpouzas <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em>&nbsp;(P45844)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.13&tcname=">3.A.1.204.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The ABCG1 transporter homologue&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Slime Molds</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG1 of <em>Dictyostelium discoideum</em>&nbsp;(Q55DW4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.14&tcname=">3.A.1.204.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter-like protein ECU11_1340</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ECU11_1340 of <em>Encephalitozoon cuniculi</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.15&tcname=">3.A.1.204.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR efflux pump, ABCG2a.&nbsp; Exports canonical MDR susbtrates such as 
calcein-AM, bodipy-verapamil, bodipy-vinblastine and mitoxantrone (<span id="ref9272.23124201" class="cite">Gokirmak <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG2a of <em>Stronglycentrotus purpuratus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.16&tcname=">3.A.1.204.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Half ABC transporter, ABCG10.&nbsp; Secretes isoflavinoids including precursors of the phytoalexin, medicarpin (<span id="ref9637.23314816" class="cite">Banasiak <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). <span style="font-weight: normal;">GmABCG5, an ATP-binding cassette G transporter, is involved in the iron deficiency response in soybean (<span id="ref34557693.38250443" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG10 of <em>Medicago truncatula</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.17&tcname=">3.A.1.204.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Scarlet.&nbsp; Part of a membrane-spanning permease system necessary for the transport 
of pigment precursors into pigment cells responsible for eye color. The scarlet and white (TC# 3.A.1.204.1) complex probably transports a metabolic intermediate (such as 
3-hydroxy kynurenine) from the cytoplasm into the pigment granules (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10172">Tearle <em>et al.</em> 1989</a>). These proteins are located in the
 membranes of pigment granules within pigment cells and retinula cells 
of the compound eye (<span id="ref10173.11294610" class="cite">Mackenzie <em>et al.</em> 2000</span>). Knockouts of scarlet in the noctuid moth, <em>Helicoverpa armigera</em>, are viable and produce pigmentless first instar larvae and yellow adult
eyes lacking xanthommatin (<span id="ref34546356.28053351" class="cite">Khan <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Scarlet of <em>Drosophila melanogaster</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.18&tcname=">3.A.1.204.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Brown.&nbsp; Part of a membrane-spanning permease system necessary for the transport 
of pigment precursors into pigment cells responsible for eye color. 
Brown and white (TC# 3.A.1.204.1) dimerize for the transport of guanine (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10174">Campbell and Nash 2001</a>).&nbsp; Knockouts of brown in the noctuid moth, <em>Helicoverpa armigera</em>, show no phenotypic effects on viability or
pigmentation (<a class="reflink" href="http://tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref34546356">Khan <em>et al.</em> 2017</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Brown of <em>Drosophila melanogaster</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.19&tcname=">3.A.1.204.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter G family member 3, ABCG3; ABCG.3.  Also called the <span class="FULL_NAME">white-brown complex homologue protein 3,</span> WBC3, of 730 aas. It is a homologue of animal eye pigment precursor uptake porters.&nbsp; The white, scarlet (TC# 3.A.1.204.17), and brown (3.A.1.204.18) genes of <em>Drosophila melanogaster</em> encode 
ABC transporter proteins involved with the uptake and storage of metabolic 
precursors to the red and brown eye colour pigments (<span id="ref10173.11294610" class="cite">Mackenzie <em>et al.</em> 2000</span>). It may also transport sesquiterpenes, defensive agents or pheromones.
 (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>). Restriction of access to the central cavity is a major contributor to substrate selectivity in plant ABCG transporters (<span id="ref34556162.36952129" class="cite">Paku≈Ça <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). See also, <span id="ref34557296.37759481" class="cite">Salgado <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG3 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.2&tcname=">3.A.1.204.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Drug resistance transporter, ABCG2 (MXR; ABCP; BCRP) (human breast cancer resistance protein, BCRP) (<span>Moitra <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). It exports urate and haem in haempoietic cells (<a>Latunde-Dada <em>et al</em>., 2006</a>) as well as cytotoxic agents (mitoxantrone, flavopiridol, methotrexate, 7-hydroxymethotrexate, methotrexate diglutamate, topotecan, rosurvastatin, and resveratrol), fluorescent dyes (Hoechst 33342) and other toxic substances (PhIP and pheophorbide a) (&Ouml;zvegy-<a>Laczka <em>et al</em>., 2005</a>; <span id="ref34550101.25475361" class="cite">Nigam 2015)</span>. It also transports folate and sterols: estradiol, and probably cholesterol, progesterone, testosterone and tamoxifen (<a>Janvilisri <em>et al</em>., 2003</a>; <a>Breedveld <em>et al</em>., 2007</a>).  It is a homotetramer (<a>Xu <em>et al</em>., 2004</a>).  It forms a homodimer bound via a disulfide bond at Cys-603 which stabilizes the protein against ubiquitin-mediated degradation in proteosomes (<a>Wakabayashi <em>et al</em>., 2007</a>), and can for dodecamers with 12 subunits (<span>Xu <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). It has 6 established TMSs with the N- and C- termini inside (<a>Wang <em>et al.</em>, 2008</a>). The following drugs are exported from human breast cancer cell line MCF-7: miloxantrone, daunorubicin, doxorubicin and rhodamine123).  Also transports reduced folates and mono-, di- and tri-glutamate derivatives of folic acid and methotrexate (<a>Assaraf <em>et al</em>., 2006</a>). It is an active glutathione efflux pump (<span>Brechbuhl <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). Mutations in ABCG2 cause hyperuricemia and gout , which led to the identification of urate as a physiological subsrate for ABCG2; it catalyzes elimination of urate across the renal tubular apical membrane (<span>Prestin <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp;Zafirlukast antagonizes ABCG2 multidrug resistance (<span>Sun <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).&nbsp;Inhibited by Sildenafil (<span>Shi <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>) and lapatinib derivatives (<span>Sodani <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).&nbsp; Mutation of basic residues can increase or decrease drug efflux activities (<span>Cai <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).&nbsp; A substrate of ABCG2 is d-luciferin, allowing bioluminescent immaging of drug efflux across the blood-brain barrier.&nbsp; Inhibitors include Ko143, gefetinib and nilotinib (<span>Bakhsheshian <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; Fluorescent substrates have been identified (<span>Strouse <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; Telabinib reverses chemotheraputic MDR mediated by ABCG2 (<span>Sodani <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Residues involved in protein trafficking and drug transport activity have been identified (<span>Haider <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; The 3-d structure in the inward facing conformation has been solved (<span>Rosenberg <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp;<span>Durmus <em>et al.</em> 2015</span> and&nbsp;<span>Westover and Li 2015</span> have reviewed BCRP-mediated transport of cancer chemotheraputic agents.&nbsp; A role for the C2-sequence of the ABCG2
linker region in ATP binding and/or hydrolysis coupled to drug efflux has been proposed (<span>Macalou <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; Functions at the blood:placenta barrier of the mouse (<span>Kumar <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). The Q141K variant exhibits
decreased functional expression and thus increased drug accumulation and decreased urate secretion, and the R482 position, which plays
a role the substrate specificity, is located in one of the substrate binding
pockets (<span>L&aacute;szl&oacute; <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Naturally occurring single nucleotide polymorphisms in humans giving rise to amino acyl residue substitutions in the transmembrane domains result in impared transport of Lucifer Yellow and estrone sulfate (<span>Sj&ouml;stedt <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). A cryoEM structure revealed two cholesterol molecules bound in the multidrug-binding pocket that is located in a central, hydrophobic, inward-facing translocation pathway between TMSs. A multidrug recognition and transport mechanism was proposed, and disease-causing single nucleotide polymorphisms were  rationalized. The structural basis of cholesterol recognition by G-subfamily ABC transporters was also revealed (<span>Taylor <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Catalyzes efflux of ochratoxin A (OTA) (<span>Qi <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Penylheteroaryl-phenylamide scaffold allows ABCG2 inhibition. 4-Methoxy-N-(2-(2-(6-methoxypyridin-3-yl)-2H-tetrazol-5-yl)phenyl)benzamide (43) exhibited a highest potency (IC50=61nM)), selectivity, low intrinsic toxicity, and it reversed the ABCG2-mediated drug resistance at 0.1muM (<span>K&ouml;hler <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). ABCG2 acts in concert with ABCA1, ABCB1 and ABCG4 to efflux amyloid-&beta; 
peptide (A&beta;) from the brain across the blood-brain barrier (BBB) (<span>Kuai <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).  Inhibited by dacomitinib (<span>Fan <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). A specific inhibitor, CCTA-1523, is a potent, selective and reversible modulator of ABCG2 (<span>Patel <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Exports uric acid (urate), and its loss promotes  onset of hyperuricemia.&nbsp; It has potential as a regulator of Gout (<span>Fujita and Ichida 2018</span>). High resolution cryo-EM structures of human ABCG2 bound to synthetic derivatives of the fumitremorgin C-related inhibitor Ko143 or the multidrug resistance modulator tariquidar have been solved (<span>Jackson <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Both compounds are bound to the central, inward-facing cavity of ABCG2, blocking access for substrates and preventing conformational changes required for ATP hydrolysis. The high resolutions allowed for de novo building of the entire transporter and also revealed tightly bound phospholipids and cholesterol interacting with the lipid-exposed surface of the TMSs (<span>Jackson <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Multiple drug binding pockets and residues involved in binding have been identified (<span>Cox <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). The third transmembrane helix and adjacent regions of ABCG2 may interact with AT1 receptor antagonists, giving rise to drug-drug interactions in multi-drug regimens (<span>Ripperger <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). The system is inhibitied by hetero aryl phenyl inhititors (<span id="ref34547779.29407974" class="cite">K&ouml;hler <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). It is present in the blood-brain, blood-testis and maternal-fetal barriers, and cryoEM of a mutant shows the protein in a substrate-bound pre-translocation state and an ATP-bound post-translocation state (<span id="ref34549084.30405239" class="cite">Manolaridis <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). A single molecule of estrone-3-sulfate (E1S) is bound in a central, hydrophobic, cytoplasm-facing cavity about halfway across the membrane. Only one molecule of E1S can bind in the observed binding mode. In the ATP-bound state, the substrate-binding cavity has collapsed while an external cavity has opened to the extracellular side of the membrane. The ATP-induced conformational changes include rigid-body shifts of the transmembrane domains, pivoting of the nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs), and a change in the relative orientation of the NBD subdomains (<span id="ref34549084.30405239" class="cite">Manolaridis <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). This shows how the energy of ATP binding extrudes E1S and other substrates, and suggests that the size and binding affinity of compounds are important for distinguishing substrates from inhibitors. Its structure, mechanism and inhibitory propensity have been reviewed (<span id="ref34549130.30464049" class="cite">Kapoor <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Y6, an Epigallocatechin Gallate Derivative, Reverses ABCG2-Mediated Mitoxantrone Resistance (<span id="ref34549426.30687102" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). ABCG2 confers resistance to several cancer treatments. Photodynamic therapy (PDT) is an anti-cancer method involving the use of light-activated photosensitisers to induce oxidative stress and cell death in cancers, but ABCG2 can efflux photosensitisers (<span id="ref34550426.31639455" class="cite">Khot <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Regorafenib sensitized MDR colon cancer cells to BCRP substrates by increasing&nbsp; intracellular accumulation without changes in the expression level or the subcellular distribution of BCRP in the cells exposed to regorafenib. Regorafenib stimulates BCRP ATPase activity and promotes a stable interaction between regorafenib and the transmembrane domain of BCRP (<span id="ref34550439.30392788" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Several potent inhibitors, effective in the millimicromolar range have been identified (<span id="ref34550899.31990564" class="cite">Zou <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Licochalcone A selectively resensitizes ABCG2-overexpressing multidrug-resistant cancer cells to chemotherapeutic drugs (<span id="ref34551369.32347726" class="cite">Wu <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The GXXXG motif promotes proper packing of the TMSs in the functional ABCG2 homodimer (<span id="ref34551467.15260487" class="cite">Polgar <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). Molecular dynamics simulations have provided insight into the steps of the substrate transport process and its regulation by cholesterol (<span id="ref34552056.32979053" class="cite">Nagy <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Drug binding cavities other than the central binding site as well as a putative dynamic transport pathway for substrates with variable structures have been revealed. Membrane cholesterol accelerated drug transport by promoting the closure of cytoplasmic protein regions. ABCG2 is present in all major biological barriers and drug-metabolizing organs, influences the pharmacokinetics of numerous clinically applied drugs, and plays a key role in uric acid extrusion (<span id="ref34552056.32979053" class="cite">Nagy <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The first intracellular loop is essential for the catalytic cycle (<span id="ref34552306.33169382" class="cite">Khunweeraphong and Kuchler 2020</span>). While all other human ABCG transporters are specific for lipids, ABCG2 has a network of residues that may confer extra conformational flexibility, enabling it to transport a wider array of substrates (<span id="ref34552964.33809494" class="cite">Mitchell-White <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). VKNG-1, an inhibitor of ABCG2, may, in combination with certain anticancer drugs, provide a treatment to overcome ABCG2-mediated MDR colon cancers (<span id="ref34553868.34572902" class="cite">Narayanan <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Sophoraflavanone (SFG) may be&nbsp; an effective inhibitor of ABCG2 to improve the efficacy of therapeutic drugs in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) (<span id="ref34553881.34496204" class="cite">Wu <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). It transports estrone 3-sulfate and many drugs (<span id="ref34555185.36016719" class="cite">Dudas <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). ZIn both domestic and nondomestic cats (felids) have mutationally alterred ABCG2 proteins and consequently experience fluoroquinolone-induced retinal phototoxicity (<span id="ref34555789.36553444" class="cite">Gochenauer <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). The multifunctionality of ABCG2 has been established, and details of the potential therapeutic role of ABCG2 in pan-cancer has been considered (<span id="ref34555828.36555598" class="cite">Lyu <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).<strong> </strong>ABCB6, ABCG2, FECH and CPOX are expressed in meningioma tissue (<span id="ref34555854.36612300" class="cite">Spille <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). ABCG2 limits the efficacy of transcriptional CDK inhibitors, and multiple kinase inhibitors disrupt ABCG2 transport 
function, thereby synergizing with CDK inhibitors (<span id="ref34556409.37147730" class="cite">van der Noord <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The efflux of anti-psychotics through the blood-brain barrier (BBB) via this system has been demonstrated (<span id="ref34556525.37239445" class="cite">Nasyrova <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The structural basis of the allosteric inhibition of human ABCG2 by nanobodies has been determined (<span id="ref34557372.37597690" class="cite">Irobalieva <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; Imperatorin restores chemosensitivity of multidrug-resistant cancer cells by antagonizing ABCG2-mediated drug transport (<span id="ref34557606.38004460" class="cite">Wu <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; <span style="font-weight: normal;">ABCG2 may be a molecular target for acute myeloid leukemia (<span id="ref34557751.38255216" class="cite">Damiani and Tiribelli 2024</span>).</span></p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><br /></strong></span></p>
<pre><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><em>	</em></strong></span></pre></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals, yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG2 (ABCP) of <em>Homo sapiens </em>(Q9UNQ0)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.20&tcname=">3.A.1.204.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-binding cassette sub-family G member 4, ABCG4, half transporter of 646 aas.&nbsp; ABCG4 can form homodimers, but also
heterodimers with its closest relative, ABCG1. Both the full-length and the short isoforms of ABCG1
can dimerize with ABCG4, whereas the ABCG2 multidrug transporter is unable to form a heterodimer
with ABCG4 (<span>Hegyi and Homolya 2016</span>). ABCG4 is
predominantly localized to the plasma membrane. AbcG4 acts in concert with ABCA1, ABCB1 and ABCG2 to efflux amyloid-&beta; 
peptide (A&beta;) from the brain across the blood-brain barrier (BBB) (<span>Kuai <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). It is involved in macrophage lipid homeostasis (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG4 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.21&tcname=">3.A.1.204.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pigment precursor transporter of 644 aas, Ok. In the noctuid moth, <em>Helicoverpa armigera</em>, Ok transports precursors from the cytoplasm into the pigment granules. Knockouts of Ok are viable and produce translucent larval cuticle and black eyes (<span id="ref34546356.28053351" class="cite">Khan <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Ok of <em>Bombyx mori</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.22&tcname=">3.A.1.204.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Root heterodimeric half ABCG subfamily lipid&nbsp; exporter, STR (817 aas)/STR2 (727 aas). Each protein has an ATPase domain followed by a 6 TMS membrane domain.&nbsp; Exports lipids made from RAM2 (glycerol-3-phosphate acyltransferase)-catalyzed monoacylglycerols, allowing accumulation of extracellular lipids, possibly 2-monopalmitin (<span id="ref34546919.28596311" class="cite">Luginbuehl <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp; Found in the peri-arbuscular membrane and required for colonization by mutualistic mycorrhizal and parasitic fungi (<span id="ref34546918.28596307" class="cite">Jiang <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungi facilitate plant uptake of mineral nutrients and obtain organic nutrients such as sugars and fatty acids, from the plant, and this ABCG transporter is required to form the symbiosis. Co-overexpressing STR and STR2 led to higher accumulation of extracelular unstaurated lipid polyesters such as cutin monomers (<span id="ref34546918.28596307" class="cite">Jiang <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>STR/STR2 of <em>Medicago truncatula</em> (Barrel medic)<em> (Medicago tribuloides)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.23&tcname=">3.A.1.204.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Homo dimeric plasma membrane AbcG1 half ABC transporter of 633 aas and 6 TMSs.&nbsp; Actively exports volatile organic compounds (Benzenoids and phenylpropanoids such as methylbenzoate and benzyl alcohol, major VOC constituents emitted by flowers) from the flower cell cytoplasm to the external environment (<span id="ref34547010.28663500" class="cite">Adebesin <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp; May also export alcohol glycosides.&nbsp; Up regulated 100-fold in petunia flowers within the 24 hour period between bud and flower opening stages. Regulated by the ODORANT1 transcription factor (<span id="ref34547010.28663500" class="cite">Adebesin <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcG1 of <em>Petunia hybrida</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.24&tcname=">3.A.1.204.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Wax precursor (cuticular lipid) exporter of 678 aas and 6 TMSs, AbcG13 (<span id="ref34547010.28663500" class="cite">Adebesin <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcG13 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.25&tcname=">3.A.1.204.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG6 of 546 aas and 4 TMSs involved in phosholipid trafficing and drug export in <em>Leishmania tarentolae</em> (<span id="ref34547713.27485333" class="cite">Gonzalez-Lobato <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG6 of<em> Trypanosoma grayi</em> (C-M)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.26&tcname=">3.A.1.204.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter G family member 26, ABCG.26; AtABCG26 of 685 aas and 6 TMSs. Confers resistance to kanamycin (<span id="ref34548640.16116418" class="cite">Mentewab and Stewart 2005</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG19 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.28"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.28&tcname=">3.A.1.204.28</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG25 of 662 aas and 6 TMSs in a C-M domain arrangement.&nbsp; Transports abscisic acid, ABA, a plant hormone that influences <span>developmental processes, including seed and bud dormancy, the control of organ size and stomatal closure (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>). </span>Strigolactones promote the localisation of the
 ABA exporter ABCG25 at the plasma membrane in root epidermal cells of 
<em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (<span id="ref34556953.37519212" class="cite">Russo <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; Thus, a mechanism for ABA homeostasis regulation is proposed in the context of 
osmotic stress acclimation: the fine tuning by strigolactones of ABCG25 
localisation in root cells (<span id="ref34556953.37519212" class="cite">Russo <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; The cryo-EM structure and molecular mechanism used by the abscisic acid transporter, ABCG25, which regulates&nbsp;stomatal closure, seed germination and development, has been described (<span id="ref34557164.37666961" class="cite">Huang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). It was solved in an inward-facing apo conformation, an ABA-bound pre-translocation conformation and an outward-facing occluded conformation. A 'gate-flipper' translocation model was proposed (<span id="ref34557164.37666961" class="cite">Huang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The structural basis for abscisic acid efflux mediated by ABCG25 in <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> has been described (<span id="ref34557285.37666962" class="cite">Ying <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>; <span id="ref34557164.37666961" class="cite">Huang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG25 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.29"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.29&tcname=">3.A.1.204.29</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG14 of 648 aas and 6 TMSs in a C + M domain arrangement.&nbsp; May transport cytokinins (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG14 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.3&tcname=">3.A.1.204.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC Transporter WHT-1</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Worm</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>WHT-1 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans </em>(Q11180)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.30"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.30&tcname=">3.A.1.204.30</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG16 of 736 aas and 6 TMSs in a C-M domain arrangement.&nbsp; Transports jasmonic acid (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG16 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.31"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.31&tcname=">3.A.1.204.31</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG6 of 727 aas and 6 TMSs in a CM domain arrangement. This transporter is an ABCG half-transporters that is required for synthesis of an effective suberin barrier in roots and seed coats, while ABCG2 and ABCG20 may serve the same function (<span id="ref34549446.25217507" class="cite">Yadav <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Seed coats of <em>abcg2 <span class="highlight">abcg6</span> abcg20</em> triple mutant plants had increased permeability to tetrazolium 
red and decreased suberin content. The root system of triple mutant 
plants was more permeable to water and salts in a zone complementary to 
that affected by the Casparian strip. Suberin of mutant roots and seed 
coats had distorted lamellar structure and reduced proportions of 
aliphatic components. Root wax from the mutant was deficient in 
alkylhydroxycinnamate esters (<span id="ref34549446.25217507" class="cite">Yadav <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG6 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.32"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.32&tcname=">3.A.1.204.32</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter, ABCG1 of 415 aas and 3 C-terminal TMSs.&nbsp; This sequence may be incomplete, being C-terminally truncated. MdABCG28 overexpression promoted shoot growth of<em> atabcg14</em> mutants (<span id="ref34550569.31744249" class="cite">Feng <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Expression and regulation by sex steroids in the Harderian gland of the Syrian hamster has been demonstrated (<span id="ref34550587.31780416" class="cite">Mares <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).
