It may be involved in protoporphyrin IX transport and of other intermediates in heme biosynthesis.&nbsp; This protein is 82% identical to the human otholog (TC# 3.A.1.204.2).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG2 of <em>Mesocricetus auratus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.4&tcname=">3.A.1.204.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The plant cuticular wax and/or lipid metabolite exporter, CER5; ABCG12; WBC12 (in the plasma membrane of epidermal cells; secretes wax to the plant surface) (<span id="ref5808.15499022" class="cite">Pighin <em>et al</em>., 2004; <span id="ref10453.19704564" class="cite">Panikashvili and Aharoni 2008</span></span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CER5 (C-M) of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Q9C8K2)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.40"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.40&tcname=">3.A.1.204.40</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC type G exporter of 961 aas and 8 TMSs in a 1 + 6 + 1 TMS arrangement.&nbsp; Expression of ATP-dependent transporter genes is induced during larval cyst development in protoscoleces (<span id="ref34551439.32373094" class="cite">Bai <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG transporter of <em>Echinococcus granulosus</em>.</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.41"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.41&tcname=">3.A.1.204.41</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG7 of 725 aas and 6 C-terminal TMSs. This protein is upregulated by drought in pigeon pea (<em>Cajanus cajan</em>) (<span id="ref34552722.33552725" class="cite">Niu <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG7 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.42"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.42&tcname=">3.A.1.204.42</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter G family member 10, ABCG10, of 590 aas and 6 C-terminal TMSs.&nbsp; In <em>Medicago truncatula</em>, the ortholog transports 4-coumarate and liquiritigenin, representing key branching points in the phenylpropanoid pathway, and possibly&nbsp; other lignin-derived aromatic compounds such as the phenylpropanoid-derived phytoalexin (<span id="ref34552908.28369642" class="cite">Biala <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG10 (C-M) of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.43"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.43&tcname=">3.A.1.204.43</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG! or ABCG2 of 660 aas and 6 C-terminal TMSs (C-M domain order). It may be a cell metabolite exporter (<span id="ref34555310.35811673" class="cite">Wunderlich 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG1 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.44"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.44&tcname=">3.A.1.204.44</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Drug resistance ABC exporter, NpABC2, of 1092 aas and 8 - 10 TMSs in a 1 (N-terminus) + 1 + 6 - 8 TMS (C-terminus) arrangement. NpABC2 plays a role in the drug resistance of <em>N. parvum</em> and affects its virulence (<span id="ref34555494.36077305" class="cite">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NpABC2 of <em>Botryosphaeria parva</em> (strain UCR-NP2) (Grapevine canker fungus) (<em>Neofusicoccum parvum</em>)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.5&tcname=">3.A.1.204.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The ABCG5 (sterolin-1)/ABCG8 (sterolin-2) heterodimeric neutral sterol (cholesterol and plant sterols) (e.g., sitosterol and lutein) (phosphoryl donors ATP &gt; CTP &gt; GTP &gt; UTP) exporter; present in the apical membranes of enterocytes and hepatocytes ((<span id="ref34552520.24036530" class="cite">Reboul 2013</span>). Cholesteryl oleate, phosphatidyl choline and enantiomeric cholesterol are poorly transported (mutation of either ABCG5 or ABCG8 cause sitosterolemia and coronary atherosclerosis) (<span>Zhang <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>; <span>Wang <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>; <span>2011</span>).&nbsp;It is involved in cell signalling, creation of membrane asymmetry and apoptosis (<span>Quazi and Molday, 2011</span>). The ABCG5/ABCG8 heterodimer (G5G8) mediates excretion of neutral sterols as well as the drug, Marinobufagenin, a Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup>-ATPase inhibitor, in the liver and
intestine (<span id="ref34550398.29582577" class="cite">Lan <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Mutations disrupting G5G8 cause sitosterolaemia, a disorder characterized by sterol
accumulation and premature atherosclerosis. <span>Lee <em>et al.</em> 2016</span> used crystallization in lipid bilayers to
determine the X-ray structure in a nucleotide-free state at 3.9 &Aring; resolution. The structure revealed a new
transmembrane fold that is present in a large and functionally diverse superfamily of ABC
transporters. The transmembrane domains are coupled to the nucleotide-binding sites by networks of
interactions that differ between the active and inactive ATPases, reflecting the catalytic asymmetry
of the transporter (<span>Lee <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). High expression levels of both ABCG5 and ABCG8 were observed in liver, the digestive tract and the mammary gland. The system plays roles in lipid and sterol intestinal absorption, biliary excretion, and lipid trafficking and excretion during lactation (<span>Viturro <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). ABCG5/G8 is active in the excretion of cholesterol and sterols into bile (<span id="ref34550648.15696852" class="cite">vanBerge-Henegouwen <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). Disruption of the unique ABCG-family NBD:NBD interface impacts both drug transport and ATP hydrolysis (<span id="ref34550948.31979415" class="cite">Kapoor <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Transmembrane polar relay drives the allosteric regulation for the ABCG5/G8 sterol transporter (<span id="ref34552302.33228147" class="cite">Xavier <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Rare mutations can give rise to tendon xanthoma along with tendosynovitis (<span id="ref34552541.30459115" class="cite">Wadsack <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). ABCG5/8 mediates secretion of neutral sterols into bile and the gut lumen, whereas G1 (TC# 3.A.1.204.12) transports cholesterol from macrophages to high-density lipoproteins (HDLs). Cryo-EM structures of human G5G8 in sterol-bound and human G1 in cholesterol- and ATP-bound states have been solved. Both transporters have a sterol-binding site that is accessible from the cytosolic leaflet. A second site is present midway through the transmembrane domains of ABCG5/G8. The Walker A motif of G8 adopts a unique conformation that accounts for the marked asymmetry in ATPase activities between the two nucleotide-binding sites of G5G8 (<span id="ref34553579.34404721" class="cite">Sun <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Residues have been mapped to the structural cores of TMSs), the NBD-TMD interface, and the interface between TMDs. They serve as sequence signatures to differentiate ABCG5/ABCG8 from other ABCG subfamily proteins, and some of them may contribute to substrate specificity of the ABCG5/ABCG8 transporter (<span id="ref34554644.35481657" class="cite">Pei and Cong 2022</span>). Structural analysis of cholesterol binding and sterol selectivity by ABCG5/G8 have been reported (<span id="ref34555485.35988751" class="cite">Farhat <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). <em>ABCG5/G8</em> gene region variants exert differential effects on lipid profiles, blood pressure status, and gallstone disease history (<span id="ref34556182.36981027" class="cite">Teng <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG5/ABCG8 of <em>Homo sapiens</em> <br /> ABCG5 (Q9H222) <br /> ABCG8 (Q9H221)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.6&tcname=">3.A.1.204.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The efflux porter for phosphatidylcholine and its analogues as well as toxic alkyl phospholipids, ABCG4 (<span id="ref6050.17542911" class="cite">Castanys-Munoz <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). Also promotes cholesterol efflux to the mature forms of HDL (HDL2 and HDL3) (<span id="ref8848.21352852" class="cite">Voloshyna and Reiss, 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Protozoa</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG4 of <em>Leishmania infantum</em> (A4HWI7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.7&tcname=">3.A.1.204.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance efflux pump, AbcG6, causes camptothecin-resistant parasites (<span id="ref5942.18243364" class="cite">Bosedasgupta <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Euglenozoa</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcG6 of <em>Leishmania donovani</em> (A8WEV1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.8&tcname=">3.A.1.204.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The epidermal plasma membrane cuticular lipid (wax) exporters, ABCG11/ABCG11 and ABCG11/ABCG12; 
ABCG11 is also called Wbc11; Desperado (DSO); COF1; PEL1. ABCG12 is also called CER5, WBC12 and D3 (<span id="ref10453.19704564" class="cite">Panikashvili and Aharoni 2008</span>).&nbsp; Required for the cuticle and pollen coat development by controlling 
cutin and possibly wax transport to the extracellular matrix. Involved in 
developmental plasticity and stress responses (<span id="ref6466.17727615" class="cite">Bird <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).&nbsp; <span class="highlight">ABCG11</span> can traffic to the plasma membrane in the absence of <span class="highlight">ABCG12 and can</span> form flexible dimers. By contrast, <span class="highlight">ABCG12</span> was retained in the endoplasmic reticulum in the absence of <span class="highlight">ABCG11</span>, indicating that <span class="highlight">ABCG12</span> can only form dimers with <span class="highlight">ABCG11</span> in the plasm membrane of epidermal cells. Some ABCG proteins may be promiscuous, having multiple partnerships, 
while others may form obligate heterodimers for specialized
 functions (<span id="ref34546920.20870961" class="cite">McFarlane <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG11 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.204.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.204.9&tcname=">3.A.1.204.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative multidrug/pigment exporter, Adp1 (<span id="ref7363.19857594" class="cite">Lamping <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Adp1 (C-M) of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em> (P25371)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.205">3.A.1.205 The Pleiotropic Drug Resistance (PDR) Family (ABCG)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.1&tcname=">3.A.1.205.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pleiotropic drug resistance (PDR; Pdr5) exporter; steroid exporter; sporidesmin toxicity suppressor (Sts1); MDR; cyclic nucleotide exporter; amphipathic anion exporter.  Its ATPase activity is inhibited by its substrate, clotrimazole; can use ATP, GTP and maybe UTP to drive efflux (<span id="ref5918.17956128" class="cite">Golin <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).&nbsp; Molecular modeling revealed aspects of the binding pocket and mechanism of action (<span id="ref9033.21034832" class="cite">Rutledge <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).&nbsp; Charged residues at the end of TMS2 affect transport (<span id="ref34545395.27189366" class="cite">Dou <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). The 23-membered-ring macrolide tacrolimus, a commonly used immunosuppressant, also known as FK506, is a broad-spectrum inhibitor and an efflux pump substrate, and mutations that minimize its export have been isolated (<span id="ref34548978.30348662" class="cite">Tanabe <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). An A666G mutation in TMS 5 of Pdr5 increases drug efflux by enhancing cooperativity between transport sites (<span id="ref34549993.31294884" class="cite">Arya <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Mutations in Pdr5 give rise to altered drug specificity (<span id="ref34550159.15836770" class="cite">Tutulan-Cunita <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>). Batzelladine D and norbatzelladine L reverse the fluconazole resistance phenotype mediated by Pdr5p. Both alkaloids were able to chemosensitize the Pdr5p-overexpressing strain by synergistic interaction with fluconazole, and both compounds also showed an inhibitory effect on the catalytic activity and on the intracellular accumulation of rhodamine 6G, but did not show significant in vitro mammalian cells toxicity (<span id="ref34552203.33130347" class="cite">Domingos <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The mechanism involves a "flippase" step that moves the substrates from one leaflet of the bilayer to the other, as a central element of cellular efflux (<span id="ref34554643.35451123" class="cite">Raschka <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). The gating region residues of Pdr5, and possibly other ABCG transporters,
 play a role not only in molecular gating but also in allosteric 
regulation, conformational switching, and protein folding (<span id="ref34555627.36370844" class="cite">Alhumaidi <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). <span id="ref34557155.37567064" class="cite">Banerjee <em>et al.</em> 2023</span> reported a comprehensive overview of the structural and functional aspects of catalytically asymmetric ABC pumps such as members of the yeast PDR subfamily.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pdr5 (Sts1; Ydr1) (C-M-C-M) of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em> (P33302)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.10&tcname=">3.A.1.205.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pleiotropic drug resistance (PDR) exporter, named ABCG40, PDR9 or PDR12, 1423 aas with 12 - 14 TMSs. It functions as a pump to exclude Pb<sup>2+</sup> ions and/or Pb<sup>2+</sup>- containing toxin compounds) (<span id="ref5817.15923333" class="cite">Lee <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>). It may also export abscisic acid (ABA) (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PDR12 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Q9M9E1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.11&tcname=">3.A.1.205.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The brefeldin resistance protein, Bfr1, (also exports actinomycin D, cerulenin, and cytochalasin B) (<span id="ref5959.7646493" class="cite">Turi and Rose, 1995</span>; <span id="ref5961.7883711" class="cite">Nagao <em>et al</em>., 1995</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bfr1 of <i>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</i> (P41820)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.12&tcname=">3.A.1.205.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The plasma membrane Pdr10, a negative regulator for incorporation of Pdr12 (TC# 3.A.1.205.3) into detergent-resistant membranes, a novel role for members of the ABC transporter superfamily (<span id="ref6541.19452121" class="cite">Rockwell <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>) (most like 3.A.1.205.1; 67% identity).<br /</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PDR10 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </em>(P51533)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.13&tcname=">3.A.1.205.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span style="caret-color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; -moz-text-size-adjust: auto; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration: none; font-family: -webkit-standard; color: #000000; font-size: medium;">The putative sterol uptake transporter, Aus1. It also protects against antifungal azoles such as fluconazole and itraconazole (</span><span style="caret-color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; -moz-text-size-adjust: auto; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration: none; font-family: -webkit-standard; color: #000000; font-size: medium;"><span id="ref7181.17913716" class="cite">Nakayama <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; -moz-text-size-adjust: auto; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration: none; caret-color: #000000; font-family: -webkit-standard; color: #000000; font-size: medium;">Aus1 of&nbsp;</span><em style="font-family: -apple-system-font; font-size: 12px; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: auto; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: auto; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-size-adjust: auto; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration: none; caret-color: #000000; color: #000000;">Candida glabrata</em><span style="font-style: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; -moz-text-size-adjust: auto; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration: none; caret-color: #000000; font-family: -webkit-standard; color: #000000; font-size: medium;">&nbsp;(Q6FUR1)</span></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.15&tcname=">3.A.1.205.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Anaerobically-induced AusI. Specifically stimulated by phosphatidylserine in proteoliposomes. May translocate cholestrol and derivatives (<span id="ref7832.21521689" class="cite">Marek <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AusI of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em> (Q08409)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.16&tcname=">3.A.1.205.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG32/PEC1 transporter.&nbsp; Required for plant cuticle production (<span id="ref9638.21628525" class="cite">Bessire <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG32/PEC1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.17&tcname=">3.A.1.205.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter, PDR1 of 1452 aas and 12 or 14 TMSs in a repeated 6 or 7 TMS CMCM arrangement.&nbsp; Secretes phytohormones such as strigolactones that regulate plant shoot architecture and stimulate germination (<span id="ref9639.22398443" class="cite">Kretzschmar <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>; <span id="ref34552517.31745915" class="cite">Demurtas <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PDR1 of <em>Petunia hybrida</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.18&tcname=">3.A.1.205.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The monolignol (p-coumaryl alcohol) transporter, ABCG29 or PDR1. In addition to this precursor of lignin biosynthesis, this transporter may transport various phenolic compounds and glucosinolates (<span id="ref9641.22704988" class="cite">Alejandro <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).&nbsp; Reported to be required for normal meiotic double strand DNA break formation resulting from interaction with SPO11-1 (<span id="ref9640.17762870" class="cite">De Muyt <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG29 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.19&tcname=">3.A.1.205.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Small molecule transporter, ABCG10.&nbsp; Poorly expressed in an <em>lrrB</em> mutant (<span id="ref9643.20457612" class="cite">Sugden <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Slime molds</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG10 of <em>Dictyostelium discoideum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.2&tcname=">3.A.1.205.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Drug/Sterol/Mutagen exporter, Snq2p</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Snq2p of <I>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</I> (P32568)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.20&tcname=">3.A.1.205.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TUR2 transporter.&nbsp; May be a general defense protein. Involved in turion (dormant buds) formation. Confers resistance to the diterpenoid antifungal agent sclareol <span id="ref9646.12061897" class="cite">(van den Br&ucirc;le <em>et al.</em> 2002</span>).&nbsp; Induced by abiotic stresses such as cold-stress, cycloheximide and 
sodium chloride (NaCl). Induction by abscisic acid (ABA) is repressed by
 cytokinin such as kinetin (<span id="ref9647.16506311" class="cite">Crouzet <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants (Aquaphytes)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TUR2 of <em>Spirodela polyrrhiza</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.21&tcname=">3.A.1.205.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC1 transporter.&nbsp; Excretes secondary metabolites such as terpenes. Involved in both 
constitutive and jasmonic acid-dependent induced defense. Secretes the terpenes, sclareol and<em> </em>sclareolide and thereby confers resistance to the fungus<em>,  B.cinerea </em>(<span id="ref9648.16126865" class="cite">Stukkens <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>).<em>&nbsp; </em>Induced by sclareolide and sclareol, and by some phytohormones 
such as jasmonic acid (JA) and ethylene. Strongly induced by compatible 
pathogens such as <em>B. cinerea</em> and the bacterium, <em>Pseudomonas syringae</em> pv 
tabaci, as well as by non pathogenic bacteria such as <em>P. fluorescens</em>, and
<em> P. marginalis</em> pv marginalis (<span id="ref9649.12848828" class="cite">Grec <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC1 of <em> Nicotiana plumbaginifolia</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.22&tcname=">3.A.1.205.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plasma membrane ABC family G member 39 (ABCG39; PDR11) paraquot uptake transporter of 1454 aas and 12 - 16 TMSs.&nbsp; Also called pleiotropic drug resistance protein, PDR11 or PDR13 (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10910">Fujita and Shinozaki 2014</a>). It may export a variety of xenobiotics (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PDR11 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.23&tcname=">3.A.1.205.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcG34 of 1453 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; Secretes a major phytoalexin, camalexin, which on the leaf surface protects the plant against necrotophic pathogens (<span id="ref34547014.28652324" class="cite">Khare <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Also protects against the antifungal agent, sclareol. <em>AtABCG34</em> expression was induced by <em>A</em><em>brassicicola</em> inoculation as well as by methyl-jasmonate, a defense-related 
phytohormone, and AtABCG34 was polarly localized at the external face of
 the plasma membrane of epidermal cells of leaves and roots (<span id="ref34547014.28652324" class="cite">Khare <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Probably transports a variety of alkaloids v(<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcG34 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.24&tcname=">3.A.1.205.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance (MDR) exporter, (Np)AbcG5/PDR5 of 1498 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; NpABCG5/NpPDR5 is barely expressed in leaf tissues under normal 
conditions, but its expression is induced by the biotic stress hormone 
methyl jasmonate, or when tissues are wounded or chewed by an insect. NpABCG5/NpPDR5 confers resistance to the 
herbivore <em>Manduca sexta</em> (<span id="ref34547015.28298475" class="cite">Toussaint <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).&nbsp; The same system, ABCG5 of soybean plays a role in iron homeoistasis and the iron deficiency response (<span id="ref34557693.38250443" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PDR5 of <em>Nicotiana plumbaginifolia </em>(Leadwort-leaved tobacco) (Tex-Mex tobacco)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.25&tcname=">3.A.1.205.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plasma membrane ABCG1 or PDR1a of 1434 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; 85% identical to TC# 3.A.1.205.21. PDR1 secretes plastid-produced diterpene(s) that are the antimicrobial compounds active in preinvasion defense, as well as the sesquiterpenoid, capsidiol, the major phytoalexin produced by <em>Nicotiana</em> and <em>Capsicum</em> species. Capsidiol is produced in plant tissues attacked by pathogens and plays a
 major role in postinvasion defense by inhibiting pathogen growth (<span id="ref34547019.27102667" class="cite">Shibata <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). &nbsp; This protein and ABCG2/PDR2, a close paralogue, export the same compounds and are essential for resistance to the potato late blight pathogen <em>Phytophthora infestans</em>. Thus, ABCG1/2 are involved in the export of both antimicrobial diterpene(s) 
for preinvasion defense and capsidiol for postinvasion defense against 
<em>P. infestans</em>.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PDR1 of <em>Nicotiana benthamiana</em> (wild tobacco)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.26&tcname=">3.A.1.205.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter, AtrB or BcatrB, that catalyzes efflux of fungitoxic compounds including the phytoalexin, camalexin.&nbsp; Camalexin also induces its synthesis (<span id="ref34547051.19154205" class="cite">Stefanato <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AtrB of <em>Botryotinia fuckeliana</em> (Noble rot fungus)<em> (Botrytis cinerea)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.27"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.27&tcname=">3.A.1.205.27</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance efflux pump of 1567 aas and 12 TMSs. Probably exports many drugs including griseofulvin, itraconazole, terbinafine and amphotericin B (<span id="ref34547250.27121717" class="cite">Martins <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>) (<span id="ref34556836.37229189" class="cite">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR of <em>Trichophyton rubrum</em> (Athlete's foot fungus)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.28"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.28&tcname=">3.A.1.205.28</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG30 or PDR2 of 1400 aas and 12 TMSs in a C-M-C-M domain arrangement.&nbsp; Responds to abiotic stresses such as heavy metals (Cd<sup>2+</sup>, Pb<sup>2+</sup>, etc), and is regulated by hormones related to pathogenic defenses (<span id="ref9647.16506311" class="cite">Crouzet <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>) . It may be a heavy metal efflux pump, but may also transport abscisic acid, influencing <span>developmental processes, including seed and bud dormancy, the control of organ size and stomatal closure (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>)</span>. This system may be a&nbsp; biomarkers responding to abiotic (heavey metal ion) stress (<span id="ref34554367.35091190" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PDR2 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.29"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.29&tcname=">3.A.1.205.29</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG37 (PDR9; PDR12, ETA4, PIS1) of 1450 aas and 12 TMSs in a CMCM domain arrangement where each M domain contains 6 TMSs.&nbsp; It confers resistance to auxinic herbicides (<span id="ref34548644.16877699" class="cite">Ito and Gray 2006</span>) and contributes oxygenated coumarins to root exudates (<span id="ref34548645.28623273" class="cite">Ziegler <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). It responds to abiotic stresses such as heavy metals (Cd<sup>2+</sup> and lead) and is regulated by pathogenic defense hormones (<span id="ref5881.17355438" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). It probably exports a wide range of compounds including monolignols (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>) and Indole butyric acid (IBA), a precursor of indole acetic acid (IAA) (<span id="ref34550747.31333697" class="cite">Damodaran and Strader 2019</span>). Fe deficiency induces the secretion of coumarin compounds by <em>Arabidopsis</em> roots, and the ABCG37 ABC transporter is required for this secretion; these compounds improved plant Fe nutrition (<span id="ref34552909.24015802" class="cite">Fourcroy <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCG37 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.3&tcname=">3.A.1.205.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Weak acid exporter, Pdr12p (exports preservative anions including propionate, sorbate and benzoate) (<span id="ref5941.18240334" class="cite">Mollapour <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Pdr12p of <I>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</I> (Q02785)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.30"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.30&tcname=">3.A.1.205.30</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug exporter, AtrF, of 1547 aas and 14 TMSs in a CMCM domain order with a 6 + 6 +2 TMS arrangement. <span>It is a pleiotropic efflux pump that confers resistance to azoles such as fluconazole, voriconazole, and itraconazole (<span id="ref34549856.26933209" class="cite">Meneau <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>;&nbsp;<span id="ref34549857.28080217" class="cite"> Li <em>et al.</em> 2017)</span></span>.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AtrF of <em>Neosartorya fumigata (Aspergillus fumigatus)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.31"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.31&tcname=">3.A.1.205.31</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pdr18 ABC pump of 1333 aas and 12 TMSs in a C-M-C-M domain arrangement. It functions to insert sterols such as ergosterol into the membrane, and Pdr18-mediated multistress resistance is linked to the status of plasma membrane lipid environment related with ergosterol content and the associated plasma membrane properties (<span id="ref34550331.29777118" class="cite">Godinho <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pdr18 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.32"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.32&tcname=">3.A.1.205.32</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR exporter, TmrMDR3, of 1503 aas and 12 TMSs in a C-M-C-M domain arrangement. Four ABC transporters (TruMDR1, TruMDR2, TruMDR3, and TruMDR5) and a second <span class="highlight">MFS</span> transporter (TruMFS2) proved to be able to operate as azole efflux pumps. Milbemycin oxime inhibited only TruMDR3. TruMDR3 transports voriconazole (VRC) and itraconazole (ITC), while TruMDR2 transports only ITC. Disruption of <em>TruMDR3</em> abolished resistance to VRC and reduced its resistance to ITC (<span id="ref34550746.31501141" class="cite">Monod <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TmrMDR3 of<em> Trichophyton rubrum</em></p>
<p></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.4&tcname=">3.A.1.205.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance protein, Cdr1 (<em>Candida</em> drug resistance 1) of 1501 aas and 14 TMSs in a CMCM arrangement with each M domain having 7 TMSs in a 6 + 1 TMS arrangement. It confers resistance to cycloheximide, xenobiotics and antifungal agents such as azoles and terbinafine (<span>Holmes <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>; <span>Schuetzer-Muehlbauer <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>); also, transports phospholipids (<span>Shukla <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). It is the major fluconazole efflux system in fluconazole-resistant <em>C. albicans</em> (<span>Holmes <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>; <span>Basso <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). Substitution of threonine-1351 results in hypersusceptibility to antifungal agents and threonine-1351 is essential for synergic effects of calcineurin inhibitor FK520 (<span id="ref34551792.15190023" class="cite">Shukla <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). It is similar to Cdr2. For additional details of both systems, as well as other MDR pumps in various <em>Candida</em> species, see <span>Cannon <em>et al.</em>, 1998</span>. Chimeras between Cdr1 and Cdr2 revealed regions determining substrate specificity (<span>Tanabe <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).&nbsp; The protein has a large polyspecific drug-binding pocket formed by many of the TMSs (<span>Rawal <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; The macrocyclic polyketide, FK520, an analologue of antifungal FK506, and a potent immunosuppressant that prevents T-cell proliferation, displays fungicidal synergism with azoles in <em>Candida albicans </em>and inhibits drug efflux mediated by ABC multidrug transporters including Cdr (<span>Nim <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; TMS 5 residues impart substrate specificity and
selectively act as a communication link between ATP hydrolysis and drug transport (<span>Puri <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).&nbsp; The 4 domains (2Cs and 2 Ms) are connected by intracellular loops that allow coupling between ATP hydrolysis and transport&nbsp; (<span>Shah <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>) and faciliitate membrane targetting (<span>Shah <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Multiple drug binding sites have been identified (<span>Nim <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). The system also transports steroid hormones such as &beta;-estradiol and corticosterone as well as rhodamine 6G using specific but overlapping binding sites (<span>Baghel <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).  The 23-membered-ring macrolide, tacrolimus, a commonly used 
immunosuppressant also known as FK506, is a broad-spectrum inhibitor 
and an efflux pump substrate, and mutations that minimize its export 
have been isolated (<span id="ref34548978.30348662" class="cite">Tanabe <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). A structural motif, called the E-helix, plays a role in the maintenance of proper structural fold and/or inter-domain contacts (<span id="ref34549302.30639597" class="cite">Vishwakarma <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). A Q1005H mutant displayed two-fold reduced ATPase activity and two-fold increased drug-resistance as compared to the wild-type protein, pointing to direct control of the non-hydrolytic NBS in substrate-translocation through ATP binding in asymmetric ABC pumps (<span id="ref34550604.31734312" class="cite">Banerjee <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). A functional Cys-deficient Cdr1 protein has been designed (<span id="ref34554096.33568458" class="cite">Madani <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Milbemycins, enniatin B, beauvericin and FK506 are broad-spectrum fungal multidrug efflux pump inhibitors that inhibit Cdr1, and inhibitor resistant mutants have alterred substrate specificity (<span id="ref34554097.34780272" class="cite">Niimi <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cdr1 (C-M-C-M) of <em>Candida albicans</em> (P43071)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.5&tcname=">3.A.1.205.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance protein, Cdr2 (confers resistance to azole and other antifungal agents/terbinafine, amorolfine, aspofungin, etc. as well as a variety of metabolic inhibitors) (<span id="ref5774.12657057" class="cite">Schuetzer-Muehlbauer <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>; <span id="ref6982.20348384" class="cite">Basso <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).&nbsp;Chimeras between Cdr1 an Cdr2 revealed regions determining substrate specificity (<span id="ref8130.21895791" class="cite">Tanabe <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). Has an external binding site for an inhibiting octapeptide derivative (<span id="ref8853.22788839" class="cite">Niimi <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). It has a CMCM domain order, and both M domains have a 5 ot 6 + 1 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cdr2 of <em>Candida albicans</em> (P78595)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.6&tcname=">3.A.1.205.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance protein, Cn Afr1 (confers resistance to azole antifungal drugs including fluconazole) (<span id="ref5771.12519188" class="cite">Posteraro <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CnAFR1 (C-M-C-M) of <em>Cryptococcus neoformans</em> (Q8X0Z3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.7&tcname=">3.A.1.205.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The multidrug resistance protein, AtrB (confers resistance to all major classes of fungicides as well as natural toxic compounds substrates include: anilinopyrimidine, benzimidazole, phenylpyrrole, phenylpyridylamine, strobirulin, azoles, dicarboximides, quintozene, acriflavin, and rhodamine 6G as well as natural toxins such as camptothecin (an alkaloid) and the stilbene phytoalexin, resveratrol) (<span id="ref6029.10931903" class="cite">Andrade <em>et al</em>., 2000</span>).  </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Fungi</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>AtrB of <i>Aspergillus nidulans</i> (P78577)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.8&tcname=">3.A.1.205.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The multidrug resistance protein, Pdr11p, mediates sterol uptake by promoting movement of sterols from the plasma membrane to the endoplasmic reticulum where esterification occurs (<span id="ref5805.15316012" class="cite">Li and Prinz, 2004</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Pdr11p of <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> (P40550)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.205.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.205.9&tcname=">3.A.1.205.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The plasma membrane Cd<sup>2+</sup>/Pb<sup>2+</sup> efflux pump (heavy metal resistance pump), PDR8 (ABCG36; PEN30, present in root hair and epidermal cells; it may export a broad range of substrates (<span id="ref5881.17355438" class="cite">Kim <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).&nbsp; Also reported to transport flavonoid glycosides (phytoalexins) as well as quercitin, kaempeferol, 4-methoxy-indol-3-ylmethylglucosinolate and salicylate (<span id="ref9642.22783269" class="cite">Badri <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>; <span id="ref34547018.16473969" class="cite">Stein <em>et al.</em> 2006)</span>.&nbsp; Key factor that controls the extent of cell death in the defense 
response (<span id="ref11143.16415066" class="cite">Kobae <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). Necessary for both callose deposition and glucosinolate 
activation in response to pathogens. Required for limiting invasion by 
nonadapted powdery mildews (<span id="ref11144.16732289" class="cite">Consonni <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PDR8 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Q9XIE2)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.206">3.A.1.206 The a-Factor Sex Pheromone Exporter (STE) Family (ABCB)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.206.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.206.1&tcname=">3.A.1.206.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>a-Factor sex pheromone (a hydrophobic isoprenylated (farnesylated) carboxymethylated peptide) exporter, Ste6 (<span id="ref9644.22933563" class="cite">Michaelis and Barrowman 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Ste6 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.206.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.206.2&tcname=">3.A.1.206.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mating factor M secretion protein, Mam1 of 1336 aas and 13 predicted TMSs.&nbsp;  <span class="highlight">Mam1</span> ABC protein is a promiscuous peptide transporter that can accommodate globular proteins of a relatively large size being capable of exporting a mating factor M- GFP fusion protein (<span id="ref10273.16288715" class="cite">Kjaerulff <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mam1 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.207">3.A.1.207 The Eukaryotic ABC3 (E-ABC3) Family (None in animals or plants)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>(functions unknown; ABC-type ATPases have not been identified.)</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.1&tcname=">3.A.1.207.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Two uncharacterized FtsX-like proteins, (1220 aas [A0ECD8] and 1209 aas [A0ECD9], respectively; both with 10 TMS in a 1+3 + 2 + 1 +3 TMS arrangement; 2-4 are homologous to 8-10; the FtsX domain; <em>P. tetraurelia</em> has at least 5 paralogues.) Three ATPases appear to most closely resemble the ABC3 ATPase of 3.A.1.207.7; two of these are very similar (95% identity), having the same size (295 aas) (A0BKU3 and A0E2Z0) while the third is larger (350 aas) (A0CMB8) and shows only 45% identity with the other two.&nbsp; We suggest the first two very similar proteins function with the two FtsX-like proteins while the third (A0CMB8) serves an idependent function. However, this has not been established.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Ciliates</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Paramecium tetraurelia</em> (M) (A0ECD9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.10&tcname=">3.A.1.207.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC3 transporter of 1365 aas (ABC membrane protein of 10 TMSs; KAF2072454); plus an ABC3-type ATPase of 445 aas; KAF2077445).&nbsp; It is not known that these two proteins function together, but they both cluster with ABC3 transporter constituents.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC3-type exporter of <em>Polysphondylium violaceum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.11&tcname=">3.A.1.207.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC3-type exporter.&nbsp; The FtsX membrane constituents is of similar sequence to other eukaryotic ABC3 membrane proteins, but a gene encoding an ATPase is not present in the same vacinity of the genome.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FtsX proteins of <em>Piromyces finnis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.12&tcname=">3.A.1.207.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>DUF214 protein of 1638 aas with a long (~500 aas) hydrophilic domain preceding the DUF214 (integral membrane domain of 10 TMSs). An ABC3-type ATPase from the same organism is included under this TC#, but it is not established that this is the ATPase that functions with this ABC3 membrane protein.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>DUF214 protein + ATPase of <em>Streblomastix strix</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.13&tcname=">3.A.1.207.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 1062 aas and 10 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Stylonychia lemnae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.14&tcname=">3.A.1.207.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FtsX domain-containing protein of 2826 aas and 11 TMSs.&nbsp; The N-terminal domain is the FtsX domain with 10 TMSs, the middle domain is a member of the mechanosensitive Ca2+ Channel (MCA) family (TC# 1.A.87), and the smallere C-terminal domain is a member of the Basigin&nbsp; family (TC# 8.A.23). It is encoded by a gene that is adjacent to a gene enciding a protein of 638 aas and one or two TMSs at the N-terminus and one TMS at the C-terminus that could be an auxiliary protein (acc# PRP88019). The organism encodes two ABC3-type ATPases, either of which could be the energizer for this efflux transporter. Their acc #s are PRP76045 and PRP78455.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FtsX domain protein of   <em>Planoprotostelium fungivorum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.15&tcname=">3.A.1.207.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FtsX-type transporter of 1235 aas and 10 TMSs. The adjacent gene incodes and adaptor protein (MU1 adaptin; acc # CDW78452) that <span>plays a role in protein sorting in the 
late-Golgi/trans-Golgi network (TGN) and/or endosomes (see family 9.B.278).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FtsX protein of <em>Stylonychia lemnae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.2&tcname=">3.A.1.207.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative permeases; Duf214 protein (1234aas; 10TMSs: 1+6+3; 2-4 are homologous to 8-10 (the FtsX domain))</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Ciliates</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative permease of <i>Tetrahymena thermophila</i> (M) (Q22NS1)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.3&tcname=">3.A.1.207.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein, UP (1465aas; 10 TMSs in a 1 + 3 + 2 + 1 + 3 TMS arrangement). <em>D. discoideum</em> has several paralogues.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Slime mold</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Dictyostelium discoideum</em> (M) - Q8ST07</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.4&tcname=">3.A.1.207.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hypothetical protein, HP, 1129aas. Homologues are found in many unicellular eukaryotes.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Amoeba</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HP of <em>Entamoeba histolytica</em> (M) (C4LT38)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.5&tcname=">3.A.1.207.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative uncharacterized ABC exporter with two constituents, a membrane porter with 10 TMSs in a 1 + 3 + 2 + 1 + 3 TMS arrangement, typical of a full length ABC3 porter, and an ATPase encoded by the adjacent gene. This is the first example of this type of protein, belonging to this ABC subfamily, in a prokaryote.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC porter of Candidatus Heimdallarchaeota archaeon LC_3 (marine sediment metagenome)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.6&tcname=">3.A.1.207.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC3-type exporter.&nbsp; The membrane component (M) has 1157 aas and 10 TMSs in a 1 + 3 + 2 + 1 + 3 TMS arrangement. An ATPase gene does not occur adjacent to or near the M protein.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC3 protein of <em>Stylonychia lemnae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.7&tcname=">3.A.1.207.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC3 exporter with two proteins and possibly an auxiliary subunit, TC# 9.B.323.3.1 (TXT58066). The membrane protein (M) has 968 aas and 10 TMSs in a 1 + 3 + 2 + 1 + 3 TMS arrangement.<br />The ATPase (C) has 392 aas. Adjacent to the M protein is a potential auxiliary protein of 1331 aas, N- and C-terminal TMSs, and an acc# TXT58066.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC3 exporter of Candidatus Lokiarchaeota archaeon (marine sediment metagenome)<br />TXT58065, M<br />TXT58064, C</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.8&tcname=">3.A.1.207.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FtsX-like permease family protein of 1128 aas and 10 TMSs in a 1 + 3 + 2 + 1 + 3 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FtsX of <em>Leishmania donovani</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.207.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.207.9&tcname=">3.A.1.207.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized protein of 1068 aas and 10 TMSs.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of <em>Chondrus crispus</em> (carragheen)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.208">3.A.1.208 The Drug Conjugate Transporter (DCT) Family (ABCC) (D&#281;bska et al., 2011)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p><span id='ref8151.21918258' class='cite'>D&#281;bska <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span></p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.1&tcname=">3.A.1.208.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multi-drug resistance-associated protein, MRP1-like protein (MLP1 or MRP1) (Exporter of leukotrienes, glutathione and cysteinyl conjugates of organic anions, drugs, unmodified hydrophobic xenobiotics and hydrophilic conjugated endobiotics). Vincristine and glutathione are co-transported. MRP1 catalyzes export of glutathione during apoptosis (<span id="ref5883.17374608" class="cite">Hammond <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). Also transports reduced folates as well as mono-, di- and tri-glutamate derivatives of folic acid and methotrexate (<span id="ref6273.16352313" class="cite">Assaraf <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>). The ABCC subgoup of ABC exporters consists of 13 members in mammals, ABCC1 to 13, and their expression levels correlate either positively or negatively (depeding on the system) with gastric cancer (<span id="ref34550636.31852133" class="cite">Mao <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). The ABCC subfamily may be involved in the transmembrane transport of organic selenium (Se) (<span id="ref34556123.36771062" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Suppression of MRP1 activity by coumarin derivatives has been documented (<span id="ref34557237.37667877" class="cite">Shahpouri <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP1 of <em>Rattus norvegicus</em> (O88269)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.10&tcname=">3.A.1.208.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug (anthracycline) resistance organic anion efflux pump (ABCC6; ABC-C6; MRP6; MOAT-E) - the ectopic mineralization disorder, pseudoxanthoma elasticum disease (PXE), protein (<span>Vanakker <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>; <span id="ref34549613.30731651" class="cite">Rasmussen <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). It exports glutathione metal conjugates as well as leukotriene C<sub>4</sub>, DNP, and N-ethylmaleimide S-glutathione, and also exports anthracyclines, epipodophyllotoxins, cisplatin, and probably probenecid, benzbromarone and indomethacin (<span>Chen and Tiwari, 2011</span>).&nbsp; The system participates in networds of complex diseases (<span>De Vilder <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). This transporter has an extra N-terminal domain (TMD0) and a loop, L0.&nbsp; TMD0 is not required for transport function, but L0 maintains ABCC6 in a
targeting-competent state for the basolateral membranes of liver and kidney cells and might be involved in regulating the NBDs (<span>Miglionico <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). PXE is a disease of altered
elastic properties in multiple tissues. Many of these mutations influence various steps in the
biosynthetic pathway, minimally altering local domain structure but adversely impacting ABCC6
assembly and trafficking (<span>Ran and Thibodeau 2016</span>). PXE is an ectopic, metabolic mineralization disorder that affects the skin, eye, and vessels. ABCC6 is assumed to mediate efflux of one or several small molecule compounds from the liver cytosol to the circulation. In mice, abrogating ABCC6 function causes alterations in the liver metabolic profile, suggesting that PXE is a metabolic disease originating from a liver disturbance (<span>Rasmussen <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). Thus, MRP6 is involved in the regulation of tissue calcification in mammals, and mutations are associated with human ectopic calcification disorders. Comparative analyses of ABCC6 and ABCC1 from invertebrates to vertebrates revealed a bony endoskeleton first evolved with ABCC1, while the ABCC6 gene is only found in bony vertebrate genomes (<span>Parreira <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE), a heritable multi-system ectopic mineralization disorder, is caused by inactivating mutations in the ABCC6 gene. The encoded protein has a specialized efflux function in hepatocytes by contributing to plasma levels of PPi, a potent inhibitor of mineralization in soft connective tissues. Reduced plasma PPi levels underlie the ectopic mineralization in PXE (<span id="ref34554015.34597610" class="cite">Kowal <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).&nbsp; AbcC6 deficiency prevents rhabdomyolysis-induced acute kidney injury (<span id="ref34557573.38057332" class="cite">Casemayou <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCC6 (MRP6) of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (O95255)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.11&tcname=">3.A.1.208.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Vacuolar metal resistance and drug detoxification protein, yeast cadmium factor (YCF1 or Ycf1p), of 1515 aas and 15 or 16 TMSs in a 5 + 6 + 4 or 5 TMS arrangement; it transports cadmium-glutathione conjugates, glutathione S-conjugated leukotriene C<sub>4</sub>, organic glutathione S-conjugates, selenodigluthatione, unconjugated bilirubin, reduced glutathione, and diazaborine (<span id="ref8207.21880115" class="cite">Lazard <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). It mediates arsenite expulsion, possibly as a glutathione conjugate. Activity is dependent on Tus1p, a guanine nucleotide exchange
factor (GEF) for the small GTPase Rho1p and a Rho1p-dependent-positive regulator of Ycf1p (<span id="ref34546347.17434123" class="cite">Paumi <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). The structure of Ycf1p reveals the transmembrane domain TMD0 and the regulatory region of ABCC transporters (<span id="ref34553358.34021087" class="cite">Bickers <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YCF1 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em> (P39109)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.12&tcname=">3.A.1.208.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bile acid transporter, BAT1 (in vacuoles)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>BAT1 of <I>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</I> (P32386)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.13&tcname=">3.A.1.208.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cyclic nucleotide (cAMP and cGMP) efflux pump, MRP8 (ABCC11); also exports other nucleoside and nucleotide analogues, and confers resistance to fluoropyrimidines and the anti-AIDS drug, 2',3'-dideoxycytidine (<span id="ref6888.12764137" class="cite">Guo <em>et al.</em>, 2003</span>). Human earwax consists of wet and dry types. Dry earwax is frequent in East Asians, whereas wet earwax is common in other populations. A SNP, 538G --&gt; A (rs17822931), in the ABCC11 gene is responsible for determination of earwax type. Cells with allele A show a lower excretory activity for cGMP than those with allele G. The 538G --&gt; A SNP is the first example of DNA polymorphism determining a visible genetic trait (<span id="ref5835.16444273" class="cite">Yoshiura <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>).&nbsp; Binding sites in ABCC11 for cGMP (cyclic guanosine
monophosphate) and 5FdUMP (5-fluoro-2'-deoxyuridine-5'-monophosphate), the active metabolite of the
anticancer drug 5-fluoro-uracil, have been identified (<span id="ref10535.23641929" class="cite">Honorat <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; MRP8 generally exports a variety of anionic lipophilic compounds including antiviral and anticancer agents (<span id="ref34543994.25896536" class="cite">Arlanov <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Inhibition of cAMP efflux can stimulate leukemia cell differentiation, cell growth arrest, and apoptosis (<span id="ref34552382.32044470" class="cite">Perez <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP8 (ABCC11) of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (Q9BX80)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.14&tcname=">3.A.1.208.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The vacuole (tonoplast) ZmMrp3 anthocyanin pigment transporter (ABCF) (<span id="ref5801.15208386" class="cite">Goodman <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ZmMrp3 of <em>Zea mays</em> <br /> ZmMrp3 (MC-MC) (Q6J0P5)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.15&tcname=">3.A.1.208.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The general organic anion exporter, MRP5 (MOATC or ABCC5).  It exports cyclic AMP, cyclic GMP, 5'-FUMP, glutathione and glutathione conjugates, and antimonial tartrate). It also transports reduced folates as well as mono-, di- and tri-glutamate derivatives of folic acid and methotrexate (<span id="ref6273.16352313" class="cite">Assaraf <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>).  When overexpressed, it can lower the intracellular concentration of nucleoside/nucleotide analogs, such as the antiviral compounds PMEA (9-(2-phosphonylmethoxyethyl)adenine) or ganciclovir, and of anticancer nucleobase analogues, such as 6-mercaptopurine, after their conversion into the respective nucleotides (<span id="ref5814.15747503" class="cite">Ritter <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>). ABCC5 is a biomarker for hepatocellular carcinoma (<span id="ref34554013.34737618" class="cite">Qiu <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP5 of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (O15440)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.16&tcname=">3.A.1.208.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The vacuolar Abc2p (SPAC3F10.11c) transporter for xenobiotics, glutathione S-conjugates and monochlorobimane (<span id="ref6030.16849797" class="cite">Iwaki <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Abc2p of <i>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</i> (MCMC; 1478 aas) (Q10185) </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.17&tcname=">3.A.1.208.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The vacuolar glutathione-conjugate and chlorophyll catabolite transporter, MRP3 (<span id="ref6033.9681016" class="cite">Tommasini <em>et al</em>., 1998</span>).&nbsp; This protein appears to have an M-M-C-M-C domain order, possibly a characteristic of this ABC subfamily.&nbsp; It exports reduced and oxidized glutathione (GSH) as well as GSH conjugates of cadmium, dinitrophenol, metolachlor, herbicies and anthocyanins (<span id="ref34548647.9223346" class="cite">Lu <em>et al.</em> 1997</span>).&nbsp; A maize ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter ZmMRPA6 confers cold and salt stress tolerance in plants (<span id="ref34557874.38135780" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP3 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Q9LK64)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.18&tcname=">3.A.1.208.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Vacuolar glutathione conjugate, glutathione exporter; mediates cadmium detoxification and <i>ade2</i> pigmentation <i>in vivo</i> (<span id="ref5765.12455987" class="cite">Sharma <em>et al</em>., 2002</span>). (Most similar to Ycf1 of <i>S. cerevisiae</i> (TC# 3.A.1.208.11; 41% identity))</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Plants</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bpt1 of <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> (P14772) </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.19&tcname=">3.A.1.208.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The possible HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> transporter, HLA3 (<span id="ref6511.19321421" class="cite">Duanmu <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>).&nbsp; Activation of HLA3 expression in high CO<sub>2</sub> acclimated cells, where HLA3 
is not expressed, resulted in increased Ci accumulation and Ci-dependent
 photosynthetic O<sub>2</sub> evolution specifically in very low CO<sub>2</sub> concentrations, which confirms that HLA3 is indeed involved in Ci 
uptake.&nbsp; It also suggests that HLA3 is mainly associated with HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> <span class="highlight">transport</span> in very low CO<sub>2</sub> concentrations, conditions in which active CO<sub>2</sub> uptake is limited (<span id="ref34545249.25660294" class="cite">Gao <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Algae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HLA3 of <em>Chlamydomonas reinhardtii</em> (A8I268)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.2&tcname=">3.A.1.208.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Hepatic canalicular conjugate exporter, ABCC2. cMRP, MRP2, CMOAT (the Dubin-Johnson Syndrome protein) (transports bilirubin glucuronides; E<sub>2</sub> 17 &beta; glucuronide, dianionic bile salts such as taurocholate, taurochenodeoxycholate sulfate and taurolithocholate sulfate; reduced glutathione; glutathione conjugates; glucuronides; cysteinyl leukotrienes; arsenic-glutathione complexes and glutathione disulfide; also exports anthracyclines, epipodophyllotosine, <em>Vinca</em> alkaloids, cisplatin, methotrexate, and the protease inhibitor, lopinavir) (<span id="ref7861.21740521" class="cite">Chen and Tiwari, 2011</span>; <span id="ref8283.22034653" class="cite">Krumpochova <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).&nbsp; MK-571 is an inhibitor (<span id="ref8909.21319959" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.,</em> 2011</span>).&nbsp; Sterol sensing residues have been identified (<span id="ref34543787.25445676" class="cite">G&aacute;l <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Catalyzes efflux of ochratoxin A (OTA) (<span id="ref34547151.28532671" class="cite">Qi <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). ABCC2 polymorphism and gender correlate with the high-density lipoprotein/ cholesterol response to simvastatin (<span id="ref34550174.30024814" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Inhibitors and activators of MRP2 as well as BCPR (ABCG2; TC# 3.A.1.204.2) and P-gp (TC#3.A.1.201.1) have been evaluated (<span id="ref34551629.32496785" class="cite">Deng <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Drug export by several MDR pumps has been examined using 3D organoids derived from the small intestine (<span id="ref34553559.34386316" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The farnesyl protein transferase inhibitor, lonafarnib (SCH66336), is an inhibitor of multidrug resistance proteins 1 and 2, Mrp1 and Mrp2 (<span id="ref34555218.14671431" class="cite">Wang and Johnson 2003</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>cMRP (MRP2; cMOAT) of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (Q92887)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.20&tcname=">3.A.1.208.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The vacuolar MRP1 of 1622 aas. Also called ABCC1 and EST1. It has 17 TMSs in a 5 + 6 + 6 arrangement with an 
N-terminal transmembrane domain of 5 TMSs.&nbsp; The domain order is N - 
MCMC, and it transports xenobiotics (<a class="reflink" href="http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref34548743">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</a>) It sequesters in the vacuole glutathione conjugates, folate mono-glutamates (pteroyl-1-glutamate) and antifolates (methotrexate); (<span id="ref6585.19136566" class="cite">Raichaudhuri <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>) (86% identical to MRP2 (3.A.1.208.5). ABCC1 and ABCC2 confer tolerance to cadmium and mercury, in addition to their role in arsenic detoxification. MRP1 of <em>Lithospermum erythrorhizon </em>may play a direct or indirect role in transmembrane transport&nbsp; of shikonin (<span id="ref34547536.29139179" class="cite">Zhu <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). ABCC1 and ABCC2 regulate stomatal closing and opening as well as anthocyanin transport (<span id="ref5947.18325934" class="cite">Frelet-Barrand <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>). It transports xenobiotics (<a class="reflink" href="http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref34548743">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</a>). The ABCC gene family and their expression analysis in pigment deposition of fiber in brown cotton (<em>Gossypium hirsutum</em>) has been reported (<span id="ref34553104.33961624" class="cite">Sun <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP1 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Q9C8G9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.21&tcname=">3.A.1.208.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The thale cress protein atMRP5 (atABCC5), a high-affinity inositol hexakisphosphate transporter; involved in guard cell signaling and phytate storage (<span id="ref6768.19797057" class="cite">Nagy <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>). Transports organic anions and phytate (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>). In humans, activities of lysosomal ABCC3, ABCC5 and ABCC10 are responsible for 
lysosomal sequestration of doxorubicin and paclitaxel-oregongreen488 in 
paclitaxel-resistant cancer cell lines (<span id="ref34557323.37767694" class="cite">Gronkowska <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP5/ABCC5 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Q7GB25)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.22&tcname=">3.A.1.208.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>California mussel ABCC/MRP-type multixenobiotic resistance efflux pump (<span id="ref5949.18401003" class="cite">Luckenbach and Epel, 2008</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCC/MRP-type exporter of <em>Mytilus californianus</em> (B2WTI0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.23&tcname=">3.A.1.208.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Sur2B (ABCC9) sulfonylurea receptor. The amino-terminal transmembrane domain of Sur2B binds Kir6.2 (<span id="ref8196.22089636" class="cite">Winkler <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). Dominant missense mutations in ABCC9, promoting open channel formation, cause Cant&uacute; syndrome (<span id="ref8704.22610116" class="cite">Harakalova <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>; <span id="ref8732.22608503" class="cite">van Bon <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).&nbsp;This protein is part of an ATP-dependent potassium (K(ATP)) channel that couples the metabolic state of a cell with its electrical activity.&nbsp; Associated with  early repolarization (ERS) and Brugada (BrS) syndromes (<span id="ref10653.24439875" class="cite">Hu <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; This ATP-sensitive potassium (K(ATP)) channel couples glucose metabolism to insulin secretion in
pancreatic beta-cells (<span id="ref34546111.17561960" class="cite">de Wet <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). The vasodilator binding sites on the SUR2 subunit have been identified (<span id="ref34554950.35562524" class="cite">Ding <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Cryo-EM structures of SUR2A and SUR2B subunits in complex with Mg-nucleotides and P1075 or levcromakalim, two chemically distinct KATP openers that are specific to SUR2, have been determined. Both P1075 and levcromakalim bind to a common site in the transmembrane domain (TMD) of the SUR2 subunit, which is between TMD1 and TMD2 and is embraced by TMSs 10, 11, 12, 14, and 17.
