These KATP openers synergize with Mg-nucleotides to stabilize SUR2 in the NBD-dimerized occluded state to activate the channel (<span id="ref34554950.35562524" class="cite">Ding <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sur2B of <em>Homo sapiens</em>&nbsp;(O60706)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.24&tcname=">3.A.1.208.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.208.24"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>Similar to MRP4 of man (TC#3.A.1.208.7).¬†A single amino acid mutation causes resistance to Bt toxin Cry1Ab in the silkworm, <em>Bombyx mori </em>(<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref8811">Atsumi <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>). 83% identical to 3.A.1.208.6.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Insects</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP4-like ABC transporter of <em>Bombyx mori</em>&nbsp;(G1UHW7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.25&tcname=">3.A.1.208.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.208.25"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.208.25"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>The ABC-thiol (cysteine; glutathione) exporter, MrpA (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9061">Mukherjee <em>et al.</em>, 2007</a>). 83% identical to 3.A.1.208.6.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Kinetoplastid protozoans</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a id="3.A.1.208"></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.208.25"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>MrpA of<em> Leishmania donovani</em><a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9061"><br /></a></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.26&tcname=">3.A.1.208.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mrp2 or ABCC2, of 2108 or 2133 aas (depending on the sequence reported).&nbsp; Confers resistance to quinolone drugs including chloroquine, mefloquine and quinine as well as glutationine conjugates (<span id="ref10533.24372851" class="cite">Mok <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>; <span id="ref34555310.35811673" class="cite">Wunderlich 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Alveolata</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mrp2 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.27"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.27&tcname=">3.A.1.208.27</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug (e.g., ivermectin) exporter, MRP-1 isoform a (<span id="ref10613.23474412" class="cite">Ardelli 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP-1 of <em>Ceanorhabditis elegans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.28"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.28&tcname=">3.A.1.208.28</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Vacuolar iron transporter, Abc3(+) of 1465 aas.&nbsp; Induced by low iron and repressed by high iron.&nbsp; Required for growth in a low iron medium.&nbsp; Probably mobilizes stored vacuolar iron (<span id="ref10713.19915076" class="cite">Pouliot <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Abc3 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.29"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.29&tcname=">3.A.1.208.29</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance-associated protein 9, MRP9 of 1359 aas.  Also called ABCC12.  Expressed in testis, but widely expressed in other tissues at low levels. Isoform <a href="http://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/Q96J65#Q96J65-5">5</a> is specifically expressed in brain, testis and breast cancer cells.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP9 or ABCC12 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.3&tcname=">3.A.1.208.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oligomycin-resistance protein YOR1 in plasma membrane (confers resistance to oligomycin, rhodamine B, tetracycline, verapamil, eosin Y and ethidium bromide; <span id="ref5916.17950691" class="cite">Grigoras <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>)).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YOR1 (M-C-M-C) of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em> (P53049)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.30"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.30&tcname=">3.A.1.208.30</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span class="SUBMITTED"><span class="FULL_SUBMITTED">ATP-binding cassette transporter 13, ABC13 or ABCC13 of 1296 aas; the sequence of the full length human protein is not available.<br /></span></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCC13 of <em>Macaca mulatta</em></p>
<p>(Rhesus macaque)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.31"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.31&tcname=">3.A.1.208.31</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance-associated protein 7, MRP7 or ABCC10 of 1492 aas.  Probably involved in cellular detoxification through lipophilic anion extrusion.  Isoform <a>1</a> is specifically expressed in spleen; isoform <a>2</a> is more widely expressed. The combination of ibrutinib and paclitaxel can effectively antagonize ABCB1- and ABCC10-mediated paclitaxel resistance (<span>Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). It may function in regulating immune cell infiltration patterns along with four other ABC transporters (ABCA8, ABCA12, ABCB6 and ABCB8) (<span id="ref34555092.35837087" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). In addition to sphingomyelin and ceramide, sugar derivatives of ceramides, hexosylceramides (HexCer), are the major circulating sphingolipids. ABCC10 partakes in modulating the synthesis and subsequent efflux of hexosyl ceramides (HexCer) to HDL in liver cells (<span id="ref34555511.36297086" class="cite">Iqbal <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Activities of lysosomal ABCC3, ABCC5 and ABCC10 are responsible for 
lysosomal sequestration of doxorubicin and paclitaxel-oregongreen488 in 
paclitaxel-resistant cancer cell lines (<span id="ref34557323.37767694" class="cite">Gronkowska <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). ABCC10/MRP7 consists of three transmembrane domains and two nucleotide 
binding domains. It mediates multidrug resistance of tumor cells to a 
variety of anticancer drugs by increasing drug efflux and results in 
reducing intracellular drug accumulation (<span id="ref34557778.38330827" class="cite">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>). The transport substrates of 
ABCC10/MRP7 include antineoplastic drugs such as taxanes, vinca 
alkaloids, and epothilone B, as well as endobiotics such as leukotriene 
C4 (LTC<sub>4</sub>) and estradiol 17 &beta;-D-glucuronide. A variety of 
ABCC10/MRP7 inhibitors, including cepharanthine, imatinib, erlotinib, 
tariquidar, and sildenafil, can reverse ABCC10/MRP7-mediated MDR. 
Additionally, the presence or absence of ABCC10/MRP7 is also closely 
related to renal tubular dysfunction, obesity, and other diseases (<span id="ref34557778.38330827" class="cite">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP7 of<em> Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.32"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.32&tcname=">3.A.1.208.32</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP-like ABC transporter of 1513 aas.¬† Induced by copper, cadmium and oxidative stress (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref11012">Gonz√°lez-Guerrero <em>et al.</em> 2010</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC1 of <em>Rhizophagus irregularis</em> (Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungus) (<em>Glomus intraradices</em>)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.33"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.33&tcname=">3.A.1.208.33</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance export pump, ABCC or MRP1 of 1822 aas (<span id="ref34544282.19118502" class="cite">Gonz&aacute;lez-Pons <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>). It exports multiple drugs and glutathione conjugates.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Alveolata</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mrp1 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.34"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.34&tcname=">3.A.1.208.34</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCC13 of 1505 aas.&nbsp; <span>Required for phytic acid accumulation in 
developing seeds. Phytic acid is the primary storage form of phosphorus 
in cereal grains and other plant seeds (<span id="ref34544396.19370321" class="cite">Xu <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCC13 of <em>Oryza sativa</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.35"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.35&tcname=">3.A.1.208.35</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR1 (ABCC1) of 1514 aas; 96% identical to the characterized protein of the same length from <em>Rhopalosiphum padi </em>(Bird cherry-oat aphid)<em><em> (Aphis padi)</em>, </em>which exports the insecticides, imidacloprid and chlorpyrifos (<span id="ref34545374.27110952" class="cite">Kang <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCC1 of <em>Acyrthosiphon pisum </em>(Pea aphid)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.36"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.36&tcname=">3.A.1.208.36</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter with two components, one of 551 aas and 6 TMSs and the other of 585 aas and 6 TMSs; both have the M-C domain order.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of <em>Bdellovibrio exovorus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.37"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.37&tcname=">3.A.1.208.37</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><span class="recommended-name">ABC-type multidrug transporter with two fused ATPases and two fused permease domains; of 1228 aas and 12 TMSs.<br /></span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Possible MDR pump of <em>Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.38"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.38&tcname=">3.A.1.208.38</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter, a 2 component system, both proteins with the M-C domain order.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of <em>Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.39"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.39&tcname=">3.A.1.208.39</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>dMDR of 1548 aas; exports daunorubicin (<span id="ref34545751.22972675" class="cite">Chahine <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR of <em>Drosophila melanogaster</em> (Fruit fly)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.4&tcname=">3.A.1.208.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SUR1 sulfonylurea receptor; subunit and regulator of &alpha;-cell ATP-sensitive K<sup>+</sup> channel (TC #1.A.2); determines ATP sensitivity; no inherent transport function known; associated with persistent hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia of infancy due to focal adenomatous hyperplasia (also called ABCC8). Gain-of-function mutations in the genes encoding the ATP-sensitive potassium (K(ATP)) channel subunits Kir6.2 (KCNJ11) and SUR1 (ABCC8) cause neonatal diabetes mellitus. Because mutant channels are inhibited less strongly by MgATP, this increases K(ATP) currents in pancreatic beta cells, thus reducing insulin secretion and producing diabetes (de <span>Wet <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). Binds ligands (blockers): glibenclamide, tolbutamide, and meglitinide as well as agonists, SR47063 (a cromakalim analog), P1075 (a pinacidil analog), and diazoxide (<span>Bessadok <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).&nbsp;ATP activates ATP-sensitive potassium channels composed of mutant sulfonylurea receptor 1 and Kir6.2 with diminished PIP2 sensitivity (<span>Pratt and Shyng, 2011</span>).&nbsp;Dominant missense mutations in ABCC9, promoting open channel formation, cause Cant&uacute; syndrome (<span>Harakalova <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>; <span>van Bon <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). The N-terminal transmembrane domain of SUR1 controls gating of Kir6.2 by modulating channel sensitivity to PIP2 (<span>Pratt <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). Familial mild hyperglycemia is due to the ABCC8-V84I mutation (<span>Gonsorcikova <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). ATP regulates KATP channels by promoting dimerization and conformational switching (<span>Ortiz <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; Mutations causing neonatal diabetes are attributed to alterations in the affinites for ATP and ADP (<span>Ortiz and Bryan 2015</span>).&nbsp; Two groups of mutations with different cellular mechanisms have been identified. 1) Channel complexes with mutations in NBD2 of SUR1 traffic normally but are unable
to be activated by MgADP. 2) Channel mutations in the TMS domains of SUR1 are retained in
the ER and have variable functional impairment (<span>Nessa <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). KATP channels (Kir6.2/SUR1) in the brain and endocrine
pancreas&nbsp; couple metabolic status to the membrane potential. In 
beta-cells, increases in
cytosolic [ATP/ADP] inhibit KATP channel activity, leading to membrane 
depolarization and
exocytosis of insulin granules. Mutations in ABCC8 (SUR1) or KCNJ11 
(Kir6.2) can result in gain or
loss of channel activity and cause neonatal diabetes (ND) or congenital 
hyperinsulinism (CHI),
respectively.&nbsp; Nucleotide binding without hydrolysis switches SUR1 to 
stimulatory conformations.&nbsp; Increased affinity for ATP gives rise to ND 
while decreased affinty gives rise to CHI (<span>Ortiz and Bryan 2015</span>). SUR1 mutations constitute a genetic aetiology for neonatal diabetes, and they act by reducing the K<sub>ATP </sub>channel's ATP sensitivity (<span>Proks <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). Polymorphic ABCC8 isoforms are key regulatory proteins of cerebral oedema in many neurological disorders including traumatic brain injury (<span>Jha <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). In polymorphisms predictive of oedema, variant alleles/genotypes confer increased risk while different variant polymorphisms are associated with favourable outcome, potentially suggesting distinct mechanisms (<span>Jha <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). KATP channels are energy sensors that are clinically validated drug targets. KATP inhibitors are prescribed for diabetes and KATP activators are used for the treatment of hypoglycemia, hypertension, and hair loss. Wu et al., 2022 [PMID<strong> 36253099</strong>] highlight the current knowledge about the drug binding modes observed using cryogenic EM. The inhibitors and activators bind to two distinct sites in the transmembrane domain of the SUR subunit. These drugs allosterically modulate the dimerization of SUR nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs) and thus KATP channel activity (Wu et al., 2022 [PMID<strong> 36253099</strong>]).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SUR1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (Q09428)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.40"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.40&tcname=">3.A.1.208.40</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative fumonisin (mycotoxin) exporter of 1489 aas and about 16 TMSs, Fum19.&nbsp; Present in an operon with fumonisin biosynthetic enzymes (<span id="ref34547247.12620260" class="cite">Proctor <em>et al.</em> 2003</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fum19 of <em>Gibberella moniliformis </em>(Maize ear and stalk rot fungus) <em>(Fusarium verticillioides)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.41"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.41&tcname=">3.A.1.208.41</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The antifungal agent, EchonocandinB, exporter, EcdL of 1479 aas and 16 TMSs (<span id="ref34547357.28927344" class="cite">Bera <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EcdL of <em>Aspergillus rugulosus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.42"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.42&tcname=">3.A.1.208.42</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP4 ABC anthocyanin/phytic acid efflux porter of 1510 aas and 12 TMSs.&nbsp; <span>It exports anthocyanin in aleurone tissues ().&nbsp; ABC transporter that may affect phytic acid
 transport and compartmentalization. It function directly or indirectly
 in removing phytic acid from the cytosol. and is required for phytic acid accumulation in developing seeds. </span><span>It is expressed most highly in embryos, but also in immature endosperm, 
germinating seed and vegetative tissues. Silencing expression of this 
transporter in an embryo-specific manner produced low-phytic-acid, 
high-Pi transgenic maize seeds that germinate normally (<span id="ref34547561.17676037" class="cite">Shi <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>). Phytic acid 
is the primary storage form of phosphorus in cereal grains and other 
plant seeds.</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP4 of<em> Zea mays</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.43"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.43&tcname=">3.A.1.208.43</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Arsenate/thioarsentate exporter, MRP12 or ABCC12</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcC12 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.44"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.44&tcname=">3.A.1.208.44</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pytate exporter of 1537 aas and 18 TMSs, ABCC5 (<span>Pandey <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCC5 of <em>Glycine max</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.45"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.45&tcname=">3.A.1.208.45</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance pump, MRP1 or ABCC1 of 1515 aas and 17 putative TMSs. The ABCC1 gene is expressed at all larval stages and in at least nine different tissues, particularly in the fifth-instar larvae and Malpighian tubules (<span>Chen <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). MRP1 (ABCC1) serves  as a functional receptor for the insect toxins, Cry1A and Cry2Ab (<span>Chen <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCC1 of <em>Helicoverpa armigera</em> (Cotton bollworm)<em> (Heliothis armigera)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.47"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.47&tcname=">3.A.1.208.47</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Vacuolar ABCC1 of 1480 aas and 17 TMSs in a 5 + 6 + 6 TMS arrangement. Transports anthocyanins including anthocyanodin 3-O-glucosides such as malvidin 3-O-glucoside (<span id="ref34548746.23723325" class="cite">Francisco <em>et al.</em> 2013;</span> <span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>). Also transports glutathione (<span id="ref34548746.23723325" class="cite">Francisco <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCC1 of <em>Vitis vinifera</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.48"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.48&tcname=">3.A.1.208.48</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance protein, MRP4 or ABCC4, of 1349 aas and 12 TMSs in an M-C-M-C domain order. The non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) diclofenac, known to cause hyperuricemia and concomitant visceral gout in <em>Gyps</em> vultures may be a result of interference with renal uric acid excretion. Three species of <em>Gyps</em> vultures are on the verge of extinction due to nephrotoxic veterinary diclofenac having entered the food chain, and because the toxicity of different avian species to the NSAIDs like diclofenac varies. MRP4, an organic anion transporter in birds, plays a unique role in unidirectional efflux of urate into the proximal renal tubular lumen for excretion and maintenance of homeostasis.&nbsp;<span id="ref34549332.30562604" class="cite">Barik <em>et al.</em> 2019</span> characterized the MRP4 channel at the molecular level to predict its structural based ligand binding properties in <em>Gallus domesticus</em> (Indian domestic chicken) and <em>Gyps himalayensis</em> (the Himalayan griffon vulture)including point and insertional mutational variants.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR4 of <em>Gyps himalayensis</em> (vulture)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.49"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.49&tcname=">3.A.1.208.49</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance-associated protein, CG4562, MRP5 or DmeI of 1362 aas and 12 TMSs with an order of domains MCMC, where both M domains probably have 6 TMSs. It has been shown to be a heme exporter, but probably has multiple substrates as is true of human MRP5 (<span id="ref34554805.35655259" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). CG4562 is mainly expressed in the gastric caeca and the anterior part of the midgut, suggesting this is the major site of heme absorption. It thus appears that CG4562 is the functional counterpart of mammalian MRP5 (<span id="ref34554805.35655259" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CG4562; MRP5; DmeI of <em>Drosophila melanogaster </em>(Fruit fly)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.5&tcname=">3.A.1.208.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Vacuolar multidrug resistance efflux pump, AtMRP2 (catalyzes vacuolar uptake of glutathione conjugates (i.e., 2,4-dinitrophenyl-GS), glucuronide conjugates (i.e., 17 &#946;-estradiol 17(&#946;-D-glucuronide), and reduced glutathione). Also exports the herbicide, 1-chloro-2, 4-dinitrobenzene, and chlorophyll degradation catabolites (<span id="ref5947.18325934" class="cite">Frelet-Barrand <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Plants</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>AtMRP2 of <I>Arabidopsis thaliana</i> (O64590)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.50"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.50&tcname=">3.A.1.208.50</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter C family member 4, ABCC4, of 1495 aas and 17 TMSs in a 5 + 6 (2 + 2 + 2) + 6 (2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement (M + M + C + M + C overall domain order).&nbsp; In <em>Crocus sativus</em>, it transports Apocarotenoid; in saffrom stigmas, crocins, it transports a mixture of apocarotenoid glycosides (<span id="ref34552517.31745915" class="cite">Demurtas <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Apocarotenoids are carotenoid derivatives produced by the nonenzymatic or enzymatic cleavage of carotenoids, followed by different enzymatic modifications. In plants, apocarotenoids play various roles, such as attraction of pollinators and seeds dispersal, defense against pathogens and herbivores, protection against photo-oxidative stresses, stimulation and inhibition of plant growth and regulation of biological processes in the case of phytohormones abscisic acid and strigolactones. While carotenoids are in general plastid-localized metabolites, apocarotenoids can reach different final destinations inside or outside the cell (<span id="ref34552517.31745915" class="cite">Demurtas <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p>
<div id="content-gene" class="entry-overview-content"></div></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCC4 of <em>Dendrobium catenatum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.6&tcname=">3.A.1.208.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Metal-thiol conjugate exporter, PgpA; glutathione and trypanothione conjugates are exported; confers arsenite and antimonite resistance (trypanothione is glutathione-spermidine). </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Protozoa</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>PgpA of <I>Leishmania tarentolae</I> (P21441)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.7&tcname=">3.A.1.208.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP4 (MDR4; ABCC4); exporter of cyclic nucleotides (cAMP, cGMP and other nucleotide analogues, particularly purine analogues, methotrexate, bile acids, prostaglandins E1 and E2, reduced folates, 9-(2-phosphonylmethyoxyethyl)adenine, leukotrienes, estradiol 17-&beta;-D-glucuronide) and drug sulfate conjugates (inhibited by nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs <span>Reid <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>; <span>Rius <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>)).  When overexpressed, it can lower the intracellular concentration of nucleoside/nucleotide analogs, such as the antiviral compounds PMEA (9-(2-phosphonylmethoxyethyl)adenine), adefovir, or ganciclovir (<span id="ref34550101.25475361" class="cite">Nigam 2015</span>), and of anticancer nucleobase analogs, such as 6-mercaptopurine, after their conversion into the respective nucleotides.  MRP4 interacts directly with CFTR (3.A.1.202.1) to control Cl<sup>-</sup> secretion (<span>Li <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). It also functions in urate elimination across the renal tubule apical membrane (<span>Prestin <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).  Thus, MRP4 is a broad specificity organic anion exporter (<span>Ritter <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>). MRP4 and CFTR together function in the regulation of cAMP and beta-adrenergic contraction in cardiac myocytes (<span>Sellers <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>). Amino acid changes can alter the uptake of drugs such as 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) and 9-(2-phosphonyl methoxyethyl) adenine
(PMEA) (<span>Janke <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).&nbsp; Positions of L1 (the linker between the two halves of the exporter), L0 (the N-terminal domain), and the zipper helices (between the two NBDs) have been suggested (<span>Chantemargue <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). ABCC4 exports proinflammatory molecules including leukotriene, prostaglandin and sphingosine-1-phosphate across the plasma membrane. These metabolites play roles in asthma (<span>Palikhe <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). Symmetrical 1,4-dihydropyridines are inhibitors of the MRP4 Efflux Pump and can be used for anticancer therapy (<span id="ref34553031.33375210" class="cite">D&ouml;ring <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). MRP4 contributes to platelet activation by extruding endogenous molecules responsible for their activation and accumulation and may also export various drugs (<span id="ref34553154.33964863" class="cite">Angelis <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Symmetrical cage compounds are inhibitors of the symmetrical MRP4-efflux pump for anticancer therapy (<span id="ref34553470.34065900" class="cite">Kreutzer <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The ABCC4 gene is associated with pyometra in dogs (<span id="ref34553522.34404837" class="cite">Arendt <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>) and Chronic Myeloid Leukemia in humans (<span id="ref34554767.34050721" class="cite">Monte <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Cellular uptake of and transport mechanisms for 6-mercaptopurine nanomedicines (6-MPNs) for enhanced oral bioavailability have been described (<span id="ref34555869.36636639" class="cite">Zou <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>), and MRP4 plays a significant role. ABCC4 is a prostaglandin E2 efflux transporter in the ovarian follicle and is a mediator of ovulation with a potential non-hormonal contraceptive target (<span id="ref34556307.36943419" class="cite">Yerushalmi <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Thus, the ABCC4 inhibitor probenecid blocks ovulation and affects key ovulatory genes in female mice in vivo.</p>
<p>.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP4 (MOAT-B; ABCC4) of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (O15439)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.8&tcname=">3.A.1.208.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>

<p><a></a></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a></a></p>
<p>Drug resistance pump; ABCC1 (MRP1), exports chemotherapeutic agents, organic anions such as leukotriene C<sub>4</sub> (LTC<sub>4</sub>), 17-&beta;-estradiol 17-&beta;-D-glucuronide, glucuronide-X (E<sub>2</sub>17&beta;G, etoposide-glucuronide), estrone-3-sulfate, folic acid and methotrexate, arsenic triglutathione, arsenic and antimonial oxyanions, glutathione (GSH), GSSG, glutathione conjugates (GSH-X; LTC<sub>4</sub>, DNP-SG, EA-SG, NEH-SG), sulfate-X (E<sub>1</sub>S, DHEAS), HIV protease inhibitors, anthracyclines, epipodophyllotoxins, and <em>Vinca</em> alkaloids.  Changing charged residues in TMS6 (K332, H335 and D336) gave rise to specific changes in specificity (<a>Chen <em>et al</em>., 2006</a>; <a>Haimeur <em>et al</em>., 2002</a>; <a>Leslie <em>et al</em>., 2004</a>).&nbsp; Also, mutations in TMS 10 alter substrate binding and export of drugs (<span>Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). MDR1 also exports cobalamine (Vitamin B<sub>12</sub>) (<a>Beedholm-Ebsen <em>et al.</em>, 2010</a>) and cytotoxic metals including antimony, mercuric ions, arsenate and arsenite, but not copper, chromium, cobalt and aluminum,&nbsp;often as glutathione conjugates&nbsp;(<a>Aleo <em>et al.</em>, 2005</a><a>;</a>&nbsp;<a>Vernhet&nbsp;<em>et al.</em>, 2000</a>). Notch1 regulates the expression in cultured cancer cells (<span>Cho <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).&nbsp; Structural and functional properties of MRP1 have been reviewed comprehensively (<span>He <em>et al.</em> 2011</span>).&nbsp; Fluorescent substrates have been identified (<span>Strouse <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; It pumps out sulfur mustards and nitrogen mustards (mechlorethamine, HN2), potent vesicants developed as
chemical warfare agents (<span>Udasin <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). It has 3 membrane domains with a total of 17 TMSs. Loss of the aromatic side chain at position 583 impairs the release of ADP and thus effectively locks the transporter in a low-affinity solute binding state (<span id="ref34548777.29976562" class="cite">Weigl <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). MRP1 Tyr<sub>1189</sub> and Tyr<sub>1190</sub>, unlike the corresponding residues in SUR1, are not involved in its differential sensitivity to sulfonylureas, but nevertheless, may be involved in the transport activity of MRP1, especially with respect to glutathione, GSH (<span id="ref34550836.15652236" class="cite">Conseil <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>). Modulators of MRP1 activity have been found (<span id="ref34551636.32474136" class="cite">M&ouml;hle <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Glu<sub>1204</sub> serves a dual role in membrane expression of MRP1 and in a step in its catalytic cycle subsequent to initial substrate binding (<span id="ref34551649.15208328" class="cite">Situ <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). The cotransport mechanism of GSH with anticancer drugs by MRP1 has been examined (<span id="ref34552206.33100008" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The first cytoplasmic loop in the core structure of ABCC1 contains multiple amino acids essential for Its expression (<span id="ref34554066.34575890" class="cite">Conseil and Cole 2021</span>). Carboplatin, paclitaxel and topotecan bind specifically to Asn510 in transmembrane domain 1 of MRP1 (<span id="ref34554606.35330134" class="cite">Haque <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). The farnesyl protein transferase inhibitor, lonafarnib (SCH66336), is an inhibitor of multidrug resistance proteins 1 and 2, Mrp1 and Mrp2 (<span id="ref34555218.14671431" class="cite">Wang and Johnson 2003</span>). A macrocyclic peptide, named CPI1, inhibits MRP1 with nanomolar 
potency but shows minimal inhibition of 
P-glycoprotein. A cryo-EM structure at 3.27 &Aring; 
resolution shows that CPI1 binds MRP1 at the same location as the 
physiological substrate leukotriene C4 (LTC<sub>4</sub>). Residues that 
interact with both ligands contain large, flexible side chains that can 
form a variety of interactions, revealing how MRP1 recognizes multiple 
structurally unrelated molecules. CPI1 binding prevents the 
conformational changes necessary for ATP hydrolysis and substrate transport (<span id="ref34556068.36893260" class="cite">Pietz <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). ABCB1 and ABCC1 function during the TGF-&beta;-induced epithelial-mesenchymal transition, and the relationship between multidrug resistance and tumor progression has been considered (<span id="ref34556216.37047018" class="cite">da Costa <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The efflux of anti-psychotics through the blood-brain barrier (BBB) via this system has been demonstrated (<span id="ref34556525.37239445" class="cite">Nasyrova <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (P33527)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.208.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.208.9&tcname=">3.A.1.208.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Canicular multispecific organic anion MDR transporter, MRP3 (also called ABCC3) (most similar in sequence to MRP2).  MRP3 exports epipodophyllotoxins, etoposide and teniposide, estradiol 17-&beta;-D-glucuronide, leukotriene C<sub>4</sub>, dinitrophenyl S-glutathione, epoposide glucuronide, methotrexate, bilirubin-glucuronides, bile acids, GSH-X (LTC<sub>4</sub>, DNP-SG) and sulfate-X (taurolithocholate-3-sulfate).&nbsp; Substrate translocation and stimulated ATP hydrolysis show positive cooperativity (Hill coefficient = 2) and are half-coupled (<span id="ref9496.23176825" class="cite">Seelheim <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).&nbsp; ABCC3 is overexpressed in various types of cancer including carcinogenic stem cells, and plays a role in liver cancer progression (<span id="ref34544750.26337276" class="cite">Carrasco-Torres <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Psoraleae Fructus ethanol extracts induced hepatotoxicity by damaging mitochondria, reducing fatty acid beta-oxidation levels, and inhibiting fatty acids ingested by bile in part due to overexpression of ABCC3 (<span id="ref34555944.36647431" class="cite">Guo <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; Steroid hormones are substrates of the ABCC3 transporter, binding in a compatible amphiphilic substrate-binding pocket (<span id="ref34556857.37485728" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).&nbsp; Activities of lysosomal ABCC3, ABCC5 and ABCC10 are responsible for lysosomal sequestration of doxorubicin and paclitaxel-oregongreen488 in paclitaxel-resistant cancer cell lines (<span id="ref34557323.37767694" class="cite">Gronkowska <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MRP3 of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (O15438)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.209">3.A.1.209 The MHC Peptide Transporter (TAP) Family (ABCB)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.209.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.209.1&tcname=">3.A.1.209.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MHC heterodimeric peptide exporter (TAP) (from cytoplasm to the endoplasmic reticulum) (TAP1=ABCB2; TAP2=ABCB3) (defects in TAP1 or TAP2 cause immunodeficiency) (TAP1/TAP2 is stabilized by tapasin isoforms 1, 2 and 3) (<span id="ref5759.12213826" class="cite">Raghuraman <em>et al</em>., 2002</span>).  TAP1 has 10 TMSs, 4 unique N-terminal TMSs and 6 TMSs that form the translocation pore with N- and C-termini in the cytosol (<span id="ref5833.16407277" class="cite">Schrodt <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>).  The TAP2 nucleotide binding site appears to be the main catalytic active site driving transport suggesting asymmetry in the transporter (<span id="ref5868.17068338" class="cite">Perria <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>). The TAP complex shows strict coupling between peptide binding and ATP 
hydrolysis, revealing no basal ATPase activity in the absence of 
peptides (<span id="ref7075.19808685" class="cite">Herget <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>).&nbsp; There are three binding sites on TAP1 for tapasis which interconnects TAP and MHC class I, promotes TAP stability and facilitates heterodimerization (<span id="ref10930.24501197" class="cite">Leonhardt <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; TAP is the target of GN1 (TC#8.B.25.1.1), a virally encoded protein inhibitor of viral peptide exposure on the cell surface (<span id="ref34544404.18802093" class="cite">Verweij <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>; <span id="ref34544703.26519531" class="cite">Rufer <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Tapasin (448 aas; O15533) stabilizes TAP2<span> (<span id="ref34546551.17244610" class="cite">Papadopoulos and Momburg 2007</span>). Tapasin is involved in the association of MHC class I 
with the transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP) and in the 
assembly of MHC class I with peptide (peptide loading).</span> TAP plays a key role in the adaptive immune defense against infected or malignantly transformed cells by translocating proteasomal degradation products into the lumen of the endoplasmic reticulum for loading onto MHC class I molecules. TAP transports peptides from 8 to 40 residues, including even branched or modified molecules, suggestive of structural flexibility of the substrate-binding pocket. The bound peptides in side-chains' mobility was strongly restricted at the ends of the peptide, whereas the central region was flexible. Peptides bind to TAP in an extended kinked structure, analogous to those bound to MHC class I proteins (<span id="ref7647.21205905" class="cite">Herget <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).  TAP translocates proteasomal degradation products from the cytosol into the lumen of the endoplasmic reticulum, where these peptides are loaded onto MHC class I molecules by a macromolecular peptide-loading complex (PLC) and subsequently shuttled to the cell surface for inspection by cytotoxic T lymphocytes. As a central adapter protein, tapasin (O15533) (<span id="ref34547505.10636848" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2000</span>) recruits other components of the PLC at the N-terminal domains of TAP. The alpha6/beta10-loop determines the nonsynonymous nucleotide binding of NBD1 and NBD2, whereas the switch region seems to play a critical role in regulating the functional cross-talk between the structural domains of TAP (<span id="ref34550881.15611256" class="cite">Ehses <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>).<span id="ref34547504.16828748" class="cite"> Koch <em>et al.</em> 2006</span> found that the N-terminal domains of human TAP1 and TAP2 independently bind to tapasin, thus providing two separate loading platforms for PLC assembly. Tapasin binding is dependent on the first N-terminal TMS of TAP1 and TAP2, demonstrating that these two helices contribute independently to the recruitment of tapasin and associated factors (<span id="ref34547504.16828748" class="cite">Koch <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>). The endoplasmic reticulum-resident human cytomegalovirus glycoprotein US6 (gpUS6) inhibits peptide translocation by the transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP) to prevent loading of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules and antigen presentation to CD8+ T cells. gpUS6 associates with preformed TAP1/2 heterodimers (<span id="ref34548638.16356928" class="cite">Halenius <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals, yeast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TAP1/TAP2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.209.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.209.2&tcname=">3.A.1.209.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Homodimeric transporter ABCB9 or TAPL of 766 aas and 10 TMSs in a 4 + 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement. It transports a broad spectrum of peptides (low affinity) from the cytosol to the lysosomal lumen and d<span>isplays a broad peptide length specificity from 
6-mer up to at least 59-mer peptides with an optimum of 23-mers. It favors 
positively charged, aromatic and hydrophobic residues in the N- and 
C-terminal positions whereas negatively charged residues as well as 
asparagine and methionine are not favored.</span> TapL transports a broad range of peptides of 6-60aas (23aas optimal). It has also been detected in the ER. It is stabilized by interaction with LAMP-1 and LAMP-2 (see 9.A.16) (<span id="ref8862.22641697" class="cite">Demirel <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).&nbsp; The protein consists of a core transporter plus an N-terminal transmembrane domain (TMD0) required to tageting to the lysosome and for interactions with LAMP-1 and -2 (<span id="ref10500.24013930" class="cite">Tumulka <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). TMD0 has a four transmembrane helix topology with a short helical segment in a lysosomal loop (<span id="ref34549228.30353140" class="cite">Bock <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Lysosomal targeting is determined by membrane localized charged residues (<span id="ref34549652.30877195" class="cite">Graab <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p>
<p>.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TAPL or ABCB9 of <em>Homo sapiens</em>&nbsp;(Q9NP78)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.209.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.209.3&tcname=">3.A.1.209.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Haf-4/Haf-9 heterodimeric half transporter of 787 aas and 815 aas, respectively.&nbsp; Probably tranports antigenic peptides. Both proteins localize to the membrane of nonacidic, lysosome-associated, membrane 
protein homologue (LMP-1)-positive intestinal granules from larval to 
adult stages. Mutants of <em><span class="highlight">haf-4</span></em> and <em><span class="highlight">haf-9</span></em> exhibited granular defects in late larval and young adult intestinal 
cells, associated with decreased brood size, prolonged defecation cycle,
 and slow growth (<span id="ref34546687.19403699" class="cite">Kawai <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>). Thus they may mediate intestinal granular formation. <span class="highlight">HAF-4</span>-<span class="highlight">HAF-9</span> heterodimer formation is required for their stabilization (<span id="ref34546688.23458156" class="cite">Tanji <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). The <span class="highlight">HAF-4</span>- and <span class="highlight">HAF-9</span>-localizing organelles are distinct intestinal organelles associated with the endocytic pathway (<span id="ref34546689.26817689" class="cite">Tanji <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>; <span id="ref34546690.28427936" class="cite">Tanji <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Haf-4/Haf-9 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.209.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.209.5&tcname=">3.A.1.209.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peptide efflux pump, MDR3 or ABCB3, of 833 aas and possibly 10 TMSs in a 1 + 1 + 8 TMS arrangement (<span id="ref34555289.35811673" class="cite">Wunderlich 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR3 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.21">3.A.1.21 The Siderophore-Fe<sup>3+</sup> Uptake Transporter (SIUT) Family </A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.21.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.21.1&tcname=">3.A.1.21.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Fe<sup>3+</sup>-Yersiniabactin uptake transporter, YbtPQ (<span id="ref5735.11320115" class="cite">Brem <em>et al</em>., 2001</span>; <span id="ref5692.10231486" class="cite">Fetherston <em>et al</em>., 1999</span>). YbtPQ is a virulence factor in the highly inflammatory microenvironment characteristic of high-titer cystitis in <em>E. coli</em> (<span id="ref34551412.26883590" class="cite">Koh <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). The <em>E. coli</em> and <em>Y. pestis</em> YbtP proteins are 99.7% identical. Multiple structures of the yersiniabactin importer YbtPQ from uropathogenic <em>Escherichia coli</em> (UPEC) have been solved in inward-open conformations of both <em>apo</em> and substrate-bound states by cryo-EM (<span id="ref34551413.32076651" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). YbtPQ does not 
adopt a known fold of typical ABC importers, but instead exhibits the fold 
of an ABC exporter. It has
two unique features: unwinding of a transmembrane helix in YbtP
 upon substrate release and tightly associated nucleotide-binding 
domains without bound nucleotides (<span id="ref34551413.32076651" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). This ABC porter is similar to FrpBC of <em>Vibrio anguillarum </em>(<span id="ref34555240.36012135" class="cite">Lages <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YbtPQ of <em>Yersinia pestis</em> <br /> YbtP (M-C)<br /> YbtQ (M-C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.21.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.21.2&tcname=">3.A.1.21.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Fe<sup>3+</sup>-mycobactin/carboxymycobactin transporter, IrtAB (<span id="ref5830.16385031" class="cite">Rodriguez and Smith, 2006</span>). IrtA contains an FAD-binding domain (<span id="ref6893.19948799" class="cite">Ryndak <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>).  <em>M. tuberculosis</em> produces two classes of siderophores, lipid-bound mycobactin and water-soluble carboxymycobactin. Iron-loaded carboxymycobactin is imported into the cytoplasm by IrtAB which has an additional cytoplasmic siderophore interaction domain that may serve as a periplasmic receptor. Membrane-reconstituted IrtAB is sufficient for the import of mycobactins, which are then reduced by the siderophore interaction domain to facilitate iron release (<span id="ref34551340.32296173" class="cite">Arnold <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Structure determination by X-ray crystallography and cryo-EM not only confirmed that IrtAB has an ABC exporter fold (as indicated by TC-BLAST searches), but also revealed structural peculiarities at the transmembrane region of IrtAB that result in a partially collapsed inward-facing substrate-binding cavity. The siderophore interaction domain is positioned in close proximity to the inner membrane leaflet, enabling the reduction of membrane-inserted mycobactin. Enzymatic ATPase activity and in vivo growth assays revealed that IrtAB has a preference for mycobactin over carboxymycobactin as its substrate (<span id="ref34551340.32296173" class="cite">Arnold <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The large transporter (Rv1348-1349) of 859 aas seems to have three domains, an extracytoplasmic receptor domain (IrtA), a central membrane domain of 6 TMSs (IrtB) and a C-terminal ATPase (IrtC). If so, there may be two potential receptors (see <span id="ref34553404.34171249" class="cite">Mandal <em>et al.</em> 2021</span> for a review). Cryo-EM structures for the <em>M. tuberculosis</em> iron-loaded siderophore transporter IrtAB has been reported (<span id="ref34556674.36882106" class="cite">Sun <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). It adopts the canonical type IV exporter fold. The structures of unliganded Mtb IrtAB in complex with ATP, ADP, or the ATP analogue (AMP-PNP) at resolutions ranging from 2.8 to 3.5 &Aring;. The structure of IrtAB bound ATP-Mg<sup>2+ </sup>shows a "head-to-tail" dimer of nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs), a closed amphipathic cavity within the TMDs, and a metal ion liganded to three histidine residues of IrtA in the cavity. Cryo-EM structures and ATP hydrolysis assays showed that the NBD of IrtA has a higher affinity for nucleotides and increased ATPase activity compared with IrtB (<span id="ref34556674.36882106" class="cite">Sun <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>IrtAB of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em> <br /> IrtA (M-C) (P63391) <br /> IrtB (M-C) (P63393)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.210">3.A.1.210 The Heavy Metal Transporter (HMT) Family (ABCB)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.1&tcname=">3.A.1.210.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The mitochondrial iron transporter, ATM1.&nbsp; The crystal structures of the nucleotide-free and glutathione-bound inward facing, open conformations have been solved at 3.1 and 3.4&nbsp;&Aring; resolution respectively (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10881">Srinivasan <em>et al.</em> 2014</a>).&nbsp; The glutathione binding site is near the inner membrane surface in a large cavity.&nbsp; An unknown sulfur compound appears to be exported by Atm1 and used for the synthesis of iron/sulfur centers in the cytoplasm.&nbsp; This compound also signals iron sufficiency/deficiency to the nucleus (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10882">Philpott <em>et al.</em> 2012</a>). [But see also, 3.A.210.15].</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Fungi</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATM1 of <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.10&tcname=">3.A.1.210.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mitochondrial ABC iron/sulfur complex transporter, AbcB12 of 542 aas.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Alveolata (Ciliates)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcB12 (M-C) of<em> Tetrahymena thermophila</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.11&tcname=">3.A.1.210.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Inner membrane miltochondrial-like homodimeric Atm1 of 608 aas and 6 TMSs per subunit.&nbsp; The structure has been solved to 2.4 &Aring; resolution (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10888">Lee <em>et al.</em> 2014</a>).&nbsp; It is required for the formation of cytosolic iron-sulfur cluster-containing proteins (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10889">Lill <em>et al.</em> 2012</a>); but see also, 3.A.210.15. It exports glutathione derivatives and confers protection against heavy-metal toxicity.&nbsp;<span id="ref34551895.32703810" class="cite">Fan <em>et al.</em> 2020</span> determined eight structures by X-ray crystallography and single-particle cryo-electron microscopy in distinct conformational states, stabilized by individual disulfide crosslinks and nucleotides. As NaAtm1 progresses through the transport cycle, conformational changes in TMS 6 alter the glutathione-binding site and the associated substrate-binding cavity. Kinking of TMS 6 in the post-ATP hydrolysis state, stabilized by MgADPVO4, eliminates this cavity, precluding uptake of glutathione derivatives. The presence of this cavity during the transition from the inward-facing to outward-facing conformational states, and its absence in the reverse direction, provide a mechanism for enforcing the export directionality of transport by NaAtm1 (<span id="ref34551895.32703810" class="cite">Fan <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Atm1 of <em>Novosphingobium aromaticivorans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.12&tcname=">3.A.1.210.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB3 of 704 aas and 6 TMSs.&nbsp; Essential for the biosynthesis of heme in mitochondria, and of iron-sulfur centers (ISC) in the cytoplasm. The protein is an <span class="highlight">ABC</span> half-<span class="highlight">transporter</span> that has an N-terminal extension required to target LmABCB3 to the 
mitochondrion.&nbsp; <span id="ref34544962.26728034" class="cite">Mart&iacute;nez-Garc&iacute;a <em>et al.</em> 2016</span> showed that LmABCB3 interacts with porphyrins and is required for the 
mitochondrial synthesis of heme from a host precursor. It complements the severe growth defect in yeast 
lacking ATM1, an orthologue of human ABCB7, involved in exporting from mitochondria a gluthatione-containing compound required for the 
generation of cytosolic ISC. Docking analyzes using trypanothione, the main thiol in the 
parasite, showed how both, LmABCB3 and yeast ATM1, contain a
 similar thiol-binding pocket. LmABCB3 is an essential gene as dominant negative 
inhibition of LmABCB3 is lethal for the parasite. The 
abrogation of only one allele of the gene did not impede promastigote 
growth in axenic culture but prevented the replication of intracellular 
amastigotes and the virulence of the parasites in a mouse model of 
cutaneous leishmaniasis.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB3 of <em>Leishmania major</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.13&tcname=">3.A.1.210.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB6 of 585 aas and about 6 TMSs with an M-C domain order.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcB6 of <em>Enterocytozoon hepatopenaei</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.15&tcname=">3.A.1.210.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter, ABCB7; PexA; Atm1, of 612 aas and 6 N-terminal TMSs with an ATPase domain C-terminal (M-C), probably specific for polysulfides, being exported from the cytooplasm to the periplasm. I is 47% identical to PexA (ABCB7) of humans (<span id="ref34549622.30918498" class="cite">Riedel <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB7 of <em>Rhodobacter capsulatus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.16&tcname=">3.A.1.210.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter permease (residues 1 - 290) with ATP-binding protein (residues 291 - 583) of 583 aas and 6 N-terminal TMSs in a 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transmembrane transporter of an endosymbiont of   <em>Acanthamoeba</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.17&tcname=">3.A.1.210.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter permease (residues 1 - 310) with ATP-binding protein (residues 311 - 593) of 593 aas and 6 N-terminal TMSs in a 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of an <span id="feature_WP_038540363.1_source_0" class="feature">endosymbiont of Acanthamoeba sp. UWC8</span></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.18&tcname=">3.A.1.210.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB6 or MDR6 glutathione sulfide exporter of 1049 aas and 6 or 7 TMSs (<span id="ref34555310.35811673" class="cite">Wunderlich 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR6 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.2&tcname=">3.A.1.210.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The vacuolar heavy metal tolerance protein precursor, HMT1 (transports phytochelins and Cd<sup>2+</sup>&middot;phytochelin complexes) (<span id="ref6467.19054771" class="cite">Pr&eacute;v&eacute;ral <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>).<br /</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast; animals, protozoa bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HMT1 of <em>Schizosaccharomyces pombe</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.3&tcname=">3.A.1.210.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The ABC transporter homologue</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast; animals, protozoa bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>ABC transporter homologue in <I>Rickettsia prowazekii</I></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.4&tcname=">3.A.1.210.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC7 or ABCB7 iron transporter (X-linked sideroblastis anemia protein, XLSA/A (<span id="ref10884.24003969" class="cite">Fujiwara and Harigae 2013</span>)).&nbsp; Glutathione-complexed [2Fe-2S] stimulates the ATPase activity in both solution and proteoliposome-bound forms (K<sub>d </sub>&sim; 68 
&mu;M). This cluster is a likely natural substrate for this transporter, 
which has been implicated in cytosolic Fe-S cluster protein maturation (<span id="ref10883.24584132" class="cite">Qi <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). It is a homodimer that may also transport heme from mitocondria to the cytosol (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast; animals, protozoa bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC7 iron transporter of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.5&tcname=">3.A.1.210.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug/Cd<sup>2+</sup> resistance homologue Pfmdr2 (MDR2, ABCB2) protein of 1024 aas and 10 TMSs in a 4 + 6 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Yeast; animals, protozoa bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Pfmdr2 protein of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.6&tcname=">3.A.1.210.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mitochondrial outer membrane/lysosome  anionic porphyrin uptake half ABC transporter, ABCB6. It is expressed in many mammalian tissues (including fetal liver) in response to intracellular porphyrin. Porphyrin uptake activates <em>de novo</em> porphyrin (haem) biosynthesis (<span id="ref5863.17006453" class="cite">Krishnamurthy <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>).&nbsp; The first TMS contains a lysosomal targetting signal (<span id="ref34543717.25627919" class="cite">Kiss <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). It transports toxic metals and anti-cancer drugs. The cryo EM structure has been determined (<span id="ref34552202.33007128" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). A slit-like substrate binding pocket may accommodate the planar shape of porphyrins, and the existence of a secondary cavity near the mitochondrial intermembrane space side may further facilitate substrate release. <span id="ref34553587.34312373" class="cite">Song <em>et al.</em> 2021</span> determined the cryo-EM structures of nanodisc-reconstituted human ABCB6 trapped in an apo-state and an ATP-bound state at resolutions of 3.6 and 3.5 &Aring;, respectively. The structures revealed a unique loop in the transmembrane domain (TMD) of ABCB6, which divides the TMD into two cavities. It restrains the access of substrates in the inward-facing state and is removed by ATP-driven conformational changes. No ligand cavities were observed in the nucleotide-bound state, indicating a state following substrate release but prior to ATP hydrolysis. Structural analyses and functional characterization suggest an "ATP-switch" model and further reveal the conformational changes of the substrate-binding pockets triggered by the ATP-driven regulation (<span id="ref34553587.34312373" class="cite">Song <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). ABCB6, ABCG2, FECH and CPOX are expressed in meningioma tissue (<span id="ref34555854.36612300" class="cite">Spille <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCB6 of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (Q9NP58; 842 aas)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.7&tcname=">3.A.1.210.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.210.7"></a></p>
<p>The homodimeric heavy metal tolerance protein 1, CeHMT-1 (AbcB6) (exports phytochelatin ((&gamma;-Glu-Cys)<sub>n</sub>)-Cd<sup>2+</sup>&nbsp;complexes as well as glutathione complexes of copper and arsenic) (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref5815">Vatamaniuk <em>et al</em>., 2005</a>).&nbsp; The N-terminal hydrophobic extension domain is required (but not sufficient) for dimerization and therefore is essential for normal function (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9174">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2010</a>, <span id="ref34548738.30104978" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Both the N- and C-terminal domains are required for proper localization in the endosomes of liver-like coelomocytes, head neurons and intestine (<span id="ref34548738.30104978" class="cite">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CeHMT-1 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em> (AAM33380)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.8&tcname=">3.A.1.210.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mitochondrial ABC transporter, ATM3, involved in iron homeostasis (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref6052">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2007</a>) and heavy metal resistance (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10885">Kim <em>et al.</em> 2006</a>). There are three isoforms: ATM1, ATM2 and ATM3 (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref6052">Chen <em>et al</em>., 2007</a>). ATM3 can replace the yeast iron/sulfur cluster exporter better than ATM1 or ATM2. Atm3 is most similar to the human and yeast homologues, TC# 3.A.1.210.4 and 3.A.1.210.1, 51% and 47% identical, respectively.&nbsp; It may function in cytosolic iron-sulfur cluster biogenesis (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10886">Bernard <em>et al.</em> 2009</a>) as well as molybdenum cofactor biosynthesis (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10887">Teschner <em>et al.</em> 2010</a>).&nbsp; It performs an essential function in the generation of cytoplasmic 
iron-sulfur proteins by mediating export of Fe/S cluster precursors. Not required for 
mitochondrial and plastid Fe-S enzymes. Probably involved in the export 
of cyclic pyranopterin monophosphate (cPMP) from mitochondria into the 
cytosol. Mediates glutathione-dependent resistance to heavy metals such 
as cadmium and lead, as well as their transport from roots to leaves. 
Regulates nonprotein thiols (NPSH) and the cellular level of glutathione
 (GSH); but see also, 3.A.210.15.&nbsp; This protein, also called ABCB25, is of 728 aas with 6 TMSs and a domain order of MC.&nbsp; It transports glutathione poly sulfides (<a class="reflink" href="http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref34548743">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATM3 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em> (Q9LVM1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.210.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.210.9&tcname=">3.A.1.210.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Ni<sup>2+</sup>/Co<sup>2+</sup> exporter AtmA.&nbsp; Repressed by Zn<sup>2+</sup>, but not induced by Ni<sup>2+</sup> or Co<sup>2+</sup> (<span id="ref6658.19132541" class="cite">Mikolay and Nies, 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AtmA of <em>Cuperiavidus metallidurans </em>(Q1LRE9).</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.211">3.A.1.211 The Cholesterol/Phospholipid/Retinal (CPR) Flippase Family (ABCA)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.1&tcname=">3.A.1.211.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The cholesterol/phospholipid/leutein flippase, ABC1 (called ABCA1 in humans; Tangier disease proteins; 2261 aas and 14 TMSs in a 1 + 6 + 1 + 6 TMS arrangement; UniProt: O95477).  An amphipathic helical region of the N-terminal barrel of the phospholipid transfer protein (PLTP) is critical for ABCA1-dependent cholesterol efflux (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref6011">Oram <em>et al</em>., 2008</a>).  PLTP helix 144-163 removes lipid domains formed by ABCA1, stabilizing ABCA1, interacting with phospholipids, and promoting phospholipid transfer by direct interactions with ABCA1. May transport sphingosine-1-phosphate (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref6632">Kobayashi <em>et al.</em>, 2009</a>). May protect from cardiovascular disease and diabetes (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref6921">Tang and Oram, 2009</a>).&nbsp;Mediates efflux of cellular cholesterol and phospholipids to apoA-I (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref8848">Voloshyna and Reiss, 2011</a>).&nbsp; Hyperglycemia accelerates ABCA1 degradation (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9855">Chang <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).&nbsp; Human ABCA1 is down regulated upon infection with <em>Chlamydia pneumoniae</em> which inhibits bacterial growth (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10312">Korhonen <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).&nbsp; Curcumin induces expression of ABCA1 (<span id="ref11089.24117066" class="cite">Tian <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). May also export retinol and retinyl palmitate (<span id="ref34552519.24036530" class="cite">Reboul 2013</span>). The role of ABCA1 in human diseases has been reviewed (<span id="ref34552738.33562440" class="cite">Jacobo-Albavera <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Production of high density lipoprotein (HDL) requires ABCA1 to drive phospholipid (PL) from the plasma membrane into extracellular apolipoprotein A-I.&nbsp;<span id="ref34555287.35974019" class="cite">Segrest <em>et al.</em> 2022</span> showed that domains of ABCA1 within the plasma membrane remove PL from the membrane's outer leaflet. After the lipid diffuses into the interior of ABCA1's outward-open cavity, PL extracted by the gateway passes through a ring-shaped domain, the annulus orifice, which forms the base of an elongated hydrophobic tunnel in the transporter's extracellular domain. Engineered mutations in the gateway and annulus inhibit lipid export by ABCA1 without affecting cell-surface expression levels. These finding that ABCA1 extracts lipid from the outer face of the plasma membrane and forces it through its gateway and annulus into an elongated hydrophobic tunnel contrasts with the alternating access model, which proposes that ABCA1 flops PL substrate from the inner leaflet to the outer leaflet of the membrane. Thus, ABCA1 lacks the charged amino acid residues in the transmembrane domain found in the floppase members of the ABC transporter family (<span id="ref34555287.35974019" class="cite">Segrest <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).&nbsp; Regulation of lipid metabolism by APOE4 in intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma <em>via</em> the enhancement of ABCA1 membrane expression (<span id="ref34557763.38274331" class="cite">Qian <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).&nbsp; Tumour metastasis in colorectal cancer occurs via the RAC1/ABCA1 axis (<span id="ref34557829.38385857" class="cite">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2024</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals and plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA1 of <em>Mus musculus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.10&tcname=">3.A.1.211.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA7. Regulates cellular efflux of phospholipids but not cholesterol, to apo A-1 (<span id="ref8848.21352852" class="cite">Voloshyna and Reiss, 2011</span>).&nbsp; Associated with late-onset Alzheimer's disease, possibly by influencing amyloid-&beta; (Abeta) accumulation (<span id="ref11277.24878767" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Known functions of ABCA7 are summarized in <span id="ref11277.24878767" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2014</span> and <span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>. People with low ABCA7 develop AD neuropathology at a younger age, those with intermediate ABCA7 develop it later, and those who developed it very late had high ABCA7, the same as the youngest controls. ABC transporters closely similar to ABCA7 similarly protect cells by removing toxic lipids (<span id="ref34552446.33336544" class="cite">Lyssenko and Pratic&ograve; 2020</span>). ABCA7 is a genetic risk factor associated with Alzheimer's Disease risk in african americans (<span id="ref34554343.35034901" class="cite">Stepler <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Essential pharmacophore features of inhibitory compounds may provide guides to theraputic treatments of AD (<span id="ref34554368.34976306" class="cite">Namasivayam <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). A metabolome-wide association study on <em>ABCA7</em> indicated a role of ceramide metabolism in Alzheimer's disease (<span id="ref34555504.36269859" class="cite">Dehghan <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Cryo-EM structures of human ABCA7 provide insights into its phospholipid translocation mechanisms (<span id="ref34557049.36484366" class="cite">Le <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA7 of <em>Homo sapiens</em>&nbsp;(Q8IZY2)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.11&tcname=">3.A.1.211.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AOH1; ABCA1 transporter.&nbsp; Substrates unknown.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA1 of<em> Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.12&tcname=">3.A.1.211.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA12 transporter of 917 aas.&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plants</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA12 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.13&tcname=">3.A.1.211.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA12 keratinocyte lipid transporter of 2595 aas (<span id="ref34543577.25338618" class="cite">Shimizu <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>).&nbsp; Functions in epidermal lipid barrier formation and keratinocyte differentiation (<span id="ref10560.23954554" class="cite">Akiyama 2013</span>).&nbsp; Defects cause a form of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis, a disorder of 
keratinization with abnormal differentiation and desquamation of the 
epidermis, resulting in abnormal skin scaling over the whole body. The 
main skin phenotypes are lamellar ichthyosis (LI) and non-bullous 
congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma (NCIE) (<span id="ref10560.23954554" class="cite">Akiyama 2013</span>). ABCA12 plays
a role in lipid transport from the Golgi apparatus to lamellar granule in human granular layer
keratinocytes (<span id="ref34545990.17927575" class="cite">Sakai <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).&nbsp;  ABCA12‚Äëassociated mutations or alterations in expression&nbsp; exhibit 
causative or contributive effects to the development of keratinized
