dermatoses, including KP and NC (<span id="ref34549033.30066947" class="cite">Liu <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>; <span id="ref34555244.35964051" class="cite">Serra <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA12 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.14&tcname=">3.A.1.211.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>cAMP-dependent and sulfonylurea-sensitive anion transporter, ABCA1 (ABCAI) of 2261 aas. It is a key gatekeeper catalyzing intracellular phospholipid and cholesterol transport (<span>Orlowski <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).&nbsp; It interacts with the MEGF10 protein and is 95% identical to the mouse orthologue, 3.A.1.211.1.&nbsp; Cholesterol efflux from THP-1 macrophages decreases in the presence of plasma obtained from humans and rats with mild hyperbilirubinemia. A direct effect of unconjugated bilirubin on cholesterol efflux was demonstrated and is associated with decreased ABCA1 protein expression (<span>Wang <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). A cryoEM structure (4.1 &Aring;) revealed that the two transmembrane domains contact each other through a narrow interface in the intracellular leaflet of the membrane, and two extracellular domains of ABCA1 enclose an elongated hydrophobic tunnel. Structural mapping of dozens of disease-related mutations allowed potential interpretation of their diverse pathogenic mechanisms. Structure-based analyses suggested a plausible "lateral access" mechanism for ABCA1-mediated lipid export that may be distinct from the conventional alternating-access paradigm.  ABCA1 acts in concert with ABCB1, ABCG2 and ABCG4 to efflux amyloid-&beta; peptide (A&beta;) from the brain across the blood-brain barrier (BBB) (<span>Kuai <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). One substrate of systems ABCA1, ABCB1 and ABCC1 is arsenate, where ABCC1 is most effective while ABCA1 and ABCB1 are less effective (<span>Zhou <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). ABCA1 transports lipids and cholesterol to apolipoprotein E (APOE) (<span id="ref34548680.30049279" class="cite">Castranio <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). Cholesterol binding to ABCA1 may interfere with ATP binding in both nucleotide-binding domains of the ABCA1 structure (<span id="ref34549214.30519876" class="cite">Dergunov <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).&nbsp; Adiponectin, possibly acting through AdipoR1 and AdipoR2, plays a key role in promoting ABCA1-dependent cholesterol efflux (<span id="ref34550034.31377319" class="cite">Hafiane <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Reverse cholesterol transport or cholesterol efflux is part of an extensive plasma membranes remodelling process in spermatozoa that induces hyperactivated motility and is imperative for fertilization. Cholesterol efflux depends on high density lipoproteins (HDLs) that interact with transmembrane cholesterol transporters, such as ABCA1 and scavenger receptor class B, type I (SR-BI; TC# 9.B.39.1.3) (<span id="ref34552874.33674849" class="cite">Bernecic <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Smoking can influence the expression of the ABCA1 gene, thereby modulating lipid transport processes in macrophages, which are part of the mechanisms of inflammation development (<span id="ref34553869.34564491" class="cite">Kotlyarov and Kotlyarova 2021</span>). The cavity enclosed within the ATP-unbound form of ABCA1 is narrow at the distal ends of the TMD as well as the ECD region, substantiating the "lateral access" theory (<span id="ref34554465.35155567" class="cite">Sunidhi <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Curcumin ameliorates lipid metabolic disorder and cognitive dysfunction via ABCA1 (<span id="ref34554485.34997713" class="cite">Tian <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). Insulin downregulates the expression of ABC A-I in human hepatoma cell line HepG2 in a FOXO1 and LXR-dependent manner (<span id="ref34555553.36251137" class="cite">Shavva <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Loss of function of the ABCA1 gene results in low levels of HDL as well as a concomitant reduction in plasma HexCer levels (<span id="ref34555511.36297086" class="cite">Iqbal <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). <span style="font-weight: normal;">Inflammation and immunomodulatory therapies 
influence the relationship between the ABCA1
transporter-mediated cholesterol efflux capacity and coronary 
atherosclerosis in rheumatoid arthritis (<span id="ref34556954.37520890" class="cite">Karpouzas <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). </span>Macrophage cholesterol efflux is mediated by ABCA1 and constitutes the initial and rate-limiting step of
 reverse cholesterol transport, displaying a negative correlation 
with the development of atherosclerosis.&nbsp; Macrophage allosterically activate AMPK (see TC# 8.A.104) to enhance ABCA1 stability by retarding the calpain-mediated degradation pathway (<span id="ref34557653.38139111" class="cite">Li <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.15&tcname=">3.A.1.211.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-binding cassette sub-family A member 6, ABCA6 of 1617 aas.  This transporter may play a role in macrophage lipid homeostasis. It is up-regulated during monocyte differentiation into macrophages but down-regulated by cholesterol loading of macrophages (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA6 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.16&tcname=">3.A.1.211.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-binding cassette sub-family A member 9, ABCA9 of 1624 aas.  May play a role in monocyte differentiation and lipid homeostasis.  Expressed in fetal tissues with highest expression in fetal heart and kidney.  Up-regulated during monocyte differentiation into macrophages. Down-regulated by cholesterol loading of macrophages (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA9 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.17&tcname=">3.A.1.211.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-binding cassette sub-family A member 10, ABCA10 of 1543 aas. May play a role in macrophage lipid homeostasis.  Highly expressed in skeletal muscle, heart, brain and gastrointestinal tract.  Down-regulated by cholesterol loading of macrophages (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA10 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.18&tcname=">3.A.1.211.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-binding cassette sub-family A member 13, ABCA13, of 5058 aas.  Expressed in testis, bone marrow and trachea (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA13 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.19&tcname=">3.A.1.211.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><pre>ABC transporter A family member 2, ABCA2 or ABCA.2 of 1621 aas.</pre></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Amoebozoa (Slime molds)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA2 of <em>Dictyostelium discoideum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.2&tcname=">3.A.1.211.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The retinal-specific ABC transporter (RIM protein, ABCR or ABCA4) (Stargardt's disease protein, involved in retinal/macular degeneration) in the rod outer segment (<span id="ref34552414.33375396" class="cite">Garces <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Changes in the oligomeric state of the nucleotide binding domains of ABCR are coupled to ATP hydrolysis and might represent a signal for the TMDs of ABCR to export the bound substrate (<span>Biswas-Fiss 2006</span>). The ABCA4 porter flips N-retinylidene-phosphatidylethanolamine, a product generated from the photobleaching of rhodopsin, from the lumen to the cytoplasmic side of disc membranes following the photobleaching of rhodopsin, insuring that retinoids do not accumulate in disc membranes <span>(Molday, 2007</span>; <span>Molday <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>; <span>Tsybovsky <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). It also transports several vitamin A derivatives (<span>Sun, 2011</span>) and phosphatidylethanolamine in the same 
direction. Mutations, known to cause Stargardt disease, decrease 
N-retinylidene-phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylethanolamine <span>transport</span> activities (<span>Quazi <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). It functions as an inwardly directed retinoid flippase in the visual cycle (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Three cryo-EM structures of human ABCA4, a retina-specific ABCA transporter, in distinct functional states have been solved at resolutions of 3.3-3.4 &Aring; (<span id="ref34553384.34158497" class="cite">Xie <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). In the nucleotide-free state, the two transmembrane domains (TMDs) exhibit a lateral-opening conformation, allowing the lateral entry of substrate from the lipid bilayer. The N-retinylidene-phosphatidylethanolamine (NRPE), the physiological lipid substrate of ABCA4, is sandwiched between the two TMDs in the luminal leaflet and is further stabilized by an extended loop from extracellular domain 1. In the ATP-bound state, the two TMDs display a closed conformation, which precludes substrate binding (<span id="ref34553384.34158497" class="cite">Xie <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). ABCA4 flips N-retinylidene phosphatidylethanolamine (N-Ret-PE) from the lumen to the cytoplasmic leaflet of photoreceptor membranes. Loss-of-function mutations cause Stargardt disease (STGD1), a macular dystrophy associated with severe vision loss.&nbsp;<span id="ref34553997.34625547" class="cite">Scortecci <em>et al.</em> 2021</span> determined the cryo-EM structure of ABCA4 in its substrate-free and bound states. The two structures are similar and delineate an elongated protein with the two TMSs forming an outward facing conformation, extended and twisted exocytoplasmic domains (ECD), and closely opposed nucleotide binding domains. N-Ret-PE is wedged between the two TMSs and a loop from ECD1 within the lumenal leaflet, consistent with a lateral access mechanism. It is stabilized through hydrophobic and ionic interactions with residues from the TMSs and ECDs (<span id="ref34553997.34625547" class="cite">Scortecci <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). ABCA4 retinopathy-associated variants may be associated with retinal structure and subclinical disease (<span id="ref34556684.37342033" class="cite">Simcoe <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Stargardt disease-associated in-frame ABCA4 exon 17 skipping results in significant ABCA4 function (<span id="ref34557177.37587475" class="cite">Kaltak <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RIM protein (ABCR) of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.20&tcname=">3.A.1.211.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA9 of 950 aas with an M-C domain order.&nbsp; Transports fatty acids and acyl CoA derivatives (<span id="ref34548743.29987003" class="cite">Lef&egrave;vre and Boutry 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA9 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana </em>(Mouse-ear cress)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.21&tcname=">3.A.1.211.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ATP-binding cassette transporter pf 1384 aas and 14 TMSs in a 1 + 6 + 1 + 6 arrangement (<span id="ref34548771.30149667" class="cite">Greiner <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>ABC exporter of <em>Amsacta moorei</em> entomopoxvirus</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.22&tcname=">3.A.1.211.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ATP-binding cassette transporterof 1506 aas and 19 TMSs in an MCMC domain arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Anomala cuprea</em> entomopoxvirus</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.23&tcname=">3.A.1.211.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-binding cassette sub-family A member 3-like isoform X1of 1571 aas and 13 or 14</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Onthophagus taurus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.24&tcname=">3.A.1.211.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCF3 or ABC50 of 712 aas and 0 TMSs. ABC50 plays a key role in translation initiation and has functions that 
are distinct from those of other non-membrane ABC proteins (<span id="ref34548649.19570978" class="cite">Paytubi <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCF3 of <em>Caenorhabditis elegans</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.25&tcname=">3.A.1.211.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC protein, OptrA, of 619 aas and 0 TMSs, having the domain order of C-C.&nbsp; It is not involved in the export of drugs (oxazolidinones and phenicols)out of the cell and may confer ribosomal protection (<span id="ref34549212.30518106" class="cite">Wang <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p>
<p>.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>OptrA of<em> Enterococcus faecalis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.26&tcname=">3.A.1.211.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA17 or ABCAH or 1733 aas and 12 TMSs in a MCMC domain arrangement. ABCA17 mRNA is expressed exclusively in the testis, ABCA17 mRNA is expressed in germ cells, mainly spermatocytes, in the seminiferous tubule. It is localized in the endoplasmic reticulum, and intracellular esterified lipids, including cholesteryl esters, fatty acid esters and triacylglycerols, were decreased in cells stably expressing ABCA17. Thus, ABCA17 may play a role in regulating the lipid composition in sperm (<span id="ref34550256.15810880" class="cite">Ban <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA17 of <em>Mus musculus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.27"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.27&tcname=">3.A.1.211.27</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC A-type transporter of 1878 aas and 7 or 8 TMSs in a 1 + 6 + 1 TMS arrangement. The differentially expressed genes in early cystic development are associated with ATP-dependent transmembrane transporters (<span id="ref34551439.32373094" class="cite">Bai <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of <em>Echinococcus granulosus</em> (tape worm)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.28"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.28&tcname=">3.A.1.211.28</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC efflux pump, ABCI3, of 3133 aas and 14 TMSs in a 1 + 6 + 1 + 6 TMS arrangement.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCI3 of <em>Plasmodium falciparum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.3&tcname=">3.A.1.211.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Multidrug resistance pump, ABCA2 (ABC2).&nbsp;Mediates trafficking of LDL-derived free cholesterol (<span id="ref8848.21352852" class="cite">Voloshyna and Reiss, 2011</span>). Transports endogenous lipids such
as myelin (<span id="ref34546363.17415208" class="cite">Soichi <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA2 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.4&tcname=">3.A.1.211.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The <i>aced</i> cell death 7 (ced-7) protein (translocates molecules that mediate adhesion between dying and engulfing embryonic cells during programmed death).  </TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Animals</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Ced-7 of <i>Caenorhabditis elegans</i> (P34358)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.5&tcname=">3.A.1.211.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The surfactant-secreting porter, ABCA3 (exports lipids and proteins into lamellar bodies).  Fatal surfactant deficiency (FSD) can result from mutations in ABCA3, causing abnormal intracellular localization (type I) or decreased ATP hydrolysis (type II). Other mutations cause pediatric interstitial lung disease (pILD) (<span id="ref34544564.18676873" class="cite">Matsumura <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>).&nbsp; ABCA3 is found in lamellar bodies of lung alveolar type II cells where it probably secretes surfactants (mixture of lipids; e.g., PC) and proteins (e.g., surfactant proteins A, B, C and D) stored in lamellar bodies and exocytosed (<span id="ref5860.16959783" class="cite">Matsumura <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>).  ABCA3 plays an essential role in pulmonary surfactant lipid metabolism and lamellar body biogenesis, probably by transporting these lipids as substrates (<span id="ref5879.17267394" class="cite">Ban <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).  <span id="ref6039.17540762" class="cite">Cheong <em>et al.</em>, 2007</span> have shown that ABCA3 is critical for lamellar body biogenesis in mice. They suggested it functions in surfactant-protein B processing and lung development late in gestation. Lymphoma exosomes shield target cells from antibody attack, and exosome biogenesis is modulated by lysosome-associated ABCA3 which mediates resistance to chemotherapy. Silencing ABCA3 enhances susceptability of target cells to antibody-mediated lysis. Mechanisms of cancer cell resistance to drugs and antibodies are linked in an ABCA3-dependent pathway of exosome secretion (<span id="ref8265.21873242" class="cite">Aung <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>). <span id="ref34554031.34638622" class="cite">Onn&eacute;e <em>et al.</em> 2021</span> used the experimental structure of human ABCA4, to model at atomic resolution the human ABCA3 3D structure including transmembrane domains (TMDs), nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs), and regulatory domains (RDs) in an ATP-bound conformation. They mapped known pathogenic missense variants on this model, pinpointing amino-acids within the NBDs, the RDs and the interfaces between the NBDs and TMDs intracellular helices, which are predicted to play key roles in the structure and/or the function of the ABCA3 transporter (<span id="ref34554031.34638622" class="cite">Onn&eacute;e <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The cryo-EM structures of human ABCA3 in two distinct conformations, both at resolution of 3.3 A, have been solved (<span id="ref34554712.35394827" class="cite">Xie <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). In the absence of ATP, ABCA3 adopts a "lateral-opening" conformation with the lateral surfaces of TMSs exposed to the membrane and features two positively charged cavities within the TMSs as potential substrate binding sites. ATP binding induces pronounced conformational changes, resulting in the collapse of the potential substrate binding cavities. These results help to rationalize the disease-causing mutations in human ABCA3 and suggest a conserved "lateral access and extrusion" mechanism for both lipid export and import mediated by ABCA transporters  (<span id="ref34554712.35394827" class="cite">Xie <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). Cigarette smoke extract combined with LPS reduces ABCA3 expression in chronic pulmonary inflammation, and this may be related to PPARgamma/ P38 MAPK signaling pathway (<span id="ref34555440.36115154" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>). ABCA3 is unstable (<span id="ref34555529.36318016" class="cite">Onn&eacute;e <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA3 of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (Q99758)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.6&tcname=">3.A.1.211.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Xenobiotic transporter, ABCA8. It transports estradiol-&beta;-glucuronide, taurocholate, LTC4, para-amino-hippurate, ochratoxin-A and hydrophilic drugs (<span id="ref5762.12379217" class="cite">Tsuruoka <em>et al</em>., 2002</span>), (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). A novel pathway in ABCA8-regulated inhibition of human hepatocellular carcinoma tumorigenesis and metastasis has been identified (<span id="ref34551637.32430024" class="cite">Cui <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA8 of <em>Homo sapiens</em> (O94911)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.7&tcname=">3.A.1.211.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Half sized ABCA exporter, AbcA</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Amoeba</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>AbcA of <i>Dictyostelium discoideum</i><br>
M-C 655 aas; (Q94479)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.8&tcname=">3.A.1.211.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcA12 Keratinocyte lipid transporter. &nbsp;Transports lipids in lamellar granules to the apical surface of granular layer keratinocytes. Extracellular lipids, including ceramide, are thought to be essential for skin barrier function. ABCA12 mutations underlie the three main types of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyoses: harlequin ichthyosis, lamellar ichthyosis and congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma. ABCA12 mutations lead to defective lipid transport via lamellar granules in the keratinocytes, resulting in malformation of the epidermal lipid barrier and ichthyosis phenotypes. Lipid transport by ABCA12 is indispensable for intact differentiation of keratinocytes (<span id="ref8484.21695020" class="cite">Akiyama, 2011</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AbcA12 of <em>Mus musculus</em>&nbsp;(B9EKF0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.211.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.211.9&tcname=">3.A.1.211.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA5 of 1642 aas and 12 TMSs. It is related to lysosomal diseases and plays important roles, especially in cardiomyocytes and follicular cells (<span id="ref34550675.15870284" class="cite">Kubo <em>et al.</em> 2005</span>). It mediates cholesterol efflux to HDL3 (<span id="ref8848.21352852" class="cite">Voloshyna and Reiss, 2011</span>) and functions in autolysosomes (<span id="ref34549664.30923664" class="cite">Sakamoto <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Animals</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCA5 of <em>Homo sapiens</em>&nbsp;(Q8WWZ7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.212">3.A.1.212 The Mitochondrial Peptide Exporter (MPE) Family (ABCB)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.212.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.212.1&tcname=">3.A.1.212.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The mitochondrial peptide exporter, Mdl1p (exports peptides of 6-21 amino acyl residues from the mitochondrial matrix as well as degradation products of misassembled respiratory chain complexes) (<span id="ref5779.12746444" class="cite">Janas <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>; van der <span id="ref5827.16352609" class="cite">Does <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>; <span id="ref5905.17892490" class="cite">Gompf <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). A leaderless Mdl1p targets to the ER membrane instead of to the mitochondria (<span id="ref5905.17892490" class="cite">Gompf <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Yeast</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Mdl1p of <I>Saccharomyces cerevisiae </i> (P33310)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.212.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.212.2&tcname=">3.A.1.212.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>ABC mitochondrial peptide/MDR half transporter, MdlB. High copy number suppressor of ATM1 [iron-sulfur cluster transporter (3.A.1.210.1)]</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Md1B of <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> (M-C) (P33311)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.212.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.212.3&tcname=">3.A.1.212.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC-type MDR2 of 802 aas and 6 TMSs.&nbsp; Exports many drugs including antifungal agents (<span id="ref34547250.27121717" class="cite">Martins <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MDR of <em>Trichophyton tonsurans </em>(Scalp ringworm fungus)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.212.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.212.4&tcname=">3.A.1.212.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mitochondrial inner membrane ABC transporter of 805 aas and 6 TMSs near the N-terminus of the protein, MDL1.&nbsp; Mdl1 is involved in conidial germination, virulence, and resistance to anilinopyrimidine fungicides in <em>Botrytis cinerea </em>(<span id="ref34556631.37318357" class="cite">Fan <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bc-Mdl1 of <em>Botrytis cinerea</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.22">3.A.1.22 The Nickel Uptake Transporter (NiT) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.22.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.22.1&tcname=">3.A.1.22.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative nickel (Ni<sup>2+</sup>) and/or Cobalt (Co<sup>2+</sup>) porter with 4 components, CbiKMQO. CbiM and CbiQ probably have 6 TMSs, but TMSs 3 and 4 are close together.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CbiKMQO of <em>Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae</em> <br /> CbiK (R)<br /> CbiM (M)<br /> CbiQ (M)<br /> CbiO (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.22.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.22.2&tcname=">3.A.1.22.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The ABC exporter, CbiMNQ<sub>1</sub>O<sub>1. CbiM and CbiQ1 both have 6 TMSs in a 2 + 2 + 2 TMS arrangement.<br /></sub></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC exporter of <em>Desulfobacterium autotrophicum</em> <br />CbiM, 203 aas and 6 TMSs (M)<br />CbiN, 186 aas and 2 TMSs (N- and C-terminal) (Probable auxiliary subunit)<br />CbiQ1, 251 aas and 6 TMSs (M)<br />CbiO1, 244 aas and 0 TMSs (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.23">3.A.1.23 The Nickel/Cobalt Uptake Transporter (NiCoT) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>This and other ECF ABC families (3.A.1.18, 23, 25, 26, 28, 31 and 32) have been reviewed (<span id='ref34549157.30485755' class='cite'>Rempel <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.23.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.23.1&tcname=">3.A.1.23.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Nickel (Ni<sup>2+</sup>) porter (<span id="ref5791.14617641" class="cite">Chen and Burne, 2003</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UreMQO of <em>Streptococcus salivarius</em> <br /> UreM (M) (Q79CJ1) <br /> UreQ (M) (Q79CJ0) <br /> UreO (C) (Q79CI9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.23.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.23.2&tcname=">3.A.1.23.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Putative cobalt (Co<sup>2+</sup>) porter (<span id="ref5791.14617641" class="cite">Chen and Burne, 2003</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Firmicutes</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CbiMQOK of <em>Clostridium acetobutylicum</em> <br />
CbiM (M) (AAK79333) <br />
CbiQ (M) (AAK79335) <br />
CbiO (C) (AAK79336) <br />
CbiK (Auxiliary?) (AAK79334)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.23.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.23.3&tcname=">3.A.1.23.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cobalt (Co<sup>2+</sup>) porter&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&delta;-Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cbi M(N)OQ of <em>Geobacter sulfurreducens</em>&nbsp;<br />Cbi M(N) (D7AE13)<br />CbiO (D7AE10)<br />CbiQ (D7AE11)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.23.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.23.4&tcname=">3.A.1.23.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The NikM2 (230 aas; 5 TMSs)/NikN2 (110 aas; 2 TMSs) pair is part or all of a nickel transporter.&nbsp; The crystal structure of NikM2 is known (PDB 4M5C; 4M58).&nbsp; It possesses an additional TMS at its N-terminal region not present on other ECF transporter of known structure, resulting in 
an extracellular N-terminus. The highly conserved N-terminal loop 
inserts into the center of NikM2 and occludes a region corresponding 
to the <span class="highlight">substrate-binding</span> sites of the vitamin-specific S component. <span class="highlight">Nickel</span> binds to NikM2 by coordination to four nitrogen atoms in Met1, His2 and His67. These nitrogens form a square-<span class="highlight">planar</span> geometry, similar to that of the metal ion-binding sites in the amino-terminal Cu<sup>2+</sup>- and Ni<sup>2+</sup>-binding (ATCUN) motif (<span id="ref10507.24366337" class="cite">Yu <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).&nbsp; Constituents other than NikN2 and NikM2 are not known but may be required for activity (T. Eitinger, personal communication).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NikM2N2 of <em>Thermoanaerobacter
 tengcongensis&nbsp;
(Caldanaerobacter subterraneus subsp. tengcongensis)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.23.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.23.5&tcname=">3.A.1.23.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative Ni<sup>2+</sup>/Co<sup>2+</sup> uptake porter, NikMNOQ (<span id="ref10507.24366337" class="cite">Yu <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NikMNOQ of <em>Thermoanaerobacter tengcongensis</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.23.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.23.6&tcname=">3.A.1.23.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cobalt (Co<sup>2+</sup>) porter <span style="text-decoration: underline;">(<span id="ref5829.16352848" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al</em>., 2006).</span></span>&nbsp; CbiMN is a bipartite S-subunit with 8 TMSs (<span id="ref9168.20868747" class="cite">Siche <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>). Dynamic interactions of CbiN and CbiM trigger activity of the transporter (<span id="ref34550438.31666178" class="cite">Finkenwirth <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>). Substrate binding (S) components rotate within the membrane to expose their binding pockets alternately to the exterior and the cytoplasm. In contrast to vitamin transporters, metal-specific systems rely on additional proteins with essential functions. CbiN, with two TMSs tethered by an extracytoplasmic loop of 37 amino-acid residues is the auxiliary component that temporarily interacts with the CbiMQO<sub>2</sub> Co<sup>2+</sup> transporter. CbiN induces Co<sup>2+</sup> transport activity in the absence of CbiQO<sub>2</sub> in cells producing the S component CbiM plus CbiN or a Cbi(MN) fusion. <span id="ref34550438.31666178" class="cite">Finkenwirth <em>et al.</em> 2019</span> showed that any deletion in the CbiN loop abolished transport activity. Protein-protein contacts between segments of the CbiN loop and loops in CbiM were demonstrated, and an ordered structure of the CbiN loop was shown. The N-terminal loop of CbiM, containing three of four metal ligands was partially immobilized in wild-type Cbi(MN) but completely immobile in inactive variants with CbiN loop deletions. Thus, CbiM-CbiN loop-loop interactions facilitate metal insertion into the binding pocket (<span id="ref34550438.31666178" class="cite">Finkenwirth <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CbiMNOQ of <em>Salmonella typhimurium</em> <br /> CbiM (M) (Q05594) <br /> CbiN (Essential auxillary subunit) (Q05595) <br /> CbiO (C) (Q05596) <br /> CbiQ (M) (Q05598)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.23.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.23.7&tcname=">3.A.1.23.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Ni<sup>2+</sup>, Co<sup>2+</sup> uptake transporter, NikMNOQ (subunit sizes: NikMN, 347 aas, 9 TMSs; NikQ, 284 aas, 4 TMSs; NikO, 254 aas, 0 TMS.&nbsp; NikMN can take up Ni<sup>2+</sup> without NikQ or NikO (<span id="ref11106.24781825" class="cite">Kirsch and Eitinger 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NikMNQO of<em> Rhodobacter capsulatus<br /></em>NikMN (M; 9 TMSs)<em><br /></em>NikQ&nbsp; (M; 5 TMSs)<br />NikO (C; 0 TMSs)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.23.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.23.8&tcname=">3.A.1.23.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Ni<sup>2+</sup>/Co<sup>2+</sup> uptake porter, CbiMNOQ (CbiM, 222 aas, 5 TMSs; CbiN, 103 aas, 2 TMSs; CbiO, 280 aas, 0 TMSs; CbiQ, 244 aas, 5 TMSs).&nbsp; CbiMN can take up Ni<sup>2+</sup> without CbiO or CbiQ (<span id="ref11106.24781825" class="cite">Kirsch and Eitinger 2014</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CbiMNOQ of <em>Rhodobacter capsulatus</em><br />CbiM (M)<br />CbiN (M)<br />CbiO (C)<br />CbiQ (M)</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.24">3.A.1.24 The Methionine Uptake Transporter (MUT) Family (Similar to 3.A.1.3 and 3.A.1.12)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.24.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.24.1&tcname=">3.A.1.24.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The L- and D-methionine porter (also transports formyl-L-methionine and other methionine derivatives) (<span id="ref5781.12819857" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al</em>., 2003</span>). The 3.7A structure of MetNI has been solved. An allosteric regulatory mechanism operates at the level of transport activity, so increased intracellular levels of the transported ligand stabilize an inward-facing, ATPase-inactive state of MetNI to inhibit further ligand translocation into the cell (<span id="ref5532.18621668" class="cite">Kadaba <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>).&nbsp; The structure of an MetQ homologue in <em>Neisseria meningitidis</em> has been solved at 2.25&nbsp;&Aring; resolution revealing a bound methionine in the cleft between the two domains (<span id="ref34545350.19733245" class="cite">Yang <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>). Conformational changes in MetQ provide substrate access through the binding protein to the transmembrane translocation pathway. MetQ likely mediates uptake of methionine derivatives through two mechanisms: in the methionine-bound form, substrate is delivered from the periplasm to the transporter (the canonical mechanism) and in the apo form, it facilitates ligand binding when complexed to the transporter (the noncanonical mechanism). This dual role of substrate-binding proteins was proposed to provide a kinetic strategy for ABC transporters to transport both high- and low-affinity substrates present in a physiological concentration range (<span id="ref34549219.30352853" class="cite">Nguyen <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MetNIQ (<em>abc-yaeE-yaeC</em>) of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> MetN (C) AAC73310 <br /> MetI (M) AAC73309 <br /> MetQ (R) AAC73308</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.24.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.24.2&tcname=">3.A.1.24.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The L- and D-methionine porter (also transports methionine sulfoxide (<span id="ref5796.14990259" class="cite">Hullo <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Firmicutes</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>MetNPQ (YusCBA) of <i>Bacillus subtilis</i> <br>
MetN (C) CAB15264 <br>
MetP (M) CAB15263 <br>
MetQ (R) CAB15262</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.24.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.24.3&tcname=">3.A.1.24.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The methionine porter, AtmBDE (<span id="ref5897.17675375" class="cite">Sperandio <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>AtmBDE of <i>Streptococcus mutans</i><br>
AtmB (R) (Q8K8K9)<br>
AtmD (C) (Q8K8K8)<br>
AtmE (M) (Q8K8K7)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.24.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.24.4&tcname=">3.A.1.24.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>L-Methionine uptake porter, MetQNI<br /</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MetQNI of <em>Corynebacterium glutamicum</em><br />MetQ (R) (Q8NSN1)<br />MetN (C) (Q8NSN2)<br />MetI (M) (Q8NSN3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.24.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.24.5&tcname=">3.A.1.24.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>L-Histidine uptake porter, MetIQN (<span id="ref9981.18833300" class="cite">Johnson <em>et al.</em> 2008</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MetIQN of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em><br />MetI (M) (Q9HT69)<br />MetQ (R) (Q9HT68)<br />MetN (C) (Q9HT70)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.24.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.24.6&tcname=">3.A.1.24.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative peptide transporter, PepABC.&nbsp; The three components of this system are encoded in an operon with a gene encoding a peptidase (Q04MS7), providing the only tentative evidence for the substrate transported.&nbsp; However the similarity with the methionine transporter of <em>Streptococcus mutans</em> (TC# 3.A.1.24.3) suggests that this porter may also be a methionine uptake porter.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PepABC of<em> Streptococcus pneumoniae</em><br />PepA (R; 284 aas)<br />PepB (C; 353 aas)<br />PepC (M; 230 aas)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.25">3.A.1.25 The Biotin Uptake Transporter (BioMNY) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>This and other ECF ABC families (3.A.1.18, 23, 25, 26, 28, 31 and 32) have been reviewed (<span id='ref34549157.30485755' class='cite'>Rempel <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.25.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.25.1&tcname=">3.A.1.25.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The biotin uptake porter (binding receptor lacking) (see also the VUT or ECF family; BioY; 2.A.88.1.1) (<span id="ref5829.16352848" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>; <span id="ref5521.17301237" class="cite">Hebbeln <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>). BioN (the EcfT component of the biotin transporter) appears to be required for intramolecular signaling and subunit assembly (<span id="ref6744.19717603" class="cite">Neubauer <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>). The Ala-Arg-Ser and Ala-Arg-Gly signatures in BioN are coupling sites to the BioM ATPases (<span id="ref8284.22216173" class="cite">Neubauer <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).&nbsp; Subunit stoicheometries have been estimated with the prediction that there are oligomeric forms of BioM and BioY in the BioMNY complex (<span id="ref9175.20738254" class="cite">Finkenwirth <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BioMNY of <em>Rhizobium etli</em> <br /> BioM (C) (226 aas; 0 TMSs; Q6GUB2)  <br /> BioN (M) (202 aas; 5 TMSs; Q6GUB1)  <br /> BioY (M) (189 aas; 6 TMSs; Q6GUB0)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.25.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.25.2&tcname=">3.A.1.25.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative biotin Ecf transporter, EcfSAA'T (function assigned based on genome context analyses).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative Ecf transporter, EcfSAA'T, of <em>Methanospirillum hungatei</em>&nbsp;<br />EcfS (M) (Q2FUL6)<br />EcfA (C) (Q2FUL5)<br />EcfA' (C) (Q2FUM0)<br />EcfT (M) (Q2FNH6)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.25.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.25.3&tcname=">3.A.1.25.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative biotin Ecf transporter, EcfSAA'T (function assigned based on genome context analyses).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative EcfSAA'T transporter of <em>Methanocorpusculum labreanum</em><br />EcfS (A2SPQ3)<br />EcfA (A2SPQ4)<br />EcfA' (A2SPQ5)<br />EcfT (A2SPQ6)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.25.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.25.4&tcname=">3.A.1.25.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.25.4"></a></p>
<p>The biotin uptake system, BioMNY. The 3-d structure of the EcfS subunit, BioY, at 2.1&Aring; resolution is known (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9211">Berntsson <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>). BioY and ThiT from <em>L. lactis</em>&nbsp;show similar N-terminal structures for interaction with the ECF module but divergent C-terminal structures for substrate binding. BioY alone binds biotin but doesn''t transport it (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9211">Berntsson <em>et al.</em>, 2012</a>).&nbsp; Ala-Arg-Ser and Ala-Arg-Gly signatures in BioN are probably coupling sites to the two BioM ATPase subunits (<span id="ref8284.22216173" class="cite"><span id="ref8284.22216173" class="cite">Neubauer <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span></span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BioMNY of <em>Lactococcus lactis&nbsp;</em><br />BioM (A) (A2RI01)<br />BioN (T) (A2RI03)<br />BioY (S) (A2RMJ9)<em>&nbsp;</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.25.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.25.5&tcname=">3.A.1.25.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Biotin/Riboflavin ECF transport system, EcfAA'T/RibU/BioY (<span id="ref9597.23359690" class="cite">Karpowich and Wang 2013</span>). RibU binds riboflavin with high affinity, and the protein-substrate complex is
exceptionally stable in solution. The crystal structure of riboflavin-bound RibU reveals an
electronegative binding pocket at the extracellular surface in which the substrate is completely
buried (<span id="ref34545451.27312125" class="cite">Karpowich <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EcfAA''T/RibU/BioY of <em>Thermatoga martima</em><br />EcfA (C) (Q9WY65)<br />EcfA'' (C) (Q9X1Z1)<br />EcfT (M) (Q9X2I1)<br />BioY (M) (Q9X1G6)<br />RibU (M)<em>&nbsp;</em>(Q9WZQ6)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.25.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.25.6&tcname=">3.A.1.25.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Riboflavin ECF transport system, EcfAA'T/RibU (<span id="ref9597.23359690" class="cite">Karpowich and Wang 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EcfAA'T/RibU of <em>Streptococcus thermophilus</em>&nbsp;<br />EcfA (C) (Q5M244)<br />EcfA' (C) (Q5M243)<br />EcfT (M) (Q5M245)<br /><span style="font-size: 10px;">RibU (M) (Q5M614)</span></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.25.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.25.7&tcname=">3.A.1.25.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The riboflavin uptake system, BioMNY.&nbsp; BioM, EtcA, ATPase, 234 aas;&nbsp; BioN, EtcT, 190 aas, 5 TMSs; BioY, EtcS, 210 aas, 5 TMSs BioY can also function as a secondary carrier and is therefore listed separately under TC# 2.A.88.1.3.&nbsp; ATP-dependent conformational changes drive substrate capture and release when BioMNY are together in a complex (<span id="ref34544159.25991724" class="cite">Finkenwirth <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RibMNY of <em>Rhodobacter capsulatus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.25.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.25.8&tcname=">3.A.1.25.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>An ECF ABC transporter with 4 subunits, EcfS/EcfT/EcfA/EcfA'.&nbsp; EcfS is also called RibU; EcfT is also called CbiQ, EcfA is also called Cbi01, and EcfA' is also called Cbi02.&nbsp; This system can take up riboflavin and possibly other vitamins (<span id="ref34544131.26052893" class="cite">Karpowich <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). ATP binding to the EcfAA' ATPases drives a conformational change that 
dissociates the S subunit from the EcfAA'T ECF module. Upon release from
 the ECF module, the RibU S subunit then binds the riboflavin transport 
substrate.&nbsp; S subunits for distinct substrates compete 
for the ATP-bound state of the ECF module (<span id="ref34544131.26052893" class="cite">Karpowich <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). RibU appears to be capable of exporting riboflavin, FMN and FAD (<span id="ref34549341.30209391" class="cite">Light <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>). More recently, this system has been shown to functioin in three capacities; all use EcfA (Ecf1), EcfB (Ecf2), both ATPases. Two of them also use RibU (EcfS).&nbsp; The first complex uses EcfT and RibU and imports FAD; the second uses FmnA and RibU and takes up vitamin B2 (riboflavin derivatives); the third uses FmnA and EetB and exports FAD (<span id="ref34556889.36744898" class="cite">Rivera-Lugo <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Thus, these three systems are partially redundant. FmnA is also called AuxA and can be found under TC# 9.B.414.1.1.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EcfSTAA' complex of <br /><em>LIsteria monocytogenes<br /></em>EcfS, RibU, 203 aas and 5 TMSs<br />EcfT, CbiQ, 265 aas and 6 TMSs<br />EcfA, Cbi01, 279 aas<br />EcfA', Cbi02, 288 aas<br />EetB, 180 aas and 5 TMSs (S5LID4)&nbsp; This protein is also in a family of homologs of unknown functions; see TC# 5.B.14.1.1. These proteins may serve as alternative subunits of this type of ABC porters (see <span id="ref34556889.36744898" class="cite">Rivera-Lugo <em>et al.</em> 2023 </span>). <br />Another putative subunit, FmnA or AuxA, is found in TCDB with the TC# 9.B.414.1.1.</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.26">3.A.1.26 The Putative Thiamine Uptake Transporter (ThiW) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>This and other ECF ABC families (3.A.1.18, 23, 25, 26, 28, 31 and 32) have been reviewed (<span id='ref34549157.30485755' class='cite'>Rempel <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.26.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.26.1&tcname=">3.A.1.26.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative thiazole ABC porter (COG4732), ThiW; 718 aas; 5 TMSs; domain order: M-C-C; plus the putative ATPase binding subunit, CbiQ homologue (binding receptor unknown) (<span id="ref6318.18931129" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ThiW/CbiQ of <em>Chloroflexus aurantiacus</em><br />ThiW MCC (SAA) (A9WGB0)<br />CbiQ M (T) (A9WGA9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.26.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.26.10&tcname=">3.A.1.26.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ATP-dependent folic acid uptake porter, FolT/EcfT/EcfA1/EcfA2.&nbsp; The crystal structure of FolT has been solved to 3.2 &Aring; resolution in substrate-bound and free conformations, revealing a potential gating mechanism (<span id="ref34544321.26198469" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FolT/EcfT/EcfA1/EcfA2 of <em>Enterococcus faecalis</em><br />FolT, 182 aas, 5 TMSs<br />EcfT, 264 aas, 6 TMSs<br />EcfA1, 279 aas<br />EcfA2, 289 aas</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.26.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.26.11&tcname=">3.A.1.26.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative pantothenate uptake porter, PanT/EcfA/EcfA'/EcfT (<span id="ref34545288.25345570" class="cite">Rodionova <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC (Ecf) pantothenate transporter of <em>Ktedonobacter racemifer<br /></em>PanT, (M, substrate binding subunit)<br />EcfA, (C) <br />EcfA', (C)<br />EcfT, (M, transducer subunit)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.26.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.26.12&tcname=">3.A.1.26.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Chloroplast heavy metal ion uptake porter with at least two components, ABCI10, 271 aas (C) and ABCI12, 391 aas (M), present in the inner chloroplast envelope. Loss of ABCI10 and ABCI11 gene products in <em>Arabidopsis</em> leads to dwarfed, albino plants showing impaired chloroplast biogenesis and deregulated metal homeostasis. The membrane-intrinsic protein ABCI12 may be the interaction partner for ABCI10. Thus, ABCI12 may insert into the chloroplast inner envelope membrane with five or six predicted TMSs (<span id="ref34550579.31736987" class="cite">Voith von Voithenberg <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCI10 and ABC12 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.26.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.26.2&tcname=">3.A.1.26.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ThiW homologue/CbiQ homologue (ThiW: 647 aas; M-C-C; 5-6TMSs) (<span id="ref6318.18931129" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ThiW/ChiQ of <em>Methanocorpusculum labreanum</em><br />ThiW MCC (SAA) (A2SPE8)<br />CbiQ M (T) (A2SPE9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.26.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.26.3&tcname=">3.A.1.26.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ThiW homologue (711 aas;
