<span id="ref6887.12376536" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al.</em>, 2002</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ThiW-EcfA1-EcfA2-EcfT of <em>Enterococcus faecalis </em><br />ThiW (M) (Q830K3)<br />EcfA1 (C) (Q839D5)<br />EcfA2 (C) (Q839D4)<br />EcfT (M) (Q839D3)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.26.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.26.8&tcname=">3.A.1.26.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative biotin Ecf transporter, EcfSAT</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative Ecf transpoter, EcfSAT, of <em>Archaeoglobus fulgidus</em>&nbsp;<br />S-subunit (M) (O29098)&nbsp;<br />A-subunit (C) (O29097)&nbsp;<br />T-subunit (M) (O29096)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.26.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.26.9&tcname=">3.A.1.26.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.26.9"></a></p>
<p>The folate transporter, FolT/EcfAA''T (The 3-d structure is known to 3.0&Aring; resolution (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9812">Xu <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>; 4HUQ).&nbsp; This transporter uses the same ECF energy coupling complex (AA''T) as 3.A.1.28.2.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>FolT/EcfAA'T of <em>Lactobacillus brevis<br /></em>FolT (M; EcfS subunit) (Q03S56)<br />EcfA (C) (Q03PY6)<br />EcfA' (C) (Q03PY7)<br />EcfT (M) (Q03PY5)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.27">3.A.1.27 The &#947;-Hexachlorocyclohexane (HCH) Family (Similar to 3.A.1.12 and 3.A.1.24)</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.27.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.27.1&tcname=">3.A.1.27.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The &#947;-hexachlorocyclohexane (&#947;HCH) uptake permease, LinKLMN (most similar to 3.A.1.12.4, the QAT family) (<span id="ref5882.17369300" class="cite">Endo <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>LinKLMN of <i>Sphingobium japonicum</i> <br>
LinK (M) (BAF51698) <br>
LinL (C) (BAF51699) <br>
LinM (R) (BAF51700) <br>
LinN (lipoprotein) (BAF51701)  </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.27.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.27.2&tcname=">3.A.1.27.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p>The chloroplast lipid (trigalactosyl diacyl glycerol (TDG)) transporter, Tdg1,2,3 (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref5914">Lu <em>et al</em>., 2007</a>).  Lipids such as mono- and digalactolipids are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of plant cells and transferred to the thylakoid membranes of chloroplasts. Mutations in an outer chloroplastic envelope protein with 350 aas and 7 putative TMSs in the last 250 residues may catalyze translocation as part of a lipid transfer complex (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref5778">Xu <em>et al</em>., 2003</a>; <span id="ref9232.22544736" class="cite">Roston <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Plant Chloroplast</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Tdg 1,2,3 of <em>Arabidopsis thaliana</em>: <br /> Tdg1 (M) (Q8L4R0) <br /> Tdg2 (R) (Q3EB35) <br /> Tdg3 (C) (Q9AT00)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.27.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.27.3&tcname=">3.A.1.27.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter maintaining outer membrane (OM) lipid asymmetry, MlaABCDEF (YrbABCDEF) (<span id="ref7039.19383799" class="cite">Malinverni and Silhavy, 2009</span>). MlaA (VacJ) is a "spreading" protein, essential for <em>Shigella&nbsp;</em>pathogenicity (<span id="ref8827.8145644" class="cite">Suzuki <em>et al.</em>, 1994</span>).&nbsp; The ABC transporter, MlaEFBD, provides energy for maintaining OM lipid asymmetry via the transport of 
aberrantly localized phospholipids (PLs) from the OM to the inner 
membrane (IM) (<span id="ref34546663.27529189" class="cite">Thong <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>). MlaD spans the periplasm, forms stable hexamers within the complex, functions in 
substrate binding with strong affinity for PLs within a channel that spans the periplasm, and modulates ATP 
hydrolytic activity. MlaB plays critical roles in both the 
assembly and activity of the transporter.&nbsp; MlaA forms a complex with OmpC and OmpF in the outer membrane to extract PLs from the outer leaflet of the OM (<span id="ref34546665.26314242" class="cite">Chong <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). MlaA is a monomeric 2 &alpha;-helical TMS OM protein that functions as a 
phospholipid translocation channel, forming a ~20-&Aring;-thick doughnut 
embedded in the inner leaflet of the OM with a central, amphipathic 
pore (<span id="ref34547597.29038444" class="cite">Abell&oacute;n-Ruiz <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). This architecture prevents access of inner leaflet phospholipids 
to the pore, but allows <span class="highlight">outer</span> leaflet phospholipids to bind to a pronounced ridge surrounding the 
channel. Members of the mammalian cell entry (MCE) protein family, one of which is MlaD, form hexameric 
assemblies with a central channel capable of mediating lipid transport across the periplasm (<span id="ref34551573.28388411" class="cite">Ekiert <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). 
MlaD forms a ring associated with the ABC 
transporter complex in the inner membrane. A soluble lipid-binding 
protein, MlaC ferries lipids between MlaD and an outer membrane protein
 complex. EM structures of two other <em>E. coli</em> MCE proteins 
show that YebT (LetB) forms an elongated tube consisting of seven stacked MCE 
rings, and PqiB adopts a syringe-like architecture. Both YebT and PqiB 
create channels of sufficient length to span the periplasmic space. These homologs transport lipids between the two membranes of 
Gram-negative bacteria, some eukaryotic organelles and possibly actinobacteria (<span id="ref34551573.28388411" class="cite">Ekiert <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>). MCE systems mediate phospholipid trafficking across the periplasm. ~3.5 &Aring; cryo-EM structures of the <em>E. coli</em> MCE protein 
LetB reveals an ~0.6 megadalton complex that consists of seven stacked 
rings, with a central hydrophobic tunnel sufficiently long to span the 
periplasm (<span id="ref34551574.32359438" class="cite">Isom <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Lipids bind inside the tunnel, suggesting that it functions 
as the pathway for lipid transport. Cryo-EM structures in the open and 
closed states revealed a dynamic tunnel lining with implications for 
gating and substrate translocation. These results support a model in which 
LetB establishes a physical link between the two membranes and creates a
 hydrophobic pathway for the translocation of lipids across the 
periplasm (<span id="ref34551574.32359438" class="cite">Isom <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). The transmembrane subunit, MlaE, has minimal sequence similarity to other transporters.&nbsp;<span id="ref34552292.33236984" class="cite">Coudray <em>et al.</em> 2020</span> reported the cryo-EM structure of MlaFEDB at 3.05 &Aring; resolution, revealing distant relationships to the LPS and MacAB transporters, as well as members of the eukaryotic ABCA/ABCG families. A continuous transport pathway extends from the MlaE substrate- binding site, through the channel of MlaD, and into the periplasm. Two phospholipids are bound to MlaFEDB, suggesting that multiple lipid substrates may be transported each cycle. The structure provides mechanistic insight into substrate recognition and transport by MlaFEDB (<span id="ref34552292.33236984" class="cite">Coudray <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). Structures of both the <em>E. coli</em> and <em>P. aeruginosa</em> MlaFEDB complexes have been determined by cryoEM (<span id="ref34552962.33845086" class="cite">Zhou <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>). The structures show that the MlaFEBD complex contains a total of twelve protein molecules with a stoichiometry of MlaF<sub>2</sub>E<sub>2</sub>B<sub>2</sub>D<sub>6</sub>, and binds a plethora of phospholipids (PLs) at different locations. In contrast to canonical ABC transporters, nucleotide binding fails to trigger significant conformational changes of both MlaFEBD and MlaFEB in the nucleotide-binding and transmembrane domains, correlated with their low ATPase activities exhibited in both detergent micelles and lipid nanodiscs. PLs or detergents appeared to relocate to the membrane-proximal end from the distal end of the hydrophobic tunnel formed by the MlaD hexamer in MlaFEBD upon addition of ATP, indicating that retrograde PL transport might occur in the tunnel in an ATP-dependent manner. Site-specific photocrosslinking experiment confirmed that the substrate-binding pocket in the dimeric MlaE and the MlaD hexamer are able to bind PLs in vitro, in line with the notion that the MlaFEBD complex functions as a PL transporter (<span id="ref34552962.33845086" class="cite">Zhou <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).&nbsp; Mla uses a shuttle-like mechanism to move lipids between the MlaFEDB 
inner membrane complex and the MlaA-OmpF/C OM complex, via a periplasmic
 lipid-binding protein, MlaC. MlaC binds to MlaD and MlaA (<span id="ref34556342.37100290" class="cite">MacRae <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). They mapped the MlaC-MlaA and MlaC-MlaD protein-protein interfaces, suggesting that the MlaD and MlaA binding surfaces on MlaC overlap to a 
large extent, leading to a model in which MlaC can only bind one of 
these proteins at a time. Low-resolution cryo-EM maps of MlaC bound to MlaFEDB suggested that at least two MlaC 
molecules can bind to MlaD at once, in a conformation consistent with 
AlphaFold2 predictions (<span id="ref34556342.37100290" class="cite">MacRae <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). The Mla system of the diderm Firmicute, <em>Veillonella parvula</em>, reveals an ancestral transenvelope bridge for phospholipid trafficking (<span id="ref34557587.37993432" class="cite">Grasekamp <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MlaABCDEF of <em>E. coli</em><br />MlaA, YrbA, OM lipoprotein component (251aas) (P76506)<br />MlaB, YrbB cytoplasmic STAS component (97aas) (P64602)<br />MlaC, YrbC periplasmic binding receptor (R) (211aas) (P0ADV7)<br />MlaD, YrbD anchored periplasmic binding receptor (R) (183aas) (P64604)<br />MlaE, YrbE inner membrane permease component (M) (260aas) (P64606)<br />MlaF, YrbF ATP binding protein (C) (269aas) (P63386)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.27.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.27.4&tcname=">3.A.1.27.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The cholesterol uptake porter (<span id="ref7040.18955493" class="cite">Mohn <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>). Takes up cholesterol, 5-&alpha;-cholestanol, 
5-&alpha;-cholestanone, &beta;-sitosterol, etc. (It is not established that all of 
these proteins comprise the system or that other gene products are not 
involved.)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cholesterol uptake porter of <em>Rhodococcus jostii</em><br />YrbE4A (ro04696; 254aas; 5-6 TMSs) (M) (Q0S7K4)<br />YrbE4B (ro04697; 283aas; 5 TMSs) (M) (Q0S7K3)<br />MceE4A (ro04698; 391aas; 1 N-terminal TMS) (R) (Q0S7K2)<br />MceE4B (ro04699; 338aas; 1 N-terminal TMS) (R) (Q0S7K1)<br />MlkA (ro01974; 363aas; 0 TMSs) (C) (Q0SFA1)<br />MlkB (ro01744; 346aas; 0 TMSs) (C) (Q0SD37)</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.27.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.27.5&tcname=">3.A.1.27.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Mce/Yrb/Mlk (Mammalian cell entry) ABC-type putative steroid uptake transporter (involved in several aspects of mycobacterial pathogenesis) (<span id="ref7040.18955493" class="cite">Mohn <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>; <span id="ref7064.16868085" class="cite">Joshi <em>et al.</em>, 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Mce transporter of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em> H37Rv<br />YrbE4A (M) (254aas; 6 TMSs) (O53546)<br />YrbE4B (M) (280aas; 5 TMSs) (O53545)<br />MceA (R) (242aas; 1 TMS) (O06356)<br />MceB (R) (244aas; 1 TMS) (O07422)<br />Mlk (C) (Mkl; MceG; 359aas; 0 TMSs) (P63357)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.27.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.27.6&tcname=">3.A.1.27.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mce1A-F hetero-hexameric uptake porter for mycolic acid and fatty acids. The structure of Mce1A is known (<span id="ref34553845.34584737" class="cite">Asthana <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>); MceE = LprK. Each of the four Mce complexes in Mtb (Mce1-4) comprises six substrate-binding proteins (SBPs; MceA-F), each of which contains four conserved domains (N-terminal transmembrane, MCE, helical and C-terminal unstructured tail domains). In the crystal structure of the MCE domain of Mce4A (MtMce4A39-140) a domain-swapped conformation is observed. The fact that there are six SBPs in each Mtb <em>mce</em> operon suggests that the MceA-F SBPs from Mce1-4 may form heterohexamers. The helical domains interact with the detergent micelle, suggesting that when assembled, the helical domains of MceA-F may form a hydrophobic pore for lipid transport, as observed in PqiB of <em>E. coli</em> (<span id="ref34553845.34584737" class="cite">Asthana <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mce1A-F of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis<br /></em>Mce1A, 454 aas and 3 TMSs, Q79FZ9<br />Mce1B, 346 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS, O07414<br />Mce1C, 515 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS, O07415<br />Mce1D, 530 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS, O07416<br />Mce1E = LprK, 390 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS, O07417<br />Mce1F, 515 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS, L0T2W6<br /><em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.27.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.27.7&tcname=">3.A.1.27.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mce2A-F hetero-hexameric receptor complex of a lipid-transporting ABC uptake system. A <em>Mycobacterium bovis</em> &Delta;mce2 double deletion mutant protects cattle against a challenge with virulent M. bovis (<span id="ref34553846.23518075" class="cite">Blanco <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). The expression ratio of all selected <em>mce</em> operon genes in all <em>M. 
tuberculosis</em> isolates was reduced at the initial phase and increased 
substantially at a later phase of growth. Higher expression of <em>mce1 </em> operon genes was found in all <em>M. tuberculosis</em> isolates as compared to 
other mce operon genes (<em>mce2</em> and <em>mce3</em> operons) at stationary growth 
phase (<span id="ref34553847.27377506" class="cite">Singh <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Mce2A-F of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis <br />Mce2A, Q79FY7, 404 aas<br />Mce2B, O07788, 275 aas<br />Mce2C, O07787, 481 aas<br />Mce2D, A5TZX3, 508 aas<br />Mce2E (IprL), I6Y461, 402 aas<br />Mce2F, O07784, 516 aas<br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.28">3.A.1.28 The Queuosine (Queuosine) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>This and other ECF ABC families (3.A.1.18, 23, 25, 26, 28, 31 and 32) have been reviewed (<span id='ref34549157.30485755' class='cite'>Rempel <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.28.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.28.1&tcname=">3.A.1.28.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative queuosine uptake transporter, QrtTUVW (<span id="ref6318.18931129" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al.,</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>QrtTUVW of <em>Salmonella enterica</em> su. typh.<br />QrtT (M) (Q8XGV9)<br /> QrtU (M) (Q8Z3V9)<br /> QrtV (C) (Q8Z3V8)<br /> QrtW (C) (Q8Z3V7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.28.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.28.2&tcname=">3.A.1.28.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a id="3.A.1.26"></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.26.9"></a></p>
<p>The folate transporter, FolT/EcfAA''T (The 3-d structure is known to 3.0&Aring; resolution (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9812">Xu <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>; 4HUQ).&nbsp; Thiamine and riboflavin may also be substrates.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EcfAA'ST of <em>Lactobacillus brevis</em><br />EcfA (C) (Q03PY5)<br />EcfA' (C) (Q03PY6)<br />EcfS (M) (Q03NM0)<br />EcfT (M) (Q03PY7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.29">3.A.1.29 The Methionine Precursor (Met-P) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.29.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.29.1&tcname=">3.A.1.29.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative methionine precursor/uptake transporter, MtsTUV (T is most similar to 3.A.1.23.2; U is most similar to 2.A.36.7.1 and 3.A.1.14.2; V is most similar to 3.A.1.23.2 and 3.A.1.25.1) (<span id="ref6318.18931129" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MtsTUV of <em>Lactobacillus johnsoni</em><br /> MtsT (M) (Q74I63) <br /> MtsU (C) (Q74I62)<br />MtsV (M) (Q74I61)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.29.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.29.2&tcname=">3.A.1.29.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>This ABC uptake porter of unknown substrate specificity is unusual in that all four subunits of a typical ECF transporter occur in a single polypeptide chain of 1148 aas with the domain order as follows: (1) a hydrophilic domain of ~200 aas, (2) the S (substrate binding) domain, (3) the first ATPase domain, (4) another hydrophilic domain, (5) the second ATPase domiain, (6) the T (transducer) domain. It is not unusual for eukaryotes to fuse domains of an ABC porter together, but this is the first one we have observed in this type of ABC transporter. Based on its similarity with TC# 3.A.1.29.1, it may transport Methionine, but the entry in NCBI indicates possible substrates to be Co<sup>2+</sup> or riboflavin (based only on sequence similarity).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ECF-type ABC transporter of <em>Hortaea werneckii</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.3">3.A.1.3 The Polar Amino Acid Uptake Transporter (PAAT) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.1&tcname=">3.A.1.3.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Histidine/arginine/lysine/ornithine porter (<span id="ref34544666.24021237" class="cite">Heuveling <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). In contrast to some homologous homodimeric systems, the heterodimeric histidine transporter of <em>Salmonella enterica</em> Typhimurium&nbsp; ligands only one substrate molecule in between its two transmembrane subunits, HisM and HisQ (<span id="ref34549220.30348830" class="cite">Heuveling <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HisJ (histidine receptor)-ArgT (arg/lys/orn receptor)-HisMPQ of <em>Salmonella typhimurium</em> <br /> HisJ (R)<br /> ArgT (R)<br /> HisM (M)<br /> HisQ (M)<br /> HisP (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.10&tcname=">3.A.1.3.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cystine/cysteine/diaminopimelate transporter, CysXYZ; these proteins are also designated FliY/YecS/YecC.&nbsp; Note, another transporter is designated CysZ in <em>E. coli</em> (TC# 2.A.121.1.1).&nbsp; CysXYZ also transports the toxic amino acid analogues, L-selenaproline (SCA; L-selenazolidine-4-carboxylic acid) and L-selenocystine (SeCys) (<span id="ref34543631.25139244" class="cite">Deutch <em>et al.</em> 2014</span>). FliY binds L-cystine, L-cysteine, and D-cysteine with micromolar affinities, but binding of the L- and D-enantiomers induced different conformational changes in FliY, where the L- enantiomer/SBP complex interacted more efficiently with the YecSC transporter. YecSC has low basal ATPase activity that is moderately stimulated by apo-FliY, more strongly by D-cysteine-bound FliY, and maximally by L-cysteine- or L-cystine-bound FliY (<span id="ref34551129.32144203" class="cite">Sabrialabe <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>). FliY may exist in a conformational equilibrium between an open, unliganded form that does not bind to the YecSC transporter and closed, unliganded and closed, liganded forms that bind this transporter with variable affinities but equally stimulate its ATPase activity. These findings differ from previous observations for similar ABC transporters, highlighting the extent of mechanistic diversity in this large protein family (<span id="ref34551129.32144203" class="cite">Sabrialabe <em>et al.</em> 2020</span>).</p>
<hr /></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cys/Dap porter of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> CysX or FliY (R)<br /> CysY or YecS (M)<br /> CysZ or YecC (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.11&tcname=">3.A.1.3.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Arginine/ornithine (but not lysine) porter (<span id="ref34550485.9791103" class="cite">Nishijyo <em>et al.</em> 1998</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AotJQMP of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em> <br /> AotJ (R)<br /> AotQ (M)<br /> AotM (M)<br /> AotP (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.12&tcname=">3.A.1.3.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Arginine/lysine/histidine/glutamine porter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Cyanobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>BgtAB of <I>Synechocystis</I> PCC6803 </br>
BgtA (C)<br> 
BgtB (R-M)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.13&tcname=">3.A.1.3.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uptake system for L-cystine (Km=2.5 &mu;M), L-cystathionine, L-djenkolate ( 2-amino-3-[(2-amino-3-hydroxy-3-oxopropyl)sulfanylmethylsulfanyl] propanoic acid), and S-methyl-L-cysteine (<span id="ref6048.15262924" class="cite">Burgui&egrave;re <em>et al.</em>, 2004</span>, <span id="ref6047.16109943" class="cite">Burgui&egrave;re <em>et al.</em>, 2005</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>TcyJKLMN (YtmJKLMN) of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em> <br /> TcyJ (R)  (NP_390816)  <br /> TcyK (R)  (O34852)  <br /> TcyL (M)  (O34315)  <br /> TcyM (M)  (O34931)  <br /> TcyN (C)  (O34900)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" The basal ATPase activity (ATP hydrolysis in the absence of substrate) is mainly caused by the docking of the closed-unliganded state of GlnH onto the transporter domain of GlnPQ. Unlike glutamine, arginine binds both GlnH domains, but does not trigger their closing. Comparison of the ATPase activity in nanodiscs with glutamine transport in proteoliposomes suggested that the stoichiometry of ATP per substrate is close to two (<span id=""ref34547823.29432725"" class=""cite"">Lycklama A Nijeholt <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GlnHPQ of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> GlnH (R)<br /> GlnP (M)<br /> GlnQ (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.20&tcname=">3.A.1.3.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative lysine uptake system, LysXY</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>LysXY of <em>Streptococcus pyogenes</em><br />LysX (R-M) (Q9A1H0)<br />LysY (C) (Q9A1H1)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.21&tcname=">3.A.1.3.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.3.21"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>Hydroxy L-proline uptake porter, HprABC (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9981">Johnson <em>et al.</em> 2008</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HprABC of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa<br /></em>HprA (C) (Q9I488)<br />HprB (M) (Q9I487)<br />HprC (R) (Q9I484)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.22&tcname=">3.A.1.3.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p>
<p><!-- test--></p>
<p><a id="3.A.1.3.22"></a></p>
<p>Amino acid transporter, AatJMQP. Probably transports L-glutamate, D-glutamate, L-glutamine and N-acetyl L-glutamate (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9981">Johnson <em>et al.</em> 2008</a>). Very similar to 3.A.1.3.19 of <em>P. putida</em></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>AatJMQP of <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em><br />AatJ (R) (Q9I402)<br />AatM (M) (Q9I403)<br />AatQ (M) (Q9I404)<br />AatP (C) (Q9I405)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.23&tcname=">3.A.1.3.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.3.23"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>Amino acid transporter, PA5152-PA5155. Probably transports numerous amino acids including lysine, arginine, histidine, D-alanine and D-valine (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9981">Johnson <em>et al.</em> 2008</a>). Regulated by ArgR.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PA5152-PA5144 of Pseudomonas aeruginosa<br />PA5152 (C) (Q9HU32)<br />PA5153 (R) (Q9HU31)<br />PA5154 (M) (Q9HU30)<br />PA5155 (M) (Q9HU29)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.24&tcname=">3.A.1.3.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative methionine uptake porter, Sco_5260, 5259, 5258. Defects cause impaired sporulation, reduced growth and reduced production of actinorhodin and undecylprodigiosin. Induced by S-adenosylmethionine (<span id="ref10324.18092466" class="cite">Shin <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Sco_5260, 5259, 5258 of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em><br />Sco5260 (R) 320aas (Q9F3K5)<br />Sco5259 (M) 316aas (Q9F3K6)<br />Sco5258 (C) 253aas (Q9F3K7)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.25&tcname=">3.A.1.3.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glutamine transporter, GlnQP. Takes up glutamine, asparagine and glutamate which compete for each other for binding to the substrate/transmembrane protein constituent of the system (<span id="ref34544696.26553850" class="cite">Fulyani <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). Tandem substrate binding domains&nbsp; differ in substrate specificity and affinity, allowing cells to efficiently accumulate
different amino acids via a single ABC transporter. Analysis revealed the roles of individual residues in determining the substrate
affinity (<span id="ref10494.23994008" class="cite">Fulyani <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). Protein-protein interactions and conformational states were studied simultaneously using PIFE-FRET (<span id="ref34552987.33823661" class="cite">Ploetz <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>GlnPQ of <em>Lactococcus lactis </em>subsp. cremoris<em> (Streptococcus cremoris)</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.26&tcname=">3.A.1.3.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative polar amino acid uptake porter, YhdWXYZ.&nbsp; Probably under NtrBC transcriptional control (<span id="ref34543657.16816893" class="cite">Jiang <em>et al.</em> 2006</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacterial</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YhdWXYZ of<em> E. coli</em><br />YhdW (R)<br />YhdX (M)<br />YhdY (M)<br />YhdZ (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.27"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.27&tcname=">3.A.1.3.27</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Basic amino acid uptake porter, ArtIQ<sub>2</sub>N<sub>2.</sub> Transports Arginine, lysine and histidine.&nbsp; Several 3-d structures have been solved (4YMS, 4YMT, 4YMU, etc., <span id=""ref34543946.25848002"" class=""cite"">Yu <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp; These revealed one binding site for substrate per ArtQ monomer.&nbsp; <span id=""ref34548048.29581409"" class=""cite"">Heuveling <em>et al.</em> 2018</span> then showed that in the close homologue, ArtMP of <em>Geobacillus stearothermophilus,</em> that just one of these two sites needed to bind substrate to get transport.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ArtIQ<sub>2</sub>N<sub>2</sub> of <em>Caldanaerobacter subterraneus subsp. tengcongensis (Thermoanaerobacter tengcongensis)<br /></em>ArtI (R)<br />ArtQ (M)<br />ArtN (C)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.28"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.28&tcname=">3.A.1.3.28</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative amino acid uptake porter, YckIJK; deletion of YckK (substrate binding protein) increases sensitivity to the antimicrobial peptide, cecropin (<span id="ref34544457.26304836" class="cite">Chen <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YckIJK of<em> Haemophilus psarasuis<br /></em>YckI (C)<br />YckJ (M)<br />YckK (R)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.29"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.29&tcname=">3.A.1.3.29</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Histidine/Arginine/Lysine (basic amino acid) uptake porter, HisJ/ArgT/HisP/HisM/HisQ [R, R, C, M, M, respectively] (<span id="ref34544667.7050111" class="cite">Gilson <em>et al.</em> 1982</span>). HisJ binds L-His (preferred), but 1-methyl-L-His
and 3-methyl-L-His also bind, while the dipeptide carnosine binds weakly; D-histidine and the
histidine degradation products, histamine, urocanic acid and imidazole do not bind. L-Arg,
homo-L-Arg, and post-translationally modified methylated Arg-analogs also bind with the exception of symmetric dimethylated-L-Arg. L-Lys and L-Orn show weaker interactions with HisJ and methylated and acetylated Lys variants show poor binding.The carboxylate groups of these amino acids and
their variants are essential (<span id="ref34546134.27865021" class="cite">Paul <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Basic amino acid transporter of<em> E. coli</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.3&tcname=">3.A.1.3.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Arginine porter</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Proteobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>ArtI (arginine receptor #1)/ArtJ (arginine receptor #2)-ArtMQP of <I>E. coli</I> </br>

ArtQ (M)<br> 
ArtM (M)<br> 
ArtJ (R)<br> 
ArtI (R)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.3.30"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.3.30&tcname=">3.A.1.3.30</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative ABC amino acid uptake porter with 3 constituents. HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.30.2&tcname=">3.A.1.30.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative thiamin transporter</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Firmicutes</p></TD><TD><b><font (Q97RS4)<em>&nbsp;</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.31">3.A.1.31 The Unknown-ABC1 (U-ABC1) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>This and other ECF ABC families (3.A.1.18, 23, 25, 26, 28, 31 and 32) have been reviewed (<span id='ref34549157.30485755' class='cite'>Rempel <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.31.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.31.1&tcname=">3.A.1.31.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The putative uptake transporter of unknown substrate specificity, HtsTUV (<span id="ref6318.18931129" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HtsTUV of <em>Bifidobacterium longum</em><br />HtsT (M) (Q8G6E7)<br />HtsU (M) (Q8G6E8)<br />HtsV (C-C) (Q8G6E9)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.31.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.31.2&tcname=">3.A.1.31.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><a></a></p><!-- test--><p>
																												                                         																																																								                                     <a id="3.A.1.31.2"></a></p>
																																																																	                                     <p>EcfSTAA of unknown function.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EstSTA of <em>Treponema denticola<br /></em>EstS<em> </em>(Q73JF1)<em><br /></em>EstT&nbsp; (Q73JF2)<br />EstAA&nbsp; (Q73JF3)</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.31.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.31.3&tcname=">3.A.1.31.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RLI1 ATPase of 608 aas and 0 TMSs, ABCE.&nbsp; Binds to the ribosome, IF3, IF5 and IF2 to promote preinitiation complex assembly (<span id="ref34547497.15277527" class="cite">Dong <em>et al.</em> 2004</span>). <span class="highlight">ABCE</span> proteins 
are present in eukaryotes and archaea and are encoded by a single 
gene in most genomes, or by two genes in a few cases. Functional 
analysis of <em><span class="highlight">ABCE</span></em> genes, primarily in <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</em>, has shown that <span class="highlight">ABCE</span> proteins have essential functions as part of the translational 
apparatus. <span id="ref34548648.30127795" class="cite">Navarro-Quiles <em>et al.</em> 2018</span> summarized <span class="highlight">ABCE</span> protein functions in ribosome biogenesis and recycling, with a 
particular focus on their known and proposed developmental roles in 
different species. The <span class="highlight">ABCE</span> proteins might represent another class of factors contributing to the role of the ribosome in gene expression regulation.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RLI1 of</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.31.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.31.4&tcname=">3.A.1.31.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RNase L inhibitor of 599 aas, ABCE1; lacks a TMS, and is not a transporter.&nbsp; It <span>antagonizes the binding of 2-5A (5'-phosphorylated
 2',5'-linked oligoadenylates) by RNase L through direct interaction 
with RNase L and therefore inhibits its endoribonuclease activity. It may&nbsp; also
play a central role in the regulation of mRNA turnover (<span id="ref34549666.11585831" class="cite">Le Roy <em>et al.</em> 2001</span>). It antagonizes the 
anti-viral effect of the interferon-regulated 2-5A/RNase L pathway, and may 
act as a chaperone for post-translational events during HIV-1 capsid 
assembly (<span id="ref34549665.9847332" class="cite">Martinand <em>et al.</em> 1999</span>).</span></p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABCE1 of <em>Homo sapiens</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.32">3.A.1.32 The Cobalamin Precursor (B<sub>12</sub>-P) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><p>This and other ECF ABC families (3.A.1.18, 23, 25, 26, 28, 31 and 32) have been reviewed (<span id='ref34549157.30485755' class='cite'>Rempel <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.32.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.32.1&tcname=">3.A.1.32.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The putative cobalamin precursor uptake transporter, CbrTUV (<span id="ref6318.18931129" class="cite">Rodionov <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>) (CbrT is most similar to 2.A.1.15.1; CbrU is most similar to 3.A.1.26.1 (MFS; e<sup>-4</sup>); CbrV is most similar to 2.A.53.11.1 and 3.A.1.2.2 (score of 0.035)) (CbrT has 6 putative TMSs; CbrV has 8-10 putative TMSs).<br /</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CbrTUV of <em>Streptomyces coelicolor</em><br />CbrT (M) (Q9KXJ5)<br />CbrU (C-C) (Q9KXJ6)<br />CbrV (M) (Q9KXJ7)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.32.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.32.2&tcname=">3.A.1.32.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative vitamin transporter, EcfSTAA</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative vitamin transporter of <em>Methanosphaera stadtmanae</em>, EcfSTAA'<br />EcfT (M) (Q2NFA7)<br />EcfA-A' (C) (Q2NFA8)<br />EcfS (M) (Q2NFA9)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.32.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.32.3&tcname=">3.A.1.32.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative cobalamin (vitamin B<sub>12</sub>) uptake porter, CbrVUT (<span id="ref34545288.25345570" class="cite">Rodionova <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>). to grow photoheterotrophically under anaerobic conditions on a range of 
phenylpropeneoid <span class="highlight">lignin</span> monomers, including coumarate, ferulate, caffeate, and cinnamate. 
RPA1789 (CouP) is the periplasmic binding-protein component of the <span class="highlight">ABC uptake</span> system (CouPSTU).&nbsp; CouP binds a range of 
phenylpropeneoid ligands with K<sub>d</sub> values in the nanomolar range. The 
crystal structure of CouP with ferulate as the bound ligand shows H-bond
 interactions between the 4-OH group of the aromatic ring with His309 
and Gln305. H-bonds are also made between the carboxyl group on the 
ferulate side chain and Arg197, Ser222, and Thr102 (<span id="ref34543653.23555803" class="cite">Salmon <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>). Within the same operon are a diguanylate cyclase (Q6N8W3) and a phenylacetate-CoA ligase (Q6N8W5).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CouPSTW of <em>Rhodopseudomonas palustris&nbsp; <br /></em>CouP (R) 385 aas<br />CouS (C) 239 aas<br />CouT (M-C) 590 aas<br />CouW (M) 346 aas<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.12&tcname=">3.A.1.4.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC-type uptake porter for pyruvate and monocarboxylate 2-oxo acids.&nbsp; Pyruvate uptake has been measured and is inhibited by monocarboxylate 2-oxo-acids such as 2-oxobutyrate, 2-oxovalerate, 2-oxoisovalerate, 2-oxoisocaproate and 2-oxo 3-methylvalerate which are probably substrates (<span id="ref8790.20851902" class="cite">Pernil <em>et al.</em> 2010</span>).&nbsp;</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC porter of <em>Anabaena</em> (<em>Nostoc</em>) strain 7120<br />Alr2535, Q8YU26, 268 aas, 1 N-terminal TMS (R)<br />Alr2536, Q8YU25, 316 aas, 9 TMSs, (M)<br />Alr2538, Q8YU24, 308 aas and 8 TMSs (M)<br />Alr2539, Q9YU22, 259 aas and 0 TMSs (C)<br />Alr2541, Q9YU20, 264 aas and 0 TMSs (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.13&tcname=">3.A.1.4.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC amino acid transport systems, of unknown specificity, but homologous to the LIV system of hydrophobic amino acid transport, similar to 3.A.1.4.1 and 3.A.1.4.10.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter of 5 constituents, LivFGHIJ of Candidatus Heimdallarchaeota archaeon<br />LivJ, R, 470 aas and 2 TMSs, N- and C-terminal<br />LivH, M, 805 aas and 20 aas in an 11 + 8 +1 TMS arrangement.&nbsp; Other LivHs are homologous to &nbsp;&nbsp; TMSs 12 - 19<br />LivI or LivM, M, 255 aas and 6 TMSs in a 5 + 1 arrangement<br />LivG, M-C, 937 aas and 19 TMSs<br />LivF, C, 233 aas and 0 TMSs</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.14&tcname=">3.A.1.4.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Branched chain amino acid uptake (BCAA) porter consisting of 5 proteins.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BCAA transporter of Candidatus Campbellbacteria bacterium GW2011_OD1_34_28 (groundwater metagenome</p>
<p>LivF (C), AKM83893<br />LivJ&nbsp; (R), AKM83894<br />LivG&nbsp; (C), AKM83896<br />LivH&nbsp; (M), AKM83897<br />LivI&nbsp; (M), AKM83898</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.15&tcname=">3.A.1.4.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter for benzoate and phenyl proponoids with 6 subunits, one receptor (R) for benzoate and one receptor (R) for phenyl proponoids derived from plant lignins. There are also two membrane constituents (M) and two cytoplasmic ATPases (C) (see proteins for this system) (<span id="ref34552916.33741621" class="cite">Vagts <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ABC transporter with six subunits:<br />Periplasmic binding receptor for benzoate (R) with 395 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS (CAI09138; ebA5303)<br />Membrane protein with 288 aas and 7 TMSs (CAI09139; ebA5304)<br />Membrane protein with 324 aas and 8 TMSs (CAI09140; ebA5306)<br />Cytoplasmic ATPase of 253 aas and 0 TMSs (CAI09141; ebA5307)<br />Cytoplasmic ATPase of 238 aas and 0 TMSs (CAI09142; ebA5309)<br />Periplasmic binding receptor for phenyl propionoids of 380 aas and one N-terminal TMS (CAI09145; ebA5316)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.2&tcname=">3.A.1.4.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Leucine/proline/alanine/serine/glycine (and possibly histidine) porter, NatABCDE.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Cyanobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>NatA-E neutral amino acid porter of <em>Synechocystis sp.</em>PCC6803 <br /> NatA (C)<br /> NatB (R)<br /> NatC (M)<br /> NatD (M)<br /> NatE (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.3&tcname=">3.A.1.4.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>General L- (and D-)amino acid uptake porter (transports acidic, basic, polar, semipolar and hydrophobic amino acids).  The amino and carboxyl groups do not need to be &#945; since &#947;-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is a substrate.  The system may function with additional binding proteins since L-alanine uptake is not dependent on BraC.</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Proteobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>BraCDEF of <I>Rhizobium leguminosarum</i> <br>

UrtC (M) <br>
UrtD (C) <br>
UrtE (C)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.5&tcname=">3.A.1.4.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The high affinity urea/thiourea/hydroxyurea porter (<span id="ref5810.15516578" class="cite">Beckers <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Actinobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>UrtA-E of <i>Corynebacterium glutamicum</i> <br>
UrtA (R) CAF19637 <br>
UrtB (M) CAF19636 <br>
UrtC (M) CAF19638 <br>
UrtD (C) CAF19639 <br>
UrtE (C) CAF19640 </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.6&tcname=">3.A.1.4.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The neutral amino acid permease, N-1 (transports pro, phe, leu, gly, ala, ser, gln and his, but gln and his are not transported via NatB) (<span id="ref5822.16135226" class="cite">Picossi <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Cyanobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>NatA-E of <i>Anabaena</i> sp. strain PCC7120 <br>

NatC (M) BAB73004  <br>
NatD (M) BAB73241  <br>
NatE (C) BAB74611   </TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.7"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.7&tcname=">3.A.1.4.7</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The protocatechuate (3,4-dihydroxybenzoate) uptake porter, PcaMNVWX (<span id="ref9009.21700663" class="cite">Maclean <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&delta;-Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PcaMNVWX of <em>Sinorhizobium (Ensifer) meliloti</em><br />PcaM (R) (Q92TN0)<br />PcaN (M) (Q92TN1)<br />PcaV (M) (Q92TN2)&nbsp;<br />PcaW (C) (Q92TN3)&nbsp;<br />PcaX (C) (Q92TN4)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.8"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.8&tcname=">3.A.1.4.8</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Branched chain amino acid uptake transporter. Transports alanine (<span id="ref9982.2120183" class="cite">Hoshino and Kose 1990</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BraC-G of Pseudomonas aeruginosa<br />BraG (C) (P21630)<br />BraE (C) (P21629)<br />BraE (M) (P21628)<br />BraD (M) (P21627)<br />BraC (R) (P21175)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.4.9"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.4.9&tcname=">3.A.1.4.9</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uptake transporter, CamABCD of cholate (steroid) metabolites, 1&beta;(2'-propanoate)-3a&alpha;-H-4&alpha;(3"(R)-hydroxy-3"-propanoate)-7a&beta;-methylhexahydro-5-indanone and a desaturated analog (<span id="ref10276.23024344" class="cite">Swain <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CamABCD of <em>Rhodococcus jostii<br /></em>CamA, R, 405 aas (Q0S717)<em><br /></em>CamB, M, 285 aas, 8 TMSs (Q0S718)<br />CamC, M-C, 607 aas, 10 TMSs in a 5 + 5 arrangement followed by the C domain (Q0S719)<br />CamD, C, 245 aas (Q0S720)<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.5">3.A.1.5 The Peptide/Opine/Nickel Uptake Transporter (PepT) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.1&tcname=">3.A.1.5.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Oligopeptide porter (also takes up amino glycoside antibiotics such as kanamycin, streptomycin and neomycin as well as cell wall-derived peptides such as murein tripeptide).  It transports substrate peptides of 2-5 amino acids with highest affinity for tripeptides.  Also transports &#948;-aminolevulinic acid (ALA). [May be regulated by PTS Enzyme I<sup>Ntr</sup>-aspartokinase.] ATP-binding to OppDF may result in donation of peptide to OppBC and simultaneous release of OppA (<span id="ref5938.18212011" class="cite">Doeven <em>et al</em>., 2008</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Proteobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>OppABCDF of <I>Salmonella typhimurium</i> </br>
OppA (R)<br> 
OppB (M)<br> 
OppC (M)<br> 
OppD (C)<br> 
OppF (C)<br> 
MppA (R) (in <I>E. coli</i>)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.10"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.10&tcname=">3.A.1.5.10</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Oligopeptide porter (transports peptides of 4-35) amino acyl residues; di- and tripeptides are not transported; hydrophobic basic peptides are preferred).  OppA determines the specificity of the system (<span id="ref5799.15169767" class="cite">Doeven <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>). A large cavity in OppA binds proline-rich peptides preferentially (<span id="ref6621.19300437" class="cite">Berntsson <em>et al.</em>, 2009</span>). Two crystal structures of OppA with different nonapeptides show binding in different registers (<span id="ref7922.21665971" class="cite">Berntsson <em>et al.</em>, 2011</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>OppABCDF of <em>Lactococcus lactis</em> <br /> OppA (R) (Q9CEK0) <br /> OppB (M) (P0A4N7) <br /> OppC (M) (P0A4N9) <br /> OppD (C) (Q07733) <br /> OppF (C) (P0A2V4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.11"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.11&tcname=">3.A.1.5.11</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Glutathione porter, YliABCD or GsiABCD (<span id="ref5818.16109926" class="cite">Suzuki <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>). Changes in the redox balance in the medium and in <em>E. coli</em> cells affect the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. An increase in the level of aeration in the culture of wild-type bacteria led to a 3-fold decrease in the mass of biofilms (<span id="ref34556693.36894813" class="cite">Kalashnikova <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>). Mutants lacking components of the glutathione and thioredoxin redox systems, as well as transporters involved in the transmembrane cycling of glutathione, showed increased biofilm formation ability. The effect of exogenous glutathione on biofilm formation depended on the culturing conditions. The addition of 0.1-1 mM Trolox (a water-soluble analog of vitamin E) was accompanied by a 30-40% reduction in biofilm formation (<span id="ref34556693.36894813" class="cite">Kalashnikova <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YliABCD of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> YliA (GsiA) (C-C) (P75796)  <br /> YliB (GsiB) (R) (P75797) <br /> YliC (GsiC) (M) (P75798) <br /> YliD (GsiD) (M) (P75799)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.12"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.12&tcname=">3.A.1.5.12</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable rhamnose oligosaccharide porter. Induced by rhamnose (<span id="ref5823.16237010" class="cite">Conners <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Thermotogae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>RtpEFGKL of <em>Thermotoga maritima</em> <br /> RtpE (R) (TM1067) Q9X0F7<br /> RtpF (M) (TM1066) Q9X0F6<br /> RtpG (M) (TM1065) Q9X0F5<br /> RtpK (C) (TM1064) Q9X0F4 <br /> RtpL (C) (TM1063) Q9X0F3</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.13"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.13&tcname=">3.A.1.5.13</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable xylan oligosaccharide porter (<span id="ref5823.16237010" class="cite">Conners <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>). Induced by xylan and xylose. Regulated by xylose-responsive regulator XylR (<span id="ref9378.23209028" class="cite">Kazanov <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Thermotogae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>XloEFGKL of <em>Thermotoga maritima</em> <br /> XloE (R) (TM0071) Q9WXS6 <br /> XloF (M) (TM0072) Q9WXS7 <br /> XloG (M) (TM0073) Q9WXS8 <br /> XloK (C) (TM0074) Q9WXS9 <br /> XloL (C) (TM0075) Q9WXT5</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.14"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.14&tcname=">3.A.1.5.14</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable cellobiose porter. Induced by barley, glucomannan (<span id="ref5823.16237010" class="cite">Conners <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Thermotogae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>CelEFGKL of <em>Thermotoga maritima</em> <br /> CelE (R) (TM1223) Q9X0V0 <br /> CelF (M) (TM1222) Q9X0U9 <br /> CelG (M) (TM1221) Q9X0U8 <br />CelK (C) (TM1220) Q9X0U7 <br /> CelL (C) (TM1219) Q9X0U6</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.15"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.15&tcname=">3.A.1.5.15</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Probable mannose/mannoside porter. Induced by beta-mannan (<span id="ref5823.16237010" class="cite">Conners <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>). Regulated by mannose-responsive regulator manR (<span id="ref9378.23209028" class="cite">Kazanov <em>et al.</em>, 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Thermotogae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>MtpEFGKL of <em>Thermotoga maritima</em> <br /> MtpE (R) (TM1746) Q9X268 <br /> MtpF (M) (TM1747) Q9X269 <br /> MtpG (M) (TM1748) Q9X270 <br /> MtpK (C) (TM1749) Q9X271 <br /> MtpL (C) (TM1750) Q9X272</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.16"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.16&tcname=">3.A.1.5.16</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>&beta;-glucoside porter (<span id="ref5823.16237010" class="cite">Conners <em>et al</em>., 2005</span>). Regulated by cellobiose-responsive repressor BglR (<span id="ref9378.23209028" class="cite">Kazanov <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Thermotogae</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>BglpEFGKL of <em>Thermotoga maritima</em> <br /> BglE (R) (TM0031) Q9WXN8 <br /> BglF (M) (TM0030) Q9WXN7 <br /> BglG (M) (TM0029) Q9WXN6 <br /> BglK (C) (TM0028) Q9WXN5 <br /> BglL (C) (TM0027) Q9WXN4</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.17"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.17&tcname=">3.A.1.5.17</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The proline betaine uptake porter (<span id="ref5855.16923898" class="cite">Alloing <em>et al</em>., 2006</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Proteobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PrbABCD of <em>Sinorhizobium meliloti</em><br /> PrbA (R) (Q92NF1)<br /> PrbB (M) (Q92NF0)<br /> PrbC (M) (Q92NE9)<br /> PrbD (C-C) (Q92NE8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.18"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.18&tcname=">3.A.1.5.18</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The oligopeptide transporter OppA1-5, B1, C1, DF (functions with five binding proteins of differing induction properties and peptide specificities; OppA1-3 are chromosomally encoded; OppA4 and 5 are plasmid encoded.) (<span id="ref5878.17237172" class="cite">Medrano <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>)</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>OppA1-5,B1,C1,D,F of <I>Borrelia burgdorferi</i><br>

</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.19"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.19&tcname=">3.A.1.5.19</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The major oligopeptide uptake porter, Opp-3 (of four paralogues, this is the only one that mediates nitrogen nutrition (<span id="ref5885.17496096" class="cite">Hiron <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Opp-3 of <i>Staphylococcus aureus</i><br>

</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.2&tcname=">3.A.1.5.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Dipeptide porter.  Also transports &delta;-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) and heme (<span id="ref6027.18178744" class="cite">L&eacute;toff&eacute; <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>).<br /</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Firmicutes</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>DppABCDE of <em>Bacillus subtilis</em> <br /> DppA (C)<br /> DppB (M)<br /> DppC (M)<br /> DppD (C)<br /> DppE (R)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.20"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.20&tcname=">3.A.1.5.20</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>5-6 amino acyl oligopeptide transporter AppA-F (<span id="ref6009.7997159" class="cite">Koide and Hoch, 1994</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>AppABCDF of <i>Bacillus subtilis</i><br>
AppA(R) (P42061)<br>
AppB(M) (P42062)<br>
AppC(M) (P42063)<br>
AppD(C) (P42064)<br>
AppF(C) (P42065)<br></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.21"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.21&tcname=">3.A.1.5.21</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Microcin C/peptide uptake porter, YejABEF (<span id="ref5902.17873039" class="cite">Novikova <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).&nbsp; The 'Trojan horse' antibiotic, microcin C, consists of a 
nonhydrolyzable aspartyl-adenylate that is efficiently imported into 
bacterial cells owing to a covalently attached peptide. Once 
inside the cell, the peptide "carrier" is removed by proteolytic processing to 
release a potent aspartyl tRNA synthetase inhibitor (<span id="ref34543666.22324995" class="cite">Severinov and Nair 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YejABEF of <em>E. coli</em>:  <br /> YejA (R) (P33913) <br /> YejB (M) (P0AFU1) <br /> YejE (M) (P33915) <br /> YejF (C-C) (P33916)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.22"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.22&tcname=">3.A.1.5.22</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>The peptide transporter OppA,B,C,D,F (influences biofilm formation; <span id="ref5809.15500975" class="cite">Lee <em>et al</em>., 2004</span>). Similar to 3.A.1.5.1, OppA is similar to the <i>Vibrio furnissii</i> OppA that provides several functions: hemolysis, antibiotic resistance, and virulence (<span id="ref6013.17873048" class="cite">Wu <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Bacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>OppABCDF of <i>Vibrio fluvialis</i>: <br>
OppA (R) (Q5V9S2) <br>
OppB (M) (Q5V9S1) <br>
OppC (M) (Q5V9S0) <br>
OppD (C) (Q5V9R9) <br>
OppF (C) (Q5V9R8)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.23"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.23&tcname=">3.A.1.5.23</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The Ethylene diamine tetraacetate (EDTA) uptake porter, EppABCD (<span id="ref5903.17873047" class="cite">Zhang <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>EppABCD of <em>EDTA-degrading bacterium BNC1</em>: <br /> EppA (R) (Q9F9T7) <br /> EppB (M) (Q9F9T6) <br /> EppC (M) (Q9F9T5) <br /> EppD (C-C) (Q9F9T4)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.24"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.24&tcname=">3.A.1.5.24</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The antimicrobial peptide (protamine, melittin, polymyxin B, human defensin (HBD)-1 and HBD-2 exporter, YejABEF (<span id="ref6812.18227269" class="cite">Eswarappa <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>). Prefers N-formyl methionine peptides, such as Microcin C (of prokaryotic origin) to non formylated peptides (of eukaryotic origin) (<span id="ref5902.17873039" class="cite">Novikova <em>et al</em>., 2007</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Proteobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>YejABEF of <em>Salmonella enterica</em> <br /> YejA (R) (Q8ZNK0) <br /> YejB (M) (Q7CQ74) <br /> YejE (M) (Q8ZNJ9) <br /> YejF (C-C) (Q8ZNJ8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.25"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.25&tcname=">3.A.1.5.25</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The ABC peptide/signalling peptide transporter. OptA binds peptides of 3-6 aas; OptS binds dipeptides. OptB,C,D are most similar to 3.A.1.5.19.</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Gram-positive bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The OptASBCDF transport system of <em>Lactococcus lactis</em><br />OptS (R) (Q64K09)<br />OptA (R) (Q9CIL2)<br />OptB (M) (Q9CILI)<br />OptC (M) (Q9CIL0)<br />OptD (C) (Q9CIK9)<br />OptF (C) (Q9CIK8)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.26"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.26&tcname=">3.A.1.5.26</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The glutathione transporter, OppA (<span id="ref7345.20808924" class="cite">Dasgupta <em>et al.</em>, 2010</span>). OppA binds glutathione and the nanopeptide, bradykinin. action involving facilitated access to a translation-enhancing region in
 <em>oppA</em> 5'UTR.&nbsp; MicF activation of <em>oppA</em> translation depends on cross-regulation by negative trans-acting effectors, the GcvB sRNA and the RNA chaperone protein Hfq (<span id="ref34556024.36860088" class="cite">Carrier <em>et al.</em> 2023</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>OppABCDF/MppA/YgiS system of <em>E. coli<br />OppA (R)</em><br />OppB (M)<br />OppC (M)<br />OppD (C)<br />OppF (C)<br />MppA (R)<br />YgiS (R)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.42"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.42&tcname=">3.A.1.5.42</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peptide transporter, SapABCDF</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SapABCDF of <em>E. coli</em><br />SapA (R)<br />SapB (M)<br />SapC (M)<br />SapD (C)<br />SapF (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.43"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.43&tcname=">3.A.1.5.43</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The metal-staphylopine (nicotianamine-like metalophore) complex uptake system, CntABCDF.&nbsp; Staphylopine binds divalent nickel, cobalt, zinc, copper and iron (<span id="ref34545351.27230378" class="cite">Ghssein <em>et al.</em> 2016</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Metal-staphylopine uptake system, CntABCDF of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.44"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.44&tcname=">3.A.1.5.44</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peptide transporter, SapABCDF. Mutants are more sensitive than the wild type to wheat alpha-thionin and to snakin-1, which is the most abundant antimicrobial <span class="highlight">peptide</span> from potato tubers. They were also less virulent than was the 
wild-type strain in potato tubers: lesion areas were 37% that of the 
control, and the growth rate was two orders of magnitude lower. Thus, the interaction of antimicrobial <span class="highlight">peptides</span> from the host with the <span class="highlight">sapA</span>-F operon from the pathogen plays a similar role in animal and in plant bacterial pathogenesis (<span id="ref34545975.9634580" class="cite">L&oacute;pez-Solanilla <em>et al.</em> 1998</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>SapABCDF of <em>Dickeya chrysanthemi (Pectobacterium chrysanthemi) (Erwinia chrysanthemi)<br /></em>SapA, 540 aas, R<br />SapB, 313 aas, M<br />SapC, 296 aas, M<br />SapD, 330 aas, C<br />SapF, 269 aas, C<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.45"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.45&tcname=">3.A.1.5.45</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Uncharacterized 5 component peptide uptake transporter with a receptor, two transmembrane proteins and two ATPases, as is common for this family of ABC porters. The five genes encoding this system, from metagenomic data for an uncultured Lokiarchaeon, occur adjacent to each other in the genome (<span id="ref34548630.28077874" class="cite">Zaremba-Niedzwiedzka <em>et al.</em> 2017</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>UP of Lokiarchaeum sp. GC14_75</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.46"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.46&tcname=">3.A.1.5.46</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative oligopeptide transporter, OppA1A2BCDF. The two membrane proteins (OppB and OppC, of 564 and 670 aas with 13 and 15 TMSs, respectively (M-subunits)) and the two ATPases (C-subunits of 342 and 369 aas, respectively) map together, but the 4 potential receptors (R) map elsewhere on the chromosome. Two of them appear to be complete and have 734 and 738 aas, respectively, each with 2 TMSs, one N-terminal and one C-terminal.&nbsp; There are two other potential receptors that may not have complete sequences.&nbsp; They are OLS21443 (721 aas with only 1 C-terminal TMS) and OLS22122 (353 aas with only 1 N-terminal TMS).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.47"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.47&tcname=">3.A.1.5.47</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Peptide uptake porter, DppABCDF (<span id="ref34550534.30076984" class="cite">Asai <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>DppABCDF of <em><span class="highlight">Treponema denticola</span></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.5.48"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.5.48&tcname=">3.A.1.5.48</a></TD><TD><b><font (0.11%u03BCM) and dissociates slowly; the complex is destabilized by nucleotide and substrate binding (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref9792">Vigonsky <em>et al.</em> 2013</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ModABC of <em>Archeoglobus fulgidus</em> <br />ModB (M; 12 TMSs; type I fold) (O30143)<br />ModC (C) (O30144)<br />ModA (R) (O30142)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.6.9"></A><A
