Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.7.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.7.1&tcname=">3.A.1.7.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Phosphate porter, PhoSPstABC.¬† Serves as both a transporter and a sensor for transcriptional activation of the <em>pho</em> regulon in the presence of low external phosphate.¬† The unphosphorylated EIIA<sup>Ntr</sup> protein of the PTS (TC# 4.A) activates PhoR, the senor kinase that phosphorylates the response regulator, PhoB, that activates the <em>pho</em> regulon (<a class="reflink" href="result.php?tc=3.A.1#ref10692">L√ºttmann <em>et al.</em> 2012</a>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhoS (phosphate receptor)-PstABC of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> PhoS (R)<br /> PstA (M)<br /> PstC (M)<br /> PstB (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.7.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.7.2&tcname=">3.A.1.7.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Phosphate transporter, PstSCAB (<span id="ref5931.18083811" class="cite">Gebhard and Cook, 2007</span>).</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>Actinobacteria</TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC>PstSCAB of <i>Mycobacterium smegmatis</i><br>
PstS (R) (Q7WTY8)<br>
PstC (M) (Q7WTY7)<br>
PstA (M) (Q7WTY6)<br>
PstB (C) (P0C560)</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.7.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.7.3&tcname=">3.A.1.7.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High-affinity phosphate-specific permease, PstAB/PhoS. The 3-d structure of PhoS = (PBP) = PfluDING) has been solved at high resolution by x-ray crystallography (<span id="ref9297.17612529" class="cite">Ahn <em>et al.</em> 2007</span>) with phosphate bound (4F1U and 4F1V; 0.95&Aring; resolution) and with arsenate bound (4F18 and 4F19; 0.88&Aring; resolution) (<span id="ref9298.23034649" class="cite">Elias <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). Phosphate binds with 500-fold higher affinity than arsenate due to a dense and rigid network of ion-dipole interactions (<span id="ref9298.23034649" class="cite">Elias <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>). The PBP from <em>Halomonas </em><em>sp</em><em>.</em>&nbsp;GFAJ-1 has a phosphate affinity 5000-fold higher than that of arsenate (<span id="ref9298.23034649" class="cite">Elias <em>et al.</em> 2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PstAB/PhoS of <em>Pseudomonas fluorescens</em><br />PstA (C) (C3KCB5)<br />PstB (M) (C3KCB6)<br />PstC (PBP) (R) (D0VWY2)<em>&nbsp;</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.7.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.7.4&tcname=">3.A.1.7.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High specificity inorganic phosphate porter, PstABCS (<span id=""ref10354.11567022"" class=""cite"">Sarin <em>et al.</em> 2001</span>). May also function as a regulator of extracellular vesicle formation via the SenX3/RegX3 two component system (<span id=""ref34548483.29895636"" class=""cite"">White <em>et al.</em> 2018</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Actinobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PstABCS of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em>&nbsp;<br />PstA2 (M) (P0A627)<br />PstB2 (C) (P95302)<br />PstC2 (M) (P0A630)<br />PstS2 (R) (O05870)&nbsp;</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.7.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.7.5&tcname=">3.A.1.7.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The phosphate transporter, PstABCS.&nbsp; The structure of PstS is known to 1.3&Aring; resolution (<span id="ref10452.24318969" class="cite">Brautigam <em>et al.</em> 2013</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p><br />Spirochaetes</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PstABCS of <em>Borrelia burgdorferii</em><br />PstA (M) (O51235)<br />PstB (C) (O51236)<br />PstC (M) (O51234)<br />PstS (R) (O51233)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.7.6"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.7.6&tcname=">3.A.1.7.6</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>High affinity phosphate-specific transporter, PstABCS, where PstA (AAZ57802) = 304 aas with 6 TMSs, PstB (AAZ57801) = 267 aas with 0 TMSs (the ATPase), PstC (AAZ57803) = 317 aas with 6 TMSs, PstS (Q46L27 or AAX46970) = 321 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS; this PstS homolog is encoded by <em>Prochlorococcus</em> phage P-SSM3 (<span id="ref34554783.35590460" class="cite">Zhao <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PstABCS of<em> Prochlorococcus </em>NATL2A</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.8">3.A.1.8 The Molybdate Uptake Transporter (MolT) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.8.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.8.1&tcname=">3.A.1.8.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Molybdate porter consisting of three proteins.&nbsp; Molybdate, after transport into cells by the <span class="highlight">ModABC</span> proteins, is metabolized by the products of the <em>mol</em> gene(s) (<span id="ref34550822.7665460" class="cite">Maupin-Furlow <em>et al.</em> 1995</span>). The repressor of the <em>mod</em> operon is ModE (<span id="ref34550823.8550508" class="cite">Grunden <em>et al.</em> 1996</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ModABC of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> ModA (R)<br /> ModB (M)<br /> ModC (C)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.8.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.8.2&tcname=">3.A.1.8.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>The molybdate/tungstate ABC transporter, ModABC.  The trans-inhibited 3-d structure of ModABC, is available (3D31.A and  3D31.B)(<span id="ref5953.18511655" class="cite">Gerber <em>et al.</em>, 2008</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Archaea</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ModABC of <em>Methanosarcina acetivorans<br /></em>ModA (Q8TTV0)<br /> ModB (M) (Q8TJ86)<br /> ModC (C) (Q8TTV2)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.8.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.8.3&tcname=">3.A.1.8.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Molybdate uptake porter with three components, R, M and C (<span id="ref34549445.30672551" class="cite">Mandal <em>et al.</em> 2019</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Molybdate porter of <em>Thermus thermophilus</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.8.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.8.4&tcname=">3.A.1.8.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Molybdate/tungstate uptake porter, ModABC with a K<sub>m</sub> of 4 - 8 &mu;M for its two substrates (<span id="ref34550824.19818021" class="cite">Smart <em>et al.</em> 2009</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ModABC of <em>Campylobacter jejuni</em><br />ModA, R, 133 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS<br />ModB, M, 224 aas and 5 TMSs<br />ModC, C, 294 aa</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.8.5"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.8.5&tcname=">3.A.1.8.5</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Molybdenum (MoO<sub>4</sub><sup>2-</sup>) uptake porter with three subunits, the receptor, R, ModA, of 261 aas (P9WGU3), the membrane protein, M, ModB, of 264 aas and 6 TMSs (P9WG13), and the cytoplasmic ATPase, C, ModC, of 369 aas (P9WQL3) (<span id="ref34553404.34171249" class="cite">Mandal <em>et al.</em> 2021</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>ModABC of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis<br /></em>ModA, R<br />ModB, M<br />ModC, C<em><br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><BR><BR></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD COLSPAN=5><b><A HREF="tccluster.php?cluster=3.A.1.9">3.A.1.9 The Phosphonate Uptake Transporter (PhnT) Family</A></b></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff"><TD COLSPAN=5><p><BR></TD></TR><TR><TD COLSPAN=5><B>Examples:</B><P></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD>TC#</TD><TD>Name</TD><TD>Organismal Type</TD><TD>Example</TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.9.1"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.9.1&tcname=">3.A.1.9.1</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Phosphonate/organophosphate ester porter (broad specificity). Reviewed by Hinz &amp; Tamp&eacute; (<span id="ref8838.22668350" class="cite">2012</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Proteobacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhnCDE of <em>E. coli</em> <br /> PhnC (C)<br /> PhnD (R)<br /> PhnE (M)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.9.2"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.9.2&tcname=">3.A.1.9.2</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Putative phosphonate/phosphite/phosphate porter, PhnDCE (<span id="ref5931.18083811" class="cite">Gebhard and Cook, 2007</span>)</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Bacteria</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhnDCE of <em>Mycobacterium smegmatis</em> <br /> PhnC (C) (A0QQ70)<br /> PhnD (R) (A0QQ71)<br /> PhnE (M) (A0QQ68)</p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.9.3"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.9.3&tcname=">3.A.1.9.3</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Phosphite uptake porter, PhnDCE of 252 aas (PhnC; Q119J0; C), 298 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS (PhnD; Q119I9; R) and 272 aas and 6 TMSs (PhnE; Q119I8; M) (<span id="ref34550773.26081517" class="cite">Polyviou <em>et al.</em> 2015</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>PhnCDE of <em>Trichodesmium erythraeum</em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#99ccff"><TD><b><A NAME="3.A.1.9.4"></A><A HREF="tcprotein.php?substrate=3.A.1.9.4&tcname=">3.A.1.9.4</a></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>Phosphite/phosphonate/hypophosphite ABC transporter, HtxBCDE (<span id="ref34550793.9791102" class="cite">Metcalf and Wolfe 1998</span>; <span id="ref34550794.15231805" class="cite">White and Metcalf 2004</span>). HtxC residue F<sub>210</sub> is a "gatekeeper" for this transporter (<span id="ref34555515.36202772" class="cite">Hirota <em>et al.</em> 2022</span>).</p></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC></TD><TD><b><font color=#3333CC><p>HtxBCDE of <em>Pseudomonas stutzeri (Pseudomonas perfectomarina)<br />HtxB, R, O69061, 298 aas and 1 N-terminal TMS<br />HxtC, M, O69062, 282 aas and 5 or 6 TMSs<br />HxtD, C, O69063, 341 aas and 0 TMSs<br />HxtE, M, O69064, 261 aas and 5 or 6 TMSs<br /></em></p></TD></TR><TR bgcolor="#ffffff" valign=top><TD COLSPAN=4 valign=top>&nbsp;</CENTER></TD></TR></TABLE>
